turns.consequence_b: The documents are archived. The legal question exists but has no immediate urgency.

turns.narrative: The service passage network itself has significant practical uses for utility maintenance.
turns.choice_a: Recommend the passage network be mapped and formally incorporated into Service District infrastructure
turns.consequence_a: A mapping project begins. Several utility teams are already planning how to use the passages.
turns.choice_b: Recommend the passages remain sealed pending a security assessment
turns.consequence_b: The passages are re-sealed. The security assessment is scheduled.

legal_triggered.description: Ward Legal Authority reviewing noble property ownership.

risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed quietly. The situation remains unresolved.

conclusion: Ward Legal Authority reviewing noble property ownership.

title: The Stolen Saint
location: Temple District -> The Shrine of St. Ova
description: A small but beloved icon from the Shrine of St. Ova has been stolen — a hand-carved figure of the patron saint of travellers, more than one hundred years old. The shrine's keeper, Brother Avel, is distraught. The icon has no monetary value but profound spiritual significance to the district's residents.

turns.narrative: The icon was the size of a hand, carved from a single piece of dark amber wood and worn smooth by a century of devotional touching. Brother Avel says only two people had keys to the shrine's inner sanctum: himself and a twice-weekly student volunteer. The student, he notes, stopped showing up last week.
turns.choice_a: Track down the student volunteer immediately
turns.consequence_a: The student — a young woman named Cela — is found at her dormitory, tearful and clearly guilty. She didn't steal it for money. She took it to save it, she says, from another student who planned to sell it.
turns.choice_b: Visit known art fences in the Market Ward to see if the icon has surfaced
turns.consequence_b: Fence Nirl has been approached about a 'small amber religious figure' but hasn't bought it yet. He can tell you who approached him.

turns.narrative: Both paths lead to the same revelation: a well-connected student named Orris planned to sell the icon to a private High Ward collector. Cela took it first to prevent this. She has the icon hidden in her room, intact.
turns.choice_a: Retrieve the icon from Cela and return it to Brother Avel
turns.consequence_a: The icon is returned intact. Brother Avel weeps. Cela is thanked for her twisted but genuine act of protection.
turns.choice_b: Expose Orris's plans to the Temple Authority before returning the icon
turns.consequence_b: Orris is publicly reprimanded by the Temple Authority. Cela is praised for her intent if not her method.

turns.narrative: Brother Avel wants better security for the icon going forward.
turns.choice_a: Help Brother Avel install a simple lock-box display case that is still visually accessible to worshippers
turns.consequence_a: A beautiful glass-fronted lock-box is commissioned from a local craftsman. The icon is safe but visible.
turns.choice_b: Recommend the icon be officially registered with the Ward Heritage Office for legal protection
turns.consequence_b: The Heritage Office registers the icon as a protected cultural artefact. Future theft carries serious legal consequences.

icon_returned_quietly.description: Icon returned. Cela thanked. Orris unexposed.

orris_exposed.description: Orris publicly reprimanded. Icon returned. Improved security installed.

risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed quietly. The situation remains unresolved.

conclusion: Icon returned. Cela thanked. Orris unexposed.

title: The Argument of Saints
location: Temple District -> The Hall of Six Faiths
description: The annual Hall of Six Faiths interfaith ceremony has deteriorated into a public shouting match between the Concordat remnant faction and the newer Order of the Veil. Both groups claim the Hall's central prayer space as their liturgical home. Temple Authority Warden Gais asks you to mediate before the argument turns physical.
key_npcs: Order of the Veil Leader Priestess Yael

turns.narrative: When you arrive, Elder Noss and Priestess Yael are three feet apart, both speaking loudly and simultaneously to different parts of the crowd. About forty worshippers are watching. No violence but the tension is thick enough to cut.
turns.choice_a: Step physically between them and call for an immediate pause
turns.consequence_a: Surprised by the sheer confidence of the intervention, both pause. The crowd is watching you now.
turns.choice_b: Speak first to Warden Gais to understand the historical allocation of Hall space
turns.consequence_b: Gais confirms: the central prayer space has no formal allocation — it was simply first-come-first-served, which has now failed.

turns.narrative: Both factions have genuine grievances. The Concordat has historical precedence in this hall. The Order of the Veil has more current worshippers by a significant margin.
turns.choice_a: Propose alternating use by ceremony type — the Concordat uses the space for memorial ceremonies, the Order for public services
turns.consequence_a: After an hour of careful negotiation, both leaders grudgingly accept the arrangement.
turns.choice_b: Propose a joint ceremony format that incorporates elements from both traditions
turns.consequence_b: Elder Noss is deeply resistant. But when Priestess Yael agrees to incorporate a Concordat candle-lighting rite into Order services, Noss visibly softens.

turns.narrative: Gais asks you to help document the agreement formally to prevent future disputes.
turns.choice_a: Draft a formal Hall Allegiance Charter that both leaders will sign publicly
turns.consequence_a: The signing ceremony becomes a positive public event. Citizens from both faiths attend and applaud.
turns.choice_b: Simply verbally witness the agreement and ask Gais to log it in Authority records
turns.consequence_b: Gais logs it. The agreement holds but has no ceremony to embed it in community memory.

consequences.item_reward: Hall of Six Faiths Charter Copy

risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed quietly. The situation remains unresolved.

loot_table: Hall of Six Faiths Charter Copy
conclusion: Formal interfaith charter signed publicly.

title: The Miracle on Alley Nine
location: Temple District -> The Temple of the Old Light
description: A beggar woman in Alley Nine claims to have been cured of her chronic leg ailment after touching a crumbling Temple wall. Within twenty-four hours, twenty more citizens are touching the wall, and the Temple priests are split between genuine faith and suspicion of a hoax.

turns.narrative: Mirra is walking without a stick for the first time she can clearly remember. Brother Daan examines her leg with a physician's eye and cannot find anything obviously fake. Sister Enne is joyful and certain this is divine. Twenty citizens are kneeling at the wall.
turns.choice_a: Ask Alchemist Rynn to examine the wall's stone composition for any non-spiritual explanation
turns.consequence_a: The wall contains trace amounts of Thermic Clay — a geothermally-formed mineral with mild analgesic and muscle-relaxing properties when warm.
turns.choice_b: Find and interview anyone who saw what happened to Mirra at the moment of healing
turns.consequence_b: A market boy saw Mirra sit and lean against the warm wall for nearly three hours before she stood and walked. Duration of thermic contact, not miracle.

turns.narrative: The scientific explanation is plausible but does not definitively rule out a miraculous component. And Mirra is genuinely healed — whatever the cause.
turns.choice_a: Present the Thermic Clay explanation to both priests and let them integrate it into their theology as they see fit
turns.consequence_a: Sister Enne declares it 'the Lord's grace expressed through good stone.' Brother Daan is satisfied with the science. Both are content.
turns.choice_b: Recommend keeping the explanation private to avoid undermining citizens' faith
turns.consequence_b: Only the Temple priests know the full picture. The miracle narrative continues publicly.

turns.narrative: The wall is now a pilgrimage point. Its thermic properties need to be managed safely.
turns.choice_a: Advise the Temple to allow controlled short-term contact sessions and monitor medical outcomes
turns.consequence_a: The Temple runs evening contact sessions. Two more citizens with chronic pain report meaningful relief.
turns.choice_b: Recommend the wall simply remains accessible as it was — people will regulate themselves
turns.consequence_b: The unofficial pilgrimage continues. The Temple accepts donations and the alley becomes a minor landmark.

sessions_organised.description: Controlled thermic contact sessions organised. Two more citizens helped.

access_remains.description: Wall remains publicly accessible. Minor pilgrimage site established.

risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed quietly. The situation remains unresolved.

loot_table: Temple of the Old Light Prayer Token
conclusion: Controlled thermic contact sessions organised. Two more citizens helped.

title: The Coughing Quarter
description: A cluster of respiratory illness cases has appeared in the Lower Ward — seventeen people in four adjacent streets all presenting the same dry cough and morning fever within a single week. Medical Quarter Director Sela believes this is environmental rather than contagious. She needs someone to identify the source.

turns.narrative: All seventeen cases live or work within two hundred metres of each other. The illness isn't spreading beyond that radius, which confirms Director Sela's hypothesis: environmental exposure. Dust Analyst Kem suggests checking the neighbourhood's air quality and building conditions.
turns.choice_a: Inspect the buildings in the affected radius for any new construction or industrial activity
turns.consequence_a: You find that a warehouse conversion project began ten days ago — seven days before the first cases. The conversion disturbed forty years of accumulated dust and old stone plaster.
turns.choice_b: Collect air samples in the affected streets at different times of day
turns.consequence_b: Morning samples are dramatically higher in fine particulate matter than afternoon. The source is something that disperses during early morning temperature changes.

turns.narrative: Investigation confirms the warehouse conversion is releasing Settled Quarry Dust — fine silica particles from the original construction period that accumulate in old walls. It's not toxic in small amounts but at this concentration it causes respiratory irritation.
turns.choice_a: Order the construction company to halt work immediately pending dust abatement
turns.consequence_a: The site supervisor is resistant but backs down when you invoke Ward public health authority.
turns.choice_b: Work with Kem to arrange free particle masks for all affected residents while the source is addressed
turns.consequence_b: Kem distributes masks to all seventeen affected households within two hours. Symptoms begin improving.

turns.narrative: Director Sela wants the conversion project to comply with dust safety standards before resuming.
turns.choice_a: Draft a compliance checklist for the construction company to meet before work resumes
turns.consequence_a: The checklist is submitted to the Ward Authority. Construction resumes ten days later with proper dust suppression.
turns.choice_b: Recommend the Medical Quarter establish a formal Environmental Illness Investigation protocol
turns.consequence_b: Sela approves. A new Environmental Illness Protocol is formally adopted by the Medical Quarter.

construction_halted.description: Construction halted. Dust abatement required before resuming.

risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed quietly. The situation remains unresolved.

conclusion: Construction halted. Dust abatement required before resuming.

title: The Apothecary's Back Room
description: An anonymous tip claims that Grey Apothecary proprietor Blex is selling unlicensed medicines out of her back room — treatments not cleared by the Medical Quarter and allegedly containing Void-adjacent compounds. Director Sela wants a discreet investigation before making any official move.

turns.narrative: The Grey Apothecary front shop is entirely normal — licensed herbs, standard pain relief, cleaning compounds. Blex is professional and careful. But you notice customers occasionally saying a specific phrase at the counter that causes Blex to pause before serving them.
turns.choice_a: Observe the counter phrase pattern and attempt to replicate it
turns.consequence_a: After careful listening you identify the phrase: 'I need the strong sort.' Using it earns you a measured look and an invitation to the back room.
turns.choice_b: Approach Blex openly as a Med Quarter health inspector
turns.consequence_b: Blex is immediately guarded and professional. No back room mention. She has done this before.

turns.narrative: In the back room you find a range of unlicensed treatments — including one for chronic pain derived from Void-mushroom extract. The treatments appear to be helping people with conditions the licensed Medical Quarter cannot adequately treat.
turns.choice_a: Report Blex to Director Sela with a full account — including evidence that patients are benefiting
turns.consequence_a: Sela is conflicted. She issues a warning rather than an arrest and begins a fast-track evaluation of Blex's formulas.
turns.choice_b: Give Blex a week to self-report to the Medical Quarter for a voluntary licensing review
turns.consequence_b: Blex, to her credit, appears the next morning and submits everything voluntarily. The review is fair and detailed.

turns.narrative: Three of Blex's formulas pass the licensing review. Two do not.
turns.choice_a: Help Blex reformat the failed formulas to remove the problematic Void compound
turns.consequence_a: With Alchemist Rynn's help, two of the formulas are reformulated without Void components and re-submitted.
turns.choice_b: Document the failed formulas for academic research to improve future treatment options
turns.consequence_b: Two formulas are transferred to the Academic Quarter for continued development under controlled conditions.

formulas_licensed.description: Three Blex formulas licensed. Two reformulated and re-submitted.

research_transferred.description: Failed formulas transferred to Academic Quarter for development.

risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed quietly. The situation remains unresolved.

conclusion: Three Blex formulas licensed. Two reformulated and re-submitted.

title: The Doctor Who Wasn't There
description: Lead researcher Dr. Vel has not reported to the Research Clinic in four days. She lives alone, had no scheduled leave, and her current research on Scourge-wound treatment regeneration is at a critical stage. Director Sela wants her found discreetly before her absence creates panic in the department.

turns.narrative: Dr. Vel's home in the Academic Quarter is locked. Her lab notes are still at the clinic — suggesting she did not plan to leave. Lab assistant Finn says she was excited about a breakthrough on day three and then simply did not come in on day four. No signs of struggle anywhere in the clinic.
turns.choice_a: Check Dr. Vel's personal calendar and correspondence for any planned meetings
turns.consequence_a: Her calendar shows a private notation: 'Follow-up: Fringe Sample Site, morning.' She went to the Scourge Fringe alone.
turns.choice_b: Ask Finn if Vel said anything unusual on day three
turns.consequence_b: Finn recalls Vel saying she needed to verify something 'in the field' about a specific type of Scourge-tissue she had been studying.

turns.narrative: Vel went to the Scourge Fringe alone to collect a follow-up tissue sample. This is against protocol. You need to find her before nightfall when the Fringe becomes genuinely dangerous.
turns.choice_a: Head to the Fringe immediately following her likely route from her calendar notation
turns.consequence_a: You find Vel two kilometres into the Fringe, entirely absorbed in scraping samples from a section of Scourge-growth. She hadn't realised how long she'd been there.
turns.choice_b: Inform a Fringe patrol to search the eastern Fringe sector while you search the west
turns.consequence_b: The patrol finds Vel an hour later but you coordinate the recovery. She is safe and mildly embarrassed.

turns.narrative: Vel is safe and her samples are extraordinary. But she broke two serious protocols.
turns.choice_a: Support Vel's formal apology to Director Sela and ask for leniency given the significance of the samples
turns.consequence_a: Sela accepts the apology. Vel's results are so promising that the incident is closed with a written warning.
turns.choice_b: Recommend Director Sela update field research protocols to prevent solo Fringe excursions
turns.consequence_b: Sela implements a mandatory buddy-system for all field research. Vel endorses the change.

vel_leniency.description: Vel given written warning. Breakthrough samples secured.

protocol_updated.description: Field research buddy-system mandatory. Vel endorses it.

risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed quietly. The situation remains unresolved.

conclusion: Vel given written warning. Breakthrough samples secured.

title: The Root Invaders
description: A species of fast-growing root vine is consuming the Green Quarter's Central Gardens — choking slower-growing rare plants. Head Gardener Bessa identifies it as Deeproot Vine, a Scourge-adjacent invasive species. She needs it removed before it spreads to the medicinal plant section.

turns.narrative: The Deeproot Vine is aggressive — it grows noticeably as you watch. Its tendrils are pale and slightly luminescent at the tips, suggesting Void-adjacent origin. Bessa says mechanical removal doesn't work: it grows back from the root system in forty-eight hours.
turns.choice_a: Ask Alchemist Rynn if a chemical suppressant could halt the root system
turns.consequence_a: Rynn provides a salt-based soil compound that inhibits Void-adjacent root growth. She estimates two applications to fully suppress the current patch.
turns.choice_b: Attempt manual removal of as much of the root system as you can access
turns.consequence_b: Manual removal takes three hours and clears seventy percent of the accessible root system. Combined with other treatment this is a good start.

turns.narrative: Rynn's assessment is that the vine was carried in via a compost amendment from the Agricultural Zone — the same batch causing problems elsewhere. The vine's root system goes down about two metres.
turns.choice_a: Apply Rynn's soil compound treatment to the entire affected area
turns.consequence_a: Two applications over two days. The vine shows visible decline by day three.
turns.choice_b: Use controlled shallow burning of the soil surface to kill the above-ground vine before applying the compound
turns.consequence_b: The burn plus compound combination works faster. The vine is effectively neutralised in a single day.

turns.narrative: Bessa wants to prevent future invasive species introductions.
turns.choice_a: Recommend a compost quarantine protocol for any new soil amendments entering the Green Quarter
turns.consequence_a: Bessa implements the protocol. All incoming compost is held for a two-week observation period.
turns.choice_b: Help Bessa plant aggressive ground-cover species in the cleared area that will naturally compete against future vine invasions
turns.consequence_b: Fast-growing competitive low-native plants are installed. The cleared area is defended naturally.

ground_cover_planted.description: Competitive ground cover planted. Future invasions deterred.

risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed quietly. The situation remains unresolved.

conclusion: Compost quarantine protocol implemented.

title: The Rare Bloom
description: The Green Quarter's Botanical Preserve has lost its only specimen of the Silver Moth Orchid — a plant that blooms once every four years and is the last known cultivated example of the species. The plant was found missing this morning, pot and all. Curator Phas is inconsolable.

turns.narrative: The Silver Moth Orchid was a fragile, distinctive plant with silver-veined petals and a faint sweet odour. The pot was ceramic with an institute mark on the base. The Botanical Preserve had one visitor yesterday afternoon: a woman who signed in as 'Ward Research Liaison Ness.'
turns.choice_a: Visit the Ward Research Office to verify if Ness is a legitimate liaison
turns.consequence_a: There is no Ward Research Liaison named Ness. The name is fake.
turns.choice_b: Track Ness's departure route using the Guard Station's access log
turns.consequence_b: The access log shows she exited via the south gate at 14:40 and took a hired carriage toward the Academic Quarter.

turns.narrative: Tracking the false identity leads you to a private collector who paid Ness to acquire the plant for their private conservatory. Ness is a professional who takes specialist botanical acquisition commissions.
turns.choice_a: Confront Ness directly while she still has the orchid
turns.consequence_a: Ness tells you she will return the plant for 400 gold — her commission fee — to avoid the complication of a formal case.
turns.choice_b: Report the situation to the Ward Authority and let them recover the plant officially
turns.consequence_b: The Ward Authority issues a recovery order. The plant is retrieved from the collector within two days.

turns.narrative: The Silver Moth Orchid is recovered intact. Curator Phas is overwhelmed with relief.
turns.choice_a: Help Phas implement a visiting researcher registration system requiring proof of affiliation
turns.consequence_a: A proper visitor registration system is implemented. ID verification becomes mandatory.
turns.choice_b: Help Phas apply for Heritage Object status for the orchid — making future theft a prosecutable heritage crime
turns.consequence_b: The Heritage Office registers the orchid. Any future theft carries significantly elevated legal consequences.

registration_implemented.description: Visitor registration system with ID verification implemented.

heritage_status.description: Silver Moth Orchid registered as Heritage Object.

risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed quietly. The situation remains unresolved.

conclusion: Visitor registration system with ID verification implemented.

title: The Silent Hammers
description: Two hundred foundry workers have stopped work without announcement or explanation. They are sitting at the factory gates in complete silence — no shouting, no banners, just quiet presence. Factory Owner Gerst is panicking. Ward Labour Advocate Renia is watching from a distance. You are asked to understand what the workers want.

turns.narrative: The silence is eerie. Two hundred people, all sitting cross-legged on the cobblestones, some with eyes closed. There are no leaders visible. You approach the nearest worker group and simply sit down beside them.
turns.choice_a: Simply sit with them quietly and wait to be spoken to
turns.consequence_a: After ten minutes, a woman named Aldra sits beside you and speaks quietly. 'We filed a grievance six months ago. No one answered it.'
turns.choice_b: Ask politely to speak with whoever represents the group
turns.consequence_b: Three people stand — Aldra, an older man named Bert, and a teenager named Mira. A delegation.

turns.narrative: The grievance: three workers were injured over the past four months by a specific press mechanism that has been repeatedly flagged as misaligned, and repeatedly left unrepaired. The workers want the mechanism fixed and the three injured colleagues compensated before they will return to work.
turns.choice_a: Inspect the press mechanism immediately to verify the workers' account
turns.consequence_a: The misalignment is immediately visible to you. This should have been fixed within a day of its first report.
turns.choice_b: Retrieve the six-month-old grievance filing to show Gerst the documented history
turns.consequence_b: The filing is on record — signed, timestamped, and completely unaddressed.

turns.narrative: Gerst is caught. The mechanism is documentiered as defective, the grievance is documented as ignored. He accepts he has no basis to fight this.
turns.choice_a: Negotiate a settlement: fix the mechanism within 24 hours and agree to a compensation framework for the three injured workers
turns.consequence_a: Gerst agrees. Workers return the next morning. Renia witnesses the settlement agreement.
turns.choice_b: Recommend the Labour Authority take over negotiations formally given Gerst's six-month non-response
turns.consequence_b: The Authority takes over. A formal enforceable settlement is issued within three days.

direct_settlement.description: Settlement negotiated directly. Workers returned next morning.

risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed quietly. The situation remains unresolved.

conclusion: Settlement negotiated directly. Workers returned next morning.

title: The Machine That Dreamed
location: Industrial Quarter -> The Clockwork Assembly Plant
description: A large automated sorting machine in the Clockwork Assembly Plant has started producing non-standard outputs — sorting materials into patterns that have no logical process basis, but which the plant's engineer believes may represent something meaningful. Operations are halted. Engineer Tova needs help determining if the machine's behaviour is a malfunction or something more.

turns.narrative: The machine produces sorted object patterns that — when watched for long enough — repeat in a clear sequence. Tova shows you a fifteen-minute recording of the output. The sequence takes twenty-two minutes to complete and then resets. It is too complex to be random but has no operational purpose.
turns.choice_a: Ask Archive Researcher Winn if the pattern matches any known Concordat encoding system
turns.consequence_a: Winn studies the pattern for twenty minutes. She confirms: it matches a known Concordat mechanical message format — the machine is outputting encoded text.
turns.choice_b: Try to decode the repeating pattern by treating it as a simple substitution cipher
turns.consequence_b: Your decoding attempt is partially successful. Several groups clearly represent numbers. More complex groups resist simple decoding.

turns.narrative: Winn confirms the machine is outputting a repeating Concordat mechanical message. Decoded, it reads: 'RESONANCE CORE ACTIVE — DEPTH 14 — REQUEST CONTACT.' The machine appears to have a Pre-Scourge Concordat component embedded in it that is communicating with something underground.
turns.choice_a: Advise Tova to document everything and report this to the Academic Quarter immediately
turns.consequence_a: The Academic Quarter is fascinated. A formal research team is assembled within a week.
turns.choice_b: Try to understand what component is responsible before reporting
turns.consequence_b: Tova opens the machine's lower access panel. A small amber-glowing module is found embedded in the base — clearly not factory-standard.

turns.narrative: The amber module is a Concordat Resonance Relay — the same technology as the Resonant Crystal from the Ridge. It has been active inside this machine for decades, using the machine's mechanical movement as a signal generator.
turns.choice_a: Remove the module carefully for Academic Quarter analysis while documenting the full situation
turns.consequence_a: The module is removed. Tova's machine resumes normal operation. The module joins the Academic Quarter collection.
turns.choice_b: Leave the module in place and recommend the Academic Quarter study the machine in situ
turns.consequence_b: The plant agrees to grant limited academic access twice a week. The research continues without disrupting the machine.

module_removed.description: Resonance Relay removed for study. Machine resumed normal operation.

in_situ_study.description: Academic Quarter studying the machine in situ.

risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed quietly. The situation remains unresolved.

conclusion: Resonance Relay removed for study. Machine resumed normal operation.

title: The Dust and the Cover
description: A catastrophic vent failure at the Rendering Works last week hospitalised three workers with severe burns. The Works owner insists it was 'an unavoidable mechanical failure.' The families of the three hospitalised workers believe it was preventable and that the owner knew the vent was fragile.

turns.narrative: Safety Inspector Dara has already completed a preliminary report. She found that the failed vent showed stress fractures consistent with at least six months of unaddressed wear. The Works Owner's maintenance logs conveniently show an inspection two weeks ago that passed everything — including the failed vent.
turns.choice_a: Examine the failed vent fragment for physical evidence inconsistent with the maintenance timeline
turns.consequence_a: The fracture pattern in the metal shows oxidisation consistent with at least twelve months of exposure — far longer than the two-week maintenance window.
turns.choice_b: Interview the maintenance crew member who signed off on the two-week inspection
turns.consequence_b: The crew member, a part-time contractor, becomes visibly nervous when pressed. He admits he was told by Pol what to write on the form.

turns.narrative: The cover-up is clear. Pol falsified maintenance records to avoid repair costs. The workers' injuries were entirely preventable.
turns.choice_a: Report the full falsification evidence to the Ward Authority for criminal proceedings
turns.consequence_a: Pol is charged with fraud and negligence. The Works is shut pending a full safety review.
turns.choice_b: Prioritise the families — work directly with Pol to negotiate a substantial compensation before formal charges are filed
turns.consequence_b: Pol is terrified of prosecution and agrees to 2000 gold per injured worker and paid medical costs. He signs an admission of fault.

turns.narrative: Regardless of criminal proceedings, the three workers need long-term support.
turns.choice_a: Connect the families with the Ward Workers' Compensation Bureau for ongoing benefits
turns.consequence_a: All three families are enrolled. Monthly compensation begins within two weeks.
turns.choice_b: Ensure all three workers are transferred to the care of the Medical Quarter's Scourge-Wound team for ongoing treatment
turns.consequence_b: Dr. Vel's team accepts the burn cases. Recovery timelines are significantly improved.

pol_charged.description: Pol charged with fraud and negligence. Works shut for safety review.

compensation_negotiated.description: 2000 gold per worker negotiated. Admission of fault signed.

risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed quietly. The situation remains unresolved.

conclusion: Pol charged with fraud and negligence. Works shut for safety review.

title: The Bread Cartel
location: Market Ward -> The Merchant Guild Hall / Multiple Bakeries
description: Following the Flour Wars and the bread riot investigation, you've been asked by Ward Warden Astrid to look deeper. Three separate bakery incidents in the past month weren't coincidences — they were orchestrated. A criminal cartel has been systematically seizing control of Market Ward's bread supply by pressuring owners into protection arrangements. Two bakers who refused have had their shops 'accidentally' destroyed by fire.

turns.narrative: Warden Astrid spreads a map of the Market Ward across her desk and circles seventeen bakeries in red. In the past three months, fourteen of them have begun paying weekly 'security fees' to a man known only as Donn. Two who refused had their properties destroyed in fires that the Fire Watch ruled accidental. The seventeenth — Baker Mira — is still refusing and is terrified. Astrid cannot move formally without evidence tying the fires to Donn — he is careful and well-connected. She needs someone who can work outside the official investigation, building a case brick by brick before Donn's boss learns they're being watched. You accept.
turns.choice_a: Start with Baker Mira — she is the active target and may have direct evidence
turns.consequence_a: Mira is expecting you. She speaks quickly, one eye on the door. She has received three visits from Donn in a week, each time escalating from polite suggestion to barely-veiled threat. She kept a handwritten note he left her: 'Join the family before the family joins you.' She hands it over with shaking hands.
turns.choice_b: Start by surveilling Donn's known collection point — the Weigh-In Warehouse on Canal Street
turns.consequence_b: You watch the warehouse for six hours. Donn collects envelopes from merchants personally, always with a second man watching the street. You note the collection times, the faces, the schedule. You have a pattern but no direct evidence yet.

turns.narrative: The handwritten note or the surveillance pattern both point to the same conclusion: Donn operates with an almost bureaucratic precision that suggests he is not the architect but an executor — someone above him designed this system. The Merchant Guild's name appears twice in your investigation so far: once in the arson report as a witness statement provider, and once in Mira's account of who told her the 'security system was industry standard.' You need to know if the Guild is complicit, captured, or oblivious.
turns.choice_a: Attend the next Merchant Guild open session as a concerned trader and listen carefully
turns.consequence_a: Guild Rep Tolver runs the session with oiled efficiency. At one point he references a 'Market Safety Collective' that all licenced traders are encouraged to join — framed as voluntary, but the phrasing is unmistakably familiar from Mira's account.
turns.choice_b: Find the fire investigation file and look for anomalies in the witness statements
turns.consequence_b: Two witness statements were provided by people who, when you track them down, have no memory of giving any statement. The signatures are forgeries — and the reports were filed by a junior clerk whose supervisor was Tolver's aide.

turns.narrative: The Merchant Guild may be the cartel's legitimate face — its institutional cover. Tolver may be knowingly involved or he may be an unwitting vessel. Either way, the 'Market Safety Collective' is the cartel's public name and the Guild Hall is its operational base of legitimacy. You need to get inside the Collective's records without alerting anyone that the investigation exists.
turns.choice_a: Approach Tolver directly and test whether he will crack under pressure, implying you already know everything
turns.consequence_a: Tolver sweats visibly. He offers to cooperate but asks for a day to prepare — a classic stall. You grant it conditionally, watching him carefully as he leaves the room.
turns.choice_b: Break into the Guild Hall's administrative annex at night to copy the Collective's membership and payment ledgers
turns.consequence_b: A tense hour of lockpicking and careful document-copying. You leave no trace. The membership list has forty-seven names and the payment column totals over 8,000 gold per month — far beyond simple protection.

turns.narrative: Whether through Tolver's cooperation or the ledger copy, you now have the scale of the operation: forty-seven businesses paying into the Collective, the money flowing through three shell accounts, and a quarterly transfer to an account in the High Ward. The cartel's real boss is someone with High Ward financial infrastructure — almost certainly a noble or senior commercial family using the cartel as a revenue stream. Baker Mira receives another visit from Donn this evening, and word reaches you that she has until tomorrow night to join or face consequences.
turns.choice_a: Arrange for Mira to publicly appear to join while secretly wiring her shop with evidence-gathering tools
turns.consequence_a: Mira agrees, terrified but trusting you. Donn returns the next morning and his conversation — caught on a wax impression device borrowed from Astrid's office — is a masterclass in coercive language.
turns.choice_b: Have Ward Guard protection placed on Mira's shop openly, forcing Donn's hand
turns.consequence_b: Donn immediately escalates. He makes contact with someone above him. You track the messenger and identify a High Ward courier route.

turns.narrative: The High Ward courier trail leads to the estate of a man named Merchant-Lord Serren, a well-regarded import trader known for grain and textiles. His public persona is impeccable. But his estate's account activity, cross-referenced against the Collective's shell records, shows monthly reconciliation transfers on the same day each month. Serren is the cartel's financier and almost certainly its architect. You now have the top of the pyramid — but no confession and insufficient evidence for prosecution. You need Donn to give Serren up.
turns.choice_a: Arrest Donn with the evidence you have and interrogate him under formal Ward custody
turns.consequence_a: Donn is tough but rattled. When you lay out the ledgers and the wax recording, his lawyer-instinct kicks in — he asks what deal is on the table.
turns.choice_b: Feed Donn false information that makes him believe Serren has already betrayed him
turns.consequence_b: Donn's paranoia ignites immediately. He makes a reckless contact with Serren demanding clarification — and the meeting is monitored by Astrid's team.

turns.narrative: With Donn either in custody or panicking, the window to act is narrow. Serren will know the investigation is closing. He has the resources to destroy records, relocate funds, and vanish behind layers of legal protection within forty-eight hours if he suspects exposure. You and Astrid have one window: act simultaneously on Donn and Serren before either can warn the other. The cartel's forty-seven protected businesses need to know they are safe to withdraw before they tip off anyone in the network.
turns.choice_a: Coordinate a simultaneous arrest — Astrid takes Serren, you handle Donn
turns.consequence_a: Donn folds immediately when you appear with full Ward authority backing. He names Serren and provides the safe house locations where evidence is stored.
turns.choice_b: Get two of the protected businesses to publicly withdraw from the Collective first, forcing a crisis that exposes Serren's network
turns.consequence_b: Two bakers — Petra and Gorm, who trust you — simultaneously withdraw publicly. The Collective's network panics. Serren makes an operational mistake, contacting Donn directly via a traceable channel.

turns.narrative: Serren's safe house raid yields extraordinary evidence: a complete operational record, a list of all shell accounts, and — most damning — personal correspondence with a Ward Councillor who provided regulatory cover for the Collective for two years. The investigation has scaled far beyond a bakery protection racket. Astrid stands in the safe house staring at the documents. 'This goes to the Council,' she says quietly. 'And then the Council member is going to come for us.' You need to decide how much political exposure you want to take.
turns.choice_a: Full disclosure to the Ward Council immediately, accepting the political firestorm
turns.consequence_a: The Councillor is suspended pending investigation. Two other Council members begin making public statements distancing themselves. The press gets hold of the story within a day.
turns.choice_b: Quietly secure the Councillor's cooperation through private confrontation before anything goes public
turns.consequence_b: The Councillor resigns citing 'personal reasons' and the Collective's records are transferred to Astrid's sealed archive. A cleaner resolution — but the Councillor faces no public consequence.

turns.narrative: With Serren's arrest and the Collective's financial network dismantled, the forty-seven protected businesses are notified of their freedom. Many are too frightened to react openly at first — years of coercion have trained them to be cautious. But one by one, over the following two days, they begin reopening their books, repairing relationships with suppliers they'd been forced to cut, and cautiously celebrating. Baker Mira bakes you a loaf and leaves it at Astrid's office with a note. The bakery district is breathing again. But Donn, now in custody, says something that stops your celebrations cold: 'Serren wasn't the top. He answered to someone too.'
turns.choice_a: Push Donn for the identity of Serren's superior immediately
turns.consequence_a: Donn is genuinely afraid to say the name. He whispers it: 'Vethaan.' A name that appears nowhere in any Ward registry. The investigation may have a second layer.
turns.choice_b: Don't push — close the active case and file Donn's claim as an unverified lead
turns.consequence_b: You close the active investigation. Donn's claim sits in Astrid's files as an open thread. The name 'Vethaan' is recorded but unverified.

turns.narrative: Serren's trial date is set. His defence team immediately files motions to suppress the safe house evidence as unlawfully obtained. A Ward judge will rule in three days. You are called as the primary witness for the prosecution. The Councillor's lawyer — the same firm that represented Serren — pays you an unofficial visit and suggests that your testimony could be 'simplified' for the court's benefit, implying cooperation would be in your interest. The implied threat is clear.
turns.choice_a: Report the lawyer's visit to Astrid immediately as witness intimidation
turns.consequence_a: Astrid is furious and charges the lawyer with contempt. The firm is suddenly very cooperative.
turns.choice_b: Play along with the lawyer just long enough to gather evidence of the intimidation attempt
turns.consequence_b: You record the conversation using the wax device again. The lawyer walks into a trap.

turns.narrative: The suppression motion is denied. Trial begins the following week. On the morning of the third day, Serren's cartel remnants make a desperate move. Donn, being transferred between facilities, is broken out by a four-man enforcement team — former city guard, well-armed and tactically coordinated. You receive the alert and are the closest responding agent. The breakout is happening on Canal Street, one block from Baker Mira's shop. [COMBAT ENCOUNTER — 4 cartel enforcers, leather armour, short blades and clubs]
turns.choice_a: Intercept the breakout team directly and prevent Donn from escaping
turns.consequence_a: A fierce running fight through the Market Ward's narrow alleys. Two enforcers are taken down. Donn is re-secured. The other two escape. Ward Guard arrives three minutes later.
turns.choice_b: Focus on securing Donn and let the enforcers go
turns.consequence_b: Donn is kept. None of the enforcers are taken. Their escape provides Astrid with intelligence about a secondary Cartel safe house they route through.

turns.narrative: With the breakout failed and Donn back in custody, Serren's legal strategy collapses. His defence team negotiates a plea — full cooperation in exchange for reduced sentence and asset forfeiture. Serren names twelve additional operators across the city and provides the complete account structure. The name 'Vethaan' comes up again — this time Serren winces when you say it aloud. He says only: 'Vethaan doesn't exist in any record. That is the point.' The trial ends in conviction. The Market Ward is free. A second, deeper operation remains open.
turns.choice_a: File a formal case opening on the Vethaan lead and begin deeper intelligence collection
turns.consequence_a: Astrid creates a sealed investigation file: OPERATION VETHAAN. It sits in her office waiting. The thread is alive.
turns.choice_b: Consider the Vethaan information disinformation designed to sow chaos — close the thread
turns.consequence_b: The Vethaan thread is formally closed. The name appears once more — in a completely different context — six months later.

turns.narrative: The Market Ward's Bakery District holds an informal celebration on the evening of Serren's conviction. Mira has organised a street table with contributions from all forty-seven freed bakeries. Warden Astrid raises a cup of tea and looks at you across the table. 'That was four months of work compressed into a week,' she says. 'I don't know whether to thank you or be frightened by how quickly this moved.' The Bread Cartel is dismantled. The forty-seven bakeries are free. Two fires remain unsolved but their perpetrators are in custody. The Ward breathes easier. The name Vethaan waits in a sealed file.
turns.choice_a: Accept recognition publicly at the celebration — your name becomes publicly linked to the Cartel's downfall
turns.consequence_a: You are publicly celebrated. Market Ward reputation soars. You also become a visible target for any Cartel remnants.
turns.choice_b: Decline recognition — remain in the background and protect your operational value for future work
turns.consequence_b: The credit goes to Warden Astrid officially. You remain anonymous. Future investigations are easier to run covertly.

public_hero.description: You accepted public recognition. Cartel dismantled. Vethaan thread opened.

shadow_operator.description: You declined recognition. Cartel dismantled. Vethaan thread opened.

partial_resolution.description: The Cartel ledger was dismantled but the Vethaan thread was closed.

risk_matrix.critical_failure: Donn escapes the trial entirely. Serren is acquitted. The Collective reforms under new leadership.

conclusion: You accepted public recognition. Cartel dismantled. Vethaan thread opened.

title: The Fermentation Chamber
location: Market Ward -> Undercity Fringe / The Yeast Quarter
description: During the Bread Cartel investigation, a seized ledger contained an encrypted line item: 'F-Chamber — subsidy — 400gm.' No one could identify what it referred to. Now a Water Authority worker reports a massive warm-air smell rising from a sealed Undercity access shaft beneath the old Yeast Quarter — a section of the Market Ward that mass-produced yeast before the Scourge. Someone is running an unauthorised operation underground. Warden Astrid suspects it is connected to the Cartel's successor or a new player exploiting the power vacuum.

turns.narrative: The access shaft Brenn identified is behind a food waste processing unit — hidden in plain sight for years. When you pry the cover, a warm yeasty exhalation rolls up from below. The shaft descends twelve metres via a metal ladder, clearly maintained and recently oiled. The smell is warm bread combined with something acrid — a fermentation process operating at industrial scale. Brenn says the heat signature on the surface has been consistent for at least two years. Whatever is down there has been running long before the Cartel's recent disruptions.
turns.choice_a: Descend immediately and investigate the chamber
turns.consequence_a: The bottom of the shaft opens into a pre-Scourge industrial fermentation hall — enormous stone vats, thirty feet across, filled with actively bubbling yeast cultures, tended by six workers who freeze when they see you.
turns.choice_b: Map the surface footprint first by checking adjacent shafts and heat signatures before descending
turns.consequence_b: Three adjacent shafts show elevated heat. The underground operation covers roughly half a city block. This is not a small operation.

turns.narrative: The six workers are not criminals — they are yeast specialists, some of whom have been working in this chamber for over a decade. Their supervisor, Yeast Chemist Alora, emerges from a side office with the calm authority of someone who has been managing a public secret for years. She does not seem surprised to see you. 'I wondered when Astrid would find us,' she says, and pours two cups of herbal tea from a kettle on her workbench. 'Would you like to understand what we're actually doing before you decide whether to shut us down?'
turns.choice_a: Hear Alora out fully before making any judgment
turns.consequence_a: Alora explains: The F-Chamber is officially unregistered because its parent Concordat-era yeast licence was never formally dissolved — the Scourge happened before the paperwork cleared. She has been producing the primary yeast culture for forty percent of Market Ward's bakeries at below-cost prices for twelve years. If you shut it down, bread prices double.
turns.choice_b: Immediately ask who is paying for this operation and where the money flows
turns.consequence_b: Alora shows you the chamber's accounts without hesitation. The operation is funded by a collective of twenty-two bakeries who pay a below-market subscription. She is not running this for profit — she is running it to keep bread affordable.

turns.narrative: The chamber's yeast cultures are extraordinary — Pre-Scourge heritage strains that produce bread of dramatically superior flavour and nutritional quality. Alora's operation has been effectively subsidising the Market Ward's bread supply for over a decade. But its unlicensed status makes it technically illegal. The Cartel's ledger suggesting a 'subsidy' connection could mean the Cartel was skimming from, protecting, or planning to exploit the chamber. Alora blanches when you show her the ledger entry — she did not know the Cartel was aware of her.
turns.choice_a: Determine whether the Cartel was actually taking money from Alora's operation
turns.consequence_a: Cross-referencing the Cartel accounts with Alora's records shows that a payment of 400 gold monthly was being made directly to Donn — but not by Alora. By one of her subscriber bakeries who was also paying Cartel protection. The Cartel had discovered the chamber and was taking a cut from a baker who wanted it kept secret.
turns.choice_b: Focus on regularising the chamber legally before someone else discovers it
turns.consequence_b: Alora says she has always wanted to regularise but feared that licensing would mean taxation and cost increases that would end the affordable bread subsidy. You could potentially find a heritage-status exemption.

turns.narrative: With the Cartel connection clarified — the chamber was a victim being indirectly exploited, not a Cartel asset — you now have a choice about the chamber's future. Alora's operation is genuinely beneficial and her heritage yeast strains are irreplaceable. But the Ward Authority cannot officially ignore an unlicensed operation of this scale once it has been logged in your investigation report.
turns.choice_a: Work with Alora to apply for emergency heritage licensing through the Academic Quarter and Ward Authority jointly
turns.consequence_a: The application process takes three weeks but succeeds. The F-Chamber is registered as 'The Pre-Scourge Yeast Heritage Facility' with protected status and a formal bread subsidy mandate.
turns.choice_b: Recommend Astrid quietly bury the F-Chamber discovery in the Cartel investigation files as 'resolved'
turns.consequence_b: The F-Chamber continues operating exactly as before, now with Astrid's informal protection. Risk remains if future investigators find the old files.

turns.narrative: During the regularisation process or the quiet burial, Alora reveals something she has kept secret even from her own workers: a second chamber deeper underground, accessible only through a hidden door in the back of the heritage yeast hall. This chamber is older — Pre-Scourge — and contains something she has never been able to fully identify. The fermentation process in the second chamber is not yeast-based. It produces a liquid that Alora has tested carefully and determined is non-toxic, but which causes mild euphoria in those who consume it. She has never given it to anyone and has told no one.
turns.choice_a: Investigate the second chamber thoroughly with Alora's guidance
turns.consequence_a: The second chamber contains what Alora's analysis suggests is an early-stage Void-Wine predecessor — a pre-Scourge attempt to produce controlled psychoactive fermentation using Void-adjacent compounds. The Concordat was developing this when the Scourge struck.
turns.choice_b: Seal the second chamber and have its existence officially registered as a potentially biohazardous discovery
turns.consequence_b: The chamber is sealed and the documentation forwarded to the Medical Quarter and Academic Quarter for evaluation. Its contents will not be accessed without trained analysis.

turns.narrative: The second chamber's contents — whether you investigated or sealed it — represent a significant discovery that changes the narrative of the entire investigation. The Concordat was developing a controlled form of Void-adjacent fermentation before the Scourge interrupted them. This is both a potential scientific breakthrough and a genuine public risk.
turns.choice_a: Brief Warden Astrid fully and recommend joint Medical Quarter / Academic Quarter study
turns.consequence_a: A joint research committee is formed within a week. Alchemist Rynn and Dr. Vel both express strong interest.
turns.choice_b: Brief only Alora — keep the second chamber's nature between you for now
turns.consequence_b: Alora agrees to monitor the second chamber under your shared oversight. The Academic Quarter remains unaware.

turns.narrative: Word has reached the High Ward that an underground heritage food facility has been discovered in the Market Ward. Merchant-Lord families who lost influence in the Bread Cartel's collapse see an opportunity: if they can claim heritage rights to the F-Chamber's yeast culture, they can control the bread subsidy and restore their market advantage. Three separate High Ward legal firms file concurrent claims on the Concordat-era licence within forty-eight hours of the Academic Quarter receiving regularisation papers. Alora is furious. Her life's work is being circled by opportunists.
turns.choice_a: Build an immediate legal defence for Alora — prove the Concordat licence belongs to the current operators by precedent of continuous use
turns.consequence_a: A Ward precedent case from forty years ago establishes that continuous operation under an unbroken Concordat licence constitutes inherited ownership. The High Ward claims are dismissed.
turns.choice_b: Go on offence — expose the High Ward firms' connections to the Bread Cartel's remnant network publicly
turns.consequence_b: Two of the three firms have documented links to Serren's former associates. The revelation causes them to withdraw their claims before a trial date is set.

turns.narrative: The legal challenge resolved, the F-Chamber is formally secure. Alora's yeast cultures are now protected heritage assets. Three Academic Quarter researchers have begun a supervised study of the second chamber's contents. But city politics are not done — the Ward Council, now aware of the F-Chamber's significance to bread prices, wants to formalise its status as a public utility. This would mean Alora loses independent control and the chamber becomes Ward-administered. Alora comes to you and says simply: 'You opened this door. I'm asking you to help me keep my hand on the key.'
turns.choice_a: Support Alora's bid for independent operation under Ward regulatory oversight — best of both worlds
turns.consequence_a: A creative legal arrangement is drafted: the F-Chamber operates independently but under a Ward Heritage Food Council that Alora chairs. Her authority is protected.
turns.choice_b: Support Ward administration — the public utility argument is strong and Alora would be protected as Head Yeast Scientist
turns.consequence_b: The Ward takes administrative control. Alora is appointed Head Yeast Scientist with full operational authority but official backing.

turns.narrative: As the F-Chamber's future is secured, an unexpected visitor arrives at the chamber's surface entrance. A young man in travel-worn clothes shows Ward documents identifying him as an heir to the original Pre-Scourge yeast facility's founding family. He has documentation predating the Concordat licence — family records from before the Scourge that establish his family built the facility over one hundred years ago. His claim is emotionally and historically valid but legally complex. Alora looks at him for a long moment and says: 'You remind me of someone. Come in. I'll show you everything.'
turns.choice_a: Support the young heir's historical claim and negotiate a partnership arrangement between him and Alora
turns.consequence_a: The young man — named Tor — becomes a co-director of the F-Chamber. He brings additional family historical records that help unlock more of the chamber's Pre-Scourge documentation.
turns.choice_b: Advise that the historical claim, while valid in sentiment, cannot override Alora's established operational precedent under wardlaw
turns.consequence_b: Tor is disappointed but not hostile. He accepts a paid historical advisory role and contributes his family records to the Academic Quarter's archive.

turns.narrative: The second chamber's academic study has produced a preliminary finding: the Pre-Scourge Void-adjacent fermentation process is viable and produces a compound that the Medical Quarter believes may have genuine therapeutic applications for Scourge wound treatment. However, upscaling the process risks producing the euphoric compound in quantities that would constitute an unlicensed psychoactive substance. The committee has reached an impasse. Outside the hearing room, someone who has been watching the F-Chamber's situation closely reaches out to you privately. They represent 'interested parties' and offer considerable resources to accelerate the compound's development — outside the committee's oversight. [HIGH-STAKES SOCIAL ENCOUNTER — determine if this is cartel remnant, Vethaan's network, or legitimate private investment]
turns.choice_a: Engage carefully and attempt to identify who 'interested parties' actually represents before rejecting or accepting
turns.consequence_a: Careful questioning and cross-referencing reveals the operative's language patterns match documented Vethaan network communications from Astrid's sealed files. This is Vethaan's people making contact.
turns.choice_b: Reject immediately and report the contact to Astrid as a potential Vethaan network probe
turns.consequence_b: Astrid's team traces the contact's routes. They identify three addresses — a new lead in the Vethaan investigation.

turns.narrative: Whether you identified them or simply reported the contact, the Vethaan network has revealed itself as interested in the F-Chamber's second chamber compounds. The sealed investigation file at Astrid's office now has three new data points. The academic committee reviews the contact attempt and agrees that the compound's development must be paused until the security situation is fully assessed — the risk of the formula falling into unknown hands is too great. A temporary research moratorium is declared. Alora and Tor accept this reluctantly but understand the necessity. The F-Chamber itself continues operating normally on bread yeast production.
turns.choice_a: Use the moratorium period to build F-Chamber's physical security against an attempted raid
turns.consequence_a: Security improvements are implemented. Two additional access points are sealed. Ward Guard begins a daily patrol of the surface access area.
turns.choice_b: Use the moratorium to complete the Vethaan lead follow-through with Astrid before they disappear again
turns.consequence_b: You devote the next week to the Vethaan leads. Two of the three addresses yield actionable intelligence.

turns.narrative: Six weeks after first descending that access shaft, the F-Chamber is a registered heritage food facility producing bread yeast for forty percent of Market Ward bakeries, its operations overseen under a hybrid governance arrangement that protects both Alora and the public interest. The second chamber is under moratorium pending security clearance. Tor has found his purpose and his family history. The Vethaan thread has grown from a whispered name to a documented network with three identified addresses. You stand in the chamber's main hall, the warm yeast smell around you, watching Alora supervise her workers with the quiet authority of someone whose life's work has finally been protected and legitimised. She looks at you and says: 'You know the bread here is better because of what's under our feet. That's true about most things, I think.'
turns.choice_a: Stay connected to the F-Chamber as an ongoing liaison — this place may become important again
turns.consequence_a: You establish a formal relationship with the F-Chamber. Future events that touch the Bakery thread may connect here.
turns.choice_b: Close your active involvement and let the chamber's new governance handle its future
turns.consequence_b: You step back. The F-Chamber's governance is solid. You have other investigations waiting.

vethaan_identified.description: The second chamber is under moratorium. Vethaan network identified as interested party. Three addresses logged.

chamber_secured.description: F-Chamber registered and secured. Vethaan contact reported but not identified.

risk_matrix.critical_failure: The second chamber's compound formula is stolen. Vethaan's network acquires it.

conclusion: The second chamber is under moratorium. Vethaan network identified as interested party. Three addresses logged.

title: The Baker's Uprising
location: Market Ward -> Merchant Guild Hall / Bakery District
description: The Bread Cartel's dismantling and the F-Chamber's public legitimisation has emboldened the Market Ward's bakery community. Led by Petra and Gorm — who have now merged their operations — forty-three bakers present a formal petition to the Merchant Guild demanding independent licensing, price floor protections, and the right to buy flour directly from the Agricultural Zone without Guild intermediaries. The Guild has responded by revoking five bakers' licences on technical grounds within 24 hours. A full trade confrontation is building. This is the bakers' chance to break free from Guild control permanently — or be crushed before they have fully organised.

turns.narrative: Petra and Gorm present you with their petition in the merged bakery — now the largest in the Market Ward and operating as a workers' cooperative. The document is thorough, legally cited, and signed by forty-three proprietors. Gorm has a bruise on his jaw. He says Guild enforcers visited last night to explain why the petition was 'inadvisable.' Petra is furious and wants to go to the press. Gorm wants to find leverage first. You were the one who dismantled the Cartel — they trust you to help them navigate this.
turns.choice_a: Advise immediate press engagement — public disclosure makes Guild enforcement dangerous and costly
turns.consequence_a: Ward journalist Ira runs the story within six hours. The Guild licence revocations become front-page news. Guild Master Tolver issues an angry denial that reads as confirmation.
turns.choice_b: Advise securing Ward Council support before going public — a Councillor's backing changes the legal landscape immediately
turns.consequence_b: Councillor Dain, who owes political capital to Ward communities after recent events, agrees to review the petition formally — a significant procedural protection.

turns.narrative: The five revoked bakers are now locked out of their premises. Their families are losing income daily. The Guild has invoked an obscure 'standards compliance' clause that requires a formal 30-day appeals process — time specifically designed to break resistance by financial attrition. You need either to accelerate the appeals or find the Guild in violation of a protection that invalidates the clause entirely.
turns.choice_a: Examine the standards compliance clause closely for procedural defects
turns.consequence_a: The clause was amended four years ago without the required full Guild membership vote — making the amendment itself procedurally void. The revocations are based on an invalid clause.
turns.choice_b: Get the five revoked bakers emergency interim licences from a sympathetic Ward Authority official while appeals proceed
turns.consequence_b: A sympathetic official issues interim operating permits. The bakers reopen immediately. The Guild is furious but legally blocked from stopping it.

turns.narrative: With the five bakers protected and the procedural defect identified, the uprising has momentum. Tolver calls an emergency Guild session and you receive an invitation — not to testify but to 'mediate.' In the Guild Hall's grand chamber, forty Guild members sit across from forty-three bakers. The air is thick. Tolver opens by offering to restore the five licences in exchange for the petition being withdrawn. Petra looks at you.
turns.choice_a: Advise Petra to reject the offer and demand the Guild recognise the independent licensing framework
turns.consequence_a: Petra stands: 'The petition is not withdrawn. We will accept licence restoration as a first step only.' The room electrifies.
turns.choice_b: Recommend accepting the offer as a tactical retreat — preserve the five shops and rebuild for a second push
turns.consequence_b: Gorm disagrees but follows your lead. The licences are restored. The petition is officially withdrawn — but the bakers begin organising a formal independent trade association that doesn't require Guild recognition.

turns.narrative: Either the confrontation intensifies or the independent trade association route is pursued. In both cases, Tolver makes a private move: he contacts the High Ward Merchant Families who have long held de facto control over the Guild. Within forty-eight hours, two of the largest wheat trading families withdraw supply contracts from six bakeries who are part of the petition. Suddenly six more bakers face closure — not from licence revocation but from inability to source flour. The Agricultural Zone's direct supply route is the bakers' lifeline now.
turns.choice_a: Travel to the Agricultural Zone and negotiate an emergency direct supply arrangement with Agronomist Liss
turns.consequence_a: Liss has been watching the Ward situation closely. She is eager to provide direct supply — the Guild intermediaries have been underpaying her farmers for years. She agrees to a trial direct-supply contract.
turns.choice_b: Expose the supply withdrawal as anticompetitive collusion to the Ward Trade Authority
turns.consequence_b: The Ward Trade Authority determines the coordinated withdrawal across two unrelated trading families constitutes market manipulation. A temporary injunction restores supply within 24 hours.

turns.narrative: The Agricultural Zone direct supply arrangement or the injunction stabilises the crisis. Tolver is now exposed on two fronts: the procedural defect, the supply manipulation. He makes a personal visit — without Guild escort — to the merged bakery. He is older than you remember. He closes the door and says: 'I have spent thirty years building something. I don't want to spend my last years enforcing it.' He offers a bargain: he will support the independent licensing framework internally if the bakers agree not to pursue the supply manipulation charge.
turns.choice_a: Accept Tolver's personal bargain — his internal support could deliver the framework faster than a fight
turns.consequence_a: Tolver is as good as his word. Three weeks later, the Guild votes to recognise independent baker licensing by a slim majority. His advocacy is the decisive factor.
turns.choice_b: Reject Tolver's bargain — the bakers deserve the full legal outcome and his personal support doesn't outweigh accountability for the supply manipulation
turns.consequence_b: The supply manipulation case proceeds. Tolver testifies against the trading families to limit his own exposure. The framework is won through the courts.

turns.narrative: The agricultural supply line is secured and the independent licensing framework is through either Guild approval or legal ruling. Forty-three bakeries are free of Guild pricing control for the first time in two generations. But the power vacuum is real: the Guild had been providing genuine services — standards enforcement, dispute arbitration, supplier verification — that the bakers now need to replicate themselves. Petra and Gorm ask you to help design the Baker's Independent Trade Council.
turns.choice_a: Draft a council charter modelled on the Guild's functional services but with democratic baker governance
turns.consequence_a: The council is constituted with twelve elected seats, rotating annually. Petra is the first Chair. Gorm is the first Standards Officer.
turns.choice_b: Recommend the bakers form a looser cooperative alliance rather than formalising a new institution
turns.consequence_b: The Baker's Alliance is informal but effective. It operates on trust and shared interest — lighter and more nimble than the Guild.

turns.narrative: Councillor Dain, who provided the formal review that protected the petition, now wants something in return: political support for his upcoming proposal to create a unified Market Ward Food Authority that would oversee all food traders, not just bakers. It sounds beneficial in principle — in practice it would give a single Ward Council committee oversight over the new Baker's Council or Alliance, potentially recreating the control problem with a different body at the top.
turns.choice_a: Negotiate with Dain — support the Food Authority in exchange for explicit carve-outs protecting baker independence
turns.consequence_a: Dain agrees to amended language. The Food Authority is created with clear independence provisions for licensed trader associations.
turns.choice_b: Oppose the Food Authority proposal as premature — the bakers need time to consolidate their independence before any new oversight body is introduced
turns.consequence_b: Dain is irritated but the opposition is sufficient to delay the proposal. The bakers have a window of genuine independence.

turns.narrative: The High Ward Merchant Families who attempted the supply manipulation have not forgotten. Two weeks after the settlement or ruling, a new entity appears in the Ward's commercial registry: The Market Ward Grain Collective, capitalised at significant funds and immediately offering bakeries below-market flour prices. It is an attempt to buy influence that the Guild lost through legitimate competition — making the bakers financially dependent again but through economic rather than coercive means.
turns.choice_a: Identify the Collective's backers and expose any connection to the previous supply manipulation attempt
turns.consequence_a: The Collective's primary investor is a holding company with documented links to the trading family that ordered the supply withdrawal. Exposed, the Collective's offer collapses as bakeries withdraw from discussions.
turns.choice_b: Advise the bakers to accept the Collective's below-market offer but structure it with a one-year exit clause at no penalty
turns.consequence_b: Smart financial positioning. Bakeries take the lower prices for one year while building their independent supply capacities from the Agricultural Zone. When the exit clause is invoked, they are self-sufficient.

turns.narrative: The Ward journalist Ira publishes a feature on the Baker's Uprising — a long-form account of everything that has happened over the past several months, from the Cartel to the F-Chamber to the Guild confrontation and the Uprising itself. The piece is well-researched and balanced. But it names you prominently as the central figure in all of it. By nightfall, you have received three anonymous messages: one is a note of congratulation that feels menacing, one is a threat to your physical safety, and one says only the name 'Vethaan' with a bread loaf drawn beneath it.
turns.choice_a: Report all three messages to Astrid with full documentation
turns.consequence_a: Astrid pulls security resources immediately. The Vethaan bread loaf symbol is added to the investigation file — it suggests someone within the bakery community, or someone with detailed knowledge of it, is connected to Vethaan.
turns.choice_b: Analyse the three messages yourself before deciding what to share
turns.consequence_b: The handwriting, paper quality, and seal wax on the threatening note match High Ward stationery. The Vethaan note was delivered by a Lower Ward child who was given a silver coin and a note to deliver.

turns.narrative: The Vethaan breadloaf symbol combined with the threatening note creates genuine urgency. The Baker's Uprising has made you a public figure and a visible target. At the same time, the Uprising itself is reaching its successful conclusion — but the final ratification of the independent licensing framework requires a Ward Council vote that is happening in two days. Two Council members who were expected to support it have gone suspiciously silent. [INVESTIGATION ENCOUNTER — determine if Council members have been pressured and counter the pressure before the vote]
turns.choice_a: Visit both Council members personally and directly ask if they have been approached by anyone regarding the vote
turns.consequence_a: One of them — the more junior — cracks under direct questioning: they received a private communication with financial inducements to abstain from the vote. You have documented bribery.
turns.choice_b: Have Astrid run surveillance on both Council members for 48 hours before the vote to catch any meetings with interested parties
turns.consequence_b: A High Ward legal courier makes a delivery to one Council member's private residence two hours before the vote — a sealed envelope that the member immediately burns without reading, apparently deciding against accepting the inducement.

turns.narrative: The bribery either documented or deflected, the Ward Council vote proceeds. The chamber is packed. Bakers from across the Market Ward stand in the public gallery watching. Petra is in the front row. The vote is called. It passes — twenty-two to seventeen, with three abstentions. The independent bakery licensing framework is now Ward law. The gallery erupts. Petra is weeping. Gorm is grinning. Tolver, sitting alone in the back of the chamber, is completely still. He catches your eye, nods once, and leaves.
turns.choice_a: Find Tolver after the vote and acknowledge what he helped accomplish
turns.consequence_a: Tolver speaks quietly. 'I've been with the Guild since I was Gorm's age. I thought it was everything. Now I think it was just a place I was comfortable.' He shakes your hand and walks away.
turns.choice_b: Let Tolver go — the moment belongs to the bakers, not to complicated acknowledgements
turns.consequence_b: You watch the celebration in the gallery instead. Pross and Rella are both there. The city feels, for a moment, capable of changing.

turns.narrative: Three weeks after the vote, the Baker's Council or Alliance holds its inaugural session. Forty-three businesses operating freely. The F-Chamber providing subsidised yeast. Direct Agricultural Zone supply flowing. Every baker in the Market Ward who wanted independence has it. The thread started with three bakery incidents that looked random but were anything but — and has ended with the Ward's food infrastructure genuinely transformed. The Vethaan thread remains open. The breadloaf symbol sits in Astrid's files. Whoever Vethaan is, they have been watching the bakery district carefully enough to know your involvement in detail. That is worth remembering.
turns.choice_a: Formally commit to investigating the Vethaan breadloaf connection actively
turns.consequence_a: OPERATION VETHAAN receives two new data points. A sub-investigation specifically targeting Vethaan's interest in the bakery district is opened.
turns.choice_b: Log the breadloaf connection and return to other work — Vethaan will surface again on their own schedule
turns.consequence_b: The connection is logged. Vethaan remains a shadow. The baker thread closes cleanly.

framework_passed_guild_support.description: Independent licensing framework passed with Tolver's cooperation. Baker's Council constituted.

framework_passed_legal.description: Independent licensing framework won through Ward Courts. Baker's Alliance formed.

risk_matrix.critical_failure: The Council vote fails. The Guild retaliates. Multiple bakeries close within a week.

conclusion: Independent licensing framework passed with Tolver's cooperation. Baker's Council constituted.

title: The Grief Merchants
location: Lower Ward -> Transit Corridor -> High Ward
description: Following the canal dock Void-Wine supplier investigation, a pattern has emerged across three districts: Void-Wine is being systematically marketed to recently bereaved citizens — those who lost family members in Scourge-adjacent incidents within the past year. The operation targets grief with pharmaceutical precision, identifies new victims within days of a death, and makes contact through seemingly sympathetic community figures. Warden Astrid has received sixteen formal addiction complaints this month alone, all from recently bereaved Lower Ward families. This is not opportunistic — it is a designed predation network.

turns.narrative: Astrid has compiled a map of the sixteen complaints. Every single victim received their first Void-Wine dose within ten days of a funeral and all of them were approached by someone they trusted — a community healer, a neighbourhood leader, a distant relative who appeared suddenly. The pattern is too consistent to be coincidence. Someone inside the bereavement community is identifying and flagging new targets. Astrid calls it 'grief scouting' — finding the vulnerable before they have had time to build defences. Your job is to identify the scout network and trace it to whoever is directing it.
turns.choice_a: Attend upcoming funerals and memorial services in the Lower Ward to identify anyone unusual attending
turns.consequence_a: Over three services in four days you notice the same two individuals: a middle-aged woman named Pross who introduces herself as a 'community healer' and offers free grief counselling, and a younger man who stays at the periphery taking notes on a small slate. You do not approach either yet.
turns.choice_b: Work backwards from the sixteen victims — find where their first contact happened and who made it
turns.consequence_b: Twelve of the sixteen victims were first approached at the Labourer's Community Hall by individuals offering 'grief circles.' The Hall's logs show sixteen unscheduled guests over the past month — all visitors without regular membership.

turns.narrative: Whether you have identified Pross or the Hall pattern, both threads converge on the same person: Healer Pross operates the 'grief circles' at the Community Hall and makes personal follow-up home visits to the most distressed attendees. She is legitimately compassionate by all accounts — neighbours genuinely trust her. But on home visits she leaves small bottles of Void-Wine as a 'calming aid for the first night.' She believes she is helping. She does not know, or does not allow herself to know, where the wine comes from.
turns.choice_a: Intervene with Pross directly and compassionately — she is a victim of the network as much as her clients
turns.consequence_a: Pross is devastated when you lay out the full picture. She has been receiving the wine through a 'grief aid donation' left at the Hall each week in an unmarked box. She genuinely did not know its Void composition.
