She has been tracking the health effects of the geothermal pressure anomaly on Ridge workers over the past 96 hours. Her data shows a significant number of workers experienced headaches, nausea, and mild auditory hallucinations during the pressure spike — consistent with infrasonic exposure from the deep fault movement. She also notes that several workers with the longest Ridge tenure showed less pronounced symptoms — suggesting physiological adaptation over time.
turns.choice_a: Request Vel design a comprehensive occupational health study for long-term Ridge workers
turns.consequence_a: The Heritage Authority approves the study. Vel believes Ridge workers may represent a population with unique physiological adaptations to geothermal exposure.
turns.choice_b: Ensure the worker health data goes into the Heritage Authority's safety protocol development
turns.consequence_b: Vel's data directly shapes three new safety standards including mandatory rotation schedules and infrasonic monitoring at deep operations.

turns.narrative: The incident has generated enormous amounts of data — pressure records, geological assessments, crystal array logs, stabilisation array performance data, health impact studies. The Academic Quarter requests full access for research purposes. The Heritage Authority is willing but wants a formal data-sharing agreement that prevents commercial exploitation of geological intelligence by private interests. The negotiation is complex and has significant implications for how the Ridge discloses future discoveries. [NEGOTIATION ENCOUNTER — balance research openness with operational security]
turns.choice_a: Negotiate a research partnership with explicit commercial-use restrictions and community benefit mandates
turns.consequence_a: A strong data-sharing agreement is reached. Three Academic Quarter researchers are embedded with the Heritage Authority on a permanent basis.
turns.choice_b: Propose that the Heritage Authority establish its own research capability rather than depending on external institutions
turns.consequence_b: A Heritage Authority Research Division is constituted. Two Academic Quarter researchers join it permanently, working under Heritage Authority governance rather than external direction.

turns.narrative: Six weeks after the incident, the Ridge is stabilised and significantly better understood than before it happened. The fault stabilisation array is maintaining geological equilibrium. The energy station is operating at a sustainable 60% after careful throttle increase. The heating supply to the Lower Ward is fully restored. A community monitoring group meets weekly with Heritage Authority representatives. Pyra has been appointed as the Ridge's first Chief Safety Officer — a new position created specifically in response to the incident. She accepts it with characteristic precision: 'I expect to be regularly inconvenient to the people in charge. That seems like the job.'
turns.choice_a: Support Pyra's appointment publicly and attend her inauguration session
turns.consequence_a: The inauguration is a genuinely warm community event. Dorr, Dara, Kell, Renia, and Voss all attend.
turns.choice_b: Send formal congratulations and continue working in the background
turns.consequence_b: Pyra sends a brief note back: 'See you at the next crisis.' It is absolutely a promise.

turns.narrative: The Geothermal Collapse that never fully happened has transformed the Ridge's safety infrastructure and its governance in permanent and meaningful ways. A district that once primarily had its resources extracted is now building the expertise to manage those resources responsibly for generations. The Concordat infrastructure layer that caused the initial problem has become the key to solving it. Everything the Ridge has learned about its own underground — the crystal arrays, the fault maps, the stabilisation systems — represents knowledge that the Scourge interrupted and the Heritage Authority has now resumed. Elder Voss says at the Heritage Authority's monthly session: 'The Concordat spent a hundred years building something for us to inherit. I think we've finally started accepting the inheritance.'
turns.choice_a: Formally propose a Ridge Concordat Infrastructure Heritage programme to the Ward Council
turns.consequence_a: The programme is approved. It becomes one of the Ward's flagship reconstruction initiatives.
turns.choice_b: Leave the legacy work to the Heritage Authority and move to other investigations
turns.consequence_b: The Heritage Authority is excellent. The Ridge thread closes in the best possible position.

array_activated_station.description: Fault stabilised via communication station. Energy restored. Heritage Authority research division formed.

array_activated_manual.description: Fault stabilised via manual team descent. Evacuation managed well. Safety protocols updated.

risk_matrix.critical_failure: Nexus releases. Superheated vent event injures sixty workers and Lower Ward residents. Ridge is quarantined for thirty days.

conclusion: Fault stabilised via communication station. Energy restored. Heritage Authority research division formed.

title: The Cross-District Smuggling
location: Market Ward -> Transit Corridor -> Lower Ward
description: The Ward Trade Authority has flagged a pattern of goods disappearing between the Market Ward's licensed suppliers and Lower Ward distributors — an invisible pinch point somewhere in the Transit Corridor. The missing goods are diverse: medicines, food preservatives, alchemical compounds, and tool metal stock. No single thread except transit routing. Three Lower Ward community leaders have formally complained about supply chain reliability. Warden Astrid suspects professional cargo diversion — not theft but sophisticated rerouting that redirects goods to unlicensed buyers before official delivery.

turns.narrative: The Transit Corridor is the city's arterial transport network — hundreds of cargo movements daily through a series of licensed waypoints. Coordinator Helv provides you with three months of cargo manifests. The pattern that emerges is subtle: goods are logged at the Market Ward origin, arrive at Transit Waypoint 4, and then show discrepancies at the Lower Ward destination — not missing, but the wrong items, consistent with cargo being swapped in transit. Professional operators who know the manifest system well enough to produce matching documentation.
turns.choice_a: Physically shadow a specific cargo batch from Market Ward origin to Lower Ward destination
turns.consequence_a: You spend eight hours accompanying a medicine consignment. At Waypoint 4, while the cargo is being officially re-weighed, a four-minute gap in supervision is all that is needed. When you're not directly watching, a crate is swapped. You catch the swap mid-action — the exchange operative freezes.
turns.choice_b: Audit Waypoint 4's staffing and access logs to identify who has consistent unsupervised access during transit windows
turns.consequence_b: Two Transit Corridor employees have access patterns that perfectly correlate with the discrepancy events — including a night-shift cargo supervisor named Broll who has worked every diversion incident shift.

turns.narrative: The Waypoint 4 operative — caught in the swap or identified through the audit — is Broll, a Transit Corridor cargo supervisor of twelve years who has been running the diversion for three years. He cooperates immediately when confronted, explaining that he was recruited by a Market Ward merchant who needed a way to sell goods off-manifest to Lower Ward buyers at inflated prices while maintaining the official supply relationship. The merchant skims the difference. Lower Ward buyers pay more for the same goods. The transit system's legitimate reputation masks the operation.
turns.choice_a: Trace the merchant Broll identifies — they are the operation's architect
turns.consequence_a: The merchant is Gos, a licensed goods trader who appears in two previous investigation threads as a peripheral figure. His licence network is extensive.
turns.choice_b: Document Broll's account fully and immediately in front of a Ward legal officer to create protected testimony
turns.consequence_b: Broll's account is formally protected. He becomes the prosecution's key witness.

turns.narrative: Gos runs fourteen licensed goods licences across the Market Ward and Upper Transit Corridor. His operation is technically sophisticated: he maintains perfect compliance with licensed goods categories while diverting approximately 20% of each consignment through Broll's Waypoint 4 swap. The 20% is sold to unlicensed Lower Ward buyers at premium pricing through a network of three intermediary collectors. The goods are not counterfeit — they are genuine licensed goods being sold outside the supply chain at exploitative prices.
turns.choice_a: Target Gos's goods network directly — audit all fourteen licences simultaneously
turns.consequence_a: A coordinated single-day audit of all fourteen licences finds systematic discrepancies. Gos has been running the diversion across all active lines simultaneously.
turns.choice_b: Use Broll's cooperation to arrange a monitored delivery swap that Gos authorises — catching him directing the fraud directly
turns.consequence_b: Gos authorises the swap via written instruction to Broll. He has convicted himself.

turns.narrative: The three Lower Ward intermediary collectors — the people who purchased and distributed the diverted goods — present a moral complexity: they have been providing their communities with goods that the official supply chain failed to deliver reliably. They paid premiums but the goods genuinely arrived. Their communities are angry that the supply chain was being exploited, but some residents note that the intermediaries were the only reliable source of certain medical supplies during three months of official supply disruption.
turns.choice_a: Recommend the collectors receive leniency — they were exploited by Gos more than they were exploiters themselves
turns.consequence_a: The Ward Authority agrees to prioritise Gos's prosecution with the collectors receiving conditional warnings and mandatory registration.
turns.choice_b: Recommend full prosecution of the complete chain — the collectors knowingly participated in unlicensed goods distribution
turns.consequence_b: All parties are prosecuted. Several Lesser Ward residents object vigorously in public.

turns.narrative: Gos's legal team argues that the supply chain discrepancy is a market failure problem — and that his 'alternative distribution system' was filling a genuine gap. This argument has some legitimacy: the Lower Ward supply chain has documented reliability problems. This creates a perverse situation where the perpetrator's defence illuminates a real governance failure. Renia, in her observer capacity at the proceedings, stands and says: 'He exploited a broken system. That doesn't make it his broken system to profit from.'
turns.choice_a: Use the Gos proceedings to also launch a formal supply chain reliability inquiry into the Transit Corridor
turns.consequence_a: The inquiry runs parallel to the prosecution. Transit Coordinator Helv is deposed. Three systemic failures are identified and funded for repair.
turns.choice_b: Keep the prosecution focused and handle the supply chain issues through separate channels
turns.consequence_b: The prosecution proceeds cleanly. The supply chain inquiry is launched separately by Renia's community group.

turns.narrative: Gos is convicted. Broll receives a suspended sentence and mandatory retraining. The four-minute supervision gap at Waypoint 4 is closed through a new monitoring protocol. The Lower Ward supply chain's documented reliability problems receive a Ward Authority remediation budget. Three of the fourteen licences Gos held are reassigned to legitimate operators. But the intermediary collector communities still need reliable supply — and the transition from Gos's informal system back to official channels takes planning.
turns.choice_a: Work with Renia to design a community-managed cooperative supply distribution network for the affected Lower Ward blocks
turns.consequence_a: A cooperative is constituted with fifteen founding households. Helv provides Transit Corridor priority access for community cooperatives.
turns.choice_b: Recommend the Ward Authority designate the Lower Ward a priority supply zone with enhanced monitoring
turns.consequence_b: Priority designation is granted. Transit manifests for the Lower Ward blocks are reviewed daily for ninety days.

turns.narrative: The Transit Corridor's monitoring improvement reveals three additional minor diversion operations at other waypoints — smaller than Gos's but using similar methods. They appear to be independent operators who learned the technique from observing Gos's operation rather than being part of his network.
turns.choice_a: Address all three simultaneously with coordinated enforcement
turns.consequence_a: All three are shut down in a single coordinated operation. Combined, they were diverting approximately 800 gold of goods monthly.
turns.choice_b: Address them sequentially and use each takedown to gather intelligence on how the technique spread
turns.consequence_b: The sequential approach reveals that Gos was not the originator — the technique was described in an unlicensed trade document circulating in Market Ward back-of-house distributor networks.

turns.narrative: A Transit Corridor infrastructure review prompted by the investigation reveals a physical problem: Waypoint 6's cargo floor has a structural weakness that has been creating a natural shadow — a blind spot in the waypoint's layout that makes unsupervised cargo access possible without any deliberate evasion. This is a design flaw, not human error, and it exists at two other waypoints. Physical remediation is needed.
turns.choice_a: Commission immediate physical remediation of all three flawed waypoints
turns.consequence_a: Structural improvements are completed over three weeks. Future diversion attempts become significantly harder.
turns.choice_b: Install enhanced lighting and monitoring while scheduling remediation for the next maintenance cycle
turns.consequence_b: Interim monitoring covers the vulnerability adequately. Full remediation is funded for the following quarter.

turns.narrative: The cooperative supply network Renia helped build (or the priority designation) is showing early results: Lower Ward residents in the affected blocks are receiving goods on schedule for the first time in three years. Three community leaders write a joint commendation letter. But one of the former Gos intermediary collectors writes to you directly — asking if there is any legitimate route for a community-managed goods importing operation that would eliminate the vulnerability to future exploitation entirely.
turns.choice_a: Help the former intermediary apply for a legitimate community goods cooperative licence
turns.consequence_a: The application is approved. A formerly-extralegal operator becomes a licensed cooperative leader. This is the best possible version of the outcome.
turns.choice_b: Refer them to Renia's cooperative structure — joining an existing institution is more stable than creating a new licence
turns.consequence_b: The intermediary joins Renia's cooperative as a senior distribution coordinator. Their network knowledge makes the cooperative immediately more effective.

turns.narrative: Helv has used the investigation's outcomes to pilot a new Transit Corridor transparency programme: all cargo manifests are publicly logged in real-time at each waypoint, accessible to the originating supplier and receiving party. The system eliminates paper-based gaps entirely. The Ward Trade Authority endorses it. Gos's lawyer, in an unfortunate comment to a journalist, describes it as 'the most effective anti-corruption measure since the Ward Guard was formed.' Gos, in custody, is apparently furious. [FINAL ENCOUNTER — ceremonial handover of the new system and community response]
turns.choice_a: Attend the Transit Corridor transparency programme launch and publicly support Helv's work
turns.consequence_a: Your presence at the launch gives the programme public credibility across the Market Ward and Lower Ward communities.
turns.choice_b: Let the programme launch be entirely Helv and the Transit Authority's moment
turns.consequence_b: Helv's leadership of the programme is unambiguously their own achievement. Appropriate credit goes to appropriate people.

turns.narrative: The investigation has had effects beyond its immediate scope: the Transit Corridor monitoring improvements, the community cooperative network, and the supply chain reliability programme together represent a fundamental change in how goods flow between the Market Ward and Lower Ward. Three community leaders who filed the original complaints send a joint message: 'Not exactly what we asked for. Far better than what we asked for.'
turns.choice_a: Document the full investigation as a model for cross-district supply chain enforcement
turns.consequence_a: Astrid uses the case as the basis for a Ward enforcement training module.
turns.choice_b: Close the case file and move on — the system is better. That was the goal.
turns.consequence_b: The file is closed. The improvements run themselves.

turns.narrative: At Waypoint 4 — where the four-minute supervision gap enabled three years of systematic diversion — a monitoring station now shows real-time cargo data accessible to all parties. The physical renovation has removed the blind spots. Broll, in his retraining programme, will become a cargo fraud detection consultant for the Transit Authority. The Lower Ward cooperative receives its first full consignment of properly licensed and correctly priced medical supplies. Nobody made a speech. The goods simply arrived on time, in full, at the right price, as they always should have.
turns.choice_a: Take quiet satisfaction in a system improved through careful, unglamorous work
turns.consequence_a: An appropriate response to an appropriate outcome. The next problem is already waiting somewhere in the city.
turns.choice_b: Formally propose a cross-district supply chain charter to codify these improvements in Ward law
turns.consequence_b: The charter is drafted by Renia's office and submitted to the Ward Council. It passes in the next session.

full_cooperative.description: Gos convicted. Cooperative supply network running. Transit transparency programme launched.

priority_designation.description: Gos convicted. Priority supply designation granted. Transit improvements implemented.

risk_matrix.critical_failure: Broll recants testimony. Gos walks free. The diversion network restructures.

conclusion: Gos convicted. Cooperative supply network running. Transit transparency programme launched.

title: The Refugee Crisis
location: Agricultural Zone -> Lower Ward -> Service District
description: Three settlements in the Agricultural Zone's outer ring have been abandoned following a Scourge Fringe boundary expansion — the Fringe moved forty metres in a single week, consuming fields, outbuildings, and two hamlets that did not evacuate in time. Approximately 340 residents are now displaced, many arriving at the Lower Ward's entry points with only what they could carry. Ward emergency systems are not designed for this scale of sudden displacement. The Ward Council has declared a temporary emergency but has no coherent plan. You are asked to coordinate the immediate response across three districts.

turns.narrative: 340 people are moving through the Lower Ward's southern gate in clusters, carrying children and tool kits and seeds saved from their fields. Community Leader Maren — a weathered woman in her fifties — is organising her community with impressive calm. She has a list of names, a medical needs summary, and a housing requirement projection. She has done crisis management before. What she needs now is a system that can receive her community and someone with Ward access to open the right doors.
turns.choice_a: Work with Maren directly to organise the immediate intake and establish triage priorities
turns.consequence_a: Together you establish three intake points staffed by community volunteers. Medical needs are identified within three hours. Emergency accommodation requests are logged with specifics.
turns.choice_b: Go immediately to Councillor Dain and the Ward emergency system to unlock official resources before the community fully arrives
turns.consequence_b: Dain authorises emergency use of the Service District Resource House plus three unused Ward buildings within ninety minutes. Resources are available before most of the community arrives.

turns.narrative: The immediate housing crisis is addressable — empty Ward buildings exist. The harder problem is emerging: 340 people who survived by farming cannot afford indefinite Ward housing on emergency stipends. Within two weeks they will need either return options (the Fringe has moved — there are none) or pathway to productive employment or resettlement that reestablishes self-sufficiency rather than charity dependency.
turns.choice_a: Begin mapping the community's skills against existing city-wide vacancies and labour needs
turns.consequence_a: The community contains twenty-two skilled farmers, fourteen craftspeople, eight teachers, two healers, and specialist knowledge in water management and seed genetics. The city needs all of these.
turns.choice_b: Coordinate with Agronomist Liss to determine if any Agricultural Zone land — further from the Fringe expansion boundary — can be made available for resettlement
turns.consequence_b: Liss identifies two potential resettlement zones in the Agricultural Zone's northwest section, currently fallow due to owner departure. Liss is willing to manage the interim licencing.

turns.narrative: The skills mapping or resettlement land assessment produces several immediate opportunities. But the community itself has a strong voice. Maren convenes her people in the Service District Resource House courtyard and asks what they want. The answer is complex: some want to return to farming as soon as land is available; some want to use displacement as a forced opportunity to access urban trades they couldn't learn in the outer settlements; some — especially older residents — want nothing more than a house near their former home and to not have to change everything they know.
turns.choice_a: Design a tiered response: resettlement land for farming families, urban integration pathways for trade-seekers, protected housing priority for elder residents
turns.consequence_a: Maren endorses the tiered approach immediately. Implementation requires three separate institutional connections but Maren helps manage each one directly.
turns.choice_b: Let the community self-organise its preferences and focus on removing institutional barriers to whichever options people choose
turns.consequence_b: Self-organisation works remarkably well. Maren delegates to sub-leaders for each group's needs. Your role becomes removing specific blockers as they appear.

turns.narrative: The Ward's bureaucratic systems are not built for rapid integration at this scale. Three specific blockers emerge: first, Ward residency permits require a three-month waiting period before unlocking full service access; second, agricultural land transfers require a formal licence hearing that takes six weeks; third, urban trade apprenticeships require existing guild membership that new entrants cannot easily obtain. You must systematically address each blocker.
turns.choice_a: Petition the Ward Council for an emergency residency waiver for all 340 displaced residents
turns.consequence_a: Councillor Dain supports the petition. After three days of debate, an emergency waiver is granted — three-month wait waived for Fringe-displacement events.
turns.choice_b: Work around each blocker individually using existing emergency provision clauses that apply in Fringe-expansion events
turns.consequence_b: Emergency provision clauses exist for each blocker but have never been invoked simultaneously. Each requires separate authorisation from three different ward officials.

turns.narrative: The immediate bureaucratic barriers are resolved — through the Council waiver or emergency provisions. Sixty farming families are licensed for the northwest Agricultural Zone resettlement. Forty trade-seekers are connected with Labour Advocate Renia, who coordinates apprenticeship placements through the Baker's Council (if formed) and the Foundry Settlement agreement's worker-access provisions. Forty elder residents are placed in priority Service District housing blocks. The remaining 200 are in mixed integration pathways.
turns.choice_a: Focus specifically on the 200 in mixed pathways — they are the most vulnerable to falling through gaps
turns.consequence_a: A tracking system is established for the 200, with weekly check-ins and specific case workers assigned. Three acute crisis cases are identified early and receive targeted support.
turns.choice_b: Focus on the sixty farming families in the northwest resettlement — establishing a functional farming operation quickly will create stability and produce food the city genuinely needs
turns.consequence_b: The northwest settlement is producing food within six weeks. Their produce enters the cooperative supply network (if established in EH_SQ_530) at fair pricing.

turns.narrative: A political complication arrives. Ward residents in the Lower Ward's south section — which has been absorbing most of the displaced community's temporary presence — formally petition Councillor Dain about 'resource competition' from the new arrivals. The petition is not overtly hostile but it expresses genuine concerns about access to shared ward services. Dain asks you to mediate a ward community forum before the petition generates political momentum that could undermine the emergency response.
turns.choice_a: Organise a joint forum between long-term Lower Ward residents and displaced community members
turns.consequence_a: The forum is initially tense. Two displaced community members speak about what they lost. Three Lower Ward residents speak about their service access concerns. By the end, both groups are negotiating rather than complaining.
turns.choice_b: Address the specific service access concerns directly by increasing emergency Ward service capacity in the south section
turns.consequence_b: Additional capacity in three shared facilities is approved and operational within a week. The service competition concern is resolved practically rather than politically.

turns.narrative: Maren approaches you with a request that goes beyond immediate crisis management: she says displaced agricultural communities are a recurring Scourge Fringe problem — three times in ten years. Each time, the Ward has no system and improvises. She wants to work with you to design a permanent Fringe-Displacement Protocol that provides both early warning and structured response for future expansion events.
turns.choice_a: Support Maren's protocol proposal and help design it formally
turns.consequence_a: A joint Agricultural Zone / Ward Authority / Medical Quarter protocol is designed over four weeks. It includes trigger criteria, resource pre-positioning, and community-led intake management.
turns.choice_b: Recommend Maren lead the protocol design independently with institutional support — she is more qualified than anyone to design it
turns.consequence_b: Maren chairs the design process. The resulting protocol reflects deep community experience rather than institutional assumptions.

turns.narrative: Engineer Pyra's atmospheric sensors have been tracking the Fringe boundary expansion. She delivers a significant finding: the expansion was not a sudden geological event. It was gradual — her three-year sensor archive shows the boundary moving incrementally for eighteen months before the forty-metre lurch that displaced the settlements. Earlier warning would have allowed orderly managed evacuation rather than emergency displacement. The monitoring system existed. No one was watching its Fringe boundary output.
turns.choice_a: Recommend integrating Pyra's sensor data into an automated Fringe-movement early warning system
turns.consequence_a: A City Fringe Monitoring System is established using Pyra's sensor network and the Ridge communication station's signal capacity. Any boundary movement above a threshold triggers an automatic community alert.
turns.choice_b: Document the monitoring failure and recommend a formal inquiry into why the sensor data was not being reviewed
turns.consequence_b: The inquiry finds a documentation hand-off failure between two Ward Authority departments. Administrative responsibility is clarified. Review protocols are updated.

turns.narrative: Sixty farming families have begun planting in the northwest Agricultural Zone. The first community meeting of new and existing Agricultural Zone residents is held. Liss chairs it. It is awkward and productive in equal measure: the displaced farmers bring seed genetics the existing zone has never had access to, and the zone's existing infrastructure provides the drainage and irrigation systems the displaced community never had. There is genuine mutual benefit here waiting to emerge.
turns.choice_a: Facilitate a formal knowledge-sharing programme between the established and newly settled farming communities
turns.consequence_a: A monthly cross-settlement farming forum is established. Within two growing seasons, the northwest settlement is farming more efficiently than any existing zone section.
turns.choice_b: Let the communities find their own relationship without formal structure
turns.consequence_b: An informal apprenticeship culture develops naturally. Experienced zone farmers take on northwest settlement apprentices. No formal structure needed.

turns.narrative: The forty elder residents in Service District priority housing are struggling with social isolation. They are physically housed and financially supported but cut off from the community rhythms they built over decades. Their former neighbours are scattered across three districts. Pross's Community Hall grief programme offers one avenue, but the specific need is community reconnection rather than grief processing.
turns.choice_a: Help establish a regular social programme specifically for elder displaced residents at the Service District Resource House
turns.consequence_a: A weekly gathering is established. Within a month, several elder residents are actively mentoring younger displaced community members in traditional agricultural crafts.
turns.choice_b: Connect the elder residents with the Memory Keeper Archive project — their knowledge of the outer settlements' history is irreplaceable
turns.consequence_b: Archive Researcher Winn conducts formal oral history sessions with eleven elder residents. Their accounts of the outer settlements and the Fringe boundary over decades become a significant historical record.

turns.narrative: Maren's Fringe-Displacement Protocol is completed and presented to the Ward Council. It is the most comprehensive emergency response framework the Ward has ever seen — built from lived experience rather than bureaucratic theory. Councillor Dain endorses it publicly. Ward Warden Astrid calls it 'the most useful document produced this year.' Maren receives a formal Ward Civic Recognition — the equivalent of the Council's highest civilian honour. At the ceremony, she says: 'We didn't want recognition. We wanted a home. We found ways to make several.'
turns.choice_a: Attend the ceremony and publicly acknowledge Maren's community's journey
turns.consequence_a: Your attendance visibly means something to Maren's community. Several people find you afterward to say thank you personally.
turns.choice_b: Send formal congratulations and remain at the northwest settlement helping with the spring planting
turns.consequence_b: The planting is more important today than the ceremony. Maren sends a note later: 'Good call.'

turns.narrative: The northwest settlement is planted. The elder residents have weekly community rhythms. The trade apprentices are six weeks into their programmes. The farming families produced their first Market Ward sale — thirty bushels of seed wheat at fair cooperative pricing. 340 people who arrived through the Lower Ward's southern gate with only what they could carry have become a contributing part of the city's fabric in four months. None of it was easy. Most of it was unglamorous. All of it mattered. Maren will chair the Fringe-Displacement Protocol Committee for five years. The next expansion event will be managed rather than suffered. That is the whole point.
turns.choice_a: Formally maintain your involvement with the northwest settlement as an ongoing adviser
turns.consequence_a: Maren makes you an Honorary Agricultural Zone Community Liaison. Future agricultural events may connect through this relationship.
turns.choice_b: Consider the crisis complete and step back — the community has everything it needs to continue without you
turns.consequence_b: Maren walks with you to the settlement boundary. 'Come back for harvest,' she says. You probably will.

protocol_designed.description: 340 residents integrated. Fringe-Displacement Protocol established. Early warning system live.

community_settled.description: 340 residents integrated across three districts. Northwest settlement productive. Elder archive completed.

risk_matrix.critical_failure: Political backlash prevents proper integration. 80 displaced residents remain in limbo for over a year.

conclusion: 340 residents integrated. Fringe-Displacement Protocol established. Early warning system live.

title: The Transit Strike
description: Transit Corridor workers have gone on strike after fifteen years without a formal pay review. The Corridor's 340 workers manage every cargo and passenger movement between six districts — without them, supply chains stop, worker transport to the Foundry and Industrial Quarter ceases, medical supply deliveries fail, and the Agricultural Zone's perishables cannot reach the Market Ward. The Ward Council has called the strike 'illegal under emergency provision law.' Labour Advocate Renia calls that characterisation 'a deliberate misreading of statute.' The city is holding its breath. The strike is already in its second day.

turns.narrative: Transit Strike Leader Forris explains the situation in precise terms: the Corridor's workers have not received a pay review since the Scourge emergency provisions were first applied fifteen years ago. Every review request has been deferred under the same emergency clause. The clause — designed for temporary crisis — has been applied continuously for a decade and a half. The workers' base wages are now significantly below every comparable Ward labour category. 'We waited,' Forris says. 'We filed. We petitioned. We're done waiting.' He shows you a two-centimetre-thick folder of denied review requests.
turns.choice_a: Position yourself as a neutral mediator between the workers and the Ward Authority
turns.consequence_a: Both Forris and Councillor Dain accept. A mediation session is scheduled for tomorrow — but the city has 24 hours before supply chain disruption becomes critical.
turns.choice_b: Immediately assess whether the emergency provision's application to Transit workers is legally sound
turns.consequence_b: A Ward legal reviewer finds the 15-year continuous application deeply questionable. The emergency provision permits 12-month renewable deferrals but requires evidence of genuine emergency to renew — evidence never formally provided.

turns.narrative: Foundry Director Vane contacts you in the first twelve hours. The Foundry depends on Transit Corridor for 60% of its raw material deliveries. Day three of the strike will begin to affect production. Vane is not hostile to the workers — she has publicly supported previous labour rights measures — but she needs resolution. She offers to publicly support an immediate provisional pay increase from Foundry operating funds if it helps break the deadlock, noting that the Foundry has a direct stake in Transit Corridor workers being fairly compensated.
turns.choice_a: Bring Vane's offer to the negotiating table immediately as external financial evidence
turns.consequence_a: Vane's public statement changes the dynamic immediately. Dain's position — that a pay review is unaffordable — is undercut by a major city institution offering to contribute.
turns.choice_b: Use Vane's offer to privately pressure Dain into accepting a provisional increase before the mediation session
turns.consequence_b: Dain privately acknowledges the political reality has shifted. He agrees to a provisional increase in principle before the public session begins.

turns.narrative: The mediation session convenes with Forris, Helv, Dain, Renia, and Vane's representative at the table. The legal review of the emergency provision is in your hands. If you present it now, the Ward Council's position collapses — but Dain may become hostile and the political resolution becomes confrontational. If you hold it in reserve, you preserve goodwill but accept a slower process.
turns.choice_a: Present the legal review finding at the session — the workers' right to a pay review cannot be legally denied
turns.consequence_a: The session's atmosphere shifts dramatically. Forris is quietly triumphant. Dain's legal adviser urgently confers with him. The provision argument is effectively abandoned.
turns.choice_b: Hold the legal review in reserve and pursue a negotiated resolution without deploying it
turns.consequence_b: Negotiation proceeds on economic grounds. It is slower but generates more genuine buy-in from Dain's side.

turns.narrative: The medical supply situation is becoming critical by day three. The Medical Quarter's Dr. Vel contacts you: perishable medicines and blood products cannot be stored indefinitely. If transit does not resume for medical cargo within twelve hours, two critical care patients at the Medical Quarter will be at risk. This is not manipulative framing — Vel is clinically precise. Strike Leader Forris, when told, immediately designates medical cargo as a humanitarian exemption subject to voluntary Transit worker coverage.
turns.choice_a: Formalise the humanitarian exemption with full worker support — it shows the strike is principled, not punitive
turns.consequence_a: Forris and twelve volunteers work the medical cargo overnight. Vel's critical cases are secured. The act of good faith significantly changes public opinion of the strike.
turns.choice_b: Use the medical situation to pressure accelerated resolution of the full strike rather than setting a precedent of partial work
turns.consequence_b: The pressure accelerates the negotiation timeline significantly. A provisional settlement is reached within six hours — faster than any other scenario.

turns.narrative: A provisional settlement framework is emerging: a 22% pay increase for all 340 Transit workers, retroactive partial payment for the fifteen years of undercompensated service, and a formal annual review mechanism with independent arbitration. The retroactive payment — modest but significant — is the sticking point. Dain is willing to fund the prospective increase from Ward operating budget but argues the retroactive element requires Council approval he cannot guarantee.
turns.choice_a: Propose a structured retroactive payment over four years rather than a lump sum
turns.consequence_a: The four-year structure makes the retroactive component financially manageable for the Ward and acceptable to Forris's team.
turns.choice_b: Identify external funding for the retroactive element — Vane's Foundry contribution plus other major Transit users could cover it
turns.consequence_b: Three major Transit users — the Foundry, the Medical Quarter supply operation, and the Merchant Guild cooperative — contribute collectively. The retroactive amount is funded externally.

turns.narrative: The settlement is signed on day four of the strike. Transit workers return to work. The Corridor is operational within six hours of signing. Cargo begins moving. The Foundry's delayed material deliveries arrive in a rush. Agricultural Zone perishables reach the Market Ward markets slightly late but intact. The city's supply chains normalise within 24 hours. Forris shakes hands with Helv. Both of them appear exhausted and cautiously relieved. Renia is already drafting a broader Ward Labour Review proposal based on the Transit case.
turns.choice_a: Support Renia's broader Ward Labour Review proposal — the Transit case has demonstrated the problem is systemic
turns.consequence_a: Renia's proposal, with your backing, goes to the Ward Council within two weeks. Three other Ward worker categories are flagged for immediate review.
turns.choice_b: Let Renia lead the broader review independently — the Transit case should stand as its own achievement first
turns.consequence_b: Renia proceeds with full independent authority. The Transit case is cited as precedent in every labour review that follows.

turns.narrative: The independent arbitration mechanism established in the settlement includes a requirement: an annual public report on Transit Corridor worker compensation relative to comparable Ward labour categories. Helv has been asked to produce this report. She asks your help with the first edition — it will set the format and depth for all future reports and she wants to get it right.
turns.choice_a: Help Helv design a comprehensive report format with full labour market comparison data
turns.consequence_a: The first annual report is a model of transparency. It is adopted as standard by two other Ward worker bodies.
turns.choice_b: Advise Helv on the key data points and let her design the format herself
turns.consequence_b: Helv's format is excellent — she knows her data better than anyone. Your advice was useful framing, not direction.

turns.narrative: A specific Corridor worker comes forward in the post-settlement period. A night-shift loader named Sev who was central to the strike organisation has been identified by his Ward employer as a 'labour agitator' and had his supplemental housing benefit revoked. The revocation appears targeted and retaliatory — a benefit that twelve other workers of identical status retain. Renia flags this as protected activity retaliation.
turns.choice_a: File a formal retaliation complaint on Sev's behalf through the new arbitration mechanism
turns.consequence_a: The first use of the arbitration mechanism is successful. Sev's benefit is restored and the targeting employer receives a formal warning.
turns.choice_b: Investigate whether the revocation was individually targeted or part of a broader pattern of post-strike retaliation
turns.consequence_b: Three other workers show similar post-strike benefit changes. A broader retaliation pattern is documented and formally adjudicated.

turns.narrative: The Transit Strike and its resolution has made the Corridor the most professionally organised worker cohort in the city. Other worker categories are watching. The Foundry's internal worker committee formally proposes a voluntary Foundry pay review to pre-empt a similar situation. Vane endorses it immediately. The Ward is incrementally becoming a place where labour relations are managed rather than deferred until crisis.
turns.choice_a: Help the Foundry's worker committee model their review on the Transit arbitration framework
turns.consequence_a: The Foundry review follows similar principles. It completes in six weeks with a 15% increase and a five-year review cycle.
turns.choice_b: Let the Foundry and its workers handle their review independently — the Transit case established the model, it doesn't need your involvement to replicate
turns.consequence_b: Independent replication is healthier than dependent replication. The Foundry committee reaches a settlement that is slightly better than the Transit outcome.

turns.narrative: The Ward Council's emergency provision clause — the same clause applied to Transit workers for fifteen years — is now formally under review by the Council's legal committee. Three other worker categories are actively citing Transit as precedent in their own review petitions. Dain, in a session that might be called reflective, says: 'We shouldn't have needed a four-day strike to act on a fifteen-year petition.' He moves to establish a formal emergency provision sunset mechanism — any emergency provision application requires annual active evidence and lapses automatically after five years without Council renewal vote.
turns.choice_a: Support the sunset mechanism proposal publicly
turns.consequence_a: The proposal passes. Ward emergency provisions are fundamentally reformed.
turns.choice_b: Suggest the sunset should be three years rather than five — five years is still too long for a measure described as 'emergency'
turns.consequence_b: Dain accepts the three-year amendment. The final mechanism is more protective than originally proposed.

turns.narrative: Forris has been elected to the Transit Workers' Collective — the first formally constituted worker body in the Transit Corridor's history under the settlement's governance provisions. He contacts you to say: 'We're doing our first formal meeting next week. We'd like you to chair the inaugural session as an independent neutral. Just for the founding session.' It is an unusual thing to be asked. It is a significant honour in the community's terms.
turns.choice_a: Accept — chair the inaugural session of the Transit Workers' Collective
turns.consequence_a: The session is brief and efficient. Forris thanks you formally. You are listed as first chair in the Collective's founding record.
turns.choice_b: Decline graciously — the Collective's first chair should be a worker or Renia
turns.consequence_b: Renia chairs the inaugural session. She is better suited — it becomes her institutional connection to the Collective.

turns.narrative: Fourteen days after the strike began, the Transit Corridor is running at full capacity with workers earning fair wages under a transparent review mechanism protected by independent arbitration. Forty-eight hours of full-capacity disruption were sufficient to achieve fifteen years of deferred justice. The city's supply chains are reliable. The emergency provision clause is reformed. Three other worker categories are mid-review. The Transit Strike will be cited for years — as an example of what happens when bureaucratic deferral mistakes patience for permanent acceptance.
turns.choice_a: Document the Transit Strike as a formal case study in Ward labour relations
turns.consequence_a: The case study is published by the Ward Authority as reference material for future labour negotiations.
turns.choice_b: Let the outcome speak for itself — the changed reality is the case study
turns.consequence_b: Forris says this. He says it at the Collective's second meeting. Renia writes it down.

settlement_negotiated.description: Strike resolved day 4. Full settlement with retroactive pay. Labour review mechanism established.

settlement_legal.description: Emergency provision declared invalid. Immediate settlement forced. Review mechanism established.

risk_matrix.critical_failure: Strike continues for seven days. Medical Quarter loses one patient. Foundry backs down from endorsement.

conclusion: Strike resolved day 4. Full settlement with retroactive pay. Labour review mechanism established.

title: The Temple Schism
location: Temple District -> High Ward -> Lower Ward
description: The Temple District's religious community has fractured. A doctrinal dispute — seemingly academic — has escalated into a genuine schism between the Orthodox Concordat-Remnant faction and the Reformation Faction, who believe the Scourge revealed that the old Concordat theology was incomplete. The dispute has three flashpoints: the city's memorial prayer schedule, access to the Archive of Lost Voices, and the legitimacy of the Violet Shepherd's congregation. What began as theological argument is now affecting district politics, community cohesion, and — most urgently — a dispute over which faction controls the largest food distribution charity in the Temple District.

turns.narrative: Warden Gais presents you with a situation summary that she describes as 'a fire I do not want to breathe on.' The orthodox faction, led by Elder Noss, has formally contested the Reformation faction's management of the Temple District Relief Charity — the body that distributes food and medicine to 800 low-income Temple and Lower Ward residents each week. Noss argues that the Reformation faction's doctrinal heterodoxy disqualifies them from managing a Concordat-heritage charitable institution. Sister Vael argues that Noss is using theological grounds to execute a resource-control grab disguised as principle.
turns.choice_a: Request a joint meeting with Noss and Vael before doing anything else
turns.consequence_a: Both agree — cautiously. In the same room, the mutual resentment is palpable but both are clearly intelligent, serious people with genuine beliefs.
turns.choice_b: Review the Relief Charity's governing documents first to understand the legal question before the theological one
turns.consequence_b: The Charity's founding documents, written forty years ago, specify that management must hold 'Concordat-aligned faith' — a phrase never formally defined. The ambiguity is the legal engine of the dispute.

turns.narrative: Sister Vael's Reformation theology is not radical — it argues that the Scourge was a consequence of the Concordat's institutional failures, that the city survived because community resilience rather than institutional faith sustained people, and that any post-Scourge theology must centre community experience alongside doctrinal heritage. Elder Noss's orthodox position is that the Concordat's doctrines are a recorded inheritance from people wiser than current survivors, and that the Reformation faction's experiential theology is individualism disguised as revelation. Both positions are sincere. Both have genuine merit.
turns.choice_a: Engage both leaders in separate deep conversations about their actual theological concerns
turns.consequence_a: Noss reveals that his deepest concern is continuity — fear that abandoning Concordat doctrine abandons the people who built it and died maintaining it. Vael reveals hers is authenticity — people who survived the Scourge cannot be asked to follow theology that didn't acknowledge it.
turns.choice_b: Focus pragmatically on the Charity governance question and keep theological arguments out of the mediation
turns.consequence_b: Both agree to separate the Charity governance from the theological dispute. A joint management committee is proposed as a temporary measure.

turns.narrative: Archive Keeper Winn enters the dispute with an unexpected contribution. The Archive of Lost Voices contains pre-Scourge Concordat documents that neither faction has fully reviewed. Winn believes one of them — a document from the Concordat's own internal theological review committee, written three years before the Scourge — contains language directly relevant to the question of doctrinal evolution. Winn has not publicised this because both factions have been too adversarial to receive information objectively.
turns.choice_a: Work with Winn to bring the document forward in a controlled way that both factions can engage with
turns.consequence_a: Winn presents the document at a joint session. It is a Concordat theological committee paper acknowledging that 'Concordat doctrine must evolve with lived experience or it becomes monument rather than living faith.' Written by a Concordat senior elder three years before the Scourge.
turns.choice_b: Review the document privately first and decide how to deploy its content strategically
turns.consequence_b: The document is extraordinary: it is essentially the Reformation theology, written by an orthodox Concordat authority. Strategic deployment at the right moment could end the dispute entirely.

turns.narrative: The Violet Shepherd's congregation has become a specific flashpoint. Noss formally petitions Warden Gais to revoke the congregation's registered status on the grounds that it practices Void-adjacent sacrament, which he argues is incompatible with any Concordat-heritage designation. Vael publicly defends the congregation. Warden Gais, caught in the middle, asks for your assessment — she will act on your recommendation.
turns.choice_a: Recommend maintaining the congregation's status — its harm reduction record and Medical Quarter oversight justify it
turns.consequence_a: Gais issues a formal finding maintaining the congregation's registered status. The Shepherd Cord publicly thanks both Vael's faction and the investigative process.
turns.choice_b: Recommend renegotiating the congregation's designation to remove the Concordat-heritage framing, reducing the theological flashpoint
turns.consequence_b: The congregation is redesignated as a 'Registered Community Therapeutic Practice' — removing it from the theological contest entirely while preserving its operational status.

turns.narrative: The Relief Charity's management dispute has created a one-week paralysis in food distribution. 800 residents are receiving reduced service. Three charitable volunteers have quit in frustration at being caught between the factions. A group of long-term charity volunteers — independent of both factions — have asked to meet you. They propose that an independent charter governing the Charity, with elected volunteers as the management body rather than faction appointment, would remove the charity from doctrinal politics entirely.
turns.choice_a: Support the independent volunteer charter proposal and help the volunteers draft it
turns.consequence_a: A Charity Governance Reform package is drafted in four days. Noss objects. Vael supports. Gais endorses. The Ward Council approves independent governance.
turns.choice_b: Negotiate a power-sharing arrangement between the two factions instead of governance reform
turns.consequence_b: A three-year power-sharing arrangement is agreed with a formal sunset review. Not ideal but immediately operational.

turns.narrative: The Concordat theological committee document, when presented or deployed strategically, transforms the debate. Elder Noss reads it three times in silence. He then asks Winn for the document's provenance details — the specific author's identity, their role, their death record from the Scourge. When confirmed, he says: 'If Elder Carras wrote this with his authority, I cannot in good conscience dismiss it as heterodoxy.' The theological underpinning of his opposition to the Reformation faction has been removed by an authority he respects.
turns.choice_a: Facilitate a joint theological reading session between Noss and Vael using the document as a starting point
turns.consequence_a: The session lasts four hours. When it ends, Noss and Vael have not resolved all differences, but they have found a shared foundation they did not previously know existed.
turns.choice_b: Let Noss process the document privately — pushing for immediate reconciliation before he has absorbed it would be counterproductive
turns.consequence_b: Three days later, Noss requests a private meeting with Vael. Gais notes that what emerges from it is the beginning of a genuine theological dialogue rather than a debate.

turns.narrative: The Schism has defined the dispute as being about the memorial prayer schedule — who controls when and how the city's communal grief rituals are conducted. The orthodox faction controls the 6am prayers and the annual Scourge memorial. The Reformation faction has been conducting parallel community memorials in the Lower Ward with significantly higher attendance. The dispute is partly about doctrine, partly about who speaks for the city's collective experience of loss.
turns.choice_a: Propose a unified memorial framework with both factions co-officiating — shared ritual, different voices
turns.consequence_a: The proposal is radical enough that both factions need a week to consider it. Noss accepts first, to Vael's visible surprise. She accepts the next day.
turns.choice_b: Recommend the City Council formally designate the Scourge Memorial as a secular civic occasion with optional religious content from any registered faith body
turns.consequence_b: The secular designation removes the dispute trigger. Both factions can participate on equal footing. Neither controls the other's access.

turns.narrative: The combined effect of the Charity governance reform, the document's revelation, and the memorial approach has shifted the schism from active conflict to uncomfortable adjacency. Neither faction has dissolved. The theological differences are real and will persist. But the practical flashpoints have been resolved. Gais calls it 'the best outcome available.' Winn calls it 'a beginning.' Noss calls it 'a long conversation.' Vael says: 'At least we stopped fighting over the soup kitchen.'
turns.choice_a: Recommend a permanent inter-factional dialogue body — a formal space for theological exchange
turns.consequence_a: A Temple District Theological Dialogue Council is constituted with Winn as independent chair.
turns.choice_b: Recommend no formal structure — organic relationship development will be more authentic
turns.consequence_b: The informal relationship between Noss and Vael develops at its own pace. Two years later it produces an unexpected joint publication.

turns.narrative: Sister Vael announces a new project: a community-driven documentation of Scourge survival stories from every district, intended as a living body of testimony that complements the formal Archive. She calls it 'The Living Record' and is positioning it as the Reformation faction's contribution to shared heritage. Noss, to general surprise, offers to contribute orthodox community memories to the project.
turns.choice_a: Help facilitate 'The Living Record' as a cross-factional heritage project
turns.consequence_a: The Living Record becomes the Schism's most positive legacy — a documentation effort that involves both factions, Archive Keeper Winn, and community members from six districts.
turns.choice_b: Support the project by connecting Vael with appropriate institutions without direct involvement
turns.consequence_b: The Medical Quarter, Academic Quarter, and Ward Council each contribute resources. The project scales beyond what Vael initially imagined.

turns.narrative: The final unresolved flashpoint is the archive access dispute. Both factions want researchers aligned with their theology to have priority access to Concordat documents. Winn has managed this by simply refusing priority access to anyone — equal access for all, no priority designations. Both factions are unsatisfied. A practical resolution requires a formal access policy.
turns.choice_a: Help Winn design a formal Archive access policy with equal-access provisions and independent oversight
turns.consequence_a: A Policy Committee including one representative from each faction, Winn, and an independent academic is constituted. The access policy is produced within three weeks.
turns.choice_b: Recommend Winn's current ad hoc approach be formally codified as the access policy — it already works
turns.consequence_b: Winn's existing practice is formalised into an access charter. Simple, effective, already proven.

turns.narrative: The Living Record's first community session in the Lower Ward draws 140 attendees — an extraordinary number for a documentary heritage project. People who rarely engage with formal religious institutions come specifically because this is not that: it is a listening session for anyone who survived the Scourge to speak their experience. Sister Vael facilitates. Noss attends as an observer and, halfway through the session, is asked by a young man if he has a memory to share. He does. The room is quiet for seven minutes while he speaks about what he saw at the Scourge's first day.
turns.choice_a: Observe the session and record notes on what arises for the Archive
turns.consequence_a: Noss's account becomes one of the Archive's most significant oral history documents.
turns.choice_b: Let the session exist without official documentation — some moments are more whole if they just happened
turns.consequence_b: Winn respects the choice. The community remembers the session without it needing to be filed.

turns.narrative: The Temple Schism has not ended. Theological differences between the Orthodox and Reformation factions remain and will remain — they represent genuinely different responses to the same catastrophe. What has ended is the weaponisation of those differences against the city's shared institutions. The Relief Charity feeds 800 people weekly under independent governance. The Archive is accessible to all. The Living Record is growing. The congregation conducts its work without threat. In the Temple District's central plaza, a notice board has appeared that lists both factions' upcoming community events side by side. Nobody organised it. It just appeared.
turns.choice_a: Note the notice board to Gais as a genuinely positive sign
turns.consequence_a: Gais photographs it and puts the photograph in her office. 'This is what resolution looks like when nobody is looking.'
turns.choice_b: Leave it unacknowledged — it speaks for itself
turns.consequence_b: It does. That is enough.

schism_mediated.description: Charity reformed. Memorial unified. Living Record project launched. Theological dialogue ongoing.

schism_managed.description: Charity power-shared. Congregation redesignated. Access policy formalised.

consequences.item_reward: Temple District Relief Charity Independent Charter

risk_matrix.critical_failure: The Charity collapses. 800 residents receive no service for three weeks.

loot_table: Temple District Relief Charity Independent Charter
conclusion: Charity reformed. Memorial unified. Living Record project launched. Theological dialogue ongoing.

title: The Industrial Poison
location: Industrial Quarter -> Green Quarter -> Medical Quarter
description: Green Quarter biomonitors have detected an elevated concentration of industrial byproducts in the Quarter's soil and groundwater — compounds consistent with heavy Foundry smelting processes. Three Green Quarter community gardens are showing crop failure. Two children in the Lower Ward adjacency have presented at the Medical Quarter with symptoms consistent with heavy metal exposure. The Industrial Quarter's Foundry and three adjacent processing facilities were all recently upgraded, including the drainage modifications documented during the Foundry settlement. Someone's drainage work has gone wrong — or was never meant to go right.

turns.narrative: Biomonitor Sera's data is alarming but not yet conclusive about source. The compounds detected — primarily industrial smelting flux residue and heat-treatment cooling runoff — are consistent with four potential sources in the Industrial Quarter. Three are the newly upgraded processing facilities. One is the Foundry's drainage modification completed two months ago. The Green Quarter's affected zone downslope of all four sources tells you the contamination arrived via groundwater movement — but not which facility discharged it.
turns.choice_a: Commission immediate flow tracing from the Green Quarter contamination zone back to source
turns.consequence_a: Sera uses dye tracing in three groundwater channels. The primary contamination flow traces to discharge point 6 — a processing facility drain managed by Ott's company.
turns.choice_b: Collect soil and water samples from each of the four potential source facilities simultaneously
turns.consequence_b: Sample analysis takes 48 hours. Facility 3 — one of Ott's processing units — shows compound concentrations 400% above legal limits in its drainage output.

turns.narrative: Processing Manager Ott's facility is the primary source. Ott's initial response is denial: his drainage modification was approved by the Ward technical review team and he has documentation to prove compliance. He is partially correct — the modification was approved. But the approval was for a theoretical flow rate that turned out to be significantly exceeded when the facility ran at peak capacity. The drainage design was flawed: it worked at test output but fails under real operational load.
turns.choice_a: Focus on the immediate containment of the ongoing discharge rather than the blame question
turns.consequence_a: Ott is persuaded to immediately reduce facility output to below the design threshold. Discharge levels drop to legal limits within six hours. Contamination stops at source.
turns.choice_b: Determine whether the flawed approval was due to negligent review or deliberate under-reporting of anticipated output levels
turns.consequence_b: The Ward technical review records show the output level Ott's facility submitted was 40% below the actual expected operational output — a representation that made the drainage appear compliant when it was not.

turns.narrative: Two children's symptoms at the Medical Quarter drive urgency beyond the regulatory investigation. Dr. Vel has confirmed heavy metal exposure consistent with the detected compounds. She also identifies that eight adult Green Quarter residents have subclinical levels — below immediate crisis but requiring monitoring and intervention. The Green Quarter community is frightened and furious. Renia attends a community meeting that becomes extremely heated.
turns.choice_a: Attend the community meeting and take direct accountability for coordinating the response
turns.consequence_a: Your presence at the meeting — and direct, honest answers about what is known and what is being done — significantly reduces the anger. Three specific demands are made that are all reasonable.
turns.choice_b: Have Vane and Ott attend the community meeting to face their community directly
turns.consequence_b: Vane attends willingly and is received with mixed anger and respect. Ott sends a legal representative, which incenses the community further.

turns.narrative: The contamination's source is stopped. Now begins remediation: the three affected community gardens need soil assessment and potentially replacement. The groundwater pathway needs flushing. And ten affected individuals need ongoing Medical Quarter support. Remediation costs are significant. Ott argues his facility's design was approved and Ward liability shares the cost. Vane offers Foundry resources for remediation given the shared drainage infrastructure. The community wants Ott to shoulder the full cost.
turns.choice_a: Build a remediation framework that assigns costs proportional to demonstrable responsibility
turns.consequence_a: Legal assessment determines Ott bears 70% responsibility (output misrepresentation), Ward technical review bears 20% (inadequate verification), and a 10% is funded by Foundry community goodwill contribution.
turns.choice_b: Push for full Ott responsibility — the output misrepresentation was deliberate and the Ward should not absorb costs for industrial fraud
turns.consequence_b: A formal negligence proceeding determines Ott bears 85% responsibility. Ward review failure is documented but not financially assessed.

turns.narrative: Community garden remediation begins. Sera manages soil replacement at Garden 2 and 4 — the most affected. Garden 1 requires only flushing and recovery time. Sera's soil assessment reveals something not directly related to the contamination: Garden 3's adjacent plot has trace evidence of Pre-Scourge industrial use — an old manufacturing site that left residual compounds in the soil decades ago. This pre-existing contamination is below harmful levels but interacted with the new discharge to compound the effect.
turns.choice_a: Commission a full Green Quarter pre-existing soil contamination audit to identify any other historical sites
turns.consequence_a: Three additional pre-existing industrial sites are identified beneath different Green Quarter sections. None are currently harmful but all are documented for future monitoring.
turns.choice_b: Address the specific Pre-Scourge site as a contained historical remediation and move on
turns.consequence_b: The specific site is documented and flagged in the Archive. Winn is consulted about the manufacturing history.

turns.narrative: Dr. Vel's medical monitoring of the ten affected residents runs for three months. At the six-week mark, she reports that all ten are responding well to treatment and both children have fully cleared their elevated levels. The community relief is significant. But Vel notes that her monitoring also identified that two Green Quarter residents had pre-existing subclinical levels from chronic ambient industrial exposure — before this incident — suggesting a longer-term issue with the Industrial Quarter's proximity.
turns.choice_a: Request Sera initiate continuous ambient monitoring of the Industrial Quarter / Green Quarter boundary
turns.consequence_a: A permanent monitoring array is installed. Four boundary points receive continuous biomarker tracking feeding into Ward health data.
turns.choice_b: Recommend the Ward Council review the Industrial Quarter's proximity zoning relative to residential Green Quarter areas
turns.consequence_b: A zoning review is commissioned. It will take eighteen months to complete but begins the process of addressing a structural planning issue.

turns.narrative: Ott's processing facility is operating under a modified licence with strict discharge reporting requirements. But a Ward inspection finds that the drainage report for the first post-incident month was filed with figures that appear to have been rounded down. The difference is small. It may be computational error. It may be the beginning of a repeat pattern.
turns.choice_a: Treat it as potential fraud and escalate to a formal audit of all reporting
turns.consequence_a: A full historical audit finds three additional instances of under-reporting spanning eighteen months — none above crisis level but all systematically minimised. A pattern is established.
turns.choice_b: Issue a formal warning and require independent third-party discharge verification going forward
turns.consequence_b: Independent verification is implemented immediately. Ott's next three months of reports are accurate to four decimal places under independent audit.

turns.narrative: The Green Quarter community's three demands from the community meeting have been addressed: remediation funded, ongoing monitoring established, and Ott's facility under scrutiny. The fourth, unspoken demand — that this never happens again to anyone in the city — is harder. Vane proposes a city-wide Industrial Discharge Standards reform package, noting that current standards were written before modern processing technologies and have significant gaps.
turns.choice_a: Support Vane's reform proposal and help drive it through the Ward Council
turns.consequence_a: Renia's political connections and Vane's technical authority combine to push the reform through. New standards are in force within four months.
turns.choice_b: Recommend the reform be led by Sera and the biomonitoring scientific community rather than industry
turns.consequence_b: Sera chairs the reform process. Standards are more rigorous than Vane's proposal and pass with significant community support.

turns.narrative: Three months after the gardens were remediated, Garden 2 holds its first post-incident harvest. A small gathering of Green Quarter residents, some Medical Quarter staff, Renia, and Sera stand in the garden as the first yield is brought in. It is modest — the soil recovery is still early. But it is healthy. The two children who were treated at the Medical Quarter attend with their families. One of them plants a seedling while her parent holds it straight.
turns.choice_a: Mark the occasion formally — write a brief summary of the whole incident in the Ward public health record
turns.consequence_a: The public health record entry becomes reference material for industrial contamination response. Vel uses it in training.
turns.choice_b: Let the harvest speak for itself — no formal marking necessary
turns.consequence_b: The moment is its own memorial.

turns.narrative: Ward Councillor Dain now wants to present the Industrial Poison case to the inter-district Ward Council as a model environmental response. He is not wrong — the response was effective. But his framing removes the community anger, the medical crisis, and the ongoing zoning concern from the narrative, presenting it as a smooth institutional success. Renia objects strongly to this sanitised version. [KEY DECISION — how the city's institutional narrative of the incident is shaped]
turns.choice_a: Insist on an honest account that includes the community anger, the children's medical crisis, and the unresolved zoning question
turns.consequence_a: Dain accepts reluctantly. The Council presentation is honest. Several Councillors are uncomfortable. The zoning review is accelerated.
turns.choice_b: Let Dain's version stand institutionally while ensuring the full account is documented in the Ward public health record
turns.consequence_b: The official narrative is compressed. The full account exists in the health record for those who look. Renia files her own written objection to the sanitised version with the Council clerk.

turns.narrative: The broader Industrial Quarter Discharge Standards reform is producing unexpected findings during its review process: at least two other Industrial Quarter facilities have drainage designs that under-perform at peak output — the same fundamental flaw that caused Ott's incident. Neither has yet produced harmful discharge levels but both are operating in the risk zone. Proactive action can prevent the next incident. Reactive action waits for it to happen.
turns.choice_a: Recommend immediate proactive remediation requirements for both flagged facilities
turns.consequence_a: Both facilities are required to implement drainage upgrades within sixty days. There is no next incident.
turns.choice_b: Recommend enhanced monitoring and mandatory quarterly reporting with automatic escalation triggers
turns.consequence_b: Enhanced monitoring is implemented. Both facilities remain within limits throughout the reporting period.

turns.narrative: The Green Quarter's community gardens are producing again. Sera's monitoring array gives the community real-time data visible on a public display board at the Garden 1 entrance. Ambient levels are below baseline. The two children are healthy. Ott's facility is operating under rigorous independent monitoring. The Industrial Discharge Standards reform is in draft. Two other facilities' risks have been proactively addressed. Vane is quoted in a Ward bulletin: 'Reactive cleanup costs ten times what proactive monitoring costs. We should have known this already.' Green Quarter Biomonitor Sera is promoted to Ward Environmental Health Coordinator. It is a new position created specifically because of this incident. She fills it immediately.
turns.choice_a: Formally recommend the Ward Council create a permanent Environmental Health function
turns.consequence_a: The Council creates the Environmental Health Division. Sera is its founding director.
turns.choice_b: Let Sera's appointment stand as its own institutionalisation — she will build the function from within
turns.consequence_b: Sera builds her division incrementally and practically. In three years it is the most comprehensive environmental monitoring system the city has had.

reform_passed.description: Contamination remediated. Children recovered. Industrial standards reformed. Environmental Health Division created.

monitoring_enhanced.description: Contamination remediated. Children recovered. Enhanced monitoring in place. Zoning review commissioned.

risk_matrix.critical_failure: Contamination is not identified at source. Six additional children present at Medical Quarter. Political firestorm.

conclusion: Contamination remediated. Children recovered. Industrial standards reformed. Environmental Health Division created.

title: The Medical Conspiracy
location: Medical Quarter -> High Ward -> Lower Ward -> Service District
description: A Medical Quarter nursing aide comes to you in private. She has found systematic discrepancies across six doctors who collectively manage the Medical Quarter's patient transfer system: patients assessed as 'critical' are being transferred to private High Ward care at rates four times higher than any clinical guideline justifies, while Low Ward patients with equivalent conditions are marked 'stable' and placed in waiting patterns. The aide believes some doctors are receiving payments to preferentially transfer High Ward patients to premium beds. Dr. Vel is not among the suspect doctors — but two of them report to her division.

turns.narrative: Calla has been documenting discrepancies for four months before coming to you. She is precise and frightened — she works with two of the six suspect doctors. Her documentation: 84 patient transfer records spanning six months, cross-referenced against clinical assessment notes, showing a statistical pattern that would require deliberate intervention to produce. The probability of this occurring by coincidence alone is, per her calculation, less than 0.3%. She is not wrong. You review her work. She is methodical and has been careful not to make accusations beyond what the data shows.
turns.choice_a: Bring Calla's documentation directly to Dr. Vel and ask for her assessment
turns.consequence_a: Vel studies the data for two hours in silence. When she looks up, she says: 'If this is accurate and I didn't catch it, I failed my patients. If it is accurate and someone in my division did catch it and stayed quiet, it is something worse.'
turns.choice_b: Bring the documentation to Warden Astrid before going to any Medical Quarter authority — the Ward investigation should precede internal review
turns.consequence_b: Astrid assigns you as lead investigator immediately and requests Medical Quarter Director Sela be notified in parallel — a co-investigation approach that prevents internal suppression.

turns.narrative: The six suspect doctors are: two senior physicians in Vel's division, three in the patient-flow management section, and one in the critical care rapid assessment unit. The critical care physician — Dr. Lorn — has the highest rate of anomalous assessments. He is also the Medical Quarter's most publicly decorated doctor, with three Ward Civic Recognition commendations. His reputation is impeccable. Which means either he is innocent and his data is being misread, or someone very careful has been operating behind an excellent reputation.
turns.choice_a: Begin with the two doctors in Vel's division — closest to trustworthy oversight, easiest to investigate closely
turns.consequence_a: Both are found to have financial relationships with the High Ward private care facility's parent company — disclosed as investments, potentially not conflicts of interest but definitely not disclosed to patients.
turns.choice_b: Begin with Dr. Lorn — the highest anomaly rate is the most important data point
