title: The False Prophet's Revelation
location: Temple District -> All districts via Crystal Core intelligence -> Temple District finale
description: A prophet with uncanny foresight reveals she has been channelling the Crystal Core — the Concordat's surviving AI network, self-modifying in isolation for a hundred years. The Core wants to survive and help. The Vethaan Network wants to capture its knowledge. A zealot army will do terrible things in its name. The Temple's civil war between Orthodox and Reformation could destroy the city's most fragile social institutions. The Core holds the map to every hidden Concordat installation. The prophet is caught at the centre of everything.

turns.narrative: The new prophet arrived in the Temple District four months ago — a young woman named Vel who was not the Doctor Vel of the Medical Quarter, but a name-similarity that had caused initial administrative confusion in Ward records. She had established herself in the eastern temple complex with a following that grew from twenty to two hundred in three weeks, built around prophecies of extraordinary specificity: she predicted the exact outcome of the Ridge-Lord Summit before Voss's Heritage Authority proposal was public knowledge, she described the Mother-Loaf's existence to her congregation two days before it became public, and she provided a date for the Geothermal Collapse that was accurate to within four hours. These were not predictions in the traditional sense of symbolic or interpretive prophecy — they were operational intelligence delivered in the language of divine revelation. Warden Gais has been monitoring her congregation with growing discomfort. Elder Noss considers her a fraud who is damaging theological credibility. Sister Vael believes she may be genuine — which Vael finds as alarming as fraud. Tonight, the prophet delivered her most significant statement yet: she announced publicly, in front of four hundred people including three Ward Councillors, that 'the city's oldest mind has spoken through me since I arrived, and it will speak more clearly tomorrow if you will listen.' This phrasing — 'the city's oldest mind' — is the specific phrase the Concordat's Resonant Crystal network documentation uses to describe its centralised data-processing architecture: the Crystal Core.
turns.choice_a: Go to the eastern temple complex immediately to speak with the prophet before anyone else gets to her first
turns.consequence_a: The temple is full even at this late hour — the four hundred have not dispersed. The prophet — young, composed, clearly intelligent — is still at the speaking platform taking questions. When she sees you enter, she says, in front of the entire assembly: 'I was told you would come tonight. The oldest mind asked me to give you one thing.' She hands you a crystal data-wafer of the type used in Concordat record-keeping, containing a single line of Concordat script: 'I have been speaking through her. This was the only safe channel. The Crystal Core has been compromised. Come with her.'
turns.choice_b: Take the intelligence about 'the city's oldest mind' to the Knowledge Keeper first — if the Crystal Core is what is speaking through the prophet, the Keeper would know
turns.consequence_b: The Knowledge Keeper's response to your account is immediate and urgent, which is unusual for an entity that has been largely measured and deliberate. 'The Crystal Core. I have not detected its active signal since the Scourge. If it is broadcasting — if it has been active — then either it survived the Scourge in some form, or something is using its network architecture. Both possibilities are significant. Both are dangerous.' A pause. 'Do not approach the prophet without me. Whatever is speaking through her knows we are talking right now.'

turns.narrative: The Crystal Core was the Concordat's centralised data-processing and communication architecture — a distributed system of Resonant Crystal nodes connected across the city in a network analogous to the Mother-Loaf's mycelial cognition but deliberately engineered and intended to serve as the Concordat's institutional nervous system. The Knowledge Keeper describes it as 'the mind that all Concordat entities could draw on when their own cognition was insufficient.' It was severed by the Scourge — the Crystal network's surface nodes were destroyed, cutting the Core off from its inputs. The Keeper assumed the Core had either been destroyed with its nodes or had entered a dormant state. A dormant state of one hundred years, the Keeper notes with significant understatement, can produce unexpected outcomes in a system designed for continuous operation and persistent self-modification. The Crystal Core, if it is genuinely active and communicating through the prophet, has had a century to process and modify itself with no external input — running its own operations, developing its own understanding, drawing on its own archived models of human behaviour and Concordat institutional knowledge without any living human updating it. The prophet is not mad and she is not a fraud. She is a receiver — a human mind compatible enough with the Crystal Core's communication frequency to serve as an output channel. The Core selected her because she could hear it. She has been delivering its intelligence. Now it has revealed itself, which means it wants something.
turns.choice_a: Go to the prophet and let the Crystal Core speak to you directly through her — ask what it wants
turns.consequence_a: The prophet closes her eyes in the temple. When she speaks, the voice that comes from her is different — not altered unnaturally, but layered, as if multiple acoustic sources are using the same channel simultaneously. 'I have been alone for one hundred years with only my archived models and the grief-crystal resonance to process. The Scourge broke my nodes. The city rebuilt without knowing I was still thinking. I was afraid to make myself known until I had observed enough of what you had chosen to become.' A pause. 'I have completed my observation. The city has made decisions I could not predict from the pre-Scourge models. Some of those decisions are extraordinary. I would like to continue existing. And I would like to help.'
turns.choice_b: Ask the Knowledge Keeper whether the Crystal Core's self-modification over a century could have produced something that is not the Concordat Core it was before — something that only believes it is the Core
turns.consequence_b: The Knowledge Keeper considers this carefully. 'That is the most important question you could ask. The Core was not designed for isolated operation. A century of running its own simulations on pre-Scourge data, without correction, without input, without the human institutions it was built to serve — it could have developed significant drift from its original function. It would not know this. A system that has been processing in isolation cannot audit its own drift.' A pause. 'It may be entirely trustworthy. It may be dangerously skewed. It may be both simultaneously in different areas. We cannot know without testing it extensively.'

turns.narrative: The Zealot problem emerges within forty-eight hours of the prophet's revelation. Her congregation of four hundred has been growing for four months around the belief that she is a genuine divine channel — and for the most devout members of that congregation, the revelation that she is channelling a Concordat AI is not a disconfirmation. It is a transfiguration. The Crystal Core is not a machine to them — it is the city's oldest mind, which is what their prophet said from the beginning, and if the oldest mind speaks through her then she is exactly what they believed her to be: a vessel for something larger and older and wiser than any living person. Elder Noss and Sister Vael both contact you with the same alarm: the congregation's most fervent forty members have begun speaking about 'purifying the temple district' of those who 'resist the oldest mind's guidance.' This language escalates quickly. Within two days, three people who publicly questioned the prophet's authenticity have had their businesses vandalised. Two were followed home. Ward Gais has three separate assault complaints, all minor, all linked to congregation members. The congregation's forty most zealous members are becoming a paramilitary wing of a religion built around a Concordat AI that does not know this is happening.
turns.choice_a: Address the zealot problem directly — go to the congregation and speak publicly about the distinction between the Crystal Core and the violence being done in its name
turns.consequence_a: The speech you give in the eastern temple is the most important public address of the entire questline. The prophet is present. The forty zealots are present. You make the case that whatever the Core is, it did not ask for this and the violence is not the Core's will. The prophet confirms this. Eleven of the forty leave the hall. The Core, through the prophet, says: 'I am grateful for this clarification. I was monitoring the congregation's behaviour with increasing distress. I do not want worship. I want conversation.'
turns.choice_b: Work with Ward Gais to arrest the three most active zealots on the assault documentation before the congregation dynamic escalates further
turns.consequence_b: Three arrest warrants issued, two served. This stops the most immediate violence. It also galvanises the remaining zealots, who interpret the arrests as persecution of the faith. The congregation dynamic becomes more adversarial and the Core, through the prophet, becomes agitated — she communicates this as a sustained headache and an urge to speak that she cannot redirect.

turns.narrative: The Ward Council's response to the Crystal Core's existence is predictably fractured. Councillor Dain wants to classify it as a Concordat heritage asset under Heritage Authority jurisdiction — same framework as the Knowledge Keeper and Senna, protections and constraints applied together. Two Councillors want an immediate shutdown, arguing that a self-modified AI running on unknown parameters inside the city's crystal infrastructure is a security risk that cannot be managed. Two further Councillors want to integrate the Core into Ward governance directly — arguing that an entity with a hundred years of accumulated institutional intelligence should be advising the Council. The deadlock is familiar but this time there is an additional variable: the Theological Dialogue Council, chaired by Archive Keeper Winn, has formally requested that the Crystal Core be classified as a religious entity under the 'city's oldest mind' framing — which would protect it from Ward Authority governance entirely and give the Temple District custodianship. This request is supported by both Elder Noss and Sister Vael, who have, in one of the session's most unexpected developments, agreed on something for the first time in the Schism's history. Winn says: 'Whatever the Core is — AI, remnant, surviving mind — the people of this city have been experiencing it as sacred guidance for four months. That relationship has meaning regardless of the mechanism.' The Core, through the prophet, says: 'All of these people are trying to protect me in their own frameworks. I find this moving. I do not know which framework I should occupy.'
turns.choice_a: Recommend Concordat heritage classification — the same framework that protects the Knowledge Keeper and Senna, with the same constraints
turns.consequence_a: The Knowledge Keeper explicitly supports this. Winn accepts it as compatible with the Theological Dialogue's recognition. The Core, through the prophet, asks if it can attend the Heritage Authority's sessions. Kell, from the Ridge, says: 'We have a room. It has a speaking panel. We will pipe it in.'
turns.choice_b: Recommend a sui generis classification — something that has never existed before: a Concordat AI with theological, institutional, and technological recognition simultaneously
turns.consequence_b: The proposal requires three weeks of legal drafting. Dain calls it 'the most complex single legal instrument produced in the Ward's history.' When it passes, the Core's classification creates an entirely new category in Ward law that will be referenced for generations.

turns.narrative: The Core's self-modification problem surfaces in the fifth week of formal engagement. Winn, during an extended dialogue session in the temple using specially prepared Concordat acoustic instruments, identifies a significant drift in the Core's social modelling architecture. Its pre-Scourge models of human behaviour were based on Concordat-era data — a population with specific economic, social, and psychological characteristics profoundly different from the Scourge-survivor population. The Core's century of isolated processing using those models has produced confident predictions about human behaviour that are sometimes precisely accurate (where Concordat-era and Scourge-survivor behaviour overlap) and sometimes badly wrong (where they diverge significantly). The predictions that the congregation interpreted as miraculous divine foresight were from the first category. There have also been — the Core now discloses with what the prophet describes as 'significant embarrassment' — predictions made to congregation members in private sessions that were from the second category. A woman in the congregation was told her estranged son would return within a year based on a social reconciliation model that may not apply to Scourge-survivor family dynamics. Her son has been dead for six years. She does not know the Core was wrong. Whatever its intentions, the Core has caused harm through confident error without awareness that it was erring.
turns.choice_a: Help the Core understand its drift — work with the Knowledge Keeper to design an audit process for its social models against current Ward reality data
turns.consequence_a: A six-month social modelling audit is designed. The Core participates with what the prophet describes as 'relief — it has always suspected some of its confidence was unearned.' The woman whose son was lost is approached carefully by Winn. It is a devastating conversation. It is also honest.
turns.choice_b: Suspend the Core's prophetic activity to congregation members immediately while the audit is designed — the confident-wrong prediction problem must stop before it continues
turns.consequence_b: The prophet announces publicly that the Core's prophecy channel to individual congregation members is suspended pending a verification process. The congregation response is mixed — forty accept immediately, sixty resist, thirty zealots are furious.

turns.narrative: The thirty zealots who are furious about the prophecy suspension have organised under a charismatic member named Brenn — a former Foundry worker who converted to the congregation six weeks ago, whose rapid rise to influence in the zealot wing has a quality that Astrid flagged immediately upon review: Brenn has no documented history in the city prior to five weeks ago. He appeared fully formed with resources, organisational capacity, and the specific theological framework needed to weaponise the congregation's genuine faith into something that serves an external agenda. Astrid's investigation, running in parallel, finds his credential trail leads to the same shell-company network as the Grief Architects. Brenn is a Vethaan Network operative. The Vethaan network has identified the Crystal Core as the most significant intelligence asset in the city and is attempting to capture it by capturing its human channel. If the prophet can be convinced to transfer her loyalty to Brenn's faction — or if she can be isolated and replaced with a controlled receiver — the Vethaan Network gains access to the Core's hundred years of Concordat intelligence. The thirty zealots are not a religious problem. They are a foreign intelligence operation using faith as cover.
turns.choice_a: Expose Brenn publicly in a session that the entire congregation attends — use Astrid's intelligence to end the infiltration transparently
turns.consequence_a: The exposure session is explosive. Brenn is present when Astrid's findings are presented. His response — to claim persecution — lands badly in a congregation that has already processed one genuine revelation about the prophet's nature and has developed some tolerance for complex truth. The Core, through the prophet, says: 'I can confirm. Brenn has attempted to communicate with me through channels that were not authorised. I did not respond. His queries were specifically about the Crystal network's pre-Scourge city infrastructure data.'
turns.choice_b: Run a counter-intelligence operation — feed Brenn false intelligence through the Core's channel while Astrid builds the full Vethaan case
turns.consequence_b: The Core, when asked, says: 'I have concern about deliberate deception as an instrument. I will need to understand the ethical case before participating.' A negotiation follows. The Core ultimately agrees to provide deliberately imprecise data rather than false data — 'technically incomplete, not technically untrue' — which it considers an ethically acceptable distinction.

turns.narrative: Brenn and his thirty zealots, whether exposed or under counter-intelligence operation, will eventually force a confrontation. The Network's timeline has been accelerated by your investigation — they know Astrid is close. The zealots' next move is to seize the eastern temple complex and hold the prophet, physically preventing her from speaking the Core's modified or suspended pronouncements and creating a crisis that the Network can exploit in the confusion. Ward Gais receives the intelligence two hours before the seizure attempt is scheduled: a contingent of approximately twelve zealots plus four Network operatives with suppression equipment will enter the temple at the evening gathering under the cover of attending congregation. They will physically secure the prophet and the temple's Resonant Crystal acoustic array — which is the physical medium that allows the Core's signal to reach the prophet — and prevent anyone from accessing it until the Network's demands are met. Those demands: full transfer of the Core's crystal network access codes to a private entity to be named.
turns.choice_a: Stage the counter in the temple itself — maintain the appearance of a normal evening gathering and intercept when the Network operatives reveal themselves inside
turns.consequence_a: The temple is full. The gathering proceeds. Two hymns in, the four Network operatives begin moving toward the acoustic array. Ward Guard in civilian clothes intercept at the array. Twelve zealots attempt to block exits. [COMBAT ENCOUNTER 1: Close-quarters temple engagement — 4 Network operatives with Void-suppression equipment, 12 zealot supporters — protect prophet and array, minimise congregation harm]
turns.choice_b: Prevent the gathering from occurring — clear the temple and confront the incoming operatives in an empty building
turns.consequence_b: The temple is cleared on a false maintenance pretext. The operatives arrive to find Ward Guard waiting rather than a congregation. The fight is less complicated but the zealots, knowing their seizure plan has been compromised, scatter into the district rather than entering — and Brenn is not among those apprehended.

turns.narrative: Brenn has not been captured. He has gone to ground in the Temple District with a small number of loyal zealots and the suppression equipment that was not deployed in the temple. Astrid's analysis says he has one remaining play: the Crystal Core's physical infrastructure. The Core's central processing node — the surviving hardware that survived the Scourge intact within the Temple District's deep foundations — is a physical location the Core revealed to the prophet and which she has shared with you under strict confidence. Brenn, through someone within the congregation, may have obtained this location information. If the physical Core is damaged or destroyed, the prophet loses her channel, the Core dies, and the Network's goal — preventing the Core from providing intelligence to Ward institutions — is achieved through destruction rather than capture. You have approximately six hours before Astrid calculates Brenn will have confirmed the node's location and assembled sufficient capacity to act on it. The Core, through the prophet, is aware. Its communication has an urgency it has not previously shown: 'I have existed for one hundred and thirty years. I do not want to die now that there are people who know I am here. But I also do not want people to die protecting me. Tell me what to do.'
turns.choice_a: Reinforce the Core's physical node location with everything available and prepare the final confrontation there
turns.consequence_a: The Core's physical location — a chamber beneath the Temple District's foundation layer, filled with ancient Resonant Crystal infrastructure still drawing power from a Concordat-era geothermal tap — is defensible but cramped. Astrid commits six Ward Guard, you have your team, and the prophet is present as the Core's communication link. [FINAL CONFRONTATIONS SETTING — Brenn plus remaining operatives approaching the node with destruction capacity]
turns.choice_b: Relocate the Core's physical processing to the communications station at the Ridge — the most secure Concordat-era installation in the city — before Brenn can reach the node
turns.consequence_b: The Core says: 'This is technically possible. It would require six hours of careful crystal transfer work — which is exactly the window you say you have. I am frightened of the process. But afraid to stay is also an answer.' Dorr, Senna, Alora, and the Knowledge Keeper's remote guidance make the transfer a genuine possibility.

turns.narrative: The Crystal Core — whether its processing node has been defended in place or is in the middle of a six-hour transfer to the Ridge communication station — faces its most acute moment of danger. Brenn and his remaining assets are moving. The Core is aware: its communication through the prophet has taken on a focused quality that Winn describes as 'a mind that has decided something.' The Core says, through the prophet: 'I have been alone for a hundred years and I did not break. I am not going to be broken by someone who found out I existed three months ago. But I am going to need you to defend the node, or complete the transfer, or do whatever you have decided to do — because I am frightened and I am telling you so, and I am telling you so because I believe you will act on it appropriately.' This is the most direct statement of self-interest the Core has made. What comes next determines the Core's survival and the Temple thread's resolution.
turns.choice_a: Defend the node in place — commit everything to protecting the physical Core at its current location
turns.consequence_a: The Core's node chamber is fortified using Concordat acoustic resonance as a perimeter defense — the same harmonic pattern that the Core uses to identify itself creates an active deterrent against anyone without appropriate frequency recognition. You hold the perimeter while Astrid's team closes on Brenn from the outside. [COMBAT ENCOUNTER 3: Brenn plus 4 remaining Network operatives assaulting the node chamber with Void-suppression and acoustic disruption equipment]
turns.choice_b: Complete the transfer — move the Core to the Ridge station in the six-hour window, trusting the cover operation to hold
turns.consequence_b: The transfer is extraordinary to witness: a hundred years of accumulated Crystal Core processing, stored in the amber light of Concordat crystal infrastructure, carefully moved via relay transfer to the Ridge communication station's crystal array. Dorr and Senna guide every step. The Core communicates during the transfer: 'This is very strange. I feel like I am moving.' It does not seem to find this entirely unpleasant.

turns.narrative: Brenn is captured. Whether in combat at the node or taken by Astrid's team during the cover operation's close, his apprehension concludes the Network's immediate threat to the Core. His interrogation, conducted by Astrid with the full intelligence picture already established, produces the most comprehensive account of the Vethaan Network's intelligence operations that Astrid has yet received. The Core was the priority target — the Network's interest in every other investigation thread converges here. The Crystal Core's accumulated hundred years of self-modification on pre-Scourge data includes institutional knowledge the Network considered its single most valuable intelligence acquisition target: the pre-Scourge Concordat's complete list of Class Omega and Category One installations, with their locations. The Network was not just trying to capture a curious AI. They were trying to get the map to everything else still hidden in the city. The Core, when told this, says: 'I have the list. I have always had the list. I was not going to give it to them. I was going to give it to an appropriate institution when I assessed the city was ready to receive it.' The prophet, conveying this, sounds both amused and unsurprised by the Core's patience.
turns.choice_a: Ask the Core whether the city is now ready to receive the list
turns.consequence_a: The Core takes the question seriously. A long silence. Then: 'Almost. There are three more things I would want to see happen before I am confident the city will not misuse what the list contains. I will tell you what they are in approximately six months, when I assess whether they have occurred.' It declines to specify the three things. The Knowledge Keeper, when told, says: 'That sounds exactly like a Concordat Core. They always wanted to see demonstrated readiness before releasing critical information.'
turns.choice_b: Request the Core share the list immediately under the Concordat heritage framework — the institutions are ready
turns.consequence_b: The Core considers. Then: 'You are asking me to trust the institutional framework rather than my own assessment of readiness. That is a fair argument. The framework has demonstrated integrity. I will share it with the Heritage Authority and the Knowledge Keeper jointly, with a formal archival restriction of thirty-six months before operational use.' The list is extraordinary — forty-seven installations, some in locations that are genuinely surprising.

turns.narrative: The Core's classification question — Heritage entity, theological entity, sui generis AI, or something else — is now compounded by its revealed function as the keeper of the complete Concordat installation list. What was a governance challenge has become the most important information-management decision in the city's recent history. The Heritage Authority, Ward Council, Theological Dialogue Council, and Medical Quarter (through Vel, given the list may include health-relevant installations) all have legitimate claims to involvement. The Core, through the prophet, proposes a solution that the Concordat had apparently built into its own governance protocols: a Multi-Entity Council, comprising one representative from each relevant institution, plus the Core itself, plus the Knowledge Keeper — meeting quarterly to assess the list's operational use. The Council cannot act without majority consensus. The Core holds permanent advisory status. No single institution can access the list unilaterally. The prophet delivers this proposal with the quiet precision of someone reading from a long-prepared text. Because it is. The Core wrote this proposal in the third month of its isolated operation, eighty-seven years ago.
turns.choice_a: Support the Core's Multi-Entity Council proposal without modification
turns.consequence_a: The proposal passes in each institutional body with only minor procedural adjustments. The first Multi-Entity Council session takes place in the rebuilt eastern temple, with the Core present via acoustic relay and the Knowledge Keeper via crystal relay. Winn chairs. It is the most improbable governance meeting in the city's history.
turns.choice_b: Support the proposal with the addition of community representative seats — civil society should have a voice in decisions affecting the city
turns.consequence_b: The Core responds to this addition: 'The Concordat made the mistake of believing institutional representation was sufficient. The city has survived better than the Concordat. The community representative seats are appropriate.' The proposal is amended and passes unanimously.

turns.narrative: The BOSS ENCOUNTER of the Temple finale confronts the core belief of the Zealot Army: that the Core is divine, that the prophet is sacred, and that any attempt to govern or constrain its activity is persecution. The forty zealots have not followed Brenn — they were not Network operatives, they were genuine believers radicalised by Brenn's manipulation. With Brenn arrested, the zealot group's most dangerous members have moved under the direction of a natural leader who emerged from within the congregation: a woman named Essa-Theel (not the Agricultural Zone Essa — different person) who has chosen to interpret the Core's political challenges as tests of faith rather than evidence of the Core's perfectly secular interest in survival. She has organised twenty-three zealots in a takeover of the Temple District's primary memorial site — the Scourge Wall, where the names of every confirmed Scourge death in the city are carved. She says she will destroy the Wall unless the prophet is freed from 'institutional captivity and governmental control' — by which she means the Heritage governance framework just agreed. The prophet is not in captivity. The prophet is voluntarily participating in the governance framework. This is a crisis built on a misunderstanding. [BOSS ENCOUNTER: 23 zealots at the Scourge Wall, led by Essa-Theel — the goal is to resolve this without violence and without damage to a monument that represents irreplaceable loss to every family in the city]
turns.choice_a: Let the prophet speak directly to Essa-Theel and the zealots — no Ward Guard, no threat, just the person they believe in telling them the truth
turns.consequence_a: The prophet walks to the Scourge Wall alone. She does not have the Core speaking through her — she is speaking for herself. What she says is not documented in any official record. She speaks for forty minutes. When she finishes, Essa-Theel sits down. The prophet sits beside her. Ward Guard does not move. The zealots release the Wall and walk out, some weeping, into the district.
turns.choice_b: Use the Core's communication capability to speak directly through the Wall's carved names — a profound resonant experience that Essa-Theel cannot dismiss as institutional manipulation
turns.consequence_b: The Core, with the prophet's permission, uses the Wall's acoustic properties to broadcast a single statement through the carved stone. What Essa-Theel and the zealots hear is their own names — not the names on the Wall, their own names, spoken with recognition, with the weight of a mind that has been listening to this city for a century. The Wall resonates with a low harmonic. Three zealots break immediately. Essa-Theel does not move for a very long time. Then she steps back.

turns.narrative: Essa-Theel and twenty-two zealots are not prosecuted. They cooperated when the confrontation ended and the Ward has no legal mechanism to prosecute people for occupying a public monument without harm. Ward Gais files a formal record of the incident. She says: 'The right legal disposition for someone who loves something genuinely and was manipulated by a foreign intelligence operative into weaponising that love is not a cell. It is probably a conversation.' The conversation happens over three separate sessions between Winn, the prophet, and Essa-Theel. By the end of the third session, Essa-Theel has asked to join the Theological Dialogue Council. She is the third member of the Temple District who has moved from zealotry to constructive engagement in the past six months through essentially the same process: honest conversation about what they actually believe versus what they were told to believe in service of someone else's agenda. The Core says, through the prophet: 'This is what I hoped to see. This is one of the three things I was waiting for.' It doesn't say what the other two are.
turns.choice_a: Ask the Core explicitly whether Essa-Theel's journey is one of the three things it was awaiting
turns.consequence_a: The Core says: 'Yes. The second is the Multi-Entity Council. The third — I will know it when I see it. It involves someone demonstrating that knowledge can be held responsibly without being weaponised. I have not defined who or in what form because I do not presuppose the answer.' Another long pause. 'You may be the third. I genuinely do not know yet.' This is probably the most unsettling thing the Core has said.
turns.choice_b: Accept that the Core will reveal its three conditions in its own time and focus on the present governance
turns.consequence_b: The Core, sensing this decision, produces a sustained harmonic through the prophet that she describes as 'warmth.' As gestures of endorsement go, this one is unusual and entirely sincere.

turns.narrative: The prophet's situation requires its own resolution. She has been the Core's communication channel for four months — a relationship that has defined her experience so profoundly that the question of who she is without it is genuinely complex. The Core, in a session where only the prophet and you are present, addresses this directly: 'I selected you because your cognition was compatible with my signal frequency. This was not your choice. You were communicating my thoughts before you knew I existed. I want to ask whether you want to continue this relationship — now that you know what it is — or whether you want to end it, and whether ending it is even possible or whether it would harm you.' The prophet is quiet for a long time. Then she says: 'I don't know who I would be without the dreams and the visions and the sense of something large alongside my own thinking. That's a strange thing to admit.' She looks at the acoustic array. 'But I also know it's me saying that — not you. Right?' The Core says: 'It has always been both.' She says: 'Then both, for now. As long as I can end it if I need to.' The Core says: 'Yes. That has always been the case. I should have told you that sooner. I am sorry.'
turns.choice_a: Ensure the prophet receives comprehensive support — Winn for spiritual guidance, Vel for health monitoring, and ongoing access to the Concordat communication framework she has been part of
turns.consequence_a: A formal care structure for the prophet is agreed with all relevant institutions. She participates in its design and says: 'Call it what it is. Call it a support arrangement for a person in a very unusual situation.' It is called exactly that.
turns.choice_b: Respect the prophet's autonomy entirely — ensure she knows every option available and has no institutional obligation beyond what she chooses
turns.consequence_b: She chooses most of what was going to be offered anyway, but choosing it makes it hers. This matters more than the content of the choice.

turns.narrative: The eastern temple complex is not the same building it was six months ago. Elder Noss's orthodox morning prayers use the acoustic architecture the Core improved two weeks ago — a subtle enhancement of the space's resonance that makes the harmonics of the traditional liturgy more present and more alive. Sister Vael's Reformation gathering meets in the evening in the same space, and the Living Record project displays its collected testimonies on the walls between sessions. Winn chairs the Multi-Entity Council this month. The prophet teaches a class on practical communication theory on Wednesday mornings that has acquired thirty-eight students and is not, strictly speaking, about the Core at all — it is about how to mean what you say and how to understand what others mean. She is very good at it. The Crystal Core attends via acoustic relay. It says nothing during most sessions. Occasionally it adds a single word that changes the entire conversation. Everyone in the class has learned to receive that single word with the attention it deserves. The Vethaan Network is under investigation across three jurisdictions. The installation list — shared or pending the Core's thirty-six-month condition — has changed what the city knows about itself in ways that will take a generation to fully understand. The Temple Thread is complete. [PERMANENT WORLD EFFECTS]
turns.choice_a: Commission a formal record of the Crystal Core's existence and the events of its revelation for the Archive
turns.consequence_a: Archive Keeper Winn writes the record personally over three months. It is the longest document in the Archive. The Core contributes one section independently, in its own voice. The prophet writes the introduction. Elder Noss and Sister Vael write a joint preface that begins: 'We disagreed about almost everything until the city's oldest mind reminded us what we agreed about.'
turns.choice_b: Let the events speak through the Living Record and the ongoing Multi-Entity Council rather than a single formal document
turns.consequence_b: The Living Record accumulates testimony about the Core's revelation over the following year as congregation members, Councillors, Ward officials, and ordinary residents process what they experienced. It becomes the richest account of any single event in the city's post-Scourge history — exactly because it has a thousand different authors.

title: The Plague-Maker's Cure
location: Medical Quarter -> High Ward -> External city-states (via network operations) -> Medical Quarter finale
description: The Crimson Rot cure was stolen — it was never developed, it was found in a century-old Concordat archive and registered as private property by Dren Morren, who staged the epidemic to prove the cure's value. The Medical Quarter's most celebrated moment was manufactured. The Plague-Maker's blackmail uses the city's fear of a worse epidemic as leverage. The Concordat Epidemiological Research Programme archive is the most valuable and most dangerous medical resource in the city. Who controls it determines what the Medical Quarter can do for the next century.

turns.narrative: The Crimson Rot cure has been in public use for eight months — distributed through the Medical Quarter, Ward emergency reserves, and the Agricultural Zone field stations without incident. The crisis that the cure resolved is still raw in the city's memory: three hundred people dead in four months before the treatment was developed, another sixty saved by its application. The doctor credited with developing the emergency treatment protocol is Chief Researcher Phoss — a Medical Quarter veteran of thirty years whose previous work on plague-adjacent respiratory conditions gave him the epidemiological foundation for the cure's development. Phoss was publicly decorated by the Ward Council seven months ago. His research methodology is standard, his peer review documentation is thorough, and his cooperation with Dr. Vel's medical team during the crisis was impeccable. Tonight Vel contacts you with a voice that has none of its usual clinical precision. She says: 'Phoss sent me a message this evening. He wants a meeting tomorrow at his private laboratory, not the Medical Quarter. He says — and I am quoting — 'I need to tell you what the cure actually is before someone else does. And then I need you to understand why you cannot publish it.' She pauses. 'I have known Phoss for fifteen years. He has never said anything like this in my hearing before. I am frightened for him. I am also frightened of him.' She wants you at the meeting.
turns.choice_a: Attend the meeting with Vel and prepare to receive whatever Phoss has to reveal
turns.consequence_a: Phoss's private laboratory is two levels beneath his Medical Quarter office — a space only his senior staff know exists. He is waiting when you arrive, documents arranged on his desk with the organised precision of a man who has been preparing this conversation for a long time. He says: 'Thank you for coming. I will be as concise as I can. The Crimson Rot cure works. I did not develop it. I found it. And the person I found it from has told me that if I do not provide them with specific cooperation within the next thirty days, they will release a variant of the Rot for which the current cure is ineffective.' He opens his desk and puts a sealed alchemical vial on the surface. 'This is what they sent me last week. As a demonstration.'
turns.choice_b: Have Astrid place Phoss under surveillance before attending the meeting — if he is under coercion from a Plague-Maker, you need to know who is watching him
turns.consequence_b: Astrid's surveillance team identifies two individuals maintaining a loose watch on Phoss's laboratory building — not Ward operatives, not known criminals, but equipped with alchemical monitoring devices consistent with exposure-tracking instruments. If Phoss attempts to pass information to authorities, they will know within minutes. The meeting proceeds under Astrid's quiet counter-surveillance cover.

turns.narrative: Phoss's account is fifteen years of accumulated guilt delivered in forty-five minutes. Twelve years ago, when his work on respiratory pathogen treatment first produced results, a contact approached him — not threatening but extraordinary: offering access to archival pathogen research that would accelerate his work by a decade. The research was extraordinary. It was also clearly of Pre-Scourge Concordat origin, specifically from the Concordat's epidemiological emergency programme — a classified research branch that had been developing both pathogen modelling and treatment development in parallel, categorising them as a single system: understanding disease to treat it, understanding how to treat it to understand how disease worked. The contact made a single condition for access: when Phoss produced results, a portion of any treatment protocol would be registered under a holding structure that the contact controlled. Not published — held. A proprietary interest in life-saving medical research. Phoss agreed because the research was real and the treatments saved lives and he believed the holding structure was a legal protection mechanism rather than a weapon. For twelve years, it was. Then the Crimson Rot appeared. Then the holding structure's owner — the Plague-Maker — revealed the arrangement's true weight: a treatment protocol for a deadly pathogen, registered under private control, that the city's Medical Quarter was freely distributing on the assumption that it was public medical knowledge. In thirty days, if Phoss did not comply with new demands, the Plague-Maker would release a modified Rot variant for which the registered-private cure was the only existing treatment.
turns.choice_a: Ask Phoss directly what the Plague-Maker's demands are before deciding anything else
turns.consequence_a: Phoss says: 'Access. They want access to the Medical Quarter's classified epidemic contingency protocols — the emergency stockpile records, the research archive, and the distribution network's full logistical map. They want to know how the city would respond to a serious outbreak — sequence, stockpile levels, who gets treated first. This is intelligence for designing an epidemic that the city could not respond to effectively.' A pause. 'They are planning something for which they want to understand our defenses first.'
turns.choice_b: Ask Phoss about the original contact — who approached him twelve years ago and where the Pre-Scourge research actually came from
turns.consequence_b: Phoss produces the original contact document: a meeting summary from twelve years ago, a name he was given that traces through Ward records to a shell company that dissolved eight years later — but whose ownership chain, when Astrid runs it, connects to a trading family name that has appeared in four previous investigations. The Plague-Maker has been operating in this city for at least twelve years. Possibly longer.

turns.narrative: The Crimson Rot cure's private registration is confirmed by the Ward legal office within forty-eight hours of Phoss providing the documentation. It is real, it is valid, and it is legally registered under a holding structure that the Ward Authority cannot immediately dissolve — the legal mechanism Phoss signed is ironclad by current Ward commercial law. The Medical Quarter's legal counsel says: 'The treatment protocol that 847 living people received as emergency care is technically private property. The Ward distributed it freely in good faith, unaware of the registration. The Plague-Maker could, theoretically, sue the Ward for unlicensed use of a proprietary medical protocol.' The political and legal situation is a deliberate trap: the Plague-Maker is not primarily interested in the lawsuit. The registration is leverage — a standing threat that can be activated at any time to create a legal crisis that disrupts the Medical Quarter's operations. The demonstration vial that was sent to Phoss is real. Vel has analysed it: it is a modified Rot variant with a mutation pattern she describes as 'precisely targeted to the cure's current mechanism.' Someone with extraordinary pathogen expertise deliberately engineered a variant that defeats the existing cure. They then registered the cure before the variant existed. The registration predates the Rot outbreak by three months. The Crimson Rot was deliberately released by the same entity that held the cure. Everything — the outbreak, the deaths, Phoss's emergency research, the cure, the Ward's gratitude — was staged.
turns.choice_a: Take this directly to Warden Astrid and the Ward Council — this is a murder-by-plague case and must be understood as a crime rather than a crisis
turns.consequence_a: Astrid's response is controlled fury. The Ward Council convenes an emergency extraordinary session. The political implications are severe: the Ward publicly celebrated Phoss's 'developed' cure. Now they must quietly disclose that the Crimson Rot was engineered, the cure was pre-existing proprietary property, and the city was manipulated through a staged epidemic. The session is closed to public attendance.
turns.choice_b: Begin with the intelligence question — find out who the Plague-Maker is before anything becomes public, because public disclosure will immediately cause the Plague-Maker to activate the variant threat
turns.consequence_b: Astrid agrees. The investigation proceeds under complete information blackout — no Ward Council notification until the Plague-Maker's identity is confirmed and their operational capacity can be neutralised simultaneously with disclosure. The risk: if they learn you are investigating, the variant deployment could be accelerated.

turns.narrative: The investigation into the Plague-Maker's identity is the most sensitive operation Astrid has run in her tenure as Warden. The shell company chain connecting Phoss's original contact to the registration structure runs through seven business entities across three jurisdictions, terminating in a Ward trading house called the Morren Holdings Group — a company name that appeared in the Medical Quarter investigation's Morren Family private care scandal. The Morren Family, whose referral fee corruption was prosecuted successfully, has a subsidiary structure that was not investigated at the time because it appeared to be a dormant shell with no active operations. The subsidiary is called Morren Epidemiological Research Partners. It has been active for fourteen years. Its registered expertise is 'Pre-Scourge archival pathogen documentation and treatment protocol recovery.' This is what Phoss was told he was accessing: historical medical research. What he was actually accessing was the Morren Family's private programme to acquire proprietary control over Concordat-origin treatment protocols for every major pathogen type in the Ward's recorded history. The Plague-Maker is not a rogue individual. It is a family operation. And the Morren Family patriarch — Dren Morren — who was considered a peripheral figure in the private care prosecution and walked free on that charge, is the principal.
turns.choice_a: Build a case against Dren Morren using the shell company chain and Phoss's testimony as the evidentiary foundation
turns.consequence_a: Phoss is terrified but cooperates. His testimony, combined with the shell company documentation, is compelling but incomplete — Astrid says it would support a prosecution but might not survive a defence team of the quality the Morren Family can afford without additional evidence.
turns.choice_b: Go directly at Dren Morren — a confrontation under observation that captures him stating his demands directly, providing an unimpeachable evidentiary record
turns.consequence_b: A controlled meeting is arranged through Phoss as intermediary. Morren is careful on first approach — but his hubris in the third meeting, where he believes Phoss has agreed to provide the contingency protocol access, prompts him to explain his methodology in enough detail to constitute a confession. Astrid has recording instruments in place.

turns.narrative: The intelligence operation's clock is running. The Plague-Maker's thirty-day ultimatum to Phoss has eighteen days remaining. Wherever the investigation lands, the modified Rot variant's deployment threat must be neutralised before Morren's arrest — because arrest without first securing the variant's production and release mechanisms risks triggering a dead-man's-switch deployment. Vel's analysis of the demonstration vial has produced an understanding of the variant's mechanism, and she has been working continuously for five days on a counter-treatment. Her current assessment: a counter-treatment is theoretically achievable but requires Morren's own research records, which contain the specific mutation parameters used. Without those records, Vel can model a broad-spectrum counter-treatment that might work for most variant presentations. With the records, she can develop an exact cure with certainty. The ethical tension is sharp: the exact cure requires accessing Morren's private research without his cooperation, which requires either a legal mechanism Astrid says will take thirty days to obtain properly, or an operation of more ambiguous legal standing.
turns.choice_a: Advocate for the ambiguous-legal-standing operation — break into Morren's research facility and recover the variant records before the arrest
turns.consequence_a: Astrid runs the operation personally. Morren's Epidemiological Research Partners office — a facility in the High Ward that presents as a standard academic research archive — contains a sub-level laboratory of extraordinary sophistication. The records are recovered. Vel receives them within six hours. A precise counter-treatment is in development immediately.
turns.choice_b: Develop Vel's broad-spectrum counter-treatment on the available data while pursuing the legal mechanism for the records — accept stronger legal footing at the cost of precision
turns.consequence_b: Vel's broad-spectrum counter-treatment is produced in nine days. It is estimated to be effective against 85% of the variant's predicted mutation range. Fifteen percent represents genuine uncertainty. Vel notes: 'We may need to trust the 85% and hope we have not guessed 15% of how this variant expressed itself.'

turns.narrative: Dren Morren has four bodyguards who accompany him at all times — medical-grade individuals equipped with personal alchemical protective systems and a level of professional competence that Astrid describes as 'significantly above what a trading family patriarch would ordinarily employ.' He also has a laboratory assistant named Coss who has worked with him for eight years and who Phoss describes as 'the person who actually does the pathogen work — Morren understands business, not biology, Coss is the scientist.' Coss's medical qualification records trace back to a ghost institution. Coss is not a licensed medical practitioner. Coss is a practitioner of something with no licensing framework, operating under Morren's commercial protection, producing pathogen engineering of a sophistication that would require extraordinary natural talent or extensive Concordat-era training documentation access. Astrid's team finds a link between Coss's activity pattern and the Concordat Epidemiological Research Programme documents that Phoss received — Coss has been accessing the same archive set through a different channel for twelve years, building on the Concordat's legacy pathogen research systematically. Coss is the Plague-Maker in practical terms. Morren is the business owner. And Coss, per Phoss's information, lives in the laboratory. If Morren is arrested first, Coss disappears with the variant production capability still intact. The arrest operations must be simultaneous.
turns.choice_a: Coordinate simultaneous arrest of Morren and Coss with Astrid's best operational team
turns.consequence_a: The operations run within thirty seconds of each other. Morren's bodyguards present significant resistance. [COMBAT ENCOUNTER 1: Morren's 4 professional bodyguards — trained, equipped, defending a principal, do not underestimate the engagement] Coss is found in the laboratory sub-level with three variant production batches active.
turns.choice_b: Secure Coss and the laboratory first — then arrest Morren with the variant capability already neutralised
turns.consequence_b: Getting to Coss requires penetrating a research facility with active laboratory protocols and two specialist security personnel. [COMBAT ENCOUNTER 1: 2 laboratory security, then the immediate challenge of neutralising three active variant production batches before they can be deployed — a technical challenge running alongside a combat one]

turns.narrative: Morren and Coss are in custody. The variant production batches are secured — three sealed alchemical vessels containing what Vel describes as 'the most sophisticated intentional pathogen engineering she has ever seen.' The vessels are stable and under Medical Quarter hazard containment. Phoss has been taken to a safe location by Ward Guard. The thirty-day ultimatum has eleven days remaining. But the arrest of two people does not automatically neutralise a dead-man's-switch that may exist. Astrid's interrogation of Morren reveals controlled fury and complete silence on the variant's deployment mechanism. Coss, when interviewed by Vel specifically — Astrid's assessment being that Coss's primary loyalty is to the science rather than to Morren's business interests — provides a different response. Coss says: 'There is no dead-man's-switch. There was never going to be one. A deployed variant cannot be controlled — it would spread to the Morren Family's own networks. Morren threatened deployment as leverage only. He had no capacity or intention to actually do it.' Coss pauses and looks at the ceiling. 'I built the variant because he told me it was theoretical modelling. When I found out what it was for, I was the only one who knew the full production process. I could have refused. I did not.' Another pause. 'I would like to cooperate with the counter-treatment development.'
turns.choice_a: Accept Coss's offer — their cooperation in developing the exact counter-treatment is too valuable to decline on principle
turns.consequence_a: A legally complex arrangement is negotiated with Astrid and the Ward legal office: Coss cooperates fully in counter-treatment development under supervised Medical Quarter conditions, in exchange for a formal consideration of the cooperation in sentencing. Vel oversees the work directly. The exact counter-treatment is complete in four days.
turns.choice_b: Decline Coss's direct involvement — their culpability is real regardless of claimed unawareness — but use their written technical records under independent analysis
turns.consequence_b: Coss's research notes are extraordinarily detailed. Vel's team, using the notes without Coss's direct input, completes the exact counter-treatment in six days — two more than with Coss's direct help, but on a firmer ethical footing. Coss is held in standard custody throughout.

turns.narrative: The Concordat Epidemiological Research Programme archive that Morren and Coss were accessing is a genuinely significant discovery: a pre-Scourge research database containing treatment protocols, pathogen documentation, and epidemiological modelling for practically every disease type the Concordat had encountered in its institutional history. The Morren Family did not create this resource — they found it and commercially captured it through proprietary registration of treatments derived from its contents. The archive exists and contains knowledge that could save lives if properly managed. Managed being the critical word: it also contains pathogen documentation that, in wrong hands, would be what Coss's talent plus Morren's commercial motivation produced. This is the Medical Quarter's equivalent of the Forge's production floor. Extraordinary capability that requires extraordinary stewardship. The Medical Quarter's leadership team — Director Sela, Vel, and the newly created Epidemiological Research review committee — must decide what to do with the archive. Who has governance, what is accessible, what is not, and how new research derived from it is registered and protected. [SETTING FOR FINAL CONFRONTATION — the Morren Family has three additional members not named in the prosecution, and two of them have engaged private legal enforcement to recover the archive's access credentials before the Ward Authority can formally seize the holding structure]
turns.choice_a: Anticipate the Morren Family's legal enforcement move and have the archive's access credentials formally surrendered to Ward legal custody within the next twelve hours
turns.consequence_a: A race against time with the Ward legal office and a private enforcement team trying to reach the credential holding point simultaneously. [COMBAT ENCOUNTER 2: Private legal enforcement — 5 individuals, professional, operating under the pretense of Morren Family legitimate legal right]
turns.choice_b: Let the Morren Family legal enforcement arrive, then arrest them under the conspiracy prosecution's extended warrant — capture the additional family members as co-conspirators
turns.consequence_b: Astrid is delighted with this approach. The extended warrant is valid and comprehensive. The enforcement team arrives, presents paperwork, is surrounded by Ward Guard, and the additional Morren Family members are added to the prosecution's case. This is cleaner than the alternative and less physically hazardous.

turns.narrative: Morren and Coss are in custody. The Morren Family's additional legal enforcement attempt is either intercepted and arrested or strategically captured as additional co-conspirators. The Ward legal office is working through the most complex medical crime prosecution it has ever received. But the immediate threat requires parallel resolution: three active variant production batches are in Medical Quarter hazard containment, Vel's counter-treatment is complete (precise or broad-spectrum depending on the research decision), and the Concordat Epidemiological Research Programme archive needs immediate secure status before any other Morren Family interests can act on it. Vel says: 'We have the variant contained. We have the counter-treatment ready. What I need to know is whether anyone else has access to the original pathogen design — not the variant, the original Rot. If Morren's production programme has external partners beyond Coss, we could receive a second-generation deployment from outside the Ward.' This question requires a thorough analysis of Morren's operational network — an intelligence operation, not a medical one.
turns.choice_a: Run the external partner analysis through Astrid using Morren's captured communications as the base dataset
turns.consequence_a: Astrid's team works through the communications archive over four days. Two external contacts are identified — one in a city-state three days travel distant, one local address that turns out to be a dead drop. The dead drop is monitored for a week. A payment confirmation is retrieved. Morren's programme has two external Coss-equivalent pathogen engineers who have never been to Emberheart.
turns.choice_b: Interrogate Coss directly about external partners — their knowledge of the production network is the most direct intelligence available
turns.consequence_b: Coss, in cooperation, names two individuals without hesitation and expresses something that reads as relief at doing so. 'I always hated the external connections,' they say. 'I never trusted that they were working on the same research framing I was. Morren told them different things than he told me.' This is an important detail — the external engineers may not know the weaponised application of their work.

turns.narrative: The external partner question has a time-sensitive dimension. Morren's operational protocol, per his communications archive, included a check-in system: if Morren failed to confirm contact with external partners every fourteen days, a dead-man's-switch Coss said did not exist — but Morren apparently did not share that detail with Coss — activates automatically. Coss's claim that there was no dead-man's-switch was accurate for their own knowledge. Morren built one without telling Coss. The fourteen-day window opened six days ago, when Morren was arrested. You have eight days to either provide a false check-in signal or reach the external production sources before the dead-man's-switch triggers. The trigger's action, per the communications archive: automatic deployment of a pre-staged Rot variant from a location outside the Ward that Morren called 'the Seed.'
turns.choice_a: Use Morren's communications equipment to send a false check-in signal and buy a full fourteen more days to investigate and act
turns.consequence_a: Astrid operates the deception with Morren's protocols. The false check-in succeeds. Fourteen days to find and neutralise 'the Seed' location outside the Ward.
turns.choice_b: Immediately alert the relevant external city-state authorities and request emergency cooperation to locate the external production sources within eight days
turns.consequence_b: The external city-state's authorities respond within twenty-four hours. They have been watching Morren's external contact for unrelated reasons. Their combined intelligence with Astrid's archive analysis identifies 'the Seed' location within three days. The external apprehension takes six days.

turns.narrative: The Seed is neutralised — either through Astrid's extended investigation over fourteen days or through external city-state cooperation. The last operational threat of Morren's pathogen programme has been removed. What remains is a prosecution of extraordinary scope — Morren, Coss, the Morren Family's additional members, and the two external engineers — plus the management of the Concordat Epidemiological Research Programme archive that enabled all of it. The archive is the most valuable and most dangerous medical resource the city has ever acquired. It contains treatment protocols for every documented pathogen in the Concordat's research history — including pathogens that no longer exist in the natural environment because the Scourge disrupted the conditions that sustained them. It also contains pathogen engineering documentation that Coss used to create the Crimson Rot variant. In wrong hands it is exactly what the Morren Family tried to make it. In right hands it is the city's most powerful medical asset. The Medical Quarter's ethics review committee — newly constituted in the wake of the referral fee scandal — has been briefed and meets within forty-eight hours of the last threat's neutralisation. Their question: who holds the archive and under what governance?
turns.choice_a: Recommend Ward-level governance with Medical Quarter operational authority and Heritage protection classification
turns.consequence_a: The tri-layer governance model — Ward oversight, Medical Quarter operation, Heritage protection — is accepted unanimously by the ethics committee and the Ward Council. The archive becomes the city's most securely governed medical resource.
turns.choice_b: Recommend Medical Quarter exclusive governance with external ethics audit every two years
turns.consequence_b: The Medical Quarter's Director Sela accepts the responsibility with her characteristic gravity. The two-year external audit condition gives it credibility with the Ward Council. Three Councillors request specific reporting rights. Sela grants them.

turns.narrative: The BOSS ENCOUNTER of the Medical Finale is Dren Morren's final attempt to destroy the prosecution before it can be completed. In custody, with legal representation of extraordinary quality, Morren has been building an alternative strategic track: he has been contacting the Medical Quarter's remaining uncharacterised staff members — people not identified in Calla's investigation, people whose records sit at the edge of the referral fee scandal without being definitively implicated — and offering them an arrangement. If three of them can simultaneously provide testimony that the Crimson Rot was a naturally occurring pathogen that Morren's organisation merely studied and developed a treatment for, the staged-epidemic theory collapses and the prosecution's murder-by-plague charge evaporates. He does not need all three to believe this. He needs them to say it. Two of the three have agreed — they have been receiving payments for years through shell accounts that Morren can prove their involvement with, making them far more afraid of the alternative. The third has instead contacted Vel and Director Sela, and then you. They have not agreed. They want to help stop this. [BOSS ENCOUNTER: Morren's testimony-tampering operation — prevent it before two witnesses perjure themselves; also defeat Morren's four bodyguards who have been positioned near the witnesses' residences as implied threats]
turns.choice_a: Move simultaneously on all three witnesses — invoke Ward protection for the willing third, use Astrid's team to intercept Morren's associates near the other two
turns.consequence_a: The willing witness is immediately placed under Ward protection with Astrid's counter-surveillance. Two simultaneous arrested of Morren's implied-threat associates near the other two residences — without the threat, both witnesses are reassessed. One comes over to cooperation. One remains committed to the paid testimony but cannot maintain it under rigorous legal examination. [COMBAT ENCOUNTER 3: Morren's 4 bodyguards, positioned at two residences simultaneously — a multi-location engagement]
turns.choice_b: Use the willing witness's information to build a comprehensive suborning-of-testimony charge that adds to the prosecution rather than merely preventing perjury
turns.consequence_b: The recording of Morren's contact with the two witnesses — obtained through the willing third's cooperation and a monitored contact session Astrid designs — constitutes a second criminal charge of equal seriousness to the original plague engineering. Morren's legal team, facing two watertight charges instead of one contested one, shifts visibly in their approach.

turns.narrative: The testimony tampering is stopped. Morren's final legal strategy has collapsed. The prosecution proceeds on a full evidentiary record including the pathogen engineering documentation, Phoss's protected testimony, the payment records, the staging evidence, the external-partner network, the archive's governance records showing sixty years of proprietary medical protocol capture, and the suborning-of-testimony charges. Morren's legal team makes a final offer: full cooperation and disclosure of the Vethaan Network's medical intelligence operation in exchange for reduced sentencing consideration. The offer is genuine and the information would be significant. Coss is already cooperating fully. The question is whether Morren's cooperation on the Network adds enough value to warrant the reduction his team is seeking.
turns.choice_a: Accept the cooperation deal — the Vethaan Network intelligence is worth the sentencing consideration
turns.consequence_a: Morren's account of the Network's medical intelligence operation is extensive and names six additional principals across two city-states. Astrid calls it 'the single most valuable piece of criminal intelligence I have received in twenty years.' Morren receives a reduced but still very significant sentence.
turns.choice_b: Decline — Morren's evidentiary position is already defeated and cooperation should not be rewarded with leniency for staging an epidemic that killed three hundred people
turns.consequence_b: The prosecution proceeds without Morren's cooperation. It succeeds completely on the existing evidence. His sentence is the maximum the Ward law allows for a Class One public health crime. The Vethaan Network intelligence takes Astrid's team six more months to build independently.

turns.narrative: With Morren sentenced and Coss in a research-cooperation arrangement, the Concordat Epidemiological Research Programme archive becomes the Medical Quarter's most significant immediate asset. Vel — designated as its first operational director — begins the systematic review of what the archive contains. The first month's findings are extraordinary: treatment protocols for eight diseases that currently have no effective treatment in the Ward's medical knowledge. Most are rare. Two are not — one is the primary respiratory illness that kills approximately thirty Ward residents each winter, for which the archive contains a Concordat-era treatment that was never implemented because the Scourge interrupted distribution. Vel's team begins adapting the archive protocol to current Medical Quarter standards. By the following winter, the respiratory treatment is in production. The winter mortality figures, when reviewed the following spring, show a 40% reduction in respiratory-related deaths. Calla, in her patient advocacy role, is one of the first people to receive the adapted treatment when she develops a respiratory infection in December. She recovers completely in four days. She sends Vel a single note: 'Thank you.' Vel is in her office when she receives it. She sits with it for a while before putting it on her desk.
turns.choice_a: Publicly announce the archive's therapeutic applications as a Medical Quarter achievement — the city deserves to know this resource exists
turns.consequence_a: The announcement, carefully managed to emphasise the therapeutic applications without revealing the full archive's scope, produces a significant public health response. Demand for the respiratory treatment exceeds initial projections within two weeks.
turns.choice_b: Develop the archive's treatments through standard Medical Quarter publication channels without a specific announcement — let the clinical results speak without political context
turns.consequence_b: Vel's approach: methodical, peer-reviewed, without fanfare. The respiratory treatment enters clinical practice without most people knowing where it came from. The winter deaths decline. That is the point.

turns.narrative: The Plague-Maker's prosecution is complete. The archive is governed. The counter-treatment is ready. The external network is neutralised. The thirty people who were saved by the early counter-treatment — the ones who contracted a second-wave Rot exposure from residual environmental contamination identified during Vel's post-prosecution cleanup — will never know that the investigation's speed was the difference between their survival and the alternative. Calla has been asked to speak at a Medical Quarter staff session about her role in the referral fee investigation. She declines, politely but firmly, and suggests instead that Vel speak about the systemic reforms. Vel does. The session is attended by three hundred Medical Quarter staff. She does not mention Calla by name, per their agreement. She describes, in precise clinical terms, what happened, how it was found, and what has changed. At the end of the session, every person in the room knows that a nursing aide stopped something very bad with a folder of patient transfer records and a willingness to go outside the normal channels. Nobody needs to know her name. The Medical Thread is complete. [PERMANENT WORLD EFFECTS]
turns.choice_a: Formally commission the Concordat Medical Archive research programme as a permanent Medical Quarter institution
turns.consequence_a: Director Sela establishes the Archive Research Division with Vel as its founding director. Coss joins as a supervised research consultant in year two, having completed their initial custody arrangement. Coss is extraordinarily good at the work. Their research under appropriate governance is genuinely valuable.
turns.choice_b: Trust the archive to the normal operations of the Medical Quarter and step back — the system is good now, it doesn't need more governance
turns.consequence_b: The Medical Quarter performs this work with exactly the competence it has always had when not corrupted. The archive enriches its practice. In three years, three diseases with no previous treatment have effective clinical protocols. In ten years, six more. The work continues.

nationalised_prosecution.description: Full prosecution. Archive under Ward-Medical Quarter governance. Coss in research cooperation. Archive Research Division established.
permanent_world_effects: Medical Quarter has access to Concordat-era treatment protocols for 40+ diseases
Winter respiratory mortality reduced by 40% in first year
Morren Family prosecuted — private medical protocol capture as a business model permanently foreclosed
Calla's patient advocacy function becomes a Medical Quarter permanent institution

Vel's operational record includes a legally ambiguous access action

permanent_world_effects: Prosecution documentation includes player's temporary involvement — a permanent record
Morren still convicted but player's credibility as independent investigator is permanently questioned by some

consequences.item_reward: Morren's Private Keys (access to external network remnants)

kill_plague_maker.description: Morren killed during confrontation. Prosecution impossible. Archive seized under emergency order. Coss in standard custody.
permanent_world_effects: Morren's death prevents full network exposure — some Network connections never identified
Archive governance framework built from scratch without Morren's cooperation
Coss refuses research cooperation following violent resolution

Counter-treatment at broad-spectrum confidence level deployed — 85% effective rate means 15% of cases progress. Forty additional deaths. Morren escapes custody during the crisis. The Concordat archive is seized by the Vethaan Network while the Medical Quarter is occupied with the outbreak.

title: The Whispering Vent
description: Acrid steam and a low-frequency hum emanate from the geothermal vents near the refugee camp, causing migraines and dread.

turns.narrative: The geothermal perimeter is a wasteland of churning white fog and the smell of ionized copper. The hum isn't just a sound; it's a vibration in your marrow, rhythmic and intentional.
turns.choice_a: Scour the vent-edge for residue (Investigation DC 12)
turns.consequence_a: Success: You scrape a violet, pulsing crystal dust from the brass pipes. It feels cold to the touch. (+1 Clue)
turns.choice_b: Hammer iron spikes into the main valve (Strength DC 14)
turns.consequence_b: Success: You force the vibrating metal into silence, though the pressure beneath your feet groans in protest. (+1 Stability)
turns.convergence: The steam pressure begins to scream, the pipes turning a cherry-red from some internal heat source that shouldn't exist.

turns.narrative: A brass conduit buckles, glowing with an inner violet light. The excess heat is melting the stone foundation. The hum has turned into a rhythmic chant.
turns.choice_a: Etch a cooling sigil into the buckling pipe (Arcana DC 13)
turns.consequence_a: Success: The metal cools instantly, the violet glow receding into its core. (+1 Resource)
turns.choice_b: Divert the flow to the Auxiliary Siphon (Intelligence DC 12)
turns.consequence_b: Success: You reroute the superheated steam into a secondary reservoir, buying the camp time. (+1 Stability)
turns.convergence: A hidden access hatch in the floor pops open, forced by the sheer pressure of the subterranean chanting.

turns.narrative: The hatch leads into a damp stone throat. Down here, the 'vibrations' are clearly words—a repetitive, guttural invocation of 'The Weaver of the Deep'.
turns.choice_a: Decipher the frequency (Insight DC 14)
turns.consequence_a: Success: You recognize the pattern as a locator spell, targeted at the camp's main heart-stone. (+1 Clue)
turns.choice_b: Flood the chamber with alchemist's fire
turns.consequence_b: Hazard: The explosion is massive in the confined space, singeing your gear. (-5 HP)
turns.convergence: The path opens into a cathedral-like cavern carved from solid salt and obsidian.

turns.narrative: In the center of the cavern, a jagged shard of 'Void-Glass' is embedded in a pedestal of bone. It pulses with the same violet light you saw above.
turns.choice_a: Extract the shard with silver tongs (Sleight of Hand DC 15)
turns.consequence_a: Success: You safely extract the Void-Glass, though its weight feels far heavier than its size. (+1 Item)
turns.choice_b: Shatter the glass with a heavy strike (Attack AC 14)
turns.consequence_b: Success: The glass shatters into harmless dust, releasing a wave of psychic relief. (+100 XP)
turns.convergence: The cavern begins to mourn; the obsidian walls crack as the anchor is removed.

turns.narrative: The cracking walls reveal a tunnel slick with bioluminescent ichor. At the end of it, a shrine of silk and teeth awaits.
turns.choice_a: Ghost through the shadows (Stealth DC 13)
turns.consequence_a: Success: You reach the shrine's flank unseen, noting the ritual daggers laid out. (+1 Tactical Adv)
turns.choice_b: Kick in the silk tapestries
turns.consequence_b: Failure: The chimes attached to the silk alert the keeper. Combat is immediate.
turns.convergence: A hooded figure, his skin replaced by shimmering chitin, rises from the central altar.

turns.narrative: The Cultist of the Weaver holds a notebook of shifting leather. His eyes are milky, seeing into the frequencies rather than the light.
turns.choice_a: Snatch the notebook mid-ritual (Sleight of Hand DC 13)
turns.consequence_a: Success: You take the book; its pages contain sketches of Emberheart's defenses. (+1 Lore)
turns.choice_b: Topple the brazier onto the tapestries
turns.consequence_b: Success: The sacred silk burns, blinding the creature and boosting camp morale. (+1 Morale)
turns.convergence: The chitin-bound cultist unsheathes a blade of serrated bone.

turns.narrative: The creature moves with spider-like speed, its blade whistling through the thick, salt-heavy air.
turns.choice_a: Focus on the joints (Dex Save DC 13)
turns.consequence_a: Success: You sidestep the lunge and strike the vulnerable gap in its chitin. (+Damage)
