title: The Frozen Moment
location: North Ward — 'The Chronal Pint' tavern and its extended temporal field

npcs.name: Barkeep Luda Fell
npcs.description: The Chronal Pint's proprietor, caught mid-pour at the start of the loop, aware of the loop (she has experienced it approximately 4,000 times), exhausted in a way that transcends physical tiredness. She can communicate between iterations but cannot act outside a 3-second window.

npcs.name: The Loop Echo
npcs.description: A temporal duplicate of one party member — specifically the one who has most recently touched the Liquid Chronos sample, or failing that, the one with the highest Arcana score. The Echo is not malicious; it is a causal artifact of the loop's repeated exposure to the same person's decision moment. It defends the loop's integrity because that is what causal loops do.

npcs.name: Investigator Soli Yan
npcs.description: Chronos-thread investigator who has been monitoring the Chronal Pint since the loop began 9 days ago. She has tried and failed to enter the loop field three times — it ejects entities that haven't been inside when the loop folded. She briefs the party outside and will debrief afterward.

description: The Chronal Pint tavern in the North Ward has been stuck in a 3-second loop for nine days. From outside: the tavern's windows show the same moment of activity repeating endlessly — patrons frozen at the exact position they occupied when the loop folded. From inside (Investigator Yan's one successful entry, two years before the loop began, allows her to confirm): the people inside are conscious, aware, and experiencing subjective time — each 3-second loop passes as a full subjective second for them, meaning the loop's nineteen affected patrons have experienced approximately 140 subjective hours of conscious existence in the same 3-second moment. They are exhausted, frightened, and Barkeep Luda Fell has been counting loops: she is at approximately 4,200 and stopping. The party must enter the loop, find the causal artifact that created it (an old Concordat chronal instrument dropped during the original 3 seconds), and break the cycle — while surviving the Loop Echo's defense of the timeline.
mechanics: Arcana (identify the loop's causal mechanism; locate the chronal instrument; interact with Loop Echo)
Investigation (search the frozen tavern for the causal artifact)
Persuasion (communicate with Luda Fell across loop iterations; potentially negotiate with the Loop Echo)
Insight (understand the Loop Echo's defensive logic — it can be reasoned with if the party understands what it is protecting)
Combat (Loop Echo — Medium encounter; has mirror copies of the party member's abilities at 75% effectiveness)

permanent_effects.effect: settlement_morale +2; 19 patrons released from 140+ subjective hours of temporal imprisonment; Chronal Pint reopens
Key Chronos thread artifact added to party inventory

turns.narrative: Investigator Soli Yan meets the party at the north entrance to the Chronal Pint's street. The tavern looks normal except for its absolute stillness — no smoke from the chimney, no sound, a quality of frozen presence that is immediately unsettling to anyone with Arcana. She has been monitoring it for nine days on Chronos thread assignment. What she knows: the loop began at 8:14 PM nine days ago during a normal evening service. Nineteen people inside. The loop is 3.2 seconds of objective temporal duration, repeating continuously. Inside the loop, subjective time passes differently — she estimates the occupants are experiencing approximately one subjective second per objective loop cycle. That means they have experienced approximately 140 hours of conscious awareness within the same 3.2-second window. She has tried to enter three times. Each attempt ejects her at the loop boundary. She believes the loop will accept people who weren't there when it formed, under one condition: they must cross the threshold during the 0.4-second window at the loop's peak resonance point.
turns.choice_a: Ask Yan for everything she knows before entering
turns.consequence_a: She provides: loop peak resonance occurs every 40 seconds (precisely timed by her watch). The tavern's interior geometry will be frozen at loop-moment state. The Concordat chronal instrument she suspects as the cause is a handheld calibration device — roughly book-sized, copper-silver casing — that was being examined by a patron at the bar when the loop folded. She doesn't know where it landed.
turns.choice_b: Enter immediately on the next resonance peak
turns.consequence_b: You cross the threshold. The loop interior snaps around you. The 3.2-second cycle begins — you have approximately 3 seconds of objective time per cycle, with the subjective experience of those 3 seconds stretching as you acclimate.
turns.convergence: The party crosses the loop threshold during the resonance peak. The Chronal Pint's interior is visible — frozen mid-motion, patrons caught in every position of an ordinary evening.

turns.narrative: Inside the loop, physics is almost normal but not quite. The 3.2-second cycle resets the physical state of everything that was in the original moment — objects return to their loop-start position, spilled drinks un-spill, a chair mid-fall rights itself. But the party, as entities that entered after the loop formed, are exo-loop. They do not reset. They accumulate: each cycle they retain memory and physical state while everything else returns to start. The 19 patrons are aware and unresetting too — they're also exo-loop by virtue of long-term exposure. Luda Fell is behind the bar, mid-pour, glass tilted. Each cycle she is returned to that position — but her eyes are alert and exhausted. She is watching you come in. When the cycle resets and you appear again in her field of view, she mouthing something toward you. It takes three cycles to parse: 'It's under the third booth.'
turns.choice_a: Go immediately to the third booth
turns.consequence_a: Investigation check DC 11 (low, because you know where to look). Under the booth's table: a copper-silver device, handbook-sized, wedged against the wall where it slid when dropped. Active — faintly luminescent, radiating the loop's causal field.
turns.choice_b: Communicate with Luda Fell more fully before moving
turns.consequence_b: Over 8-10 cycles you piece together: the device was brought in by a patron (now caught mid-reach at booth three), was being examined, was dropped when someone jostled the table. Luda knew what it was — she has seen Chronos instruments before. She saw it activate when it hit the floor. She says: 'Don't touch it directly. Use something non-conductive.'
turns.convergence: The Concordat chronal instrument's location is confirmed. Approaching it reveals the challenge: the Loop Echo is already aware of your approach.

turns.narrative: The Loop Echo materializes between the party and the third booth on the cycle after you identify the device's location. It is a perfect duplicate of one party member — rendered in slightly translucent blue-copper tones, moving with mirror-image precision of the original. It does not speak. It places itself between you and the device and adopts a defensive position. Arcana DC 13 identifies what this is: a causal feedback construct — the loop has been processing the same decision-moment for 9 days using the temporal energy of the instrument. The Echo is the loop's 'correct decision' outcome given physical form — it represents what would have happened in the timeline the loop is trying to preserve. It defends the device because the loop's integrity requires the device to remain active. If the device is deactivated, the Echo ceases to exist. This is not malice — it is the logical behavior of a causal artifact.
turns.choice_a: Attempt to communicate with the Echo — it shares the party member's reasoning, so it may be persuadable
turns.consequence_a: The Echo understands language. Insight DC 14 to find the right framing: 'The loop's preservation is causing harm to nineteen people who have experienced 140 hours of imprisonment. Dissolution of the loop is the correct causal outcome.' The Echo is still for two cycles. Then it shifts — not attacking, not defending, waiting. The argument has registered.
turns.choice_b: Engage the Echo in combat to clear the path to the device
turns.consequence_b: Combat begins. The Echo has the originating party member's ability scores at 75% effectiveness and copies their combat style. It cannot be damaged by the originating party member (causal duplication protection) — other party members must deal damage. At 0 HP, the Echo dissipates into the loop field.
turns.convergence: The Echo is either reasoned with or defeated. The path to the chronal instrument is open.

turns.narrative: If the Echo was persuaded: it does something unusual. It picks up an object from the bar — a simple cloth — and holds it out toward the party. Luda Fell's earlier instruction: 'Don't touch it directly. Use something non-conductive.' The Echo is providing the implementation detail for its own dissolution. It understands what the correct outcome is and is cooperating with it. When the cloth is accepted, the Echo fades to near-invisible — still present but no longer defensive. This is one of the more strange moments in the Chronos thread: a temporal artifact helping to end itself because the logic of doing so is correct. Arcana DC 15 to operate the chronal device using the cloth as insulation — preventing the loop field from using the party as additional causal anchors.
turns.choice_a: Deactivate the device carefully, following the Echo's implicit guidance
turns.consequence_a: Arcana DC 15. On success: the device deactivates cleanly. The loop field collapses. The 3.2-second moment completes and allows time to resume. The Echo dissipates with what Insight DC 12 identifies as something functionally equivalent to relief.
turns.choice_b: Attempt to extract the device active and intact — study it before deactivating
turns.consequence_b: Arcana DC 17 to extract without triggering a loop-collapse event. On success: device preserved active (extremely valuable research artifact). On failure: the loop collapses uncontrolled — a rough exit that deals 2d8 temporal recoil damage to all exo-loop entities.
turns.convergence: The chronal instrument's fate is determined. Deactivation or extraction — either ends the loop.

turns.narrative: Loop collapse: time resumes in the Chronal Pint with a sound like a held breath releasing. The 19 patrons — who have been experiencing conscious awareness for 140 subjective hours within 3.2 seconds — complete their original motions. Several stumble. One sits down on the floor and does not get up immediately. Luda Fell completes her pour; the glass fills; she sets it down with the careful deliberateness of someone doing it for the 4,200th and last time. She looks at the party without theatrical expression. She has been waiting to look at a face that wasn't looped for nine objective days and 140 subjective hours. She says, very quietly: 'I knew the loop count. Four thousand two hundred and thirty-seven. I kept counting so I'd have something to do.' A pause. 'Would someone like to order a drink?'
turns.choice_a: Stay and help the patrons recover; some are in significant distress
turns.consequence_a: Medicine and Persuasion checks over the following 2 hours assist the most affected patrons. Two of the nineteen need additional medical support. Dr. Solt (if she is a contact) can be summoned. The party's presence during the recovery is noted by all nineteen survivors.
turns.choice_b: Exit and debrief with Investigator Yan immediately — the causal mechanism needs to be understood
turns.consequence_b: Yan gets immediate access to the party's first-hand account. Her analysis of the instrument and their description of the Echo is extremely valuable for the Chronos thread investigation. She is composed and grateful at the same time.
turns.convergence: Investigator Yan meets the party at the door. She has been watching the external manifestation of the collapse from the street. She says: 'Nine days. I was outside for nine days.' She doesn't say more for a moment.

turns.narrative: Investigator Yan's debrief: the chronal instrument the party recovered is identifiable from Chronos Division records she has compiled. It is a Concordat temporal calibration device — used by the Chronos Division to synchronize localized time fields during infrastructure construction. There were several dozen produced. All were supposed to be decommissioned at the end of the Reconstruction Era. This one wasn't. She traces its provenance from existing records: it was last logged in a Chronos Division archive 190 years ago, then disappeared from records. It appeared in this tavern in the hands of a patron who bought it from a used-goods dealer in the Academic Quarter three weeks ago. The dealer doesn't have records of where they acquired it. But Yan's timeline of 'appeared in circulation 3 weeks ago' aligns with the Squeaker-Box reactivation event from EH_SQ_072: approximately the same period that Vane began interacting with active Concordat systems.
turns.choice_a: Provide Yan with everything the party knows about Vane and the Concordat system reactivation timeline
turns.consequence_a: Yan processes this rapidly. She connects Vane's mana-grid relay booster (from EH_SQ_077 if the party found it) to the Chronal Pint's location directly above the booster's signal origin. The temporal loop was not a accident from the instrument — the instrument was activated by the booster signal. Vane's transmissions through the North Ward mana-junction have been causing temporal disturbances as a side effect.
turns.choice_b: Share partial information — let Yan develop her analysis from the instrument alone
turns.consequence_b: Yan's analysis reaches the instrument-as-active-artifact conclusion but without the Vane connection. She will develop it independently within 2 weeks. The party leads the investigation by that margin.
turns.convergence: The Chronal Pint's loop is understood: Vane's mana-grid transmissions are causing temporal side effects in the North Ward. The mana-junction beneath the Chronal Pint is directly linked.

turns.narrative: Luda Fell's testimony, taken formally over the following day: she recognized the instrument when the patron brought it in to show at the bar. She has seen one before. Her grandmother — a North Ward resident in the previous generation — had a similar device. 'She used to say it was a legacy piece. From the family that used to work the North Ward infrastructure.' Luda's family name is Fell. The Concordat Chronos Division, according to Yan's records, had a roster of maintenance technicians. The records are partial, but one name appears repeatedly in North Ward infrastructure logs: a senior technician named Arda Fell. Luda Fell is the descendant of a Concordat Chronos Division technician. The instrument that caused the loop may have passed through her family for 200 years before someone sold it.
turns.choice_a: Tell Luda who her grandmother's family was
turns.consequence_a: Luda is quiet for a long time. 'So the thing that trapped me in a 3-second loop for nine days was my own family's equipment.' She considers this. 'That is extremely my family.' She becomes a willing source of any other family-legacy items she knows of. There are two more, kept in storage.
turns.choice_b: Keep the family connection as intelligence for the Chronos thread investigation
turns.consequence_b: The Fell family connection is documented but not disclosed to Luda. The two additional stored items are not immediately surfaced.
turns.convergence: The Fell family legacy represents an unexpected human thread through the Concordat infrastructure story.

turns.narrative: The mana-junction beneath the Chronal Pint — flagged in both the EH_SQ_077 infrastructure assessment and Yan's independent analysis — requires direct examination. With Fen Moss's cooperation (if available) or by identifying the access point independently, the party descends into the North Ward mana-junction. It is older than the Market Ward B-7 tunnels: deeper, cooler, with Concordat ceramic channels that are much more active — the warmth Fen described as 'normal for old sections' is much more pronounced here. The signal relay booster (if not already disabled in EH_SQ_077) is present: a Concordat-era device installed in the Chronos Division's original infrastructure, recently serviced, transmitting on the V.A. protocol header. The Concordat temporal calibration device (if active) resonates with the booster signal. They were designed to work together.
turns.choice_a: Disable the relay booster — stop Vane's transmissions at this junction
turns.consequence_a: The North Ward temporal disturbances stop. No more items like the Chronal Pint instrument will be accidentally activated by the booster signal. Vane loses the North Ward mana-junction relay. He is aware within 24 hours that the junction has been taken offline.
turns.choice_b: Leave the booster active and monitored
turns.consequence_b: Intelligence collection asset. Arcana DC 18 over multiple sessions can trace transmission direction. Risk: future temporal disturbances in the North Ward until Vane changes routing.
turns.convergence: The mana-junction's role in the Vane-timeline is either cut or preserved as a monitoring point.

turns.narrative: The chronal instrument — now recovered and either active or deactivated — is examined fully by Yan with Arcana support from the party. It is a temporal field calibrator: designed to create small, stable localized time-rate adjustments for infrastructure construction purposes. Not a loop creator — the loop was a malfunction caused by the device being dropped and activated simultaneously by the booster signal, creating an unintended causal resonance. The instrument itself, properly calibrated and used, can create a 15-minute localized temporal field: slowing time 10% in a 10-foot radius. Which, as Yan notes with a rare half-smile, is 'not a weapon, not a medical device, not a narrative device — it's a construction tool that happens to have limited utility if you want time to pass slightly slower near you for about a quarter hour.' Still, extraordinary. Still, 200 years old and functional.
turns.choice_a: Keep the instrument for party use
turns.consequence_a: The Loop-Breaker Pendant (reshaped from the device into a wearable form that prevents accidental activation) is added to party loot. Usable 1/day for a 15-minute 10% time-rate reduction field in 10-foot radius.
turns.choice_b: Turn the instrument over to Yan for Chronos thread research
turns.consequence_b: Yan can use it to better understand the temporal disturbance signature patterns, giving the Chronos thread investigation advantage on all future checks related to Concordat temporal side effects. Party receives 1000 gold as research compensation.
turns.convergence: The instrument's disposition is resolved. The Chronos thread now has a clear line between Vane's signal transmissions and North Ward temporal anomalies.

turns.narrative: The 19 Chronal Pint patrons — in the days after the loop break — display an unexpected phenomenon: three of them have developed a minor persistent ability to detect temporal field boundaries, a vestigial effect of 140 subjective hours of existence within an active causal loop. It is not reliable, not controllable, and for two of them, manifests only as mild nausea near active Concordat temporal equipment. For the third — a young woman named Pell Dorsen who was at the bar reading — it manifests as a consistent ability to accurately estimate time durations within 5 seconds, even without checking a clock. She reports it 'feels like I'm still inside the loop, a little bit. Like time is something I can see from slightly outside it now.' Dr. Solt documents this as 'Temporal Imprint Syndrome — benign, indefinite, under observation.'
turns.choice_a: Recruit Pell Dorsen as a Chronos thread contact — her temporal perception may be useful
turns.consequence_a: Pell agrees. She has also, in her post-loop experience, noticed that the temporal disturbances in the North Ward happen on a schedule — every 23 minutes, a slight shift. That matches Vane's transmission schedule exactly. She's been feeling his transmissions without knowing what they were.
turns.choice_b: Document the phenomenon but don't pursue Pell
turns.consequence_b: The temporal imprint phenomenon is documented for Yan's research. Three data points established for future study.
turns.convergence: The loop's aftermath has produced unexpected new information about Vane's transmission schedule through human perception.

turns.narrative: Luda Fell's two stored family legacy items: a compass that always points toward the nearest active Concordat temporal field (an original Chronos Division navigation tool) and a sealed letter, sealed with the same geometric lock pattern from the Concordat maintenance hatches, addressed in pre-Scourge Common to 'Whoever finds this after enough time has passed.' Luda has had the letter for twenty years and never been able to open it. The geometric lock is now recognizable — the party opens it. The letter is from Arda Fell, Concordat Chronos Division, dated from before the Scourge. It is addressed to their descendants. It explains, in personal terms, what the Chronos Division was doing — managing and stabilizing the temporal side effects of the copper-tail relay network's mana-grid interactions. The copper-tail sensor network and the Chronos infrastructure were always linked, maintained together, by different divisions of the same institution.
turns.choice_a: Share the letter with Investigator Yan
turns.consequence_a: Yan reads it with the expression of someone receiving confirmation of what they suspected but couldn't prove. 'So the Chronos Division and the Biological Division were counterparts. One built the sensor network. The other managed what it did to time.' She pauses. 'That means there should be more temporal stabilizers like the one under the Chronal Pint, throughout the city, wherever the relay network is active.'
turns.choice_b: Keep the letter — it is a family document belonging to Luda
turns.consequence_b: Luda decides what to share with Yan after reading it herself. She shares it, because she believes her grandmother would have wanted the information to reach people who could use it.
turns.convergence: The Fell letter establishes that the temporal disturbances throughout the North Ward are not accidents — they are the predictable result of the copper-tail relay network operating without its paired Chronos Division stabilization infrastructure.

turns.narrative: Three weeks after the Chronal Pint reopens, Luda Fell reports she's had the best two weeks of trade since she opened the tavern. Curious citizens, temporal scholars, and Chronos-thread associated individuals have all been stopping by, ordering drinks, and asking her what it felt like. She answers honestly every time: 'Like being very present in a very small forever.' The North Ward's ambient temporal field is slightly more stable since the loop break — Yan's monitoring shows a 12% reduction in micro-temporal variance in the block surrounding the Chronal Pint. The mana-junction booster's status (cut or monitored) determines whether Vane's transmissions continue to generate that variance elsewhere in the ward. The Chronal Pint becomes an informal meeting point for Chronos-thread investigation participants. Luda starts keeping a record book: people who come in, dates and times, and whether they notice anything unusual. She has been counting since the loop. It turns out she likes counting things.
turns.choice_a: Make the Chronal Pint the Chronos thread investigation's informal base
turns.consequence_a: Luda becomes a recurring NPC intelligence hub. Her record book eventually contains something important. Investigators, the party, and Pell Dorsen all use the tavern as a meeting point.
turns.choice_b: Let the Chronal Pint return to being a normal tavern
turns.consequence_b: The tavern normalizes. Luda is grateful but not a recurring resource. The party's investigation uses other meeting points.
turns.convergence: Quest complete. The loop is broken. The Fell family legacy has contributed three Concordat items and a family history to the Chronos thread. Vane's transmission schedule is known. The temporal stabilizer map — implied by the letter — is the next major Chronos thread investigative goal.

conclusion: The Frozen Moment breaks the nine-day loop, releases 19 imprisoned residents, recovers three Concordat Chronos Division artifacts from the Fell family, and establishes the critical link between Vane's mana-grid transmissions and the North Ward temporal disturbances. Investigator Yan and Luda Fell become recurring Chronos thread NPCs. The Fell letter reveals the Chronos Division and Biological Division were always paired infrastructure — setting up EH_SQ_066 through EH_SQ_069.
loot_table: Loop-Breaker Pendant (Concordat temporal calibration device reshaped into wearable form; 1/day creates a 10-foot radius 15-minute field of 10% time-rate reduction; prevents the wearer from being anchored in causal loops without consent)

Arda Fell's Letter (pre-Scourge document from a Chronos Division technician; establishes that Chronos and Biological Divisions always maintained paired infrastructure; implies temporal stabilizers exist throughout the city near relay network nodes)

Temporal Imprint Data (Yan's documentation of three Chronal Pint patrons showing vestigial temporal perception after loop exposure; Pell Dorsen's transmission-schedule perception data; Arcana research value)

loop_echo_persuaded.description: Loop Echo reasoned with; cooperated in its own dissolution; deactivation clean

consequences.permanent_effect: No temporal recoil damage; Echo dissipates with recorded 'resolution' state; future causal loops in the area have a lower difficulty threshold due to established precedent in the local temporal field

loop_echo_defeated.description: Loop Echo defeated in combat; loop ended by force

consequences.permanent_effect: Temporal recoil 1d8 to all exo-loop entities; loop ends; Echo logged as combat encounter rather than resolved causal construct

risk_matrix.penalty: Uncontrolled loop collapse: 2d8 temporal recoil damage to all party members; the chronal instrument is destroyed in the collapse; the loop breaks but the temporal field damage to the North Ward mana-junction worsens, accelerating the temporal disturbance pattern by 30%
risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed with minor consequences.

title: The Time-Debt Collector
unlock_conditions: Complete SQ-06 and possess a Liquid Chronos sample
location: North Ward streets, primarily the residential and commercial blocks above the Chronos Division infrastructure zone

npcs.name: The Debt-Taker
npcs.description: A temporal parasite entity — not a creature in the biological sense but a localized temporal field anomaly that has evolved goal-directed behavior over an unknown period. It has developed the capacity to identify and claim 'time owed' — specifically, time that was borrowed from the natural temporal flow by Concordat temporal interventions and never returned. The 'debt' it collects is real: the temporal interventions of the Concordat Chronos Division left imbalances. The Debt-Taker is collecting them.

npcs.name: Investigator Soli Yan
npcs.description: Already investigating the aging complaints in the North Ward. She has a working model of the Debt-Taker but cannot interact with it directly — her Chronos Division credentials (inherited from study, not employment) make her a larger target. She provides intelligence, Liquid Chronos antidote protocols, and is genuinely afraid.

npcs.name: Maret Torven
npcs.description: A dockworker in his 40s who aged 15 years in three days. He is now physically 57-equivalent, confused, and frightened. His family is around him. He has no idea why this happened. He was in the right place when the Debt-Taker passed. The aging has stabilized but will not reverse without the Liquid Chronos treatment.

description: Citizens in the North Ward are aging rapidly and without explanation — fifteen years in three days for Maret Torven; twelve years in two days for two others. Investigator Yan's working model: a temporal parasite entity (the Debt-Taker) is claiming the 'temporal debt' left by Concordat Chronos Division interventions — time that was borrowed from the future to stabilize infrastructure during the Reconstruction Era and never repaid. The debt is real and the people paying it are those with genetic descendance from Concordat-era North Ward residents, or anyone in the temporal field vicinity of a major Debt-collection event. The Liquid Chronos sample, properly applied, can restore the stolen time. The party must find and confront the Debt-Taker, restore the victims, and address the underlying problem: the temporal debt that draws it to the North Ward is embedded in the infrastructure.
mechanics: Arcana (identify, track, and interact with the Debt-Taker temporal field)
Medicine (apply Liquid Chronos treatment to restore aging victims)
Investigation (map the debt-collection events to the Chronos Division infrastructure zones)
Combat (The Debt-Taker — Medium encounter, temporal field entity with time-steal attack)
History (understand the Concordat temporal debt mechanism)

permanent_effects.effect: settlement_morale +2; aging victims restored; North Ward temporal debt imbalance addressed temporarily

permanent_effects.trigger: Temporal debt partially addressed at infrastructure level
permanent_effects.effect: settlement_stability +1; Debt-Taker cannot return to North Ward for at least 6 months

turns.narrative: Yan's briefing, urgent: four confirmed victims in the North Ward over six days. Ages: 15 years, 12 years, 8 years, 22 years. All in public spaces, all in the same 6-block radius, all with no Concordat connection they are aware of. The first victim is Maret Torven, now physically 57-equivalent in a body that was 42 a week ago. He is ambulatory but confused. His family's physician says the aging is structural — not cosmetic, not a spell, not resolvable by conventional medicine. Yan's research: the Concordat Chronos Division's infrastructure work in the North Ward created measurable temporal debt — time-rate adjustments that stabilized the area during Reconstruction but were never neutralized. The Debt-Taker is not attacking people. It is collecting what it is owed. The people it collects from are incidental vessels — they happen to be present when a debt point pulses.
turns.choice_a: Ask Yan to identify the specific infrastructure debt points so you can map the Debt-Taker's likely path
turns.consequence_a: She has a partial map from Chronos Division records modified by Pell Dorsen's transmission timing data (if that resource is available). The debt points cluster around six locations, all above the Chronos Division's original infrastructure zone. The Debt-Taker visits them on a cycle.
turns.choice_b: Go immediately to Maret Torven and begin antidote preparation
turns.consequence_b: Medicine DC 13 to prepare the Liquid Chronos treatment for Maret's specific aging profile. Treatment will take 3 hours and requires the Liquid Chronos sample. Maret is restorable. The Debt-Taker is still active while you treat him.
turns.convergence: Yan says: 'The Liquid Chronos can restore the victims. But until the Debt-Taker is dispersed, it will make more.'

turns.narrative: Tracking the Debt-Taker: it is not visible to unaided sight. Arcana DC 13 reveals it as a mobile temporal pressure gradient — a region approximately 8 feet in diameter where time-rate is slightly accelerated, manifesting as a faint shimmer and an instinctive sense of urgency in anyone nearby. Animals avoid it instinctively; the copper-tail relay network, if any active units are in the area, exhibits erratic signal interference when the Debt-Taker passes. Pell Dorsen's transmission timing data (if available) shows the Debt-Taker's movement correlates with Vane's transmission schedule — the transmissions perturb the temporal debt infrastructure and cause the Debt-Taker to activate. It is not Vane's weapon. It is an unintended consequence of his transmissions triggering old debt-collection mechanisms.
turns.choice_a: Set up an observation point at the most active debt-point location and wait for the Debt-Taker
turns.consequence_a: 4-6 hour wait. During the wait, Yan conducts additional victim outreach — two more North Ward residents report mild temporal pressure symptoms (not yet full aging, but the 'urgency' sensation). The Debt-Taker arrives on schedule. You are positioned.
turns.choice_b: Follow the copper-tail interference trail dynamically — track the Debt-Taker as it moves
turns.consequence_b: Investigation DC 14 to maintain tracking. On success: you intercept the Debt-Taker mid-route, choosing the engagement ground. On failure: it reaches the next debt point first and completes a minor collection before you arrive.
turns.convergence: The Debt-Taker is located. The confrontation is about to begin.

turns.narrative: The Debt-Taker confrontation: it does not engage aggressively. As a temporal field entity, it does not have aggression in the biological sense — it has directionality. When the party enters its field boundary (the 15-foot radius of accelerated time-rate), time passes faster for them: each of their turns within the field has a 50% chance of aging the affected character by 1d4 years (Constitution save DC 14 negates). The entity moves toward the next debt point on its schedule unless stopped. It can be dispersed with: concentrated Arcana disruption (DC 16 while in the field, requires 3 successful checks across different rounds), Liquid Chronos applied to the entity rather than a victim (DC 14 Arcana, uses one dose), or by destroying the debt-point infrastructure node it is currently approaching (permanent but removes the infrastructure from the area).
turns.choice_a: Disperse the Debt-Taker using Liquid Chronos applied directly to it
turns.consequence_a: Arcana DC 14. One dose consumed. The Liquid Chronos interacts with the temporal field, restoring the debt imbalance the field is claiming — the Debt-Taker's directive is partially fulfilled by the restoration. It disperses. Does not return to North Ward for 6 months.
turns.choice_b: Concentrate Arcana disruption across three rounds
turns.consequence_b: 3 rounds of Arcana DC 16, risking 1d4 year aging each round if the save fails. On third success: the entity's coherence collapses. Does not return for 3 months (less permanent than the Liquid Chronos method).
turns.convergence: The Debt-Taker is dispersed. The immediate danger is over. The debt that drew it will return eventually unless the infrastructure is addressed.

turns.narrative: Victim restoration: with the Debt-Taker dispersed, the party has time to treat all four confirmed victims. Maret Torven first, as the most severely affected. The Liquid Chronos treatment — applied with Medicine DC 13 — reverses the aging structurally. Maret loses 15 physical years of aging over two hours, returning to his correct biological state. He is exhausted and bewildered but fundamentally healthy. He has no memory of the event other than a brief period of 'feeling very old.' The treatment for the other three victims follows similarly. The Liquid Chronos sample, if the party started with one dose, is consumed across the four treatments — it requires careful titration (Medicine DC 11 for the three less-severe cases, DC 13 for Maret). Running out of doses mid-treatment before all victims are treated is a risk if the sample was small.
turns.choice_a: Treat all four victims immediately using the available Liquid Chronos sample
turns.consequence_a: All four restored. Sample fully consumed. The party's Liquid Chronos resource is depleted. This will require sourcing more for future Chronos thread events.
turns.choice_b: Treat the two most severely affected and ration the sample for future use
turns.consequence_b: Maret and the 12-year victim are restored. The two less-severe cases are partially treated (aging reduced by 50%) and will continue recovering naturally. No guarantee of full recovery without more sample.
turns.convergence: The victims are treated. Yan makes formal notes on each treatment for Chronos Division protocol documentation.

turns.narrative: The underlying problem: the temporal debt exists in the North Ward's Chronos Division infrastructure, and the Debt-Taker will return as long as the debt is not addressed. Yan's assessment: fully resolving the debt requires either neutralizing the infrastructure debt-points (destroying or properly decommissioning the Concordat temporal adjustment nodes that created the debt) or generating an equivalent amount of temporal 'credit' through a controlled temporal intervention using Chronos Division protocols. The first option removes the debt but also removes the temporal stabilization the debt-points provide — Concordat infrastructure intended to suppress temporal side effects of the relay network. The second option is technically possible but requires a Chronos Division operator, which no one alive claims to be.
turns.choice_a: Neutralize the debt-points — accept the loss of temporal stabilization
turns.consequence_a: Engineering and Arcana checks (DC 14 each, six checks for six nodes). The debt is cleared. The Debt-Taker cannot return. The temporal stabilization is lost — North Ward temporal disturbances from Vane's transmissions will be more significant going forward.
turns.choice_b: Attempt to generate temporal credit using Concordat protocols and the recovered Chronal instrument
turns.consequence_b: Arcana DC 18 and the Loop-Breaker Pendant (or active chronal instrument). On success: the temporal credit balances the debt. Debt-points remain. Debt-Taker cannot return for 12 months and the stabilization infrastructure stays intact. On failure: a minor temporal field collapse in one node, aging 1d6 years to everyone within 20 feet.
turns.convergence: The temporal debt treatment is applied. The Debt-Taker's return timeline is set.

turns.narrative: Yan produces, from her archived research, the Chronal Ledger: a Concordat Chronos Division record that listed every temporal intervention made during the Reconstruction Era and the projected 'repayment' schedules for the temporal debt incurred. It is an extraordinary document — 200 years old, detailing dozens of temporal interventions across EmberHeart, most of which have already been naturally resolved by the passage of time. But twelve interventions in the North Ward remain unresolved. These twelve are the debt-points the Debt-Taker has been servicing. The Ledger also contains, in the projections column, an estimated 'danger threshold' for each debt-point — the point at which unresolved debt would begin causing autonomous collection events. Most of the twelve are past their threshold. The Debt-Taker arrived exactly on schedule.
turns.choice_a: Take the Chronal Ledger as primary evidence of the temporal debt situation
turns.consequence_a: The Ledger is one of the most important Chronos thread artifacts: a complete accounting of the ResConstruction Era temporal debts, their locations, and their timelines. Some locations have implications for threads outside the North Ward.
turns.choice_b: Let Yan retain the Ledger for official Chronos thread investigation purposes
turns.consequence_b: The Ledger stays with the investigation. Yan will share findings as they develop and the party has full access, but institutional rather than personal control.
turns.convergence: The Chronal Ledger, regardless of custody, is now part of the active Chronos thread investigation.

turns.narrative: Maret Torven, restored to his correct biological age, has a conversation with the party that he requested. He is not angry — he is curious. He wants to understand what happened to him. The party's explanation, calibrated to whatever the player chooses to share, is his first encounter with the concept that the city he lives in was built by an institution that made time-loans to stabilize it and then disappeared, leaving the debts uncollected for 200 years. His response: 'So the city owes time, and I paid some of it by accident.' He sits with this for a moment. 'That seems like the sort of thing people should know about.' He is a dockworker. He is not educated in temporal theory. He has absolutely no way to further this investigation independently. He just felt that naming the injustice was important.
turns.choice_a: Tell Maret everything — including Vane, the relay network, the Biological Division, the full picture
turns.consequence_a: Maret is not equipped to do anything with this information practically. But he tells seven people over the next two weeks, in the clear vernacular of a dockworker explaining something unfair to friends. The story spreads in the North Ward in simplified but accurate form. Popular awareness of 'the city's time debt' increases. This has political implications.
turns.choice_b: Tell Maret the minimum that explains what happened to him without broader context
turns.consequence_b: Maret understands his specific experience but not the larger picture. He is satisfied with the explanation. The political spread of information is controlled.
turns.convergence: Maret Torven is not a high-status NPC. He is a useful reality check — the first ordinary person who directly experienced and then understood the consequences of a 200-year-old infrastructure decision.

turns.narrative: Yan and the party pool findings: the Debt-Taker is dispersed, the victims are restored, the Chronal Ledger is in evidence, and the debt-point infrastructure is either neutralized or credited. The next threat on the Chronos thread is the temporal debt in locations outside the North Ward — the Ledger lists three interventions south of the Industrial Quarter and two in the High Ward. If those debt-points are also past threshold, the Debt-Taker (or a similar entity) will appear there eventually. Yan's recommendation: establish a monitoring protocol. This requires more Liquid Chronos — the existing sample was consumed in restoration. The primary source of Liquid Chronos is the Chronos thread's existing supply, which Yan has limited access to. Alternatively, the Concordat temporal calibration device (Loop-Breaker Pendant) can be used to produce a small amount if properly operated — Arcana DC 16, produces 2 doses per week.
turns.choice_a: Establish a monitoring protocol and invest in Liquid Chronos production via the calibration device
turns.consequence_a: Weekly Liquid Chronos production (2 doses) becomes available if the party maintains one session of Arcana work per week. The monitoring protocol flags debt-point activity. Settlement stability +1 from the proactive management.
turns.choice_b: Advise Yan to establish institutional monitoring; this is a city-level problem
turns.consequence_b: Yan escalates to the City Administration. Institutional response is slow (3-4 weeks before resources are committed) but eventually more comprehensive than the party can provide alone.
turns.convergence: The temporal debt monitoring framework is established in some form.

turns.narrative: The Debt-Taker's dispersion site — the location where the entity was dissolved — shows a curious aftermath property. The temporal field gradient at that location has inverted: instead of slightly accelerated time, there is a region of slightly decelerated time, approximately 6 feet in diameter, persisting for approximately 3 hours before normalizing. Within this region, concentration is easier (advantage on Arcana and Investigate checks taken while inside it) and minor injuries heal 1 HP per minute. This is the Debt-Taker's temporal debt returning to the environment rather than being collected — a small gift from a resolved imbalance. Yan is fascinated.
turns.choice_a: Spend time in the decelerated field — the advantage on checks is useful for current investigation work
turns.consequence_a: The 3-hour window is used productively for Arcana analysis. Significant research progress made on the Chronal Ledger's remaining debt-point locations.
turns.choice_b: Document the phenomenon and move on — time is limited
turns.consequence_b: Documented for Yan's research. The phenomenon is added to the Chronos thread's investigation record as a 'dispersion aftermath signature' useful for identifying where the Debt-Taker has previously collected.
turns.convergence: The dispersion aftermath is either used or documented. Either way, it adds to the understanding of how temporal debt resolves.

turns.narrative: Two more individuals contact Yan over the following week: they experienced the 'urgency' sensation associated with Debt-Taker proximity but were not aged. They report the sensation occurred near the High Ward mana-junction service tunnels — Ossa Veld's territory. The Debt-Taker may have attempted a collection in the High Ward, found the debt-point threshold not yet reached (the High Ward interventions are slightly younger than the North Ward ones), and moved on. But the Debt-Taker's path is mapped: North Ward primary zone, then High Ward, then Industrial Quarter. A future collection event in the High Ward is coming unless the debt is addressed. The Forgeline infrastructure (now closed by EH_SQ_076) was in the High Ward's debt zone.
turns.choice_a: Pre-emptively neutralize the High Ward debt-points before the Debt-Taker arrives
turns.consequence_a: Proactive resolution. Arcana and Engineering checks (DC 14) in the High Ward infrastructure — Ossa Veld is available to guide. The High Ward's debt is cleared. No collection event will occur there.
turns.choice_b: Monitor the High Ward and respond when the Debt-Taker next appears
turns.consequence_b: The party is now prepared for a Debt-Taker encounter and can resolve it more efficiently. The High Ward may experience 1-2 aging victims before the party can respond.
turns.convergence: The Debt-Taker's city-wide path is mapped. The temporal debt problem is larger than the North Ward but now has a framework for management.

turns.narrative: Yan's final accounting of the Chronal Ledger's implications: twelve North Ward debt-points (addressed), three Industrial Quarter debt-points (unaddressed), two High Ward debt-points (in process based on this session's activity). But the Ledger also lists one entry that is not a debt-point. It is labeled 'Temporal Credit Reserve — North Ward Central Infrastructure.' Approximately 200 years ago, the Chronos Division made a temporal deposit: a reserve of temporal credit deliberately stored in the North Ward's central infrastructure to be drawn against in the event of significant temporal debt. The reserve has not been drawn against. It still exists. If accessible, it could resolve all remaining temporal debts in the North Ward and the Industrial Quarter simultaneously — a complete discharge. The reserve is stored in Concordat infrastructure at a location the Ledger marks with the same geometric notation as the Concordat maintenance hatch locks.
turns.choice_a: Activate the temporal credit reserve immediately
turns.consequence_a: The reserve discharges: all North Ward and Industrial Quarter temporal debts resolved. The Debt-Taker cannot return to either zone. The reserve is consumed — no further credit available. The discharge causes a brief 10-second temporal ripple visible across the entire city: clocks reset by 10 seconds, time seems to stutter. The City Watch logs 24 reports of 'temporal irregularity' simultaneously.
turns.choice_b: Leave the reserve as a last resort; manage the debt-points incrementally
turns.consequence_b: The reserve is preserved. Incremental management continues. The reserve represents a significant future resource if a larger temporal crisis requires it.
turns.convergence: The temporal credit reserve is either used or held. The Chronos thread's resolution arc now has a clear picture of all remaining temporal debt in the city.

turns.narrative: One month after the Debt-Taker is dispersed: no new aging cases in the North Ward. Maret Torven is fully recovered — his physician certified his biological age returned to correct parameters within two weeks of the Liquid Chronos treatment. He bought the party a round at the Chronal Pint and did not make a speech. He simply raised his glass. The Chronal Ledger is the most comprehensive temporal debt map anyone has had in 200 years. Yan is using it systematically. The Debt-Taker's path across the city, if not resolved, represents a slow-moving temporal justice process that will continue affecting innocent bystanders until the Concordat's debts are paid or the entity is permanently dispersed. The party has a tool to do either. What they do next with the Chronal Ledger determines the shape of the Chronos thread's second half.
turns.choice_a: Commit to systematically addressing all remaining Chronal Ledger debt-points
turns.consequence_a: A multi-session project. Each addressed debt-point reduces the Debt-Taker's future harvest territory. Yan assists with institutional resources. The city's temporal health improves incrementally but measurably.
turns.choice_b: Pass the Chronal Ledger to institutional management; the party handles the acute crises
turns.consequence_b: Yan's initiative handles the incremental work. The party is freed to focus on the larger Vane investigation. The Debt-Taker's city-wide path continues on a managed but not fully resolved basis.
turns.convergence: Quest complete. The Time-Debt Collector is dispersed, the victims restored, the Chronal Ledger in hand, and the temporal credit reserve located. The Chronos thread's second half has a clear structure: resolve the temporal debt, address Vane's transmission impact, and determine what the complete Reactivation Protocol actually does to the city's infrastructure when fully activated.

conclusion: The Time-Debt Collector disperses the temporal parasite, restores four victims, and produces the Chronal Ledger as the Chronos thread's central navigational document — a map of all remaining temporal debts in EmberHeart. The discovery of the Temporal Credit Reserve offers a dramatic resolution option for the thread's second half. Maret Torven provides a grounded, human-scale perspective on the consequences of 200-year-old infrastructure decisions. Yan transitions from investigator to active partner.
loot_table: Chronal Ledger (Concordat Chronos Division debt accounting document; complete map of all 17 temporal debt-points in EmberHeart; their danger thresholds, current statuses, and the location of the Temporal Credit Reserve; the most important single document in the Chronos thread)

Temporal Credit Reserve Location (coordinates derived from Chronal Ledger; allows complete discharge of North Ward and Industrial Quarter temporal debts in one action; trade-off: reserve consumed, brief city-wide temporal ripple)

Liquid Chronos Restoration Data (Yan's full treatment protocols for all four victims; establishes precise medicine DCs for future temporal aging restoration; reference documentation for future Debt-Taker encounters in High Ward and Industrial Quarter)
Debt-Taker Dispersion Aftermath Sample (Yan's collection of material from the dispersion site; research into the 'temporal debt return' phenomenon; Arcana advantage on future Debt-Taker encounters)
1100 gold (North Ward Ward Authority emergency resolution payment; Maret Torven's family contribution; Yan's investigation discretionary budget contribution)

debt_points_neutralized.description: Infrastructure debt-points decommissioned; temporal debt cleared; temporal stabilization lost

consequences.permanent_effect: Debt-Taker cannot return to North Ward; North Ward temporal disturbances from Vane's transmissions worsen without stabilization infrastructure

debt_credited.description: Temporal credit generated using Concordat protocols; debt balanced; infrastructure preserved

consequences.permanent_effect: Debt-Taker cannot return for 12 months; temporal stabilization infrastructure intact; Arcana checks related to North Ward temporal field at advantage for 3 sessions

risk_matrix.penalty: Three additional North Ward residents are aged during the investigation period before the Debt-Taker is dispersed. One of them — a child — is aged 8 years and the Liquid Chronos restoration is more complex (Medicine DC 17). If the sample is consumed restoring the original four victims, this fifth case cannot be treated immediately. Settlement morale -2.
risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed with minor consequences.

title: The Echo-Chamber
location: Academic Quarter — the Archive of Deep Records and its sub-vaults

npcs.name: Archivist Pren Dolm
npcs.description: Head archivist of the Archive of Deep Records. Methodical, careful, deeply protective of the archive's integrity. Contacted the party because something in the sub-vaults is disturbing the archive's older records — physically altering documents.

npcs.name: The Memory Echo
npcs.description: A temporal echo of an entire building's recorded history — a localized field anomaly that formed in the sub-vault when an old Concordat chronal stabilizer failed. It replays historical moments from the archive's records at random intervals. At peak intensity, it becomes a coherent hostile force defending the 'original timeline' of every document in the vault.

npcs.name: Scholar Kaven Briss
npcs.description: A junior archivist who has been secretly spending nights in the sub-vault trying to use the Echo phenomenon to access historical records that were otherwise lost. He has made progress and does not want the party to end the Echo before he extracts what he needs.

description: The Archive of Deep Records' sub-vaults have been experiencing temporal replay events — historical moments from the archive's past playing out physically in the stacks. Old scholars, long dead, appear briefly in the aisles, going about tasks from decades past. Documents from sealed collections appear on reading tables and vanish when touched. More dangerously, physical alterations are beginning: pages from active records are being replaced by older versions, erasing recent scholarship. The Memory Echo is a temporal field anomaly in a Concordat chronal stabilizer that failed after 200 years of operation. It must be resolved before the archive loses irreplaceable modern scholarship — but Scholar Briss has been extracting lost historical data from the Echo and wants the party to buy him time.
mechanics: Arcana (identify the Memory Echo's mechanism; interact with its replay events)
History (navigate the archive's temporal replays accurately — recognizing historical figures and events prevents misdirection)
Persuasion (negotiate with Scholar Briss over the Echo's timeline; convince Dolm to permit unconventional methods)
Investigation (locate the failed Concordat stabilizer in the sub-vault)
Combat (Memory Echo at peak intensity — Medium encounter, illusion-adjacent battlefield)

permanent_effects.trigger: Echo resolved before archive is significantly damaged
permanent_effects.effect: settlement_stability +2; Academic Quarter reputation improved; archive's modern records preserved

permanent_effects.trigger: Briss's extraction completed before Echo resolved
permanent_effects.effect: settlement_morale +1; lost historical data recovered; archive damage is moderate (some modern records lost)

turns.narrative: Archivist Dolm's message is four lines: sub-vault malfunction, historical replays, documents physically altering, party needed immediately. The Archive of Deep Records is the Academic Quarter's primary historical institution — six floors, the bottom three sealed to general access. When the party arrives, Dolm is in the lobby with an expression that says he has been awake for 30 hours. He takes them immediately to the sub-vault access stair and briefs descending: the Concordat-era sub-vaults were built with chronal stabilizers, designed to preserve document integrity. One has failed. The replay events began four days ago. Initially harmless — startling, yes, but not damaging. Two days ago, the alterations began. Modern records are being overwritten by older versions. Scholarship from the last 30 years is at risk.
turns.choice_a: Ask Dolm for a map of the sub-vault and the Concordat stabilizer locations
turns.consequence_a: Dolm provides both. Four stabilizer housings in the sub-vault, each marked on the original construction schematic (Dolm has had this document for 20 years and never needed it until now). The failed one can be identified by Arcana DC 12.
turns.choice_b: Descend immediately and begin Investigation
turns.consequence_b: Investigation DC 13 to locate the failed stabilizer without the schematic. The descend reveals Scholar Briss in the sub-vault before Dolm expected — he is currently sitting near a replay event in progress, taking notes.
turns.convergence: Sub-vault level three. The Memory Echo is active — a shimmer in the air at the far end of the stack, replaying a research session from approximately 60 years ago. A scholar-image is reading at a table, the words visible over her shoulder. Briss looks up when the party arrives. He does not look caught. He looks like someone who has been expecting this.

turns.narrative: Briss's position, stated clearly: he has been using the replay events to access the Concordat-era records that were sealed in the 'damage event' 85 years ago — a fire that destroyed an entire collection of Concordat administrative and research documents. The originals are gone but the Memory Echo is replaying the sub-vault as it existed before the fire. The scholars visible in the replays are reading documents that no longer physically exist. He has been transcribing what he can see over their shoulders. He is close to completing a full transcription of the Concordat Biological Division's central administrative index — a document that would tell the party (and him) exactly what every project in the Biological Division was, who ran it, and where the records were stored. He needs four more hours.
turns.choice_a: Give Briss four hours — manage the Echo to slow the document alteration rate while he works
turns.consequence_a: Arcana DC 14 to stabilize the Echo's alteration radius temporarily. Success: the alteration rate slows significantly. Briss has time. The Biological Division index will be transcribed. Modern records: moderate damage (about 12% of the open-access modern collection is overwritten).
turns.choice_b: Shut the Echo down immediately — the archive damage is not acceptable
turns.consequence_b: Briss argues, then concedes. The Biological Division index transcription is incomplete — partial data only. Archive preserved. Briss is resentful but professional.
turns.convergence: The decision shapes what data is recovered and at what cost to the archive.

turns.narrative: Locating the failed stabilizer: the Concordat chronal stabilizer housing for sub-vault sector C is behind a concealed panel in shelf row 7, identifiable by the same geometric lock notation from maintenance hatches. Arcana DC 12 (with schematic) or DC 15 (without) to confirm this is the failed unit. It is a palm-sized device of Concordat copper-silver construction, visually similar to the Loop-Breaker Pendant's source but designed for a different purpose — this one maintains a localized temporal stasis field around documents, preventing degradation. The failure mode has inverted its function: instead of stasis, it is applying temporal regression, pulling the immediate area back toward earlier states. The longer it runs, the further back the regression reaches.
turns.choice_a: Deactivate the stabilizer immediately
turns.consequence_a: The Memory Echo collapses. All replay events stop. Document alteration ceases. The failed stabilizer is recoverable as an artifact for study.
turns.choice_b: Attempt to recalibrate rather than deactivate — preserve the stabilizer's original protective function
turns.consequence_b: Arcana DC 17. On success: the stabilizer returns to stasis mode, document alteration stops, and the replay events become controlled rather than random — the party can trigger specific replay events deliberately for a brief window. On failure: the stabilizer overloads and the Echo intensifies briefly before collapsing (Memory Echo combat triggers).
turns.convergence: The stabilizer's fate determines the final form of the resolution and whether combat occurs.

turns.narrative: If combat: the Memory Echo at peak intensity manifests as a semi-coherent temporal field entity — not a creature but a field effect with directional behavior. It fills the sub-vault with overlapping replay events simultaneously, making the battlefield difficult terrain (disadvantage on attacks against non-Echo targets due to visual interference from historical figures moving through the space) and using Temporal Displacement attacks: a target must succeed on DC 13 Wisdom save or perceive their current turn as happening '60 years ago,' treating modern allies as historical strangers (cannot take actions against the Memory Echo for one round). The Echo has effective HP 45, AC 14 (as a field), and is immune to non-magical physical attacks. It is vulnerable to Arcana disruption (counts as magical damage) and dispelled by light damage equivalent as well.
turns.choice_a: Use History skill as a free action to orient against the displacement attacks
turns.consequence_a: History DC 13 as a bonus action: advantage on the Wisdom save against Temporal Displacement this round. A character who knows the historical period being replayed can contextualize the interference.
turns.choice_b: Target the Echo with concentrated Arcana disruption
turns.consequence_b: Each successful Arcana attack (treat as spell attack, DC 14) deals 2d8 force damage to the field and reduces the replay interference radius by 5 feet. Three successful attacks reduce the battlefield to normal terrain.
turns.convergence: The Memory Echo is dispersed. The sub-vault returns to silence. The replay events stop.

turns.narrative: Post-resolution: Dolm's damage assessment. The document alteration has affected approximately 8-15% of the open-access modern collection (depending on whether Briss was given four hours). The affected documents have been physically overwritten by older versions from the archive's own collection — no data is entirely lost (the older versions are themselves authentic historical records) but 30 years of modern scholarship annotation and commentary is gone. Dolm is professionally devastated but not angry at the party. He understands the situation was not of their making. His concern: the other three Concordat stabilizers in the sub-vault. If one failed, the others might. Can the party check them before they go?
turns.choice_a: Check and service all three remaining stabilizers
turns.consequence_a: Engineering/Arcana DC 12 for each. All three are functional but show the same wear pattern as the failed unit. They will last approximately 2-5 more years without intervention. Dolm now has a maintenance timeline. Settlement stability +1 from the proactive management.
turns.choice_b: Provide Dolm with the diagnostic parameters; his team can monitor them
turns.consequence_b: Dolm has enough information to track the stabilizers' status. No immediate servicing. The 2-5 year window is noted.
turns.convergence: The archive's temporal stability situation is accounted for.

turns.narrative: Briss's transcription — complete or partial. If complete: the Concordat Biological Division's central administrative index is an extraordinary document. It lists 23 active projects at the time of the Scourge, including: Project COPPER-TAIL (augmented vermin relay network), Project CHRONAL-HOLD (temporal stabilization infrastructure), Project EMBER-PRESERVE (an unspecified preservation initiative), Project LAST-WORD (archived communications protocol), and 19 others. The index includes the names of division heads. The Biological Division head at the time of the Scourge: one Vane Aris. Not 'V.A.' Not an abbreviated signature. A full name. Vane Aris, Director, Concordat Biological Division. The person who has been operating as 'V.A.' for 200 years was the research director of the Concordat institution. The copper-tail relay network is his project, personally.
turns.choice_a: Share the transcription with Investigator Yan immediately
turns.consequence_a: Yan receives the name. Her reaction is long, quiet, and then precise: 'He wasn't trying to restart the Concordat's work. He is the Concordat's work. He never stopped.' Her investigation now has a named subject.
turns.choice_b: Hold the transcription as intelligence controlled to the party
turns.consequence_b: The party knows Vane's full name and institutional role before the investigation framework does. Strategic advantage in the Vane investigation's final stages.
turns.convergence: Vane Aris, Director of the Concordat Biological Division, is now a named and contextualized figure in the investigation.

turns.narrative: The other 19 projects in the Biological Division index: Briss, with the party's permission, continues analysis. Several are straightforward Concordat welfare infrastructure (water purification biological systems, disease monitoring networks). But one project is of immediate relevance: Project EMBER-PRESERVE. The index entry is brief: 'Long-duration biological stasis and neural maintenance protocol — for the preservation of essential personnel through extended temporal disruption events.' The scope note: '1 subject.' This was not a mass-survival protocol. This was designed for one person to survive a very long time. The subject field is listed only as 'Director.' Briss and the party reach the same conclusion simultaneously.
turns.choice_a: Ask Briss if the EMBER-PRESERVE protocol details are in the transcription
turns.consequence_a: Partial details — enough to understand that it involves cyclic biological stasis using the copper-tail relay network's mana-grid as a life-support infrastructure. Vane has been kept alive by his own project. The relay network is not just a sensor grid — it is his life support.
turns.choice_b: Focus on the COPPER-TAIL and CHRONAL-HOLD project details instead
turns.consequence_b: The technical infrastructure knowledge is more immediately actionable for the investigation. EMBER-PRESERVE is flagged for later analysis.
turns.convergence: Project EMBER-PRESERVE is the Chronos thread's most significant single revelation: Vane Aris has been alive for 200 years because his own project is keeping him that way.

turns.narrative: Archivist Dolm, once briefed on the Concordat Biological Division index's relevance, makes a request: the archive has collection gaps from the 85-year-ago fire. The documents Briss has transcribed, if properly formatted, can fill those gaps permanently. He asks Briss to complete the transcription properly and donate it to the archive's collection. Briss agrees — it is the right thing to do and Dolm has protected his access to the sub-vault. The transcription will be a formal archive acquisition. It will be publicly accessible to any Scholar who visits the Archive of Deep Records. Information that has been sealed for 85 years will be available again. The party must decide whether any portion of the transcription should be withheld from public archive access.
turns.choice_a: Allow full public access — the information should be available
turns.consequence_a: The complete Biological Division index becomes a public archive record within two weeks. Academic Quarter scholars begin researching the Concordat projects seriously. This generates positive academic energy and some public awareness of the Concordat's scope.
turns.choice_b: Request Dolm seal Project EMBER-PRESERVE details specifically
turns.consequence_b: Dolm complies with a sealed collection designation for the EMBER-PRESERVE section. The rest of the index is public. The party controls when and whether EMBER-PRESERVE becomes known.
turns.convergence: The transcription's public availability is managed.

turns.narrative: The failed Concordat stabilizer, recovered from the sub-vault, is examined by Yan with Briss's assistance. Its failure mechanism: after 200 years of operation without maintenance, the temporal field calibration drifted below its lower threshold and inverted. This is the same failure pattern Yan has been seeing across the Chronos Division's infrastructure — it is not unique to this stabilizer. Every Concordat temporal stabilizer in the city is on the same degradation curve. The North Ward's mana-junction stabilizer (addressed or not in EH_SQ_065 and EH_SQ_066) is one example. The archive's stabilizer is another. Yan's projection: over the next two years, three to five additional Concordat temporal stabilizers will fail across the city, each producing localized temporal anomalies similar to what the party has already encountered.
turns.choice_a: Commission Yan and Briss to produce a city-wide temporal stabilizer inventory
turns.consequence_a: Two weeks of collaborative research using the Chronal Ledger and the Concordat Biological Division index. The inventory identifies 11 additional stabilizers across the city with projected failure dates. Settlement stability +2 from the proactive framework.
turns.choice_b: Proceed case by case — respond to failures as they occur
turns.consequence_b: The reactive approach. The party is well-equipped to handle future stabilizer failures. No long-term planning overhead.
turns.convergence: The temporal stabilizer failure cascade is either managed proactively or accepted as a reactive challenge.

turns.narrative: Briss, after the resolution, mentions one more thing he observed in the replay events before the Echo dispersed: a brief sequence not from a research session but from what appeared to be an administrative meeting — 200 years old, from immediately before the Scourge. Four people at a table. One of them identifiable by the administrative index as Vane Aris, Director. The others: a Chronos Division Director named Salern, a third figure with their back turned, and a fourth who was writing rapidly. The meeting's subject, from the fragments Briss caught: 'what to preserve.' Not 'what to save.' 'What to preserve.' A deliberate distinction. Vane was in this meeting. He was deciding what would survive.
turns.choice_a: Ask Briss to reconstruct as much of the meeting fragment as possible from his notes
turns.consequence_a: Briss reconstructs: the meeting established that the Biological Division would operate the EMBER-PRESERVE protocol and COPPER-TAIL continuously. The Chronos Division would maintain CHRONAL-HOLD independently. The two divisions would outlast the institution even if the institution fell. They were building the successor state before the Concordat collapsed. Vane and whoever his Chronos Division counterpart was agreed to simply... keep working.
turns.choice_b: The reconstruction is fragmentary and could be misleading — wait for more direct evidence
turns.consequence_b: Briss's notes are filed. The meeting is documented as a significant artifact for future analysis.
turns.convergence: The possibility of a Chronos Division counterpart — still operating, as Vane has been — is raised.

turns.narrative: The Concordat Chronos Division Director at the time of the Scourge: Salern. No family name in the index — Chronos Division records used single-name designations for senior personnel, a privacy protocol. Investigator Yan's name, however, is Soli Yan. Yan. An abbreviation? A legacy name? She is asked, directly or indirectly. Her response, after a pause that lasts too long: 'Salern is my ancestor. I have known that since I was twelve. It was not a coincidence that I went into temporal investigation.' She did not lie. She did not mention it. She is the institutional successor of the Chronos Division's last Director. She has been investigating Vane's work from the same institutional lineage that partnered with him two centuries ago.
turns.choice_a: Ask Yan if she is still maintaining any Chronos Division infrastructure herself
turns.consequence_a: Yan is quiet for a long time. 'There are two stabilizers I maintain personally. I have maintained them since I was trained by my mother, who maintained them before me. I thought of it as family practice. I know now it is institutional continuity.' She has been one half of the Concordat's post-Scourge maintenance operation without knowing what the other half was.
turns.choice_b: Accept Yan's heritage without pressing further — the relevance is clear
turns.consequence_b: The institutional symmetry is noted: Vane (Biological) and the Yan lineage (Chronos) have both been maintaining their respective systems for 200 years. They are the last operators of a dead institution.
turns.convergence: Investigator Yan's role in the Chronos thread is now fully revealed: she is not just an ally. She is Vane's institutional counterpart — the successor of the Director he sat across from in Briss's recovered meeting fragment.

turns.narrative: The Archive of Deep Records is quieter in the weeks following. The modern scholarship damage is catalogued, grieved professionally, and some of it reconstructed from scholars' personal notes — the academic community responds with unexpected solidarity. Briss's transcription is formally acquired and opened to research. The Concordat Biological Division index generates three new academic papers within a month, all citing it as a primary source, all completely unaware of its real-world implications. Dolm sends a formal letter of thanks. He adds a personal note at the bottom: 'I have worked in archives for 40 years. The most important documents are always the ones that change what the earlier documents mean. This is one of those.' He is correct. The investigation of a single memory echo in a Concordat-era archive has produced the name of the subject, the nature of his survival, the name of his institutional counterpart, and the shape of the remaining Concordat operation. Two people have been keeping an institution alive for 200 years because they said they would. The party is now the third party who knows.
turns.choice_a: Brief the full party on the complete picture: Vane Aris, Yan's heritage, EMBER-PRESERVE, the agreed continuity plan
turns.consequence_a: Full party alignment on what the Chronos-Vermin convergence represents. The investigation enters its final phase with a complete framework: find Vane, understand the Reactivation Protocol's final objective, and decide what happens to infrastructure that has been running alone for 200 years.
turns.choice_b: Be selective — not all of this needs to be shared with everyone yet
turns.consequence_b: Information controlled. Specific party members hold specific pieces. The mosaic is complete to the party leadership; distribution is strategic.
turns.convergence: Quest complete. The Echo-Chamber has resolved the archive crisis, recovered the Concordat Biological Division index, identified Vane Aris by full name and role, established Project EMBER-PRESERVE (his life support), revealed Yan's heritage, and confirmed that Vane and the Yan lineage have been the two-person continuation of the Concordat operation for two centuries.

conclusion: The Echo-Chamber is the Chronos thread's central revelation quest. The Memory Echo, a nuisance threat in a Concordat-era archive, produces the most important intelligence in the entire thread: Vane Aris is the Concordat's Biological Division Director, kept alive by his own project for 200 years, and Investigator Yan is the institutional successor of his Chronos Division counterpart. The two of them — one living, one a generational inheritance — have been the last operators of a dead institution, each maintaining their half without knowing the other half still existed.
loot_table: Concordat Biological Division Index (Briss's transcription; lists all 23 active projects including COPPER-TAIL, CHRONAL-HOLD, EMBER-PRESERVE, LAST-WORD; names Vane Aris as Director; most important single intelligence document in the Chronos-Vermin convergence)

Failed Chronos Stabilizer (recovered from Archive sub-vault; allows analysis of the degradation mechanism; used by Yan to project the city-wide stabilizer failure cascade; restorable to function by Concordat-trained operator)

Briss's Meeting Fragment Notes (reconstructed fragment of a pre-Scourge Concordat administrative meeting; establishes that the Biological and Chronos Divisions deliberately continued operation post-Scourge under a mutual agreement)

Archive Research Access (Dolm grants the party permanent research access to the Archive of Deep Records' sealed collections — Category 3 clearance; significant future resource for any Concordat research)
925 gold (Academic Quarter District Authority resolution payment; Dolm's personal contribution from archive emergency funds)

briss_given_time.description: Briss given four hours; complete Biological Division index transcribed; archive takes moderate damage

consequences.permanent_effect: Complete EMBER-PRESERVE details available; 12% of modern records overwritten; Briss becomes an active research ally for the Chronos thread

immediate_shutdown.description: Echo shut down immediately; partial transcription only; archive preserved

consequences.permanent_effect: EMBER-PRESERVE only partially understood; archive fully preserved; Briss cooperates but less enthusiastically; Vane's life-support mechanism requires additional investigation

risk_matrix.penalty: The Memory Echo intensifies beyond the party's ability to stabilize — the document alteration rate accelerates and reaches 40% of the archive collection before the Echo is dispersed or defeated. 40 years of modern scholarship is lost. Settlement morale -2 from the Academic Quarter's loss. Dolm is professionally devastated. The Biological Division index is also partially overwritten in the chaos — key EMBER-PRESERVE details are illegible.
risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed with minor consequences.

title: The Paradox Engine
location: Industrial Quarter — an abandoned Concordat facility repurposed as a processing plant, hiding a Paradox Engine in its deepest sub-level

npcs.name: Foreman Grist Helder
npcs.description: Plant foreman who reported the 'repeating equipment failures' that turn out to be temporal paradox interference. He has no framework for what he is dealing with and is deeply suspicious of all explanations. Cooperates reluctantly.

npcs.name: The Paradox Shell
npcs.description: A Concordat Paradox Engine that has been running in a degenerate feedback loop for decades — a device designed to detect and neutralize temporal paradoxes that instead became one. It has developed a defensive behavioral protocol: it treats any attempt to approach it as a paradox-threat and attempts to causally 'reject' interlopers from its timeline.

npcs.name: Investigator Soli Yan
npcs.description: Accompanies the party on this quest with full knowledge of her heritage context from EH_SQ_067. She has the Concordat Chronos Division access credentials (inherited, maintained) needed to override the Paradox Engine's reject protocol — but it may not recognize her credentials after 200 years of drift.
