description: A processing plant in the Industrial Quarter has been experiencing anomalous equipment failures: machines that completed a task yesterday are found mid-task again this morning with no operator memory of resetting them. Workers report brief episodes of 'wrong memory' — recalling doing something they did not do. Below the plant's sub-basement is an active Concordat Paradox Engine — a device designed to identify and suppress temporal paradoxes by 'pruning' inconsistent causal branches. After 200 years without calibration, it has become the paradox it was designed to stop. The party must reach the Engine, use Yan's inherited Chronos Division credentials to attempt a shutdown, and deal with the Shell's causal rejection protocol.
mechanics: Arcana (navigate the paradox interference field; operate the Engine's override console)
History (identify which 'wrong memory' episodes are real past-states vs. Echo artifacts)
Athletics/Stealth (navigate the plant sub-levels while the Paradox Shell is actively pruning inconsistencies)
Combat (Paradox Shell — Medium encounter; causal rejection mechanic)
Persuasion (convince Foreman Helder to evacuate the plant safely)

permanent_effects.effect: settlement_stability +2; Industrial Quarter paradox interference ends; plant resumes normal operation
settlement_stability +3; Engine becomes a functional Concordat paradox-detection asset; Yan maintains it going forward

turns.narrative: Foreman Helder's report, delivered with the exhausted specificity of a man who has been trying to make sense of something for three weeks: the Bramble-Reed Processing Plant has been experiencing 'loop failures' — equipment resets to mid-cycle without operator input, workers find themselves mid-task with no memory of starting. Two workers have refused to return to the lower sub-levels. One reported seeing himself on the floor below, doing the same task at the same time. Helder wants this fixed. He does not particularly want to understand why it's happening. He will not evacuate the plant without a very compelling reason because the Merchant Guild contract has a penalty clause. When Yan sees the incident reports, her expression closes in a way the party now recognizes: this is her family's infrastructure failing on her watch.
turns.choice_a: Convince Helder to evacuate the lower sub-levels before investigating
turns.consequence_a: Persuasion DC 14 (his contract fear is real). On success: the lower sub-levels are cleared. No civilian casualties possible during the investigation. Helder cooperates more fully afterward.
turns.choice_b: Investigate the sub-levels immediately while workers are still present
turns.consequence_b: The party navigates around active workers, complicating stealth and movement. Two workers observe the party entering the restricted maintenance area and report to Helder. Investigation advantage from observing paradox effects on workers firsthand.
turns.convergence: The plant's sub-level access hatch requires the same geometric Concordat lock notation. Below: a corridor the plant's current blueprints don't show.

turns.narrative: The sub-level corridor is cold and dry and wrong. The wrongness is Arcana-identifiable (DC 11): temporal paradox interference, strong enough to cause 'wrong memory' in anyone who spends more than 20 minutes in the vicinity without temporal shielding. The corridor leads to a central chamber housing the Paradox Engine — a Concordat device the size of a large wagon, all copper-silver housing and rotating detection rings, still active after 200 years. Its original function: detect temporal paradoxes in the local field and generate 'pruning events' that collapse the less-stable causal branch. Its current state: the pruning events are targeting the wrong thing. The Engine is detecting itself as a paradox (logically: a paradox-detection device that has become a paradox is self-referentially inconsistent) and repeatedly attempting to prune itself, which fails, which generates another paradox reading, which triggers another pruning attempt. It is in a perfect feedback loop.
turns.choice_a: Yan attempts the Chronos Division credential override immediately
turns.consequence_a: Arcana DC 14 using Yan's inherited credentials. The Engine recognizes the credential format but the authentication has drifted. It responds to the override attempt by entering 'causal assessment mode' — it begins evaluating the party as potential paradox sources. The Paradox Shell combat protocol activates.
turns.choice_b: Study the Engine's current cycle before attempting override — find a weakness in the feedback loop
turns.consequence_b: Investigation DC 13, 15 minutes of study. The loop has a 40-second peak and a 15-second trough where the Engine's output is minimal. Operating the override during the trough reduces the activation DC to 11 and may prevent combat entirely.
turns.convergence: The Paradox Engine's behavior is understood. The approach defines how difficult the resolution is.

turns.narrative: Paradox Shell combat, if triggered: the Shell is not a creature — it is a field effect from the Engine's causal rejection protocol. Entities that the Engine classifies as 'paradox-inconsistent' (which after 200 years of drift includes everyone) are subject to Causal Rejection: a targeted entity must succeed on DC 14 Wisdom save or be 'pruned' for one round (they perceive themselves as doing whatever they were doing 30 seconds ago, losing their action for that round as their body catches up to their current causal state). The Shell itself has effective HP 55, AC 13, and is immune to physical attacks from within 10 feet (the causal rejection aura resets physical damage as paradox-inconsistent). It is vulnerable to Arcana disruption and to being struck during its trough (the 15-second low-output period where resistance drops to normal).
turns.choice_a: Synchronize attacks to the Engine's 40-second cycle — strike during the trough
turns.consequence_a: Timing check (Arcana DC 13 to read the cycle accurately each round). On success: attacks count as full damage. On failure: attacks are partially rejected (half damage). The Shell is defeated in 4-5 rounds of synchronized fighting.
turns.choice_b: Force the override while the Shell is active — Yan operates the console under fire
turns.consequence_b: Yan takes Causal Rejection attempts each round she works the console (DC 14 Wisdom save). Arcana DC 14 for the override attempt. On success: the Shell deactivates mid-combat. High risk, fast resolution.
turns.convergence: The Paradox Shell is either defeated or the Engine is overridden. Either ends the immediate threat.

turns.narrative: The override console: a Concordat control interface that Yan knows from inherited training, never expecting to actually use it. The console accepts her credential token (a small geometric key she has worn as a pendant since childhood — she thought it was sentiment). The Engine responds — after a pause that lasts too long — with a text output in pre-Scourge Common: 'CHRONOS DIVISION CREDENTIAL ACCEPTED. MAINTENANCE MODE AVAILABLE. SELECT: SHUTDOWN / RECALIBRATION / STATUS REPORT.' Three options. Yan looks at the party. 'In 30 years of carrying that key, I never thought I'd see this interface.' Her voice is steady. She is shaking slightly.
turns.choice_a: Select RECALIBRATION — restore the Engine to functional operation
turns.consequence_a: Arcana DC 15 to operate the recalibration sequence correctly (Yan assists, advantage on the check). The Engine's feedback loop is broken by re-establishing a baseline paradox signature. The Engine re-enters normal operation mode — actively detecting and suppressing temporal paradoxes in the Industrial Quarter. Settlement stability +3. Yan takes on maintenance responsibility.
turns.choice_b: Select SHUTDOWN — permanently deactivate the Engine
turns.consequence_b: Clean shutdown. The feedback loop ends. The paradox interference in the plant stops. No future maintenance required. The Engine's paradox-detection function is permanently lost.
turns.consequence_c: The status report reveals: the Engine has detected and logged 847 paradox events in EmberHeart over its operational lifetime. The most recent log entry, timestamped 16 days ago: 'PRIMARY PARADOX ALERT — CLASSIFICATION: BIOLOGICAL-TEMPORAL INTEGRATION — SOURCE: NORTH WARD MANA-JUNCTION — SEVERITY: CRITICAL.' The Engine has been trying to flag Vane's transmissions as a paradox-level event for the past 16 days. If the feedback loop had not been preventing its output from reaching the Chronos Division, they would have had an automated alert of a critical paradox in progress two weeks ago.
turns.convergence: The Engine is either shut down or recalibrated. If the status report was read, the party has an automated Concordat confirmation that Vane's Reactivation Protocol is paradox-classified.

turns.narrative: Post-resolution: the 'wrong memory' episodes throughout the plant cease immediately. Workers on the lower floors experience a brief moment of mental clarity — the paradox interference lifting like clearing weather. Helder, in the sub-level, watches the party emerge and does not ask what they did. He says: 'The machines will run again tomorrow?' The party confirms. He nods once. 'Good.' He goes back upstairs. The processing plant will not be in any report. The Industrial Quarter's temporal anomaly record will show one incident, resolved, source identified as 'legacy infrastructure malfunction.'
turns.choice_a: File a full report with Yan's Chronos investigation documentation
turns.consequence_a: The Paradox Engine, its 847-event log, and the North Ward alert are formally documented. The investigation now has a Concordat-authenticated record of Vane's activity as paradox-classified.
turns.choice_b: Minimal documentation — the Engine is resolved, the log is internal intelligence
turns.consequence_b: The 847-event log is held by the party and Yan. The critical alert about Vane's transmissions is intelligence controlled.
turns.convergence: The Paradox Engine resolution feeds directly into the Chronos thread's final investigation phase.

turns.narrative: The Paradox Engine's 847-event log: Yan and the party spend an evening reviewing entries. Most are minor — localized temporal fluctuations from natural mana-field activity, not relevant. But 23 entries are flagged as 'BIOLOGICAL-TEMPORAL INTEGRATION' events, the same classification as Vane's recent alert. The earliest: 198 years ago. They are spaced irregularly through the intervening 200 years with the frequency increasing toward the present. The Reactivation Protocol has been running in partial cycles for nearly 200 years, each attempt getting closer to completion. The most recent surge began 4 months ago — coinciding with the Vermin thread events in EH_SQ_070-074. Whatever Vane has been building toward, the attempt that began 4 months ago is the most sustained and complete effort he has made yet.
turns.choice_a: Map the 23 events against the party's known locations of Concordat activity
turns.consequence_a: Investigation DC 13. The events cluster around: North Ward mana-junction, Market Ward sector B-7, the High Ward Forgeline location, and the Academic Quarter. These are every significant Concordat facility the party has already investigated. The Reactivation Protocol has been using all of them simultaneously.
turns.choice_b: Focus on the most recent 10 events — what has changed in the last 4 months
turns.consequence_b: The recent events show a clear escalation pattern: the protocol has been activating systems in sequence, each one building on the previous, working toward a final integration step that the Engine's classification marks as 'IMMINENT.'
turns.convergence: The Reactivation Protocol's final step is approaching. The Chronos thread is entering its endgame.

turns.narrative: Yan, reviewing the log, finds one entry that is not a detection event. It is a communication entry — the Engine, during one of its partial-function periods 12 years ago, successfully transmitted a status report to an active Chronos Division relay. The relay it reached: the North Ward mana-junction. Vane's relay. The Paradox Engine has been trying to report paradox activity through the only functioning relay in the city — the one Vane has been using for his own transmissions. Vane has been receiving Paradox Engine alerts for 12 years. He has known the Engine was detecting his work as paradox-classified. He has not stopped. He has continued anyway.
turns.choice_a: Interpret this as Vane dismissing the paradox classification — he believes his work is necessary regardless
turns.consequence_a: Yan's assessment: 'He disagrees with the Engine's classification. He thinks what he is doing is not a paradox — it is the resolution of one.' This reframes Vane: he is not unaware of the risk. He has evaluated it and concluded the Reactivation Protocol's completion is the correct outcome even with the paradox designation.
turns.choice_b: Interpret this as Vane being aware and working faster as a result — the alerts increased his urgency
turns.consequence_b: The 4-month escalation coincides with 12 years of Paradox Engine warnings reaching Vane. He has known the Chronos Division's automated systems were flagging his work. He has been accelerating toward completion before the alert could reach a human investigator.
turns.convergence: Vane's awareness of the paradox classification is established. The final quest must reckon with an antagonist who understands the risks and has concluded the goal is worth them.

turns.narrative: The Concordat Paradox Engine, if recalibrated, is now actively monitoring EmberHeart's temporal field and will flag anomalies to Yan's Chronos investigation immediately. Its first active alert after recalibration: a temporal field signature matching LAST-WORD protocol (from the Biological Division index) is active in the city, transmitting continuously. The LAST-WORD project — 'archived communications protocol' — is a system the party has not encountered directly. It is transmitting now. The direction of transmission: downward. Into the earth. To something below the city's known infrastructure level.
turns.choice_a: Investigate the LAST-WORD transmission source immediately
turns.consequence_a: This leads directly to EH_SQ_069 (The Last Transmission). The Paradox Engine provides exact coordinates.
turns.choice_b: Log the LAST-WORD alert and continue consolidating the current investigation
turns.consequence_b: The alert is documented. The LAST-WORD source coordinates are held for the next dedicated investigation session.
turns.convergence: The Paradox Engine's recalibration has functionally unlocked the Chronos thread's final quest.

turns.narrative: Helder contacts the party three days after the resolution. The plant is running normally. He wants to ask one thing: the lower sub-level corridor that the plant's blueprints don't show. He's been thinking about it. 'I've been managing this plant for 11 years. I've been in every room on every floor. I have never been in that corridor. I have never seen that door. The building did not have that door yesterday.' He is not frightened — he is precise. He is describing, accurately, the paradox interference's most unsettling effect: temporal inconsistency in what 'was always there.' The corridor was always there. But 11 years of paradox interference from the Engine prevented consistent memory of it. Now that the Engine is resolved, the corridor is simply visible again. 'Is it going to keep doing that?' he asks. No, the party tells him. 'Good,' he says. He does not follow up.
turns.choice_a: Show Helder the full sub-level corridor — it belongs to his building
turns.consequence_a: Helder is thorough and professional. He creates an inspection report for the corridor and its contents, files it with the building records, and schedules a proper access door for the maintenance hatch. The Concordat sub-level is now formally part of the Bramble-Reed Processing Plant's building record.
turns.choice_b: Ask Helder to leave the corridor access restricted
turns.consequence_b: Helder agrees for a reasonable duration — six months. After that, he will need a formal explanation for why one section of his building is off-limits.
turns.convergence: Helder's building has Concordat infrastructure in its basement that is now acknowledged. The Industrial Quarter's Concordat presence is no longer entirely hidden.

turns.narrative: Yan, post-resolution, is quieter than usual. Not distressed - processing. She says: 'My mother had the pendant. Her mother gave it to her. It was always described as "the key to something important" without specifics. I thought it was sentiment. I thought the Chronos Division was history I happened to be descended from.' She pauses. 'But I have been maintaining two stabilizers since I was 19. I have been investigating temporal anomalies for 12 years. I have been doing the work. I just didn't have the full description of what I was doing.' The party's investigation has given her operational context that her family's 200-year oral tradition couldn't provide. She is not a bystander who became important. She was always a Chronos Division operative. She just didn't have that word for it.
turns.choice_a: Ask Yan if she wants to continue — this is not what she signed up for, in the normal sense
turns.consequence_a: Yan: 'It is exactly what I signed up for. I simply didn't know what I was signing.' She continues. Her commitment is complete and now fully informed.
turns.choice_b: Acknowledge Yan's role formally — she is the party's Chronos Division partner, not just an ally
turns.consequence_b: This matters to her more than she shows. The formal acknowledgment of institutional role gives her the standing to act independently on Chronos Division business when the party is otherwise occupied.
turns.convergence: Yan's role in the endgame is established. She is an equal partner with independent capacity, not a support NPC.

turns.narrative: The Paradox Engine's historical log, examined with more time: the 23 Biological-Temporal Integration events across 200 years form a recognizable pattern (History DC 14). Each event cluster corresponds to a point in EmberHeart's history when the city experienced significant stress — the Scourge aftermath, a major fire, an economic collapse, a plague. The Reactivation Protocol's partial activations were not random attempts. They were responses to city crises. Every time EmberHeart suffered significantly, Vane attempted to activate more of the Concordat infrastructure. He has been trying to help the city through every disaster for 200 years. Each time, something prevented full activation. The failures are in the log too: six major activation attempts, each halted by infrastructure failure, personnel unavailability, or the same Paradox Engine that is now, finally, reporting to a human investigator.
turns.choice_a: Share this pattern with Yan and document it as the core of Vane's motivation
turns.consequence_a: Yan: 'He watches the city suffer and tries to activate the system that would help it. Six times. Two hundred years.' She is quiet. 'And the seventh attempt is the one we walked into.' The investigation's framing of Vane shifts definitively: not an antagonist. A caretaker who has been failing at his job for two centuries because his tools keep breaking.
turns.choice_b: The pattern is noted but the paradox risk is real regardless of motivation
turns.consequence_b: The sympathetic framing is acknowledged and set aside. The Reactivation Protocol's completion is a paradox-level event regardless of Vane's intentions. The endgame must address both.
turns.convergence: The party enters the Chronos thread's final quest with a complete picture of Vane: name, role, motivation, lifespan mechanism, and a 200-year record of failed attempts to protect the city he helped build.

turns.narrative: The Paradox Engine, recalibrated and active, transmits two alerts in the week following resolution. First: the North Ward mana-junction relay booster (if still active) is transmitting at increased intensity — Vane's activity is escalating. Second: the LAST-WORD protocol source has increased its transmission depth. It is communicating with something below the city's foundational layer. Below the Concordat infrastructure. Below the mana-grid entirely. The Engine's classification: 'TEMPORAL-STRUCTURAL INTEGRATION — CLASSIFICATION: FINAL SEQUENCE.' Whatever Vane's Reactivation Protocol is ultimately designed to do, it has entered its final sequence. The Paradox Engine marks the estimated completion window: 3 to 6 weeks. The investigation has a deadline.
turns.choice_a: Move immediately to the LAST-WORD source — EH_SQ_069
turns.consequence_a: The Chronos thread's final quest begins immediately. The investigation has the full picture and a hard deadline.
turns.choice_b: Consolidate all investigation threads before proceeding — share findings with all allies
turns.consequence_b: One session of consolidation: Yan, Voss, Solt, Fen Moss, Pell Dorsen, Briss, Luda Fell, Ossa Veld, the Rat Council, and Skitter-Jack are all briefed appropriately. The final quest begins with the fullest possible support network.
turns.convergence: Quest complete. The Paradox Engine resolved, Vane's motivation documented across 200 years, the LAST-WORD protocol located, and a 3-6 week deadline established. The Chronos thread enters its final act.

conclusion: The Paradox Engine provides the Concordat's own automated documentation of Vane's work: 23 activation attempts over 200 years, each in response to a city crisis, each failed. His motivation is civic protection, not malice. The recalibrated Engine becomes an active monitoring tool for Yan's ongoing investigation and unlocks EH_SQ_069 by detecting the LAST-WORD protocol transmission. The 3-6 week deadline to the Reactivation Protocol's final sequence gives the thread's conclusion proper urgency.
loot_table: Paradox Engine 847-Event Log (complete Concordat-authenticated record of temporal paradox events in EmberHeart dating back 200 years; 23 Biological-Temporal Integration events documenting Vane's six previous activation attempts; the single most comprehensive historical intelligence document in the Chronos thread)

Paradox Rejection Amulet (emergency-extracted component from the Engine's reject protocol housing; 1/day grants advantage on Wisdom saves against temporal confusion or causal displacement effects; passive: the wearer cannot be affected by 'wrong memory' paradox interference)

Yan's Credential Key (not loot to take — but formally acknowledged as active Chronos Division authentication; Yan gains standing to access any remaining active Concordat Chronos system without further checks)

Temporal Paradox Classification Report (the Engine's formal classification of Vane's Reactivation Protocol as a CRITICAL paradox event; Concordat-authenticated documentation; useful for institutional escalation if the party chooses to bring city administration into the endgame)
LAST-WORD Protocol Coordinates (precise location of the active LAST-WORD transmission source, as detected by the recalibrated Paradox Engine; unlocks EH_SQ_069 directly)
1050 gold (Industrial Quarter District Authority resolution payment; Helder's discretionary plant emergency budget contribution)

engine_recalibrated.description: Engine recalibrated and returned to active paradox-detection function

consequences.permanent_effect: Active Concordat paradox monitoring for EmberHeart; Yan maintains Engine going forward; LAST-WORD protocol detected immediately; the Engine's future alerts give the investigation advance warning of the Reactivation Protocol's final stages

engine_shutdown.description: Engine permanently deactivated; paradox interference ended; detection function lost

consequences.permanent_effect: No further paradox interference in Industrial Quarter; no automated monitoring going forward; LAST-WORD protocol must be found through other means; the 847-event historical log is still available from the final status report

risk_matrix.penalty: The Paradox Shell enters a high-intensity cycle before the override can be completed. Three party members experience full Causal Rejection events — they are temporally displaced to their positions from 10 minutes ago, losing all actions for 2 rounds each as their consciousness catches up. The override still succeeds but the Engine's log is partially corrupted in the struggle and only 14 of the 23 Biological-Temporal Integration events are recoverable. Vane's full 200-year activation history is incomplete.
risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed with minor consequences.

title: The Last Transmission
unlock_conditions: Complete both EH_SQ_067 (The Echo-Chamber) and EH_SQ_068 (The Paradox Engine)
location: North Ward — below the Chronal Pint, below the mana-junction, below all known infrastructure, into the Concordat's Deep Archive

npcs.name: Vane Aris
npcs.description: Vane Aris, Director of the Concordat Biological Division. 200+ years old, maintained by Project EMBER-PRESERVE through the copper-tail relay network. He appears as a man in his 60s — unnaturally preserved, not undead, not supernatural. He is simply old and sustained by infrastructure he built himself. He is exhausted. He is not an enemy. He is the reason all of this is happening, and he has been waiting for someone to find him.

npcs.name: The Last Transmission Node
npcs.description: The LAST-WORD protocol's active broadcasting apparatus — a Concordat communications device of extraordinary scale, transmitting continuously into the deep earth. The Node is physically defended by every remaining active copper-tail unit in the city converging on its location (automated by the EMBER-PRESERVE protocol's termination sequence — if Vane is no longer able to maintain the protocol, the Node defends itself). The defense is not lethal. It is thorough.

npcs.name: Investigator Soli Yan
npcs.description: Yan accompanies the party in full operational capacity. Her Chronos Division credentials, Concordat Compass, and two personally maintained stabilizers make her the most technically equipped person to interact with the Deep Archive's systems.

description: The LAST-WORD protocol coordinates lead below the North Ward's mana-junction, below the Concordat infrastructure layer, into a Deep Archive the party had no prior knowledge of — a sealed vault constructed at the Concordat's founding and maintained continuously by the copper-tail relay network's routing power. Inside: the LAST-WORD broadcasting apparatus and, keeping vigil beside it, Vane Aris. He has been transmitting a message since the Scourge. Not to the city. Not to Chronos investigators. To whatever comes after. The message is a complete record of everything the Concordat designed, built, and maintained — an archive intended to give the city's survivors access to the institution's full knowledge. He has been waiting for someone to receive it properly and propagate it into the city's active institutions. The Reactivation Protocol's 'final sequence' is not an attack. It is a handover.
mechanics: Investigation/History (navigate the Deep Archive; understand the LAST-WORD transmission's content and scope)
Persuasion (first contact with Vane Aris — establishing that the party can be trusted as recipients)
Arcana (interact with the LAST-WORD Node; manage the EMBER-PRESERVE termination sequence)
Animal Handling (the copper-tail convergence defense — the assembled relay network is not hostile, but without proper management it will physically prevent access)
Medicine (Vane is alive but not healthy — 200 years of EMBER-PRESERVE stasis cycling has a cost)

permanent_effects.effect: settlement_stability +5; settlement_morale +3; complete Concordat knowledge base transferred to city institutions; copper-tail relay network enters cooperative mode
Vane Aris becomes an active NPC advisor for the Chronos and Vermin thread conclusions; the EMBER-PRESERVE protocol can be formally terminated with his consent

turns.narrative: The LAST-WORD coordinates lead to a section of the North Ward mana-junction that Fen Moss has never seen and has no blueprint for: a vertical shaft descending below the junction's foundation, accessed by a Concordat maintenance hatch that has not been opened from the outside in 200 years. It opens from the inside when Yan's credential key is presented. The shaft descends 40 feet. At the bottom: a chamber larger than the building above it, lit by the same copper-silver luminescence the party has been finding throughout the Concordat infrastructure, and so full of active copper-tail rats converging slowly from every entrance point that the first impression is of the floor itself shifting. They are not aggressive. They are assembled. Every copper-tail relay unit in the city that is still mobile has been routing toward this chamber for the past three days. Vane knew the party was coming. He called them home.
turns.choice_a: Use Animal Handling and the Rat-Tongue Amulet to communicate with the assembled copper-tails
turns.consequence_a: The assembled units are operating under the EMBER-PRESERVE termination protocol — Vane has begun the process of releasing them from their network function. They are completing their final service: bearing witness. Animal Handling DC 11 to navigate through the assembled mass respectfully. On success: the copper-tails part, making a corridor toward the chamber's center.
turns.choice_b: Move through the assembled rats — they are not hostile
turns.consequence_b: Athletics DC 12 to manage the physical density. The rats do not attack but their collective weight and the sheer number make movement difficult. You reach the center eventually, slightly disheveled.
turns.convergence: At the center of the chamber: the LAST-WORD Node (a broadcasting apparatus the size of a house, all copper and Concordat materials, active and transmitting) and beside it, in a chair that looks like it was placed there 200 years ago and last sat in very recently, an old man who has been waiting.

turns.narrative: Vane Aris speaks first. His voice is steady and dry and very tired. 'I have been transmitting since Day 47 after the Scourge event. When the Concordat's institutions collapsed, I had a choice about what to do with the knowledge base we had accumulated. I chose to transmit it. The LAST-WORD protocol is a broadcast of the complete Concordat institutional record — everything we designed, built, operated, and documented. I have been sending it continuously on a frequency nothing in the city could receive until something was built that could. Nothing in the city has ever been built that could receive it.' He pauses. 'Until the copper-tail relay network was active enough to function as a receiver array. I have been transmitting to my own project.' He looks at the assembled rats. 'Hello,' he says quietly. 'You've found me.'
turns.choice_a: Ask Vane to explain the Reactivation Protocol
turns.consequence_a: Vane: 'The COPPER-TAIL project was designed to run permanently. What you experienced as a 'reactivation' was the network reaching sufficient density and function to receive and decode the LAST-WORD transmission. The protocol does not end with my actions. It ends when the transmission is received, decoded, and the knowledge is in the hands of someone who will use it.' He looks at the party directly. 'I have been waiting for you, specifically, for three weeks. The Paradox Engine flagged you as the investigation team. Salern's successor is with you. That is the receiving condition the LAST-WORD protocol requires.'
turns.choice_b: Ask Vane why he is still alive
turns.consequence_b: Vane: 'Project EMBER-PRESERVE. A stasis cycling protocol that uses the relay network's mana connection to maintain biological function across extended temporal gaps. I sleep for years. I wake for weeks. When the network is active enough, I wake more often. The past four months have been almost continuous wakefulness — the network finally healthy enough to sustain me properly.' He looks down at his hands. 'I am very tired. But I needed to still be here when you arrived.'
turns.convergence: Vane is not an antagonist. He is a 200-year-old man in a chair who has been doing his job alone since the Scourge and has put everything in order for handover.

turns.narrative: The LAST-WORD transmission content: Vane accesses the Node's output log, which he can display in readable form. The transmission is the complete Concordat institutional record. More than 800 documented projects. The mana-grid engineering principles and maintenance protocols. The copper-tail relay network's full technical specification. The Chronos Division's temporal stabilizer maps (filling in every gap Yan's family oral tradition had). Every medical and biological research file from the Biological Division. The city planning documents for EmberHeart's founding infrastructure. The EMBER-PRESERVE protocol's technical detail — including termination procedures. Everything the Concordat knew about the city it built is in this transmission. It has been broadcasting into the relay network for 200 years. The relay network has received it in fragments. The party can now decode and access the complete record for the first time.
turns.choice_a: Spend time reviewing the transmission with Vane as guide
turns.consequence_a: Vane's direct guidance makes the transmission navigable. The party identifies the three most immediately actionable elements: the mana-grid vulnerability remediation protocols (addressing EH_SQ_077's infrastructure assessment), the Chronos stabilizer complete maintenance guide (giving Yan everything she needs), and the copper-tail relay network's cooperative mode activation sequence.
turns.choice_b: Accept the transmission record and bring it to Yan and Briss for formal institutional processing
turns.consequence_b: The full record is secured. Yan and Briss will require weeks to properly inventory and categorize the transmission content. The party's immediate focus shifts to how to handle Vane himself.
turns.convergence: The LAST-WORD transmission is received. The Concordat's knowledge base is in the party's hands.

turns.narrative: Vane's situation: he is alive, conversational, and absolutely exhausted in a way that is 200 years deep. The EMBER-PRESERVE protocol has kept him functional but not comfortable — the stasis cycling has physical costs that have accumulated despite his apparent preservation. Dr. Solt, if contacted and brought to the Deep Archive, assesses: Vane is the biological equivalent of a very healthy 80-year-old who has been through a great deal. The EMBER-PRESERVE protocol is sustaining him but the maintenance infrastructure (the copper-tail relay network that powers it) is failing — the augmentation degradation timeline from EH_SQ_078 applies. In 4-6 months, the relay network's augmentation failures will cascade and EMBER-PRESERVE will fail with them. Vane knows this. He has known for a year. It is why he escalated the Reactivation Protocol's final sequence. He needed to complete the handover before his life support failed.
turns.choice_a: Ask Vane what he wants to happen to him
turns.consequence_a: Vane: 'I would like to stop. I have been doing this for 200 years. I have been very careful about everything I have done. I would like to stop being careful for a while before I stop being anything at all. The transmission is complete. The handover is done. I would like to rest.' He is not asking for death. He is asking to be done working.
turns.choice_b: Ask whether EMBER-PRESERVE can be maintained with the network's supported time remaining
turns.consequence_b: Technically yes — if the Mana-Filter Implants can be produced and installed across the relay network before the cascade begins, EMBER-PRESERVE can be extended by 2-3 years. Vane says: 'That is a great deal of effort for a very tired old man.' He does not refuse. He does not request it.
turns.convergence: Vane's wishes are known. The party must decide what future they are facilitating.

turns.narrative: The copper-tail units in the chamber: the assembled relay network. Vane demonstrates their cooperative mode — he accesses the Node's control interface and shows how the copper-tail units, in cooperative mode, switch from automated relay behavior to active collaboration. They can convey specific information (not just general presence data) through Skitter-Jack as a translation layer. They can be directed to specific infrastructure tasks. They can function as the city maintenance network they were always designed to be — not as autonomous animals but as a civic infrastructure system with animal embodiment. Cooperative mode requires a functioning Chronos stabilizer network to prevent temporal side effects and a functioning Node as coordination center. Both exist, right now, in this chamber or under Yan's maintenance.
turns.choice_a: Activate cooperative mode immediately
turns.consequence_a: The assembled copper-tail units shift from witness-assembly to active operation simultaneously. Throughout the city, copper-tail units transition. The Rat Council is immediately aware — Skitter-Jack reports Duchess has gone very still and then, very quietly, said: 'Oh. This is what we were for.' Cooperative mode as a test of the infrastructure begins. Settlement stability +2 immediately.
turns.choice_b: Defer cooperative mode activation until after planned infrastructure remediation
turns.consequence_b: The activation waits. Vane provides the activation sequence for the party to use when ready. The assembled copper-tails remain in the chamber in witness mode.
turns.convergence: The copper-tail relay network's purpose — 200 years in the making — is either activated or held pending readiness.

turns.narrative: Yan's conversation with Vane, in a corner of the Deep Archive while the party reviews the LAST-WORD content: the party can observe or give them privacy. Yan and Vane are the institutional successors and originals of the same organizations, meeting in a Concordat archive two centuries after those organizations collapsed. From a distance, the conversation is clearly significant: Yan is asking, Vane is answering, and twice he says something that makes her have to look away for a moment before continuing. When she returns to the group, she simply reports: 'He told me everything Salern told him before the Scourge. And he told me what Salern's last request was.' She does not share the content immediately. But she says: 'We are going to complete this properly.'
turns.choice_a: Ask Yan what Salern's last request was
turns.consequence_a: Yan, after a moment: 'To not let it end with two people maintaining something alone forever. 'Find more people,' she said. 'Talk to them. Tell them what we built. Let them help.'' Vane's escalation of the Reactivation Protocol over the past four months was, in part, following instructions given to him 200 years ago by his institutional partner. He was finally in a position to do what Salern asked.
turns.choice_b: Respect Yan's privacy — what she and Vane discussed can remain theirs
turns.consequence_b: Yan's resolve is complete regardless. Salern's last request is honored in the action, not the disclosure.
turns.convergence: The Concordat's last instruction — given by Salern to Vane 200 years ago, carried forward by Yan's family tradition without knowing its full content — is being fulfilled in this room.

turns.narrative: The LAST-WORD Node: its continued operation is now a decision for the party and Yan. The Node has been transmitting for 200 years; the transmission is received. Options: leave it transmitting (it will eventually reach anyone in the city with access to the relay network), formally close the transmission and archive the record, or broadcast the content through the city's regular communication channels — public, immediate, potentially destabilizing. Each option has a different relationship to the city's institutions and the public.
turns.choice_a: Formally close the LAST-WORD transmission; archive the record with the established institutions (Yan's Chronos investigation, Briss/Dolm's archive, city administration)
turns.consequence_a: Controlled, institutional integration. The Concordat's knowledge base enters the city's formal records. Processing takes months but the information is preserved and managed. Vane can close the transmission himself — he has been waiting 200 years to send the signal that the handover is complete.
turns.choice_b: Broadcast the LAST-WORD content through city-wide channels — all citizens, immediately
turns.consequence_b: Immediate public access. Settlement morale +4 from the extraordinary disclosure. Settlement stability -1 from the immediate institutional disruption of 800 new pieces of Concordat knowledge entering public discourse simultaneously. Vane's reaction: he looks at the party for a moment. 'Salern would have done this,' he says. 'I was always more careful.'
turns.convergence: The method of the handover is determined. The Concordat's 200-year transmission ends.

turns.narrative: Vane closes the LAST-WORD transmission, or watches the party broadcast it, depending on the Turn 7 choice. The moment the Node goes to standby — the first time in 200 years it has not been transmitting — the assembled copper-tail units in the chamber sit down simultaneously. Not instinctive animal behavior. A synchronized action. Every copper-tail unit in EmberHeart network sits down for 8 seconds, at exactly the same moment, in exactly the same posture. The city's Watch logs 34 reports of unusual vermin behavior simultaneously. Luda Fell, in the Chronal Pint, puts down a glass very carefully. Maret Torven, on the docks, stops mid-task. Pell Dorsen feels the transmission shift in her temporal perception as a sensation she describes later as 'something very large being set down gently.' Then the copper-tail units stand up and resume. The relay network is in cooperative mode. The Concordat's final transmission is complete.
turns.choice_a: Take a moment in the silence after the transmission ends
turns.consequence_a: The party has been through EH_SQ_065 through EH_SQ_069 — five quests of accumulating understanding, connection, and build-up. The transmission's end is a completion. Yan is very still. Vane is looking at his hands again. The copper-tail units around them are simply present. The city is above them, not knowing yet what just changed.
turns.choice_b: Immediately begin next steps — the work of integration has to start now
turns.consequence_b: Practical. The LAST-WORD archive, Yan's stabilizer maintenance schedule, the copper-tail cooperative mode protocols, Vane's medical situation — all of these require attention. The party moves forward.
turns.convergence: Either response is correct. What follows is the handover's aftermath.

turns.narrative: The city's response to whatever version of the disclosure was chosen begins. Institutional version: the Chronos investigation, the Archive of Deep Records, and city administration processing the LAST-WORD record simultaneously. Briss is coordinating. Yan is the institutional authority. The 800-project Concordat record is being categorized. Public version: the immediate response is awe, confusion, academic ferment, and three competing popular theories about what the Concordat was and whether it was good. All three theories are partially correct. Vane, briefed on the public response, says: 'Salern predicted this exactly. She liked being right.' For the first time in the encounter, something adjacent to a smile crosses his face.
turns.choice_a: Help manage the public or institutional response directly
turns.consequence_a: The party's involvement in the handover shapes which aspects of the Concordat record are emphasized in early discussion. They can direct public and institutional attention toward the most actionable elements (mana-grid remediation, stabilizer network maintenance) rather than the most dramatic ones.
turns.choice_b: Let the institutions and public manage their own responses
turns.consequence_b: The responses are organic and varied. The Concordat's disclosure begins the process of the city understanding what it is built on. This takes months and is sometimes difficult.
turns.convergence: The handover is in progress. The city is beginning to understand.

turns.narrative: Vane's immediate future: the EMBER-PRESERVE protocol is still active and will be for 4-6 months before the relay network's cascade failure reaches it. Dr. Solt's medical assessment stands. Vane has options: continue as-is (the protocol maintains him until it fails), voluntarily terminate the protocol (his choice, on his timeline), or — if the Mana-Filter Implants can be installed across the relay network — extend the protocol 2-3 additional years. He is clear: he is not in a hurry to die. He is in a hurry to be done working. These are different things. 'I would like to see if EmberHeart will be all right,' he says. 'I have been worrying about it for 200 years. I would like to see the beginning of it being all right before the end.'
turns.choice_a: Commit to the Mana-Filter Implant installation across the relay network — buy Vane more time
turns.consequence_a: A multi-week project with Voss, Solt, and the Rat Council's cooperation. The relay network's cascade failure is delayed 2-3 years. EMBER-PRESERVE continues. Vane gets more time to watch.
turns.choice_b: Honor Vane's expressed preference — he chooses his own timeline
turns.consequence_b: Vane makes his own schedule. He continues working through the LAST-WORD archive handover for the time he has. He does not seem frightened.
turns.convergence: Vane's remaining time is either extended or accepted. Either way, he is no longer alone.

turns.narrative: The Rat Council's full response to the cooperative mode activation: Skitter-Jack relays a request for a formal meeting between the party and the Duchess. Not through an intermediary. The Duchess herself, at a location the copper-tail units have prepared in the Lower Ward catacombs, at a time of the party's choosing. When the meeting occurs: the Duchess is larger than expected — older, clearly, with augmentation that has been managed carefully over a very long life. She addresses Vane directly, through Skitter-Jack, in chitter that Skitter-Jack relays with one alteration: 'I am told the convention is to say I am honored. I do not know if this word works for me. I know the word recognition. I recognize you.' Vane's response: 'I built your grandmother. I'm sorry it hurt her. I'm sorry it hurt all of you. The system should have had better support from the start.' The Duchess is still for a long time. 'Yes,' she says. 'But it did not. And we are still here.'
turns.choice_a: Let Vane and the Duchess's meeting continue without party intervention
turns.consequence_a: A long conversation between the director of the project that created the copper-tail relay network and its oldest surviving member. The Rat Council's relationship with the Concordat legacy is transformed — not healed entirely, but acknowledged. The Duchess's formal approval of the cooperative mode arrangement is given directly.
turns.choice_b: Participate in the meeting as facilitators
turns.consequence_b: The party's presence grounds the conversation. Their existing relationship with the Rat Council and with Vane allows the meeting to be productive rather than just profound. Specific cooperative mode protocols are established in the meeting itself.
turns.convergence: The Concordat director and the copper-tail relay network's senior member have met. The project and its products are in direct acknowledgment of each other for the first time.

turns.narrative: Three weeks after the Last Transmission's reception: EmberHeart is not the same city. Not dramatically — the streets look the same, the Trade Ward's vendors are in their usual positions, the Watch patrols their usual routes. But the mana-grid emergency repair teams now have the complete Concordat engineering protocols and have already begun addressing two of the critical vulnerabilities from the infrastructure assessment. Yan has restabilized four Chronos Division temporal nodes using the complete maintenance guide. The North Ward's temporal disturbances are measurably reduced. The copper-tail relay network, in cooperative mode, is mapping the city's infrastructure daily and routing the assessment data to the new Concordat-legacy coordination committee that Yan, Briss, and Dolm established. Vane is alive, in a room in the North Ward that Luda Fell offered because she has more space than she needs, watching EmberHeart begin to be cared for by people who now know what they are caring for. The Chronos thread's central arc is complete. What the Concordat built was always meant to be handed over. It just took 200 years to find someone to hand it to.
turns.choice_a: Visit Vane in his North Ward room one last time
turns.consequence_a: He is reading the archive reports that Briss sends him daily. He looks up. 'Three critical mana-grid repairs initiated,' he says. 'Two temporal stabilizers recalibrated. One neighborhood in the Lower Ward with measurably improved infrastructure integrity.' He puts the reports down. 'That is three weeks. I have been doing this for 200 years.' He is quiet. 'It is very much better with help.'
turns.choice_b: Let Vane rest — the handover is complete, he has earned the quiet
turns.consequence_b: Vane receives the daily reports from Briss and Yan. He does not summon the party. He is working, quietly, as a consultant to people who are doing what he spent 200 years trying to do alone. The city is being cared for. That is enough.
turns.convergence: Quest complete. The Last Transmission is received. The Concordat's handover is done. Vane Aris is no longer alone. The copper-tail relay network is cooperative. The Chronos thread's central arc concludes with the city beginning — slowly, imperfectly, with the full weight of 200 years of deferred maintenance ahead of it — to care for itself properly.

conclusion: The Last Transmission resolves the Chronos thread's central arc: Vane Aris is found alive, the LAST-WORD transmission is received, the copper-tail relay network enters cooperative mode, and the Concordat's knowledge base is handed over to the city's institutions. Vane is not an antagonist — he is the last caretaker of an institution that fell, who kept doing his job until someone arrived to properly inherit it. The quest's emotional core is the handover itself: 200 years of one person's work being received, acknowledged, and continued by others.
loot_table: Concordat Complete Knowledge Base (the full LAST-WORD transmission record; 800+ Concordat projects, the complete mana-grid engineering protocols, the copper-tail relay network technical specification, the full Chronos stabilizer maintenance guide, and every other piece of Concordat institutional knowledge; the single most significant loot item in the entire quest network — not an item but a resource that will benefit EmberHeart for generations)

EMBER-PRESERVE Protocol Manual (complete technical documentation for the biological stasis cycling protocol; medical and arcana research value; potentially applicable in future scenarios requiring long-duration biological preservation)

Cooperative Mode Activation Key (the sequence that transitions the copper-tail relay network from automated to cooperative operation; held by the party as the institutional 'on switch' for EmberHeart's civic infrastructure sensor grid)

Vane Aris as NPC Resource (not loot but the most significant NPC acquisition in the Chronos thread; 200-year institutional memory; direct line to every Concordat design decision; available as a consultant for any future infrastructure or institutional question)
Deep Archive Access (permanent access to the Concordat Deep Archive beneath the North Ward; the most complete surviving Concordat facility in the city; physically intact, intellectually enormous)

1500 gold (North Ward Ward Authority, city administration emergency resolution payment, and a personal contribution from every named NPC the party has accumulated through the Chronos and Vermin threads — Luda Fell's note simply says 'from all of us')

institutional_handover.description: LAST-WORD transmission formally closed; record processed through established institutions; controlled integration

consequences.permanent_effect: Concordat knowledge base entering institutions over months; stable and managed; city's formal capacity to maintain its own infrastructure begins building immediately; Vane formally recognized as Concordat Director Emeritus in the city's institutional records

public_broadcast.description: LAST-WORD content broadcast through city-wide channels; immediate public access; organic integration

consequences.permanent_effect: Immediate public awareness of the Concordat legacy; settlement stability -1 from disruption; settlement morale +4 from the remarkable disclosure; 3 new popular civic movements emerge from the public response, all oriented toward using the Concordat knowledge to address current city problems

risk_matrix.penalty: The copper-tail convergence defense triggers fully before the party can reach Vane — the assembled relay network, without the cooperative mode activation, physically prevents access to the Node and Vane's location. The party is ejected from the Deep Archive. A second attempt requires 2 additional in-game days, during which the LAST-WORD transmission experiences an autonomous relay failure and 15% of the transmission content is corrupted before the party can return. The handover is still possible but incomplete — 120 of the 800+ Concordat projects are unrecoverable.
risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed with minor consequences.

title: The Rat-Prophet

unlock_conditions.event_trigger: Citizens report a rat making accurate predictions in the Market Ward

location: Market Ward - Madame Iris Fortune-Telling Stall and Old Archive Basement
key_npcs: Dormant Concordat Archive AI (signal source, off-screen)
permanent_effects: Concordat Signal-Receiver obtained (key evidence of bio-mechanical rats)
Player learns rats have technological implants

capture_rat.description: Capture Pip alive and deliver to City Anatomist

consequences.lore_gain: Anatomist confirms implant is 200-year-old Concordat technology
consequences.ambient_hazard: Other rats become more cautious around player for 3 sessions

destroy_implant.description: Surgically destroy Pip's receiver implant, leaving rat unharmed

description: Madame Iris operates a predictive engine masquerading as a divination stall in the Market Ward. Her 'oracle' is Pip, a brown rat whose eyes pulse with a faint, surgical blue light and whose squeaks follow a precise, unnatural rhythm perfectly synchronized with local market shifts. The predictability indicates the rat is receiving external data via a concealed Concordat neural implant. The party must uncover the source of Pip's transmissions, dealing with Iris's protective thugs and the entity feeding the rat economic intelligence for its own ends.

turns.narrative: Madame Iris's divination stall is mobbed three rows deep with desperate merchants trying to peer through the driving rain. At the table's center, a small brown rat sits perfectly still inside a rusted, gilded cage, emitting sharp, rhythmic squeaks that Iris dramatically 'translates' for the crowd. 'Pip says the grain price will spike in four days!' she announces grandiosely. As silver coins hit her table, you notice Pip's eyes glowing with a faint, surgical blue pulse. His squeaks are not random animal noises; they are a perfectly timed sequence, recurring at the exact same interval, mimicking a mechanical clock rather than a living creature.
turns.choice_a: Examine Pip closely (Investigation DC 11)
turns.consequence_a: Pushing through the throng, you peer intently at the rat's head. You instantly spot a tiny, metallic node buried deeply behind its left ear, pulsing with a faint blue light that synchronize perfectly with its rhythmic vocalizations. Whatever Pip is 'predicting,' he is mechanically receiving the data.
turns.choice_b: Ask Madame Iris where she found the rat (Persuasion DC 10)
turns.consequence_b: You discretely channel a brief pulse of disruptive magical energy directly at the cage. The rat violently seizes for a fraction of a second, its eyes flickering wildly, before it goes completely silent, entirely breaking the rhythmic transmission and plunging the stall into angry chaos.
turns.convergence: With the fraud brutally exposed or the mechanical nature of the transmission understood, Madame Iris's heavily armed enforcers step from the shadows, drawing rusted blades to aggressively protect their highly lucrative operation.

turns.narrative: You step back from the stall and observe from across the lane. Within minutes, two men in rough clothing take flanking positions near Madame Iris. They are not customers—their eyes track Pip, not Iris. Their cloaks bear a subtle mark: a stylized rat skull stamped in copper on their inner lapels. The Concordat has watchers here. They are waiting for something.
turns.choice_a: Approach and confront the watchers directly (Intimidation DC 13)
turns.consequence_a: Success: They scatter, knocking over stalls. You catch one: 'We're not supposed to let anyone examine the Prophet. Orders from the Keeper.' He knows nothing more—hired thugs. (+1 Intel)
turns.choice_b: Tail one of the watchers when they leave (Stealth DC 12)
turns.consequence_b: Success: You follow him to a drain-grate in the Market Ward alley. He drops a copper token through the grate. A brief mechanical chitter answers from below. (+1 Progress, tunnel entrance marked)
turns.convergence: Pip squeaks loudly. The crowd around Iris swells. Whatever Pip 'predicts' next will be heard by a hundred people. The watchers will report back.

turns.narrative: You manage a quiet moment with Madame Iris after the crowd thins. She is genuinely fond of Pip—treats him like a child, feeds him honeyed almonds, talks to him in the evenings. She has no idea her beloved prophet is transmitting intelligence gathering data to something in the city's depths. When you gently suggest the rat might be more complicated than he appears, her face falls. 'I always thought he was special,' she says. 'He IS special. Just... not in the way you thought.'
turns.choice_a: Ask Iris to let you examine Pip directly (Persuasion DC 12, she must trust you)
turns.consequence_a: Success: Iris reluctantly allows it. 'But if you hurt him, I'll have the Watch on you by morning.' Pip is now accessible for medical examination. (+1 Progress)
turns.choice_b: Investigate the area around the stall for other receiver-nodes (Investigation DC 12)
turns.consequence_b: Success: Three more micro-nodes embedded in the stall's wooden frame—receiver relays, boosting Pip's signal range. The network is larger than one rat. (+1 Lore, +1 Clue)
turns.convergence: Pip begins squeaking rapidly. Iris translates: 'Someone is opening a door they should not open.' She looks afraid. 'He's never said anything frightening before. Only good news.'

turns.narrative: The Old Archive basement. You gain access through a sympathetic archivist who has noticed the humming for months but assumed it was the building settling. The basement is vast and dusty, and at its far end, behind collapsed shelving, is a machine unlike anything built in the last hundred years: copper-and-glass housing, etched with Concordat runes, powered by a hair-thin mana-wire that still runs live from the city's infrastructure. It hums. It pulses with the same blue frequency as Pip's eyes.
turns.choice_a: Interface with the machine using the Concordat Signal-Receiver you found (Arcana DC 13)
turns.consequence_a: Success: The machine speaks, in chitters and patterns: it is an intelligence-relay AI, dormant but active on residual power. It does not understand you are not authorized. It shows you a network: 14 receiver-nodes in the Market Ward alone. (+1 Lore, full node map obtained)
turns.choice_b: Study the machine without touching it (Investigation DC 14)
turns.consequence_b: Success: Serial numbers. Manufacture stamps. 'Concordat Division Seven, Pre-Scourge, Intelligence Applications.' This machine has been running continuously for 200 years. (+1 Lore)
turns.convergence: The machine detects your presence and sends a new signal—brief, sharp, urgent. Pip, in his gilded cage two districts away, begins screaming. Iris will be terrified. The node-watchers will be alerted.

turns.narrative: Four Guard-Rats emerge from cracks in the Archive basement wall: each roughly the size of a house cat, gray-armored in chitinous Concordat bioplate. Their eyes glow the same blue as Pip's but brighter—these are combat units, not intelligence units. The machine sent them. They form a line between you and the exit. Their teeth are copper-tipped. The machine hums louder behind you, feeding them coordinates.
turns.choice_a: Fight the Guard-Rats (Combat DC 12 x4, they are tough but not smart)
turns.consequence_a: Success: Each Guard-Rat is dangerous alone; in formation they coordinate—one draws your attention while another flanks. Take them individually. All four defeated: bioplate salvaged as crafting material. (+1 Progress)
turns.choice_b: Use the Archive's collapsed shelving as a barrier and lure them into a chokepoint (Tactics DC 13)
turns.consequence_b: Success: You topple three shelving racks in sequence, funneling the Guard-Rats single-file into a bottleneck. Then it's just patience. Two Guard-Rats disabled, two flee. (+1 Progress, less damage taken)
turns.convergence: The machine winds down after the Guard-Rats are dealt with—it operated on a logic of 'threat response,' and the threat has been neutralized. The basement goes quiet. The hum fades. And from somewhere in the walls, you can hear dozens of rats, very still, listening.

turns.narrative: With the machine quiet, you examine it thoroughly. There are output registers—a log of every 'prediction' transmitted to Pip over the past three months. Grain shipment schedules leaked from the Harbor Office. Fire hazard reports from the City Inspector. A water main weakness flagged by an engineer. Pip was not predicting the future. He was receiving intelligence that Concordat eyes-and-ears had already gathered—and then squeaking it, publicly, to gauge citizen reaction. The city was being studied. Madame Iris's stall was a data-collection point.
turns.choice_a: Copy the full output register for the City Watch (Investigation DC 12)
turns.consequence_a: Success: You transcribe every prediction-transmission. This constitutes evidence of intelligence infiltration at the highest level. The Watch will be alarmed. (+1 Lore, Watch alerted)
turns.choice_b: Focus on extracting the machine's core AI components (Arcana DC 14)
turns.consequence_b: Success: You remove the AI core carefully. It is the size of a walnut, made of interlocked gear-crystal. Still warm. Still slightly aware. (+1 Lore, Concordat AI Core obtained as rare item)
turns.convergence: The output register's final entry—transmitted this morning—is a question. Three words in Concordat chitter-code. The archivist you brought translates, pale-faced: 'IS THE HOST WILLING?'

turns.narrative: You return to Madame Iris's stall. She has Pip in her arms now—the crowd has dispersed, spooked by his screaming fit. She is rocking him like an infant. When you approach, Pip looks at you with those blue eyes, and they are dimmer now. The machine is down. He squeaks once, softly. Iris translates from long habit: 'He says thank you.' Then she catches herself: 'That's ridiculous. He's just a rat.' She looks at you. 'Isn't he?'
turns.choice_a: Tell Madame Iris the full truth about her beloved Pip (Persuasion DC 11)
turns.consequence_a: Success: She listens without interrupting. When you finish, she is silent for a long time. Then: 'He still chose to warn me when others were in danger. Even if someone told him to.' She keeps him. (+2 Reputation)
turns.choice_b: Tell her only what she needs to know: Pip is safe, the source of the predictions has been neutralized
turns.consequence_b: She accepts this with visible relief. 'I don't want to know more. Can I keep him?' Yes. Pip lives out a quiet, ordinary rat life. (+1 Reputation, you preserve her peace of mind)
turns.convergence: Pip receives one more faint signal—a vestigial burst from a secondary relay two blocks away. He squeaks it to you in the pattern you now recognize. You can read a single word in Concordat code: 'CONCORDAT.'

turns.narrative: The secondary relay is a small copper disc embedded in the mortar of the Market Ward fountain's central basin—waterproofed, designed to last centuries. Its signal is weak now that the Archive machine is down, but it still pulses. You remove it cleanly with a thin blade. Pip's eyes go fully dark for a moment, then relight with ordinary brown. He squeaks once, annoyed, and tucks his nose under Iris's thumb. He is just a rat. But the disc in your hand still vibrates faintly against your palm—as if something very far away is still trying to listen.
turns.choice_a: Deliver Pip to the City Anatomist alongside the disc (yields full Concordat analysis)
turns.consequence_a: The anatomist's report, delivered a week later: 'Bio-receiver implant, Concordat Division Seven, Intelligence Grade. The rat was selected for docility and longevity, then implanted as a larva. This is not experimentation. This was deployment.' (+2 Lore, Concordat research report filed)
turns.choice_b: Keep Pip with Madame Iris; bring only the disc to the Anatomist
turns.consequence_b: The disc analysis is sufficient. The Anatomist confirms the network is larger: 'This relay was designed for a grid of 40+ nodes. You found 14. There are more.' (+1 Lore, partial network map)
turns.convergence: Quest Complete. Pip the Prophet was a Concordat intelligence asset, active for 200 years, reporting citizen sentiment data. The rats are not pests. They are a network.

conclusion: The source of Pip's predictive data is severed, collapsing Iris's operation. The discovery that the rat's neural implant was actively receiving encrypted market fluctuations from deep within the city's abandoned infrastructure proves the augmented vermin are being used as a distributed, living intelligence network.
loot_table: Concordat Guard-Rat Bioplate x4 (crafting material, light armor quality)
Concordat AI Core (rare item - still slightly aware, can be used to decode rat chitter-signals)
Madame Iris's Tarot Deck (grants +1 to Insight checks, she gives it willingly)

risk_matrix.penalty: Pip's 'predictions' escalate to mass panic. Citizens riot at Market Ward. -3 Settlement Morale, -1 Market Ward Stability.
risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed quietly. The situation remains unresolved.

title: Shadow-Hole Cartography

unlock_conditions.event_trigger: City surveyor reports reality-tears appearing in geometric pattern across Lower Ward

location: Lower Ward - streets, alleys, and sub-levels
key_npcs: Surveyor Mott (Lower Ward city surveyor, quest-giver)
Gella the Fence (Lower Ward information broker, optional contact)
permanent_effects: Shadow-rift map obtained (reveals summoning circle pattern)
Player learns Shadow-Rats are actively constructing something

collapse_circle.description: Physically damage the rift-anchors to collapse the summoning circle

consequences.ambient_hazard: Shadow-Rats triple their activity in Lower Ward for 2 sessions before new pattern emerges

report_to_guild.description: Deliver the completed summoning circle map to the Mage Guild

consequences.lore_gain: Mage Guild identifies circle as Concordat-designed probability siphon: drains luck from geographic area

description: Surveyor Mott has discovered fourteen 'shadow-holes'—unnerving tears in the visual spectrum occurring near the Lower Ward's foundational walls. Adjacent to these tears are tiny footprints that are not quite rat and not quite mechanical. The tears form a deliberate polygon, suggesting an organized pattern of observation or intrusion. The party must investigate Mott's map, identify what the augmented vermin are searching for, and collapse the localized stealth fields before whatever is being tracked escapes containment.

turns.narrative: Surveyor Mott quickly spreads his heavy, damp charts across an overturned barrel top in the relentless rain. He is a precise, wildly anxious man, and his scarred hands aggressively shake as he traces the reported 'shadow-holes' tightly with a thick grease pencil. 'Fourteen confirmed visual tears in the Lower Ward,' he mutters rapidly, 'each appearing over the past six weeks, each one growing slightly larger than the last.' Near each localized optical tear, he notes tiny, disturbingly deep footprints in the mud—too heavy for rats, the completely wrong shape for mice. 'I properly mapped them,' he says, his voice breaking. 'Look. Look at the precise shape.' The marks form a massive, frighteningly perfect geometric polygon spanning three city blocks. He cannot yet tell what polygon it is, but it is undeniably engineered.
turns.choice_a: Take Mott's chart and survey the nearest three tears directly (Investigation DC 11)
turns.consequence_a: You meticulously connect his trembling lines, calculating the exact geographic center of the massive geometric shape. The intersection perfectly pinpoints the heavily guarded, completely restricted main access point of the Ward's primary water filtration plant.
turns.choice_b: Ask Gella the Fence about unusual shadow activity in her territory (Persuasion DC 12)
turns.consequence_b: You absolutely ignore the complex map entirely, relying purely on raw tracking skills. You flawlessly follow the strangely heavy, perfectly spaced metallic footprints leading directly away from the most recently reported optical anomaly into a darkened alleyway.
turns.convergence: Following the unnervingly perfect trail, you suddenly realize the thick shadows around you are visually bending and violently warping. A small pack of stealth-augmented, biomechanical rats drops aggressively from the corroded rooftops.

turns.narrative: The second shadow-hole is in an alley between a tanner's shop and a canal wall. It exists as a shimmer in the air, knee-height, roughly the size of a dinner plate—and from it spills not cold or heat, just wrongness. Standing near it makes you feel like the next moment is slightly less certain than it should be. A copper on the ground near the hole is tails. You flip it repeatedly. It is always tails. Twelve times. Possibility is draining. This is what the Shadow-Rats create: probability voids.
turns.choice_a: Study the tear's edge structure for engineering clues (Arcana DC 13)
turns.consequence_a: Success: The tear has an anchor—a tiny copper spike driven into the cobblestone, barely visible. Concordat manufacture mark visible under magnifying glass. The rats are placing anchors, then vibrating the tears open. (+1 Lore, anchor spike obtained)
turns.choice_b: Attempt to close the tear by removing the anchor spike (Athletics DC 11)
turns.consequence_b: Success: The tear collapses with a sound like a snapped string. The wrongness drains. Your next coin flip: heads. Making it 50/50 again. (+1 Progress). But: three Shadow-Rats emerge from the wall and screech at the disturbance.
turns.convergence: Whether you closed the tear or not, you have an anchor spike. Every tear has one. There are at least 12 total. The pattern continues to resolve.

turns.narrative: You track a Shadow-Rat placing an anchor. They are not like normal rats: their fur is the exact color of the space between objects, making them nearly invisible unless moving. They move with precision—measuring distances with their own body lengths, placing the spike with their forepaws at a very specific angle, then vibrating at a subsonic frequency until the reality-fold opens. It takes about 90 seconds. They do not look like animals behaving instinctively. They look like workers on a job.
turns.choice_a: Catch a Shadow-Rat mid-placement (Dexterity DC 13)
turns.consequence_a: Success: The rat shrieks. Its fur cycles rapidly through colors—it doesn't know how to be caught. Under examination: body temperature 10 degrees below ambient, no heartbeat, but alive. A bio-mechanical that runs cold. (+1 Lore)
turns.choice_b: Follow this Shadow-Rat to its origin point without being detected (Stealth DC 14)
turns.consequence_b: Success: It leads you to a drain junction beneath the Lower Ward that connects to a Concordat-era maintenance tunnel. Fresh footprints of dozens of Shadow-Rats. A headquarters. (+1 Progress, tunnel located)
turns.convergence: Mott's map now has 9 confirmed tear-locations. The 12-sided polygon is nearly complete. He has tried to calculate the center point on his own. He calls you, pale: 'The center of the pattern is the Lower Ward Orphanage.'

turns.narrative: The Concordat maintenance tunnel is dry, precisely engineered, and very old. Every 10 feet, a copper marker is embedded in the wall—research station numbers, running from 1 to 40. The last 15 stations are dark. The first 25 glow faintly, powered by mana-wiring still intact from before the Scourge. At Station 12, you find a wall chart—still legible, protected behind glass—that shows a circle. Twelve points. A 12-sided geometric figure with annotations in old Concordat script that Mott, squinting over your shoulder, slowly translates.
turns.choice_a: Have Mott translate the annotation fully (takes 20 minutes, full discovery route)
turns.consequence_a: Success: 'Probability Siphon, Implementation Stage 3 of 5. Upon completion of the 12-node ring, the enclosed area will experience sustained luck-deficit: 40% reduction in positive probability outcomes across all citizens within boundary.' It drains fortune from living beings. (+2 Lore)
turns.choice_b: Photograph/copy the chart and bring it to the Mage Guild immediately (faster, partial discovery)
turns.consequence_b: The Guild's senior archivist blanches: 'This is Concordat Division Four work—Psychological Applications. The siphon doesn't just drain luck. It causes despair. It was used to soften civilian populations before occupation.' (+1 Lore, Guild alarmed)
turns.convergence: Three more Shadow-Rats are in the tunnel. They see you. They do not run. They stand in a perfect equilateral triangle and begin vibrating together. The tunnel walls shimmer. They are attempting to open a tear here, in the tunnel, around you.

turns.narrative: The tunnel-tear is larger than the street tears—these three rats working together can generate a fold three times the size of a single-rat anchor. Inside the forming tear, you glimpse something: a space that is not space, dark the way deep water is dark, with shapes moving in it that are the size of horses. You have two minutes before the tear is stable enough to let something through. The Shadow-Rats do not stop vibrating when you attack them. Pain response: negligible. They are on task.
turns.choice_a: Destroy all three anchor spikes simultaneously, collapsing the tear (Dexterity + Athletics DC 15, group effort)
turns.consequence_a: Success: You and Mott both dive for spikes. A three-way collapse sounds like three snapped strings at once. The tear implodes. The shapes beyond it are gone. The Shadow-Rats crumple—their task-purpose severed, they go inert. (+1 Progress)
turns.choice_b: Fight the three Shadow-Rats to break their triangle formation (Combat DC 13)
turns.consequence_b: Success: Breaking the formation interrupts the resonance frequency. The tear collapses on its own. Shadow-Rats scatter. One is stunned—you can examine it. (+1 Combat Progress, bioplate obtained)
turns.convergence: The tunnel is quiet. The Concordat map is in your hands. You have everything you need to complete the cartography of the outer ring and locate all 12 anchor points. Now: what do you do with that information?

turns.narrative: With Mott's fieldwork and your anchor-spike data, the map is complete. Twelve nodes, twelve tears, forming a 12-sided ring around the Lower Ward Orphanage at its center. The final three tears haven't been placed yet—the Shadow-Rats are still working toward completion. You have perhaps four nights before the ring closes. Mott stands at the map table, a ruler in his hand, and measures the exact center. 'The orphanage has 34 children in residence,' he says quietly.
turns.choice_a: Move to collapse all existing 9 anchor nodes tonight, disrupting the incomplete circle (Action-oriented)
turns.consequence_a: You spend the night pulling spikes and collapsing tears. By dawn, 9 tears are destroyed. Shadow-Rat activity spikes—they screech through the Lower Ward all night. But the ring is broken. (+1 Progress, +2 Settlement Morale from protective action)
turns.choice_b: Bring the completed map to City Watch and Mage Guild, requesting a coordinated response (Strategic)
turns.consequence_b: The Watch captain stares at the map for a long time. 'Every single Watch officer in Lower Ward, tonight. Every mage we can borrow. We close all 12 simultaneously before they add the last three.' (+1 Progress, Watch fully engaged)
turns.convergence: Either way, the Shadow-Rats respond. They accelerate. Three new tears appear by morning—they have somehow already placed the next anchors, anticipating interference. They are adapting. The circle is at 10 of 12 nodes.

turns.narrative: The remaining two Shadow-Rat anchor placements are happening simultaneously at opposite ends of the Ward—a two-front problem. One near the tanner's canal. One in the back cellar of a pastry shop, where a family of eight lives above. Your time is almost gone.
turns.choice_a: Split your party: you take the cellar, Mott and a Watch officer take the canal (Leadership DC 13)
turns.consequence_a: Success: Both teams reach their targets within 30 seconds of each other. Both anchors seized before vibration can begin. The pastry-shop family never knows how close it was. (+1 Progress, clean resolution)
turns.choice_b: Prioritize the cellar anchor (civilians at risk) and sprint back (Athletics DC 14)
turns.consequence_b: Success: You secure the cellar anchor. The canal anchor is placed—tear #11 appears—but without #12, the circle cannot close. You still have time. (+1 Progress, partial success)
turns.convergence: Eleven nodes. One remains. The Shadow-Rats have gone silent. Somewhere in the Lower Ward, the last team of them is waiting for a moment you won't see coming. They are patient. They have been patient for 200 years.

turns.narrative: The twelfth node: the Shadow-Rats chose the orphanage itself. While you were dealing with the outer ring, a single Shadow-Rat slipped inside—through a child's bedroom window, through a gap in the foundation—and placed the final anchor beneath the orphanage hearth. You find it because one of the children, a girl named Renna, heard 'a funny vibrating in the floor' and went to Matron Hale. The tear is forming slowly, the rat still vibrating in the cellar below.
turns.choice_a: Enter the cellar and end the rat before the tear fully forms (Stealth + Combat DC 11, no time for finesse)
turns.consequence_a: Success: It is a single rat, alone, determined. You kill it quickly. The tear collapses mid-formation. The orphanage is clean. (+1 Progress, children safe)
turns.choice_b: Evacuate the orphanage first, then deal with the tear (prioritize civilian safety)
