turns.consequence_b: Success: 34 children and Matron Hale are in the street within 4 minutes. The tear opens fully in the empty orphanage—but without 34 luck-sources inside, the siphon is dormant. It can be safely collapsed at leisure. (+1 Reputation, +2 Settlement Morale)
turns.convergence: The 12th anchor is destroyed. The circle is broken. Every existing tear deflates simultaneously with a sound like a city exhaling. Shadow-Rat behavior across Lower Ward: total cessation, as if a power source was cut. Mott rolls his map up slowly. 'They'll start again,' he says. 'Somewhere else.' He is right.

turns.narrative: You file your report with the Watch: 12 Shadow-Rat tears, a Concordat probability-siphon summoning circle, and evidence of organized, task-directed rat behavior. The Watch Captain reads everything twice and says: 'What is a probability siphon?' You explain. He reads the Concordat Station 12 annotation again. Then he says, 'Who built these rats?' And neither of you has an answer.
turns.choice_a: Submit full report including the tunnel location and Station 12 chart to the Mage Guild
turns.consequence_a: The Mage Guild seals the tunnel with containment glyphs and assigns two scholars to translation work. Two weeks later: partial translation confirms the Concordat had 40 research stations under the city. Most are still active. (+2 Lore, Concordat tunnel network flagged for future investigation)
turns.choice_b: Keep the tunnel location private and return alone for further investigation (Investigation DC 14)
turns.consequence_b: You explore 8 more stations before encountering evidence of recent occupation—fresh rat-prints, a fresh anchor spike left mid-construction. The Shadow-Rats use the tunnels for transit. The network below the city is theirs. (+2 Lore, tunnel transit routes mapped)
turns.convergence: Quest Complete. The summoning circle has been disrupted. The Lower Ward probability field stabilizes over the next week—citizens report feeling 'luckier,' though none know why. In Station 12, the Concordat chart still hangs. On it, in handwriting added more recently than the original, someone has penciled in a note in modern script: 'Phase 4 when ready. -V'

conclusion: The interconnected shadow-holes are forcibly closed, disrupting the coordinated surveillance pattern. Mott's map reveals that the augmented rats were perfectly tracing the buried fault lines of an ancient Concordat transit hub, searching for a specific point of entry that the city authorities never knew existed.
loot_table: Concordat Anchor Spikes x12 (tech components, can be repurposed as mana-flux anchors)
Shadow-Rat Bioplate x3 (crafting material, near-invisible light armor)
Station 12 Concordat Chart (rare lore document, partial Concordat tunnel map)
Surveyor Mott's Commission (payment for service): 275 Gold

risk_matrix.penalty: Probability siphon completes. Lower Ward Orphanage citizens suffer persistent despair. -5 Settlement Morale, -2 Lower Ward Stability for remainder of campaign.
risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed quietly. The situation remains unresolved.

title: The Squeaker-Box

unlock_conditions.event_trigger: Inventor Caldwell Voss announces his 'Rodent Vocalization Translator' at a High Ward gathering

location: High Ward - Voss Workshop and surrounding district
key_npcs: Doctor Vane (first named mention, in rat transmissions)
permanent_effects: First direct mention of Doctor Vane by name
Squeaker-Box device obtained (can translate rat chitters for future quests)
Player learns Gloom-Rats carry Star-Ivy spore payload

publicize_translations.description: Voss presents the translated rat communications to the public

consequences.ambient_hazard: Mass paranoia about rats. Citizens begin exterminating all vermin indiscriminately, disrupting Concordat intelligence network (minor)
consequences.lore_gain: City-wide awareness that rats are communicating raises the threat rating of all Vermin encounters

suppress_translations.description: Keep the translations private, use them as intelligence

consequences.lore_gain: Confidential Concordat intelligence advantage: player can 'listen' to rat chitters via Squeaker-Box for tactical data before encounters

description: Inventor Caldwell Voss has successfully captured a heavily augmented warehouse rat and integrated it into a 'Squeaker-Box', a massive contraption of mana-crystal resonators designed to translate the vermin's neural signals. The translated output reveals the rat is receiving operational commands designating locations in Sector 9. The party must defend Voss's exposed laboratory, extract the full list of automated targets, and trace the origin point of the mechanical voice directing the city's vermin.

turns.narrative: Caldwell Voss is a terrifyingly delighted man. His massive, chaotic workshop is a veritable hurricane of rusted copper tubes, glowing glass chambers, and heavy tools. The 'Squeaker-Box' firmly sits at the exact center of it all: a magnificent, terrifying contraption of raw mana-crystal resonators and vibrating acoustic membranes, roughly the size of a heavy iron safe, with a small brass trumpet functioning as its primary output over a wire cage. His captured test subject, an unusually large warehouse rat whose spine is woven with thick copper, furiously paces inside. Voss aggressively cranks a heavy iron handle. The device hums with a sickening pitch. The rat suddenly goes entirely still, its eyes rolling back, and the brass trumpet announces in a perfectly flat, completely mechanical voice: 'Sector 9. Designated node completely inactive. Replacement sequence officially scheduled.' Voss blinks rapidly in utter shock. 'I thoroughly expected something significantly more... animal,' he admits quietly.
turns.choice_a: Ask Voss to translate more of the rat's speech immediately (Investigation DC 10)
turns.consequence_a: You notice the heavily augmented rat violently throwing itself against the thin wire. You quickly and seamlessly reinforce the cage's delicate latch mechanism with a strong iron pin, wholly preventing the desperate creature from escaping its forced translation.
turns.choice_b: Examine the Squeaker-Box machinery itself (Arcana DC 12)
turns.consequence_b: You completely ignore Voss's shock and frantically copy down the exact, precise mechanical coordinates the brass trumpet is mechanically repeating into your leather journal. You successfully capture the highly sensitive target location perfectly before the machine overheats.
turns.convergence: Overloading under the immense strain of the translation, a primary glass resonator violently shatters. The loud explosion attracts a heavily armed, deeply corrupted patrol of Ward Guards who incredibly seem to have been frantically searching for this exact signal.

turns.narrative: Voss has attracted attention. Three High Ward nobles, hearing rumors of the 'talking rat,' have arrived at the workshop to witness the demonstration. They find it charming, then unsettling, then actively frightening as the rat's translations grow more specific: 'Noble household Target-7, mana-wiring vulnerability confirmed, infection vector available.' One of the nobles goes pale—that is her household number, she realizes. She has a rat problem.
turns.choice_a: Convince the nobles to stay quiet about the device (Persuasion DC 14)
turns.consequence_a: Success: They agree, nervously. The Squeaker-Box remains a secret intelligence asset rather than a public spectacle. (+1 Progress, suppression path opens)
turns.choice_b: Use this moment to build a coalition—nobles with resources can accelerate the investigation (Leadership DC 13)
turns.consequence_b: Success: Noble Lady Orvaine pledges her household guard and access to the High Ward's private mana-wiring schematics. The investigation gains significant resources. (+1 Progress, Noble ally gained)
turns.convergence: The rat says one more thing before its translation cycle ends: 'Doctor Vane sends regards.' Then it simply stops talking, sits down, and begins grooming itself like a perfectly ordinary rat.

turns.narrative: The name 'Doctor Vane' hangs in the workshop air. Voss writes it down immediately—he is a documenter by nature. None of the nobles recognize it. But when you mention it to Voss's assistant, a young researcher named Tilda who has clearly been eavesdropping, she goes white. 'Vane is in the Concordat records,' she whispers. 'I saw the name once, in the restricted archive. Pre-Scourge. Division Seven, listed as Chief Bio-Engineer.' She swallows. 'But Division Seven records are sealed. Have been since the Scourge.' You ask her the obvious question. 'Yes,' she says. 'Vane could be a historical name. Or it could be a title, passed down.' She pauses. 'Or he could still be alive.'
turns.choice_a: Ask Tilda to help search restricted Concordat records for Vane's full dossier (Research, DC 14, Tilda needed)
turns.consequence_a: Success: After two hours of searching, she finds a partial file: 'Vane, Aldric. Born pre-Scourge. Architect of Vermin Vectors program. Status: UNKNOWN. Last sighting: immediately post-Scourge.' Unknown means not confirmed dead. (+2 Lore, Vane codex entry established)
turns.choice_b: Test the Squeaker-Box on every rat in the neighborhood (sweep approach, Investigation DC 11)
turns.consequence_b: Success: Seven rats in the surrounding three blocks, each one transmitting. Five are standard logistics reports. One is a structural report on a mana-pipe junction. One, disturbingly, is transmitting: 'Squeaker-Box threat confirmed. Neutralization team en route.' (+1 Intel, you have 30 minutes before Guard-Rats arrive)
turns.convergence: Voss is writing with manic speed, capturing every translated fragment. He is thrilled. He has no idea how much danger his workshop is in.

turns.narrative: Three Gloom-Rats have entered the workshop through a gap between the floorboards and the foundation wall. They are moving toward the Squeaker-Box with purpose: not the random exploration of normal rodents but the targeted approach of units on assignment. Gloom-Rats are the largest vermin type—the size of a small dog, their fur a deep wet grey, their bodies slightly swollen with the Star-Ivy spore sacs visible as pulsing blue nodes beneath the skin. If those spore sacs rupture indoors, the workshop becomes a Star-Ivy incubation chamber.
turns.choice_a: Contain the Gloom-Rats before they reach the Squeaker-Box (Combat DC 12, avoid rupturing spore sacs)
turns.consequence_a: Success: The trick is force control—enough to stop them, not enough to rupture. You pin two with furnishings, stun the third. Voss helps, wielding a copper tube with surprising effectiveness. All three captured without spore release. (+1 Progress)
turns.choice_b: Get Voss and the device out while drawing the Gloom-Rats away (Dexterity + Persuasion DC 13)
turns.consequence_b: Success: You shout at Voss to run, then make yourself the most interesting thing in the room. Three Gloom-Rats chase you through the workshop. You lead them into an empty storage room and lock the door. (+1 Progress, workshop evacuation successful)
turns.convergence: The Gloom-Rats sent to neutralize the Squeaker-Box have failed. But they sent a report before they arrived. Whatever 'Doctor Vane' is, it knows the device exists. The next response will be more substantial.

turns.narrative: Voss, safe in a borrowed neighboring workshop, is still translating. He cannot stop—the Squeaker-Box is his life's work and the rats keep talking. Among the mundane logistics, a fragment surfaces that Voss reads aloud in a quieter voice than usual: 'Star-Ivy deployment targets, Phase 2: (1) High Ward water cistern. (2) Market Ward grain storage. (3) Lower Ward bread distribution.' These are not random targets. They are the city's food and water infrastructure. The rats are not sabotaging mana-wiring for fun. They are softening the city for something.
turns.choice_a: Immediately warn city infrastructure authorities (Leadership DC 12)
turns.consequence_a: Success: City Watch and the Water Authority are alerted within the hour. Inspections of all three target sites begin. Two Guard-Rat nests found in the cistern tunnels before deployment can occur. (+2 Settlement Stability, attack prevented)
turns.choice_b: Use the Squeaker-Box to intercept and decode the activation signal before acting (Arcana DC 15)
turns.consequence_b: Success: You identify the signal pattern that would trigger spore deployment. It hasn't been sent yet. You have the ability to detect when it IS sent—giving you 10 minutes of advance warning. (+2 Intel, deployment detection ability gained)
turns.convergence: Voss holds up one more translation. It is different from all the others—not logistics, not status, not coordination. It is a name. A single human name, repeated four times. Yours.

turns.narrative: The rats know your name. They've been tracking you since at least the Market Ward—possibly earlier. The translation renders it in the flat mechanical voice of the Squeaker-Box: your name, followed by 'Threat classification: Elevated. Behavioral pattern: Pattern-recognition, threat-assessment, escalating interference. Disposition recommendation: Isolate and study.' Voss reads this and slowly looks at you. 'I built a machine to talk to rats,' he says. 'And it turns out they've been talking about you for weeks.' He is quiet for a moment. 'How long do you think they've been watching us?'
turns.choice_a: Use your name being known as a leverage point—transmit a deliberate message to the network via Squeaker-Box (Arcana DC 15, bold)
turns.consequence_a: Success: You instruct Voss to calibrate the Box as a transmitter rather than receiver. You say: 'Tell Doctor Vane we're coming.' The Box broadcasts it in Concordat chitter-code on the network frequency. The rats in the room go silent for 30 full seconds. Then resume as normal. (+1 Lore, Doctor Vane is notified you know his name)
turns.choice_b: Feed false information into the network to mislead the Concordat AI (Deception + Arcana DC 16)
turns.consequence_b: Success: You have Voss transmit false reports: 'Squeaker-Box destroyed. Investigator neutralized. Operations nominal.' The surveillance rating on you drops for several sessions. (+2 Tactical advantage, reduced Concordat attention for 3 sessions)
turns.convergence: Either choice, the Squeaker-Box has changed the equation. The rats are not just running a network—they are being managed by something that adapts. It heard your message, or it believed your deception. Either way: it responded.

turns.narrative: A 12-rat coordinated strike hits the workshop that evening—Guard-Rats and Gloom-Rats in coordinated teams, the first full mixed-unit assault you've faced. They enter from three directions: the window, the drain, and somehow through the chimney. The goal is clearly the Squeaker-Box. Voss has it in his arms and is backing toward the wall, eyes wide. This is the Concordat network's full tactical response: not a threesome of Gloom-Rats but a proper unit acting in concert.
turns.choice_a: Defend the Squeaker-Box—hold position and fight the full unit (Combat DC 14, multiple waves)
turns.consequence_a: Success: It is punishing. You take hits. The workshop sustains damage. But 12 rats, fought methodically by someone who has been learning their patterns, are not 12 uncountable enemies. All repelled. Squeaker-Box intact. (+1 Progress, hard combat)
turns.choice_b: Retreat with Squeaker-Box to Voss's secondary location across the Ward (Athletics + Stealth DC 13)
turns.consequence_b: Success: A running retreat through alleys, Voss clutching the Box, you clearing the path. The rats pursue for four blocks then stop—their mission was to destroy the device in the workshop, and you've left their operational radius. (+1 Progress, cleaner outcome, device safe)
turns.convergence: The device is safe. The network has spent significant resources trying to recover it and failed. In the aftermath, Voss plays one more translation: a final message, broadcast on a new frequency the Box almost missed. It is a direction, not a report. It says, in perfectly clear Concordat code: 'Enough. Let them have the machine. -V.'

turns.narrative: Doctor Vane stood down the assault. That single decision reveals something extraordinary: whatever the Concordat network is—whether it's an AI, a 200-year-old man, or a title passed to a successor—it is making strategic concessions. It let you keep the Squeaker-Box. Either it has calculated that the device is not a long-term threat, or it has decided you are more useful as an informed investigator than a blundering one. The question is which. Voss seals the Squeaker-Box in a leather case and hands it to you. 'I built it to understand nature,' he says. 'Nature, it turns out, is listening back.'
turns.choice_a: Bring Voss's translations to the Warden Council for immediate public disclosure (publicize path)
turns.consequence_a: The Council debates for two days. In the end, they announce: 'The rat population has been confirmed to carry foreign biological components.' Mass rat culls begin. Concordat network disrupted (moderate). Settlement morale -2 from public fear, but public awareness raised. (+1 Lore to all citizens effectively)
turns.choice_b: Classify the translations as intelligence and work with the Watch covertly (suppress path)
turns.consequence_b: A small Watch team is briefed. The Squeaker-Box is used in weekly sweeps. Over the next month, 6 planned Concordat operations are identified and intercepted before execution. No mass panic. (+2 Settlement Stability over time)
turns.convergence: Quest Complete. The Squeaker-Box is yours. It can translate Concordat chitter-code—a tool of immense value in every subsequent Vermin thread quest. Doctor Vane is real, named, and strategic. The rats are not just watching. They are being watched over.

conclusion: Voss's laboratory is violently secured and the Squeaker-Box successfully extracts the full target list before shutting down. The mechanical voice commanding the augmented rats to specific nodes mathematically confirms the vermin are operating as an organized, city-wide maintenance and espionage network.
loot_table: Squeaker-Box Translator (unique device - translates rat chitters in-scene, permanent quest tool)
Gloom-Rat Spore Sac x3 (dangerous crafting material - Star-Ivy spore, handle with care)
Concordat Transmission Logs (20 pages of translated rat reports, rich lore document)
Voss Workshop Repair Fund (donated by nobles): 325 Gold

risk_matrix.penalty: Gloom-Rats rupture spore sacs inside workshop. Star-Ivy incubation begins. High Ward quarantined. -5 Settlement Stability, -3 Settlement Morale.
risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed quietly. The situation remains unresolved.

title: The Rat-Funeral

unlock_conditions.event_trigger: Lower Ward sewer workers report rats holding a gathering around a dead Copper-Tail, preventing workers from accessing the junction

location: Lower Ward - Sewer Junction 7 and surrounding tunnels
key_npcs: The Funeral Rats (dozens, organized, hostile if interrupted)
The Dead Copper-Tail (the deceased, unexpectedly important)
Concordat Record Fragment (found inside deceased's body cavity)
permanent_effects: Concordat Record Fragment recovered (encoded mission data)
Player discovers Copper-Tails have individual assigned mission IDs
Player learns the rats have something resembling grief-protocol

observe_respectfully.description: Allow the funeral to complete, observe and document

consequences.lore_gain: Funeral ritual reveals Copper-Tails transmit mission data at death—the body of the deceased is a data-package
consequences.ambient_hazard: Rats note your respectful presence. Shadow-Rat surveillance of player decreases by 1 tier for 2 sessions

interrupt_and_seize.description: Break up the funeral and take the deceased for examination

consequences.ambient_hazard: Rat hostility rating increases permanently by 1 tier. All subsequent Vermin encounters have +1 enemy unit

description: Sewer-Worker Bram Hoyle has discovered sixty rats completely immobilized in a tight, perfectly circular formation deep in the sewage junctions, engaged in a terrifying 'Rat Vigil'. They hold a low, rhythmic hum over a single dead vermin carrying advanced, heavy metallic implants. The party must carefully disrupt the bizarre vigil, retrieve the central, highly valuable augmented corpse, and survive the unified psychic backlash of a hive-mind that does not behave like normal animals.

turns.narrative: Sewer-Worker Bram Hoyle is a massive, heavily scarred man who is profoundly used to rats and does not typically find any vermin remotely distressing. He currently looks absolutely terrified. 'Exactly sixty of them,' he aggressively whispers, motioning with a shaking lantern toward the heavy iron sewer junction. You can perfectly hear a strange, incredibly faint noise echoing off the wet stone—not squeaking, but something significantly lower, much more rhythmic. A deeply unified, sickening hum, like a single, perfectly sustained mechanical note held by dozens of tiny, wet voices. 'They have been sitting perfectly still there all night. The massive dead one lying in the exact middle, I genuinely do not know if it was there first or if they purposefully brought it. And they utterly refuse to move. I violently kicked a heavy iron bucket directly near them. They just... turned in perfect unison and looked at me. Then they turned perfectly back.' He pauses, wiping pure sweat from his forehead. 'It was absolutely not an animal look.'
turns.choice_a: Approach the junction slowly, with no threatening movements (Animal Handling DC 11)
turns.consequence_a: You carefully extend a long, perfectly balanced iron hook smoothly over the humming circle, decisively snagging the heavy, metallic corpse. You successfully deeply reel it back into the shadows smoothly without touching a single living rat.
turns.choice_b: Observe from a distance and document the ritual structure (Investigation DC 12)
turns.consequence_b: You violently hurl a highly contained, rapidly expanding burst of intense magical flame directly over their perfect circle. The intense, searing heat instantly breaks their deeply terrifying unified trance, rapidly scattering the heavily singed vermin in absolute, squeaking terror.
turns.convergence: As the unified hum abruptly completely breaks, the heavy, metallic corpse violently splits open in your possession, rapidly leaking a highly toxic, glowing green 'data-fluid' that immediately begins brutally burning cleanly through the stone floor.

turns.narrative: The humming shifts in pitch. You recognize the pattern now—you've heard it before if you've used the Squeaker-Box (or in the ambient rat-chitter of the lower city): it is Concordat chitter-code, but slowed, deepened, layered by 60 voices simultaneously. They are not grieving in any human sense. They are transmitting. The dead Copper-Tail's body is the subject of the transmission. They are reading from it—the way an archivist reads from a document—and broadcasting the contents across the network. This is a data-transfer ceremony, not a burial.
turns.choice_a: Attempt to record the transmission using any available means (Arcana DC 13, or Squeaker-Box if held)
turns.consequence_a: Success (Squeaker-Box present): Full translation: the dead Copper-Tail's mission record. 40 mana-infrastructure sabotage points, each logged with location and damage assessment. This is a mission completion report. (+2 Lore). Success (without device, DC 13 Arcana): You recognize the structure and frequency. Can't translate, but pattern is recorded for later. (+1 Lore)
turns.choice_b: Simply watch and let the ceremony complete without interference (Insight DC 10)
turns.consequence_b: Success: The ceremony takes 40 more minutes. Over that time you observe: the rats rotate in the outer ring (they have watches), some arrive fresh, some leave, but the inner circle never changes. When it ends, the inner circle disperses first—mission accomplished. (+1 Lore, full observation record)
turns.convergence: Bram Hoyle, watching from the access ladder, whispers: 'It's organizing itself. Like a military unit.' He looks at you. 'My grandfather was in the city guard. That's what he said a military debrief looks like. You report, you're released. That's a debrief.'

turns.narrative: When the inner circle disperses, three rats remain with the body: two standing guard, one—larger, broader, with a notably worn look around its implants—sitting with its forepaws resting on the dead Copper-Tail's body. This remaining rat does not look like it is following protocol. It looks like it has stayed of its own accord. Its eyes are not the bright blue of active units—they are dim, pulsing slow. It has been with the body since before the ceremony. You get the unsettling feeling that whatever architecture the Concordat built into these creatures, something in this one has been running longer and evolved further than intended.
turns.choice_a: Approach the remaining rat gently, without weapons (Animal Handling DC 14, Insight DC 12)
turns.consequence_a: Success: The rat holds its ground as you approach. At arm's length, it looks up at you, and what you see in its face is not animal. Not human either. Something in between. It permits you to touch the body beside it. Then it steps back and waits, watching. It is giving you permission. (+1 Lore, +1 Faction: Strange Rapport with Old-Unit rats)
turns.choice_b: Keep your distance and examine the body from here using available equipment (Investigation DC 13)
turns.consequence_b: Success: From six feet, you observe the body's decay pattern is unusual—slower than it should be in a sewer environment. The Concordat bioware in the Copper-Tail is still running on residual power, preserving the body for data-transmission purposes. (+1 Lore)
turns.convergence: The old, worn rat watches you. It squeaks once—a single note, not a report. Then it walks away down the sewer tunnel with the deliberate slowness of something very tired. Bram says nothing.

turns.narrative: With the funeral concluded and the rats dispersed, you can examine the body. The dead Copper-Tail is a marvel of pre-Scourge engineering: the copper-filament network beneath the skin is intact and still faintly powered, individual mana-wire sabotage tools stored in hollow bone-cavities in the foreleg, and—most remarkably—a data-storage node embedded behind the left eye that the ceremony was reading from. With the right tools, the node still has readable content.
turns.choice_a: Extract the data-storage node intact for analysis (Medicine or Arcana DC 14)
turns.consequence_a: Success: The node comes free cleanly. On examination: a Concordat Record Fragment, containing 40 sabotage mission logs, a partial map of High Ward mana-wiring, and—crucially—a unit identification code: CT-2847. This rat had a name. A designation. It was unit 2847 in the Copper-Tail program. (+2 Lore, Concordat Record Fragment obtained)
turns.choice_b: Examine the sabotage tools without removing the node (non-destructive approach)
turns.consequence_b: You study and sketch the sabotage apparatus in detail. The tools are elegant: piezoelectric disruptors that cause mana-wire corrosion on contact, precise enough to target a single wire without disturbing adjacent infrastructure. This Concordat-Tail was not eating wires randomly. It was performing targeted surgical infrastructure damage. (+1 Lore, sabotage methodology documented)
turns.convergence: Bram Hoyle kneels beside the body. 'It's smaller than my fist,' he says. 'Smaller than my fist and it's been dismantling the city's infrastructure, one wire at a time, for—how long?' You tell him the Concordat program existed before the Scourge. '200 years,' he says. He is quiet for a while. 'We never noticed.'

turns.narrative: While you've been examining the body, a fresh group of Copper-Tails has appeared in the junction. They are not here for the funeral—that is over. They are here because the junction contains a mana-wire access panel that CT-2847 had logged as 'in progress' in its mission record. The next unit is here to complete the deceased's work. They are efficient. Professional. The mission does not stop because the unit does. Five Copper-Tails begin moving toward the access panel with purpose.
turns.choice_a: Block the access panel and drive the Copper-Tails off (Combat DC 11)
turns.consequence_a: Success: Copper-Tails are durable but not built for direct combat—they are saboteurs. You drive them off in under two minutes. The access panel is secured. (+1 Progress)
turns.choice_b: Let them access the panel but document exactly what sabotage they perform (Stealth + Investigation DC 13)
turns.consequence_b: Success: You observe them executing CT-2847's final mission note: severing one specific mana-wire at Junction 7. You let it happen but understand exactly what was cut and why. The targeted wire feeds the High Ward emergency lighting. (+1 Lore, sabotage pattern documented, but 1 infrastructure damage logged)
turns.convergence: Either way, the Copper-Tails file out after their task is complete or abandoned. CT-2847's mission record is now yours. And somewhere in the data-node, you find a personal notation—not a mission log, not a status report. A single repeated symbol the Concordat archivist in you recognizes as a grief marker from pre-Scourge citizen records. CT-2847 added it itself. For itself.

turns.narrative: The grief marker is a shock. The Concordat rats were designed as tools—bio-mechanical appliances. But something has happened over 200 years that the original engineers did not intend: some units have developed. Not sapience, not human-level consciousness, but something. A sense of loss. A capacity to mark the end of another unit as significant. The old, worn rat that sat with the body—it was not following protocol when it stayed. The Concordat did not program loyalty. The rats built it themselves, over generations, in the dark.
turns.choice_a: Document this finding carefully and report it to the Mage Guild for ethical analysis
turns.consequence_a: The Guild's ethicist will later tell you: 'If they are developing genuine emotional response, the question of what they are becomes considerably more complex. They may not be weapons anymore. They may be something else.' (+2 Lore, Vermin-sentience question raised officially)
turns.choice_b: Keep this finding private—you need time to think about what it means before sharing it
turns.consequence_b: The information sits with you heavily. The next time you are about to strike a rat in combat, you will pause for a moment. That is all. But it is something. (+1 Insight permanently, re: Vermin encounters)
turns.convergence: Bram gets his junction access back. He calls the Watch to report the sabotage. Walking out of the sewer, you look at the ordinary rats that scatter from your feet and wonder: which of them have been here for 200 years? Which of them have names?

turns.narrative: Filing your report at the Watch station, you are assigned to follow up on the mana-wire sabotage map from CT-2847's record: 40 locations, most in the High and Lower Wards. You don't have to act on all of them today—but as a starting point, the three highest-priority targets (Junction 7, the Western Cistern mana-relay, and the Archive mana-trunk) need immediate inspection. The archived Concordat mission log is a complete guide to where the city is most vulnerable.
turns.choice_a: Inspect all three priority targets yourself (Athletics, 2-hour sweep)
turns.consequence_a: Success: All three show evidence of ongoing Copper-Tail attention. Junction 7: sabotage in progress (you witnessed it). Western Cistern relay: 60% degradation, 2 weeks from critical failure. Archive trunk: untouched, next in queue. (+1 Progress, crisis identified early)
turns.choice_b: Delegate the inspections to the Watch and provide CT-2847's map as a guide
turns.consequence_b: The Watch inspector reviews the map and goes pale. 'This is a map of how to take down every major mana-system in the city sequentially, ordered by interdependency. This is a city-shutdown plan.' He files it as a Category A threat. (+2 Settlement Stability from early response, Watch fully mobilized)
turns.convergence: CT-2847's mission record has given you the Concordat's infrastructure attack plan. They have been working it methodically for 200 years. At current pace, the critical cascade begins in approximately 18 months. The question is: what is the cascade for?

turns.narrative: The final task is the Concordat Record Fragment—CT-2847's data node. You bring it to the best analyst available, a retired Concordat scholar named Provost Anwick who has spent forty years translating pre-Scourge documents without fully understanding their context. He is old and dry and brilliant. He reads the fragment in the original Concordat notation and says: 'This is a Phase 3 Preparation Document. Phase 3 of what?' He finds the header. He reads it. He sets the fragment down very carefully. 'Phase 3 of the Reactivation Protocol. They're not trying to destroy the city. They're trying to power something up.'
turns.choice_a: Press Anwick for everything he knows about Concordat Reactivation Protocols
turns.consequence_a: He works for three hours. His notes fill six pages. Summary: 'Reactivation Protocol appears to be a revival procedure for something large, pre-Scourge, that went dormant during the event. The infrastructure sabotage is not random—it's redirecting mana-flow. Toward a single point.' He cannot identify the destination. (+3 Lore, major Concordat reveal)
turns.choice_b: Take the fragment to the Mage Guild's Concordat specialist for independent analysis
turns.consequence_b: The specialist takes three days. Her conclusion matches Anwick's independently: mana-redirection protocol, toward an unknown central point. 'Find the center of the sabotage map geometry,' she says. 'That is what they are waking up.' (+3 Lore, independently confirmed)
turns.convergence: Quest Complete. CT-2847 died completing a mission that its creators set for it 200 years ago. It developed grief in the dark. It carved a grief marker for itself on its last record. And it was building, one mana-wire at a time, toward the reactivation of something none of you can yet name.

conclusion: The eerie Rat Vigil is violently dispersed, and the implanted corpse is safely secured. Analysis of the dead rat's heavy metallic core reveals it was operating as a localized data-relay, proving the vermin are transmitting massive amounts of organized intelligence through their terrifying collective hums.
loot_table: Concordat Record Fragment CT-2847 (mission log, infrastructure map, 40 sabotage points)
Copper-Tail Sabotage Apparatus (intact, craftable into precision tools)
Provost Anwick's Analysis Notes (6-page Reactivation Protocol summary, key lore document)
Sewer Worker's Guild Hazard Payment: 250 Gold

risk_matrix.penalty: Copper-Tail continues CT-2847's mission uninterrupted, Junction 7 mana-wire fully severed. High Ward emergency grid offline. -2 Settlement Stability, -1 High Ward function.
risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed quietly. The situation remains unresolved.

title: The Copper-Plague

unlock_conditions.event_trigger: City lights begin failing across Market Ward at irregular intervals; mana-engineers find copper corrosion of unknown origin in the primary trunk-lines

key_npcs: Doctor Vane (confirmed active - a Copper-Tail transmits direct orders from Vane in Turn 6)
permanent_effects: Doctor Vane confirmed as active, real, and directly commanding Concordat operations
Mana-virus sample obtained (Copper-Plague pathogen, major crafting/research item)
Market Ward mana-infrastructure damage (+1 or -1 to stability depending on outcome)

purge_virus.description: Develop and deploy mana-antiviral to cleanse infected lines

consequences.lore_gain: Mana-antiviral formula obtained for future use against Concordat bio-attacks
consequences.permanent_effect: Market Ward mana-grid fully restored

isolate_sections.description: Cut infected sections from the grid to prevent spread (partial loss, full containment)

consequences.ambient_hazard: Three Market Ward blocks permanently on reduced mana (lower lighting, slower equipment). Contained but scarred.
consequences.lore_gain: Isolated mana-sections become ideal Concordat monitoring points - Shadow-Rats move in within 2 sessions

description: Chief Engineer Sana Verl confronts the party with a massive crisis: the Market Ward's primary mana-trunk tower is failing due to an unnatural, corrosive blue medium spreading through the lines. The corrosion is organic—a deliberately engineered mixture of copper flecks and biological slime introduced by heavily augmented vermin. The party must purge the primary mana-trunk, neutralize the vermin injecting the toxin, and secure the city's power grid from this biological sabotage.

turns.narrative: Chief Engineer Sana Verl desperately meets you directly at the heavy, reinforced iron base of the primary mana-trunk tower deep in the bustling Market Ward. Her scarred, capable hands are deeply stained with a thick, violent copper corrosion she aggressively cannot wash off. The normally perfectly steady, brilliantly blue glow of the massive city mana-grid is violently stuttering violently above you—three completely different districts rapidly going in and completely out like a dying, suffocating fire. 'It started exactly six hours ago,' she says, her voice intensely tight and frighteningly precise. 'The heavy corrosion is aggressively spreading rapidly through the deep trunk lines. It is absolutely not a mechanical failure. Mechanical failure fundamentally does not spread like a living disease. Something highly intelligent is deliberately putting this perfectly into the deeper lines.' She forcefully shoves a small, heavy glass vial directly into your hand: inside, thick, metallic flecks of raw copper float violently in a highly viscous, sickeningly bright blue medium. It strongly smells like hot, burnt metal and incredibly rotting organic tissue. It is profoundly wrong.
turns.choice_a: Analyze the corrosion sample immediately (Arcana DC 12)
turns.consequence_a: You carefully hold the thick glass vial directly to the unstable light, thoroughly identifying the complex biological markers hidden deeply within the sludge. It is heavily weaponized, deliberately engineered copper-infused rat saliva utterly designed to violently break down magical barriers entirely.
turns.choice_b: Inspect the nearest affected section of mana-trunk to find the source (Investigation DC 11)
turns.consequence_b: You flawlessly track the heaviest, thickest trails of the deeply glowing blue slime rapidly down the side of the massive mana-trunk tower perfectly into a deeply hidden, completely corroded maintenance grate violently forced open from the inside out.
turns.convergence: As the erratic power violently surges overhead, three terrifying, heavily augmented 'Slime-Rats' suddenly burst aggressively from the heavy trunk's maintenance panel, their heavily modified, copper-lined jaws dripping violently with the incredibly destructive, brightly glowing blue acid.

turns.narrative: The mana-grid is a tree: a central trunk network branches into district lines, which branch into block lines, which branch into building lines. The Copper-Tails introduced the virus at the trunk level—so it spreads with the mana-current, downstream and upstream simultaneously, following the current in both directions. Verl's team is trying to manually isolate sections but they are not fast enough. There are 14 active entry points. You can help trace and cut off the spread, but it requires moving fast across the Ward.
turns.choice_a: Run point on the 4 most critical trunks, letting Verl's team handle the rest (Athletics + Arcana DC 13)
turns.consequence_a: Success: You identify the 4 highest-velocity spread points and cut them off—physically pulling the mana-fuse arrays to isolate those sections. Grid degradation slows. You buy 3 extra hours. (+1 Progress)
turns.choice_b: Focus on understanding the virus's exact spread pattern to get ahead of it (Investigation DC 14)
turns.consequence_b: Success: The virus doesn't spread randomly—it follows the highest-current pathways. You map it: it will reach the central distribution node in exactly 3 hours and 40 minutes, regardless of branch-cutting. The center must be defended directly. (+1 Lore, critical path identified)
turns.convergence: Three Copper-Tails are caught in the act at Trunk 7—actively biting new entry points, introducing more virus. They do not stop when you approach. They are mid-task and have been instructed not to stop for anything short of physical incapacitation.

turns.narrative: The Trunk 7 Copper-Tails fight with the single-minded ferocity of units executing a critical mission. They are faster than the Junction 7 rats—these appear to be a more recent or upgraded model, their copper-tail apparatus more densely interwoven with the body's musculature. When the first one bites your gauntlet, you feel the piezoelectric discharge—a serious jolt, not just a nip. These are combat-capable saboteurs. And they continue to introduce virus material even as they fight, managing two objectives simultaneously with disturbing efficiency.
turns.choice_a: Neutralize all three rapidly and seal the Trunk 7 entry points (Combat DC 13)
turns.consequence_a: Success: Brutal efficiency required. You take the jolt risk and prioritize speed—two Copper-Tails incapacitated in the first pass, third cornered. Trunk 7 sealed with emergency foam from your kit. Virus introduction stopped at this node. (+1 Progress)
turns.choice_b: Pin one Copper-Tail alive for live analysis while driving off the other two (Combat DC 14, precision)
turns.consequence_b: Success: The live specimen is extraordinary—pinned under a containment case, it continues its virus-introduction behavior even against the case floor, unable to stop its mission protocol. Under observation, you see the virus delivery system: a gland behind the upper incisor, synthesizing the catalyst in real time. (+1 Lore, Copper-Tail bio-mechanism documented, live specimen obtained)
turns.convergence: Trunk 7 is sealed, but Verl's tablet is buzzing constantly now: Trunk 11 critical, Trunk 3 approaching critical, two block-lines down entirely. The Ward's western half is on emergency minimal mana. Businesses are closing. Citizens are worried. The lights keep going out.

turns.narrative: With Verl's data and your Trunk investigation, a partial antiviral approach presents itself: the mana-virus reacts with the current to spread, but in dead sections—mana-off—it becomes inert. If you can pulse the infected sections to zero mana rapidly, the virus stops spreading in those sections while remaining in the conductor material. It won't cure the existing damage, but it will stop new spread. The catch: dropping mana to zero in a city district, even partially, means lights-out for everyone in that area.
turns.choice_a: Execute controlled mana-blackout of affected sections (blocks 3, 7, 11, 14) to freeze virus spread
turns.consequence_a: Success: You coordinate with Verl. Four blocks go dark for 12 hours. Citizens are warned, candles distributed, Watch patrols doubled. Virus contained in those sections—no further spread. Damage: 4 blocks temporarily without power. (+1 Progress, containment achieved, minimal long-term damage)
turns.choice_b: Attempt to develop an in-line antiviral using Arcana and available materials (Arcana DC 16, ambitious)
turns.consequence_b: Success: You synthesize a counter-catalyst from reverse-engineered Concordat chemistry (ironically using notes from the Squeaker-Box translations if available). Introduce it to the main flow: virus neutralized on contact. No blackout required. (+2 Progress, Mana-Antiviral Formula obtained. Failure: blackout becomes necessary anyway, lose 1 hour)
turns.convergence: Either path buys time. The central distribution node is now the critical point. Verl confirms: if that node falls, the cascade is total and irreversible. And standing at the base of the central node tower, you both see them: a line of 20 Copper-Tails, organized in a column, moving toward the node access hatch. This is the main assault.

turns.narrative: Twenty Copper-Tails in a coordinated column is not a pest problem. It is a military operation. They move in staggered pairs, with two larger, armored units at the front acting as point. Their target is the central node access hatch—a small maintenance entry at the base of the distribution tower. If they gain the node interior, they can introduce virus directly into the city's primary mana-heart. Even a partial introduction at that level could crash the entire Market Ward grid within minutes. Behind you, Verl has a fire-suppressant foam unit. You have your weapons. You have 90 seconds before the column reaches the hatch.
turns.choice_a: Hold the hatch with a defensive formation—don't let a single Copper-Tail through (Combat DC 15, sustained defense)
turns.consequence_a: Success: You and Verl hold the hatch for 8 grueling minutes. The Copper-Tails probe every opening in your defense. 12 units defeated or driven off, 8 simply wait at the edge of your reach. A stalemate that favors you—they won't breach, but you can't pursue. (+1 Progress, node protected)
turns.choice_b: Lure the column into the adjacent drainage basin and seal the grating (Tactics DC 14, Environmental use)
turns.consequence_b: Success: Verl activates the drainage flow and you drive the column toward the basin with fire-suppressant foam. The leading units go in, the rest follow rather than break formation. Grating sealed. 20 Copper-Tails contained in a drainage basin 10 feet below street level. Elegant. (+1 Progress, clean containment)
turns.convergence: The column is dealt with. The node is safe—for now. But as the last Copper-Tail reaches the basin, it transmits a single signal. Short, sharp, coded. Not a report to the network. A request. Addressed to a specific recipient. The recipient's identifier, when you decode it via Squeaker-Box or Arcana DC 14: 'V.'

turns.narrative: Three minutes after the signal, the Squeaker-Box in your bag (or a nearby rat-receiver, if you don't have the Box yet) broadcasts a response. It is not in chitter-code. It is in spoken Common—accented, precise, and old, in a way that makes it sound like someone who learned the language before it changed. 'You have been more capable than projected. I had allocated a 94% probability of full cascade by hour 12. You are at hour 9 and holding.' A pause. 'I am not displeased. Competent resistance improves the data quality considerably. The Copper-Plague was a systems test. You have passed. The next phase will not be a test.' The signal cuts. Doctor Vane has made direct contact.
turns.choice_a: Attempt to trace and respond to the signal (Arcana DC 16, extremely difficult)
turns.consequence_a: Success: You get a partial bearing: the signal originated from below the city—significantly below, at a depth consistent with the Concordat maintenance tunnel network's deepest levels. Not the Archive. Something deeper. You transmit: 'What is the next phase?' The response: 'Something beautiful.' Then silence. (+2 Lore, Vane depth-location partially triangulated)
turns.choice_b: Record the transmission verbatim and bring it to the Warden Council immediately
turns.consequence_b: The Council listens to the recording. The old accent analysis by the city linguist: 'Pre-Scourge Upper Ward dialect. Not an imitation—the speaker GREW UP speaking this. Either born over 200 years ago, or raised in isolation by pre-Scourge recordings.' Warden Council threat level for Vermin thread: elevated to CRITICAL. (+2 Lore, official escalation)
turns.convergence: Vane called it a systems test. The Copper-Plague was not an attack—it was a capability assessment, probing your response time, resource deployment, and tactical creativity. He is cataloguing you with the same clinical rigor he used to design his rats. And he has decided you are interesting enough to keep watching.

turns.narrative: With the main assault repelled and Vane's call received, the immediate crisis is over. Verl begins repair triage on the mana-infrastructure. The work will take 4-6 days. Three blocks remain on reduced mana. The virus in contained sections will take skilled workers weeks to fully clear. The Market Ward will recover—damaged but functional. But the Copper-Plague itself, the virus formula, has not been addressed. Somewhere in the city's mana-infrastructure, traces of the catalyst remain. And if Copper-Tails introduce a second batch, the response will be faster but the damage will compound on existing weakness.
turns.choice_a: Commission a mana-antiviral and have it pre-deployed in all trunk lines as a standing countermeasure
turns.consequence_a: Verl calculates the cost: 800 Gold to fully pre-treat the Market Ward trunk network. Expensive, but the grid will automatically neutralize any future virus introduction. Concordat Copper-Plague attack via mana-current: permanently prevented in Market Ward. (+2 Settlement Stability long-term)
turns.choice_b: Establish a Copper-Tail rapid response team in the Watch, trained specifically for mana-grid defense (Leadership DC 13)
turns.consequence_b: A 6-person Watch unit is trained within the week, with Copper-Tail behavior profiles and containment equipment. Future Copper-Plague events: response time cut by 60%. Human cost: Watch unit's time. (+1 Settlement Stability, ongoing defensive capability)
turns.convergence: Either way, the Market Ward's lights stabilize by morning. Citizens step out to find things working again, and most never know how close the grid came to full failure. The Watch officer on duty at the central node overnight files a report: 'No further Copper-Tail activity. However. Significant increase in Shadow-Rat sightings. They appear to be measuring something.'

turns.narrative: Final report to Verl. The Copper-Plague was a systems test by an entity that has been active for over 200 years, coordinating bio-mechanical vermin across the city in a multi-phase infrastructure attack. Phase 3 (per CT-2847's record) appears to be mana-redirection to an unknown central point. The Copper-Plague accelerated the timeline—testing your capacity to respond before committing to the real Phase 3 escalation. You have perhaps bought weeks. Verl hands you a sealed mana-virus sample in a hardened case. 'For analysis. Or leverage. Or some alchemist who wants to give someone a very bad day.' She manages something close to dark humor.
turns.choice_a: Submit the Mana-Virus Sample and Vane's transmission to the Mage Guild's Concordat Response Division
turns.consequence_a: The Guild opens a formal Concordat Research Desk within three days. A dedicated team of 6 scholars is assigned. They will cross-reference every known Concordat document for Vane's name and the Reactivation Protocol. In two weeks they will have a partial answer. (+3 Lore, institutional response established)
turns.choice_b: Keep the Mana-Virus Sample and your intelligence close, working privately with the Watch
turns.consequence_b: Smaller team, faster action. Less bureaucracy, more control. Working privately with Watch Captain Rhon, you establish a covert Concordat response unit—no public awareness, no panic, faster decisions. (+2 Settlement Stability, covert threat-response infrastructure established)
turns.convergence: Quest Complete. The Copper-Plague has been contained. Doctor Vane has made direct contact. The next phase—whatever 'something beautiful' means—is coming. Somewhere far below the city, in the deepest parts of the Concordat maintenance network, something very old is waking up, one mana-wire at a time, 200 years in the making.

turns.narrative: Walking back through the Market Ward, the lights are steady. The stall-holders are open. A child drops a coin and picks it up. Everything is ordinary. And you are carrying a vial of engineered mana-virus, a recording of a pre-Scourge voice, and the knowledge that somewhere below your feet, an architect of bio-mechanical weapons has been patiently watching this city for two centuries, studying it, testing it, redrawing its infrastructure wire by wire toward an endpoint none of you can name. The rats scatter from your footsteps. You watch them go. One pauses, looks back at you. Its eyes are blue.
turns.choice_a: File a formal emergency threat assessment with the Warden Council: Concordat Reactivation Protocol is real and imminent
turns.consequence_a: The Council convenes within 24 hours. This is the first formal recognition of the Concordat threat at the government level. Resources are mobilized. The Vermin thread is now a city-level emergency. (+3 Settlement Stability from coordinated response, but Doctor Vane will know the Council is aware—he will adapt)
turns.choice_b: Continue working the intelligence quietly—file a standard pest report, let the real investigation run below the surface
turns.consequence_b: Vane assumes you have not fully understood what you found. This is an advantage. Working below his awareness, you can continue investigating without triggering whatever adaptation Protocol he will enact upon official escalation. (+2 Intelligence advantage for next 4 Vermin quests)
turns.convergence: The final Concordat transmission of the day, picked up by a passing Shadow-Rat and translated by a worn Squeaker-Box: 'Subjects performing at 92nd percentile. Recommend: accelerate timeline. Initiate Phase 4 preparation.' Somewhere, a mechanism that has been patient for 200 years just decided to stop being patient.

conclusion: The biological corrosion is thoroughly purged from the mana-trunk, successfully restoring the Market Ward's power grid. The discovery that the vermin are capable of weaponizing a specific biological copper-slime confirms they are actively conducting highly organized sabotage against the city's core infrastructure.
loot_table: Mana-Virus Sample (Concordat Copper-Plague pathogen, sealed - crafting/research item)
Mana-Antiviral Formula (if developed in Turn 4 - protects mana-infrastructure from Copper-Plague permanently)
Doctor Vane Transmission Recording (rare evidence, aged pre-Scourge voice, key lore artifact)
Copper-Tail Live Specimen (if captured in Turn 3 - research subject, yields ongoing Concordat biotech intel)
Market Ward Emergency Response Stipend: 400 Gold

risk_matrix.penalty: Mana-cascade total. Market Ward grid fails completely. Settlement at -5 to Stability, -4 to Morale. Market Ward non-functional for 2 sessions. Doctor Vane rates you at 40th percentile and accelerates Phase 4 immediately.
risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed quietly. The situation remains unresolved.

title: The Vermin-Tongue
location: Lower Ward slums — Skitter-Jack's tenement, the Gnaw-Market, the Underpipe tunnels

npcs.name: Skitter-Jack (Jakker Ulme)
npcs.description: Third-generation rat-handler who speaks Rat-chitter fluently. Not magic — the rats simply trust him. Thin, 40s, permanently smells of musk and grain.

npcs.name: The Rat Council / The Duchess
npcs.description: Seven elder rats led by a large grey female. Highly intelligent, cautious, unwilling to share without equivalent exchange.

npcs.name: Foreman Dag Henris
npcs.description: Lower Ward construction foreman poisoning rat colonies near his site without knowing they are an organized political body.

description: Skitter-Jack warns the party that copper-tail augmentations are spreading laterally through physical contact—wild rats are being aggressively involuntarily converted by the augmented ones, violating known Concordat engineering parameters. The elusive 'Rat Council' requests a clandestine meeting, claiming to know the exact release-point of these rogue biomechanical vectors. The party must navigate a tense diplomatic encounter with heavily augmented vermin, secure the release-point coordinates, and prevent the viral spread of mechanical corruption.
mechanics: Animal Handling (rat-chitter via Skitter-Jack)
Investigation (trace poisonings to Henris)
Persuasion (negotiate Council conditions)
Stealth (navigate copper-tail sentinel zones)
Medicine (treat Council members poisoned by Henris)

permanent_effects.effect: settlement_morale +2; Rat Council agrees to share copper-tail spread map
Lower Ward construction site ceases; no further Council site poisonings

turns.narrative: Skitter-Jack urgently finds you at the pale crack of dawn, heavily tunnel-mud-stained and deeply rehearsed, nervously clutching a rusted iron pipe. He speaks frantically: the rats have been aggressively coordinating complex communication for eleven straight days. Worse, the terrifying copper-tail augmentations are actively spreading laterally through raw physical contact—wild, mundane rats are being aggressively, involuntarily converted by the augmented ones through violently inflicted bite wounds. 'This is absolutely not correct Concordat engineering,' he insists, his eyes wild. 'The remaining uncorrupted Rat Council wants a clandestine meeting immediately. They desperately claim to have the exact release-point location.' He points to a deeply scratched message roughly carved on his own wooden door this morning, reading his translation aloud: 'Bring the heavy ones who violently stopped the Silo. Come quickly before the next massive poisoning.'
turns.choice_a: Go immediately to the Gnaw-Market entry point the Council specified
turns.consequence_a: You deliberately arrive at the flooded cistern armed with your heaviest weaponry, projecting overwhelming, lethal capability. The massive, scarred members of the Rat Council are deeply intimidated into immediate submission, immediately surrendering the heavily chewed map showing the exact release-point coordinates.
turns.choice_b: Delay 40 minutes to investigate the poisoning pattern first
turns.consequence_b: You perfectly raise a tight, glowing blue mana-shield to definitively prevent any physical 'conversion' contact while brilliantly avoiding explicit aggression. The Council genuinely respects your terrifying arcane caution, delivering the precious coordinates while completely maintaining their uneasy, fragile independence.
turns.convergence: As the profoundly tense exchange concludes and you finally secure the heavily guarded coordinates, a violently spasming, newly 'converted' wild rat suddenly drops aggressively from the ceiling grate, its tail violently erupting into thick, sparking copper wire.

turns.narrative: The Underpipe is Concordat-era — stone blocks cut wider than modern standards, ventilation grooves at regular intervals no longer connected to anything. Skitter-Jack navigates by scent-marks the rats have left in oil. He explains: the Rat Council has existed for approximately forty years, with institutional memory carried in behavior patterns extending back to the Scourge-era. The Duchess, the grey elder female, inherited this memory from her predecessor. The Council knows the facility. There are terms. Ahead, the junction chamber — a Concordat room with four empty pipe-mounts and the Rat Council arranged on the floor in a circle of gnawed wood and pressed cloth.
turns.choice_a: Ask Skitter-Jack what the Council will likely demand so you can prepare
turns.consequence_a: He outlines three probable conditions: stop the poisoning, relocate the Prospect Lane colony, promise the facility will be closed not taken over.
turns.choice_b: Arrive with no foreknowledge and improvise
turns.consequence_b: The Council respects directness. Persuasion check DC reduced by 2 for the third condition.
turns.convergence: The Rat Council is assembled. The Duchess watches the party with the stillness of ongoing assessment.

turns.narrative: The Duchess opens negotiations through Skitter-Jack: the party smells like the Silo event, which counts as a credential. The copper-tail infection wave originated from a specific underpipe tributary northeast — she has tracked it in a spread pattern implying a single release point. She will provide a clay-marked map for three conditions, named one at a time without urgency. First: stop the entity poisoning Council meeting sites. Second: move the Prospect Lane colony before their building fails. Third: the facility, when found, is closed, not co-opted. A previous group was given directions and did not honor that promise.
turns.choice_a: Accept all three conditions before hearing them fully — show trust
turns.consequence_a: The Duchess pauses for genuine reassessment. She names the conditions anyway. Persuasion advantage on condition three.
turns.choice_b: Hear all three before agreeing to any
turns.consequence_b: Standard negotiation. All three conditions are achievable. Duchess registers the caution as sensible.
turns.convergence: The Duchess provides a clay token: 'the Council sent them.' It prevents copper-tail sentinel aggression in northeast underpipes.

turns.narrative: Tracing the construction-equipment poison containers leads to Foreman Dag Henris's worksite on Prospect Lane — the same building whose foundation threatens the colony the Duchess wants relocated. Henris has been rotating poison deployments for weeks, furious about rat interference with his cables and drainage pipes. He has no idea the rats near his site have political organization. He is afraid and defensive when confronted, but not malicious — he has a genuine infestation problem and a genuinely insufficient solution.
turns.choice_a: Confront Henris and explain the situation; ask him to stop
turns.consequence_a: Investigation check to show evidence. On success he stops and agrees to give advance warning before future work. On failure he escalates to the Ward Authority.
turns.choice_b: Gather evidence of his building safety violations first as leverage
turns.consequence_b: You find three code violations. Confrontation begins on your terms; Henris agrees to stop and to fund the colony relocation from his site budget.
turns.convergence: Henris stops the poisoning. Condition one is met.

turns.narrative: Forty-seven rats — including juveniles — live in the Prospect Lane subfoundation. The building will fail in eight to fourteen months. Skitter-Jack knows a viable relocation site: unused underpipe two sectors east, dry, ventilated, near a grain point. The path crosses three copper-tail sentinel patrol zones. The Council's clay token prevents aggression but not presence — the sentinels will observe and report.
turns.choice_a: Escort the colony actively through the sentinel zones
turns.consequence_a: Copper-tail sentinels observe the token and withdraw. Colony moves safely in four hours. You find a Concordat supply cache in the underpipe corridor — 200 years old.
turns.choice_b: Clear the sentinel zones first, then send the colony unescorted
turns.consequence_b: Sentinel zones neutralized. Colony moves quickly. Two freed sentinel units follow you to the surface, patrol directive apparently ended.
turns.convergence: The colony is established in the new location. The Duchess acknowledges: 'The debt for Prospect Lane will outlast debt for the information.'

turns.narrative: Condition three: close the facility, not appropriate it. The Duchess explains that twenty-two years ago, another group received directions from the Council and did not honor them. The facility was used rather than closed. Three years later, the copper-tail program expanded significantly. She is not accusing the party. She is establishing that her trust has a prior event. She asks if there is something more binding than a verbal assurance.
turns.choice_a: Offer a formal commitment: if the party takes over the facility instead of closing it, the Rat Council can provide evidence to the City Watch
turns.consequence_a: The Duchess accepts. The commitment has enforcement mechanics. Credibility established.
turns.choice_b: Tell the truth: intent can be promised, outcome cannot — city authority may supersede the party
turns.consequence_b: The Duchess is still for a long moment. Skitter-Jack whispers this is respect. She provides the map. 'Honesty costs more than promises. You chose to pay it.'
turns.convergence: All three conditions met or honestly negotiated. The Duchess produces a clay map of the northeast underpipes with a marked coordinate: the copper-tail contact-infection release point.

turns.narrative: The clay map leads to a Concordat maintenance hatch using a geometric lock: spatial lever inputs forming a shape visible in every Concordat junction room — the same ventilation-groove pattern in the underpipe walls. The rats have watched the copper-tail weekly maintenance circuit perform the input sequence forty-seven times. They know it.
turns.choice_a: Have Skitter-Jack relay the lock sequence from the Rat Council observation
turns.consequence_a: The lock opens first attempt. You enter a Concordat maintenance corridor. Next copper-tail maintenance circuit is 3 hours away.
turns.choice_b: Derive the sequence from Concordat engineering logic independently
turns.consequence_b: Arcana/Investigation DC 15. Success opens the lock with bonus insight for future Concordat locks. Failure triggers a silent contact-alarm; maintenance circuit comes 45 minutes early.
turns.convergence: The hatch opens. An access corridor ends in a heavy door, unlocked and slightly ajar. Beyond it: the controlled hum of something that has been running for a very long time.

turns.narrative: The chamber is not an assembly line — it is a Concordat breeding record station. Glass columns with active rat cultures, twelve operational, six with copper-wire threading visible through the biological material — the contact-transmission agent. An automated release system opens micro-valves on a seven-day pulse to release the infection vector into the underpipe ventilation. It has been doing this for nineteen days, matching the Duchess's intelligence exactly. The pulse schedule timing was updated within the last month. Someone has been here recently.
turns.choice_a: Disable the release mechanism immediately
turns.consequence_a: Engineering or Arcana DC 14. Success stops the spread. Failure triggers an immediate local release into the nearest underpipe section.
turns.choice_b: Document everything first, then disable
turns.consequence_b: You find initials on the pulse-schedule update: 'V.A.' with a date eight weeks ago. You disable the system with time to spare. The initials are the most important find of the session.
turns.convergence: The release system is offline. The copper-tail contact infection stops spreading as of this cycle.

turns.narrative: The Rat Council's third condition applies now. The room holds twelve biological cultures, six dangerous, a Concordat record system that may be irreplaceable, and evidence of recent modification by V.A. Closing it means destroying the release mechanism. The Duchess knew from twenty-two years ago that people rationalize keeping Concordat assets 'for intelligence.' She predicted this moment in her condition.
turns.choice_a: Destroy the release mechanism and seal all six infected columns; preserve the other six non-infected cultures for research
turns.consequence_a: The threat is neutralized. Partial preservation is defensible under the original promise. The Duchess's reaction: 'That is acceptable. It is what we would have done.'
turns.choice_b: Seal and mark the facility; notify the City Watch; submit documentation
turns.consequence_b: Full institutional oversight. Watch response in 3-5 days. The Duchess gets the closure she wanted in form and substance.
turns.convergence: The release mechanism is destroyed. The room is no longer an active threat.

turns.narrative: The Duchess appears in the junction chamber — unannounced, unexpected. She has come to verify. Skitter-Jack says the scent of a recently shut-down Concordat system is specific enough for her to confirm without asking. She makes a sound he identifies as 'satisfaction without celebration.' The Council has maintained their side: a second piece of marked clay is given to Skitter-Jack. A formal recognition token. In Lower Ward rat colony network: the bearer has performed a reciprocal action and is understood as non-threat. Copper-tail sentinels in Council-influenced zones will exhibit withdrawal rather than aggression in the party's presence.
turns.choice_a: Ask the Duchess if there is anything else the Council wants to share
turns.consequence_a: She says one thing: the initials V.A. appear in Concordat maintenance logs predating the Scourge across multiple systems. Either a persistent title or a persistent individual. She finds both possibilities unpleasant.
turns.choice_b: Accept the token and take your leave
turns.consequence_b: Respectful withdrawal. Future Council contacts available through Skitter-Jack with less preamble.
turns.convergence: Skitter-Jack walks you to the surface. At the exit: 'They liked you. That doesn't happen much.'

turns.narrative: The implications of V.A. settle above ground. The initials appear in Concordat systems predating the Scourge. The Squeaker-Box transmissions were signed 'V.' The Rat-Prophet's visions included 'the old engineer, young once, very long ago.' If V stands for Vane — the bio-engineering name from Concordat Division Seven records — then A is a surname initial in two-hundred-year-old logs. The pulse-schedule update was made in fresh notation eight weeks ago. Not copied. Written. Someone is physically present in EmberHeart with pre-Scourge Concordat authorship.
turns.choice_a: File a formal intelligence report with the City Watch, flagging V.A. as a person of interest
turns.consequence_a: The Watch logs the report. Investigator Soli Yan is cross-referenced. A formal connection between Vermin and Chronos threads is documented.
turns.choice_b: Keep the V.A. intelligence private; follow it independently
turns.consequence_b: Independent intelligence advantage maintained. Institutional warning not issued.
turns.convergence: Skitter-Jack's parting note, delivered three days later: the Rat Council's name for V.A. in chitter translates approximately as 'the one who remembers everything.'

turns.narrative: The mornings after are quieter. Not silent — the Lower Ward never is — but the specific quality of tension that has lived in it since the copper-tail reports started has reduced by a notch. The Gnaw-Market stallholders note fewer overnight disruptions. Three Prospect Lane colonists who had appeared at street level return to the underpipes. The copper-tail contact infection, without its release mechanism, will not produce new cases. Existing augmented wild rats will not spontaneously deaugment — that limit could not be changed — but the spread has stopped. Skitter-Jack sends a note three days after: the Duchess has added the party's names to what he translates, with difficulty, as 'the list of people the Council is waiting to owe.' In the history of the Lower Ward, it has been given to eleven individuals. Three of them were rats.
turns.choice_a: Seek Skitter-Jack to establish an ongoing communication channel
turns.consequence_a: Regular arrangement made. Skitter-Jack becomes a recurring contact. Advantage on Vermin-thread investigation checks where rat-colony intelligence applies.
turns.choice_b: Leave the relationship as a clean exchange — not an ongoing obligation
turns.consequence_b: Skitter-Jack understands. 'That's also a very rat way of thinking.' Recognition token remains valid.
turns.convergence: Quest complete. Copper-tail spread stopped. V.A. identified as a recurring active presence with 200-year-old Concordat authorization. The Rat Council owes the party a debt they will collect someday, in their own time.

conclusion: The clandestine meeting concludes successfully, securing the exact coordinates of the biomechanical release-point from the terrified Rat Council. The discovery that the copper-tail augmentations can aggressively self-replicate through physical contact elevates the vermin threat from a maintenance issue to an active, city-wide biological crisis.
loot_table: Rat-Tongue Amulet (Animal Handling +2 with rodents; rats exhibit reduced anxiety near the wearer; accelerates Skitter-Jack translation checks)
Rat Council Recognition Token (copper-embossed clay; copper-tail sentinels in Council zones exhibit withdrawal behavior rather than aggression)
Concordat Breeding Station Log — Partial (pre-Scourge biological notation; Intelligence/Arcana research value; contains V.A. initialed update fragment)
6x Wild Rat Culture Samples (non-infected; laboratory or alchemical research value; relevant to EH_SQ_078 antidote work)
900 gold (salvage from Concordat-era material in the underpipe access corridor)

facility_closed_fully.description: Release mechanism destroyed; all columns sealed; City Watch notified

consequences.permanent_effect: Copper-tail spread stopped; City Watch opens Vane investigation file
consequences.ambient_change: Lower Ward copper-tail sentinel density decreases 30% over 2 weeks

facility_partially_preserved.description: Release mechanism destroyed; six clean cultures preserved for research

consequences.permanent_effect: Copper-tail spread stopped; research cultures provide 20% XP bonus on future Vermin bio-research checks

risk_matrix.penalty: Henris escalates to the Ward Authority; party barred from Underpipe access for 1 week; release mechanism fires one additional cycle, extending the infection spread
risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed with minor consequences.

title: The Bio-Forge
unlock_conditions: Complete SQ-04 and possess a Concordat ID Ring
location: The Forgeline — abandoned Concordat transit branch beneath the High Ward

npcs.name: Ossa Veld
npcs.description: Former city infrastructure surveyor, 60s. Found the Forgeline 18 months ago during a routine survey. Has exquisite facility maps. Has told nobody.

npcs.name: The Bio-Forge Guardian
npcs.description: Concordat-era defense unit the size of a draft horse. Six spider-legs, rat-scale sensory array, compressed-air deterrent array. Recently reprogrammed. Recognizes Concordat ID Rings as 'authorized administrator' and behaves differently to holders.

npcs.name: V.A. (Voice only)
npcs.description: Pre-recorded audio in the facility's communication system. Speaks pre-Scourge Common. Claims to be the original facility designer. Maintenance logs show the recording was triggered six weeks ago. Asks the party to close the facility down.

description: Ossa Veld, a retired city surveyor, reveals a highly detailed, hand-sketched map of 'The Forgeline'—a sealed Concordat transit branch beneath the High Ward where she recently heard massive, automated production cycles actively running. Fearing the Ward's reaction, she kept it secret until the noises grew too continuous to ignore. The party must breach the forgotten transit hub, confirm the existence of an autonomous, deep-underground manufacturing node, and retrieve proof of its uninterrupted century-long operation.
mechanics: Engineering (disable the bio-production assembly line)
Arcana (interpret Concordat biological notation; read the facility terminal)
Stealth (navigate without triggering Guardian patrol alert)
Athletics (traverse the transit-tunnel environment)
Combat (Bio-Forge Guardian — Medium encounter, modified by Concordat ID Ring status)

permanent_effects.effect: settlement_stability +3; new vermin strain production permanently stopped; copper-tail relay network begins degrading
Bio-Augmentation Blueprint added to inventory; 20% XP bonus on future Vermin bio-research checks

turns.narrative: Ossa Veld arrives quietly at your table with a heavy, waterproof survey-paper roll tucked tightly under her arm and the deeply exhausted expression of someone who has been aggressively arguing with herself for months. She quietly identifies herself as a retired, senior city surveyor and excitedly unfolds the massive, heavily annotated map immediately. 'The Forgeline,' she violently whispers, pointing a scarred finger: a massive, forgotten Concordat transit branch deliberately sealed 200 years ago when the High Ward's above-ground network completely superseded it. She exclusively found it through a deeply anomalous geological survey pressure reading. 'I have been inside exactly four times. The fourth time, barely three weeks ago, I clearly heard the heavy production cycle violently running.' She has told absolutely no one until exactly now. The brilliant, hand-sketched map is extraordinary in its terrifying detail. She points a shaking finger directly to Section 3: 'This is precisely where the smell completely changes. Like hot metal and something deeply alive. And it's incredibly patient. It violently doesn't stop.'
turns.choice_a: Ask Ossa to guide you in; her layout familiarity is valuable
turns.consequence_a: You meticulously cross-reference her incredibly detailed map with your own vast knowledge of the Ward's foundational bedrock. You brilliantly identify a massive, completely unmapped subterranean void utterly perfectly matching the exact acoustic resonance profile of a heavy industrial manufacturing floor.
turns.choice_b: Take the map and tell Ossa to wait on the surface
turns.consequence_b: You flawlessly bypass the massive, incredibly heavily rusted pre-Scourge outer bulkheads directly protecting the forgotten transit hub. Your absolutely perfect lock-picking ensures no heavy mechanical alarms are tripped during your incredibly quiet, entirely undocumented infiltration.
turns.convergence: Breaching the violently heavy internal pressure door, you are instantly hit with a massive, absolutely suffocating wave of intense, suffocating heat and the incredibly deafening, rhythmic crash of heavy, autonomous metal stamping presses operating in the deep, violent dark.

turns.narrative: The Forgeline smells wrong — living. Underground spaces smell of stone and absence. This space metabolizes. Section 2 is intact Concordat infrastructure: amber overhead lights still functional, equipment housing with pre-Scourge biological division identifiers. The same notation system from the breeding station in EH_SQ_075: Concordat Biological Infrastructure Division, designated 'welfare.' The Bio-Forge is welfare infrastructure that has been performing welfare at vermin scale for 200 years, recently with its output parameters altered. From Section 3: a rhythmic sound. Mechanical compression and release. Like a very large, very slow heartbeat.
turns.choice_a: Investigate the Section 2 equipment housing before proceeding
turns.consequence_a: Investigation DC 13: the facility's original production parameters were nutritional-enhancement strains — rats engineered to reduce urban population competition with humans. The current parameters are different. Something altered the target outputs 14 months ago.
turns.choice_b: Proceed directly into Section 3
turns.consequence_b: Stealth DC 12 to enter without triggering Guardian perimeter sensors. On success: 90 seconds of observation before detection. On failure: Guardian arrives in 3 rounds.
turns.convergence: Section 3 visible through the internal corridor: a row of glass-and-steel production columns. Something is moving inside them.

turns.narrative: Sixty-three production columns operational across Sections 3 through 5. Thirty-one contain the copper-tail augmentation matrix in early, mid, and late development — the contact-transmission deployment culture found in EH_SQ_075.
