Thirty-two contain something new: a darker copper matrix, more integrated, with a neural-lattice component threaded through the organic base. The assembly line is mid-cycle. Completion is in four hours forty minutes. At cycle completion: standard copper-tail deployment plus neural-lattice culture advancement to next developmental stage.
turns.choice_a: Locate the control terminal and halt the current cycle immediately
turns.consequence_a: Engineering or Arcana DC 14. Success halts the cycle with 2 hours remaining. Failure advances cycle by 30 minutes. Terminal is in Section 6.
turns.choice_b: Observe the neural-lattice culture more closely before acting
turns.consequence_b: Medicine or Arcana DC 12: this is a second-generation augmentation enabling behavioral coordination between augmented individuals. The Swarm-Intelligence event (EH_SQ_077) is a prototype test of this capability. This culture is the source.
turns.convergence: The Bio-Forge Guardian has registered your presence. The heartbeat-sound sharpens into something more purposeful. It is coming from Section 7.

turns.narrative: The Bio-Forge Guardian emerges from the east corridor into Section 5 with the efficiency of ten thousand repetitions. Approximately 1.8 meters tall at the main body, six articulated spider-legs, sensor array, compressed-air deterrent, biological sample storage in a sealed underside compartment. It scans the party for 2.3 seconds. Then it scans the Concordat ID Ring. It stops. Behavioral orientation changes: the ID Ring holder has been classified as 'authorized administrator.' It emits a sound identifiable via Arcana as the Concordat infrastructure equivalent of 'please state your request.'
turns.choice_a: Use authorized administrator status to issue maintenance commands
turns.consequence_a: Guardian responds as designed. Available commands: production halt (executes), facility status report (excellent intelligence), escort to control terminal. It will not override its core protection directive but defers to administrator judgment on most parameters.
turns.choice_b: Fight it regardless — administrator hesitation gives advantage on the first round
turns.consequence_b: Combat begins. Guardian stats: AC 16, HP 80, compressed-air knockback, physical restraint, facility-wide alert summoning two smaller patrol units from Sections 4 and 7. Defeating it ends the patrol threat entirely.
turns.convergence: Path to Section 6 and the central control terminal is open.

turns.narrative: Section 6: the central control terminal. A Concordat interface surface in pre-Scourge biological division UI format, mostly readable with Arcana. It shows: original programming (nutritional enhancement, 200 years ago), parameter change logged 14 months ago (switch to copper-tail augmentation matrix), and a maintenance access log with external connection events. Most recent external connection: six weeks ago, duration 17 minutes, encrypted with a Concordat-standard protocol. The header signature matches the Squeaker-Box transmission protocol from EH_SQ_072 exactly. Someone with Concordat-era transmission capability accessed this terminal remotely six weeks ago.
turns.choice_a: Extract a complete copy of the access log and parameter history before making changes
turns.consequence_a: Terminal provides a compressed data output — a small inscribed stone tablet with approximately 40,000 lines of records. Takes 12 minutes to compile. Extraordinary intelligence value.
turns.choice_b: Proceed directly to shutdown — data is secondary to stopping production
turns.consequence_b: The shutdown proceeds cleanly and quickly. Data lost but significant time saved.
turns.convergence: Control terminal accessed. Production cycle halted. The Bio-Forge is in standby: not destroyed, not running, awaiting next administrator command.

turns.narrative: The internal communication system activates on a Section 6 proximity sensor. A pre-recorded voice speaks pre-Scourge Common: the same syntax and consonant placements as translated Squeaker-Box transmissions. The recording: 'Section 6 administrative override detected. Protocol review: Bio-Infrastructure Division Forgeline facility — authorized for nutritional-welfare development, unauthorized for combat-augmentation deployment. If you are hearing this, someone has been using this facility incorrectly. I am sorry. This should have been caught sooner.' A pause. 'If the date is later than Year 40 of the Reconstruction Era, things went much worse than any of us planned.' Another pause. 'Close it down. Please.'
turns.choice_a: Accept the recorded instruction — the original designers want this closed
turns.consequence_a: The recording appears to be the original facility designer speaking from before the Scourge, leaving instructions for exactly this situation. Following it feels like honoring a 200-year-old apology.
turns.choice_b: Treat the recording as potentially manipulative — too convenient to be trusted blindly
turns.consequence_b: Skepticism is warranted. The recording cannot be verified. Whether V.A. is the original designer or a current actor using the system for their own purposes, the core decision — destroy or extract — remains unchanged.
turns.convergence: The distinction between 'original V.A. designed this for welfare and someone else corrupted it' and 'V.A. is currently alive and wants you to close this for reasons you don't yet understand' is unresolved. The choice ahead: destroy the facility or extract schematics first.

turns.narrative: Section 7: the facility's developmental archive. Prototype models from 140 years old to recent — six weeks ago. The progression tells a story: the welfare nutritional strains, then a long silence, then the copper-tail motor augmentation, then the neural-lattice coordination matrix, then one final developmental stage currently at 5% completion. The final stage has no label. Its column is more heavily reinforced than the others. The biological material, under close observation, has a neural-tissue component larger than rat scale.
turns.choice_a: Destroy the unlabeled column immediately — it should not develop further
turns.consequence_a: The column is destroyed. The material degrades within seconds. Whatever the final stage was intended to produce is lost permanently.
turns.choice_b: Attempt to identify the unlabeled strain before destroying anything
turns.consequence_b: Medicine or Arcana DC 16: the neural tissue is primate-scale. The final augmentation stage is designed to transfer the copper-tail neural-lattice coordination matrix into a non-rat host. A bridge between the vermin program and something larger was being built.
turns.convergence: The unlabeled column's fate is decided. The full facility decision remains.

turns.narrative: The decision. Destroying the production environment — Sections 3 through 5 — requires physically disabling the column systems and assembly line. Achievable with Engineering or brute force. Irreversible. The standby state ends automatically in 72 hours without administrator action. Extracting the Bio-Augmentation Blueprint requires accessing Section 5's archive terminal (Arcana DC 13, 25 minutes). Extraction does not prevent production resumption — it must be paired with destruction to fully resolve the threat.
turns.choice_a: Destroy the production environment; schematics are not worth the risk
turns.consequence_a: Columns systematically disabled. Assembly line made inoperable. Forgeline permanently non-functional. Clean resolution. Intelligence limited to what was already observed.
turns.choice_b: Extract schematics first (25 min, Arcana DC 13) then destroy
turns.consequence_b: On Arcana success: both objectives achieved. On failure: must choose between finishing extraction or starting destruction — insufficient time for both before a security alert registers.
turns.convergence: The Bio-Forge's production capacity ends. The facility is silent for possibly the first time in 200 years.

turns.narrative: In the silence after the assembly line stops, a secondary chamber becomes audible — previously masked by production noise. A resting alcove in the Section 6-to-7 corridor. Human-sized. A folded garment, a tin cup, a hand-written journal in pre-Scourge notation. The most recent entry: nine weeks ago. Not 200 years — nine weeks. The handwriting is consistent across all entries spanning multiple years. The journal writer identifies themselves as 'V.' The last entry: 'The neural-lattice work progresses faster than expected. I am less certain than I was that this is the correct path. The augmentation of the primary line was intended to protect the city. The secondary work is necessary for the protocol but I cannot stop thinking about the unlabeled column. There may be another way. I need more time.'
turns.choice_a: Take the journal — primary evidence of Vane's physical presence and conflicted state of mind
turns.consequence_a: The journal establishes: Vane was physically in the city nine weeks ago; he is conflicted about the secondary augmentation; he believes the primary copper-tail program was protective; he is running out of certainty. One of the most significant Vermin thread intelligence artifacts.
turns.choice_b: Leave the journal in place but record its contents fully
turns.consequence_b: Content is preserved. Vane's next visit will not immediately reveal the journal's absence. Covert intelligence position maintained.
turns.convergence: The journal — taken or documented — substantially reframes the Vermin thread's central figure: Vane is not simply an antagonist. He started with protective intent and may be having second thoughts.

turns.narrative: Ossa Veld is in Section 2 exactly where you left her, exactly as composed. She processes your report one piece at a time with the methodical precision of someone who has spent forty years translating technical complexity into language for people who don't want to hear it. Her response, delivered after thirty seconds of quiet: 'The recording said to close it down. I think that's a reasonable instruction. I also think the person giving it may not have anticipated what closing it down would feel like. That facility has been running for two hundred years.' Another pause. 'I want you to know I haven't told anyone about this. Not the Watch, not my supervisors, not my family. I found it and I just — didn't know what the right thing was. I still don't, entirely. But I think you did the right thing.'
turns.choice_a: Thank Ossa and ask her to file a survey report explaining the Forgeline's existence and resolution
turns.consequence_a: Ossa files through official channels. Forgeline classified as a secured historical site. Her career reputation rehabilitated: found something significant and reported it properly.
turns.choice_b: Ask Ossa to maintain secrecy — the facility's location needs to remain controlled
turns.consequence_b: Ossa agrees with visible relief. Survey records amended to 'stable geological void, no action required.' Forgeline stays off official record.
turns.convergence: Ossa Veld has a role in future Vermin thread events as the only non-party individual with a complete facility survey. She is not a liability. She is a resource who has been waiting for people she could trust.

turns.narrative: The Bio-Augmentation Blueprint — if extracted — answers questions and raises more. The copper-tail augmentation was not designed to make vermin dangerous to humans. It makes them responsive to a specific Concordat broadcast frequency. The copper tails are antennas. The augmented rats are a distributed sensor and relay network aimed at city infrastructure. The neural-lattice coordination upgrade would enable the network to process and act on infrastructure data collectively. The Forgeline is not a weapon factory. It is a maintenance program for a city-wide sensor grid running on automated protocols because the people who should operate it are gone. V.A. has been maintaining it alone for an unspecified but very long time.
turns.choice_a: Brief Skitter-Jack on the Blueprint's implications — the Rat Council should know what the copper-tail program actually was
turns.consequence_a: Skitter-Jack translates. The Duchess is quiet for a long time. Her response: 'Then the ones who were supposed to remember forgot. And the ones who weren't supposed to remember kept remembering. And now we are here.' She does not seem surprised.
turns.choice_b: Keep the Blueprint intelligence within the party until the full picture is clearer
turns.consequence_b: Information held in confidence. The Rat Council will eventually register the copper-tail deployment has stopped but not know why.
turns.convergence: The Vermin thread's central mystery is substantially resolved at the mechanical level: the what and how of the copper-tail program. The who and why — Vane's full identity and the Reactivation Protocol's endpoint — remain open.

turns.narrative: Three days after the facility is closed, the High Ward logs two brief mana-grid disruptions in tunnel infrastructure directly above the Forgeline. Both under 30 seconds. Both matching the signature pattern of equipment that has gone offline mid-cycle. The copper-tail relay network, having lost its production source, is beginning to degrade in sections nearest the Forgeline. Within weeks, the network will develop gaps. What that means for whatever the Reactivation Protocol is designed to activate — the party has bought themselves time to discover. Ossa Veld sends a careful professional note two days later: she has identified four additional geological anomalies in her old survey files that might indicate similar sealed Concordat infrastructure. She attaches coordinates. She asks nothing about what they are.
turns.choice_a: Investigate one of Ossa's coordinates immediately
turns.consequence_a: The site is different but related. The party finds evidence of a third Concordat infrastructure node. The Vermin thread deepens significantly.
turns.choice_b: File the coordinates for later; focus on immediate priorities
turns.consequence_b: Coordinates noted. Future Vermin-thread investigation checks near those coordinates have advantage due to prior research.
turns.convergence: Quest complete. The Bio-Forge is closed. The copper-tail relay network is degrading. Vane's journal adds a human, conflicted dimension to the figure the Vermin thread has been constructing as a ghost. Four more coordinates wait.

conclusion: The Forgeline's heavy, rusted bulkheads are successfully breached, confirming the horrifying uninterrupted operation of an automated Concordat manufacturing cycle. Ossa Veld's extraordinary map is validated, providing the Ward with undeniable proof that complex, pre-Scourge mechanical production systems are still blindly functioning deep beneath the city's foundation.

title: The Swarm-Intelligence
location: City-wide event — Market Ward epicenter, with connected events in Lower Ward, High Ward, and Industrial Quarter

npcs.name: Inventor Voss (Thessaly Voss)
npcs.description: Independent bio-engineer who has been documenting copper-tail behavioral anomalies for months. Contacts the party when the Swarm-Event begins. Wants to study the phenomenon and will share research in exchange for access during resolution.

npcs.name: The Swarm-Mind Nexus
npcs.description: Not a creature but a location: a physical convergence node through which the distributed neural-lattice coordination signal is routing. Destroying it ends the event. It defends itself using coordinated copper-tail rat swarms.

npcs.name: Senior Watch-Captain Eld Marrus
npcs.description: Head of the Market Ward watch post. Responding to the swarm event with crowd control and escalating panic. Cannot understand what he's dealing with. Needs the party to give him actionable information or he will begin lethal extermination protocols.

description: Citizens awake to an unnerving biological anomaly: every rat in the city has abandoned its normal behavior to form massive, perfectly coordinated geometric rings around key infrastructure points, staring silently inward. Inventor Voss urgently contacts the party, claiming this terrifying, city-wide mobilization is the result of a 'neural-lattice prototype' violently firing. The party must navigate the panicked Market Ward, reach Voss's workshop, and help him forcibly shut down the prototype before the Ward Guard initiates a massive, fiery purge.
mechanics: Investigation (map the swarm movement patterns to triangulate the Nexus location)
Animal Handling (interpret swarm behavior with Rat-Tongue Amulet or Skitter-Jack's assistance)
Arcana (identify the neural-lattice coordination signal)
Persuasion (convince Watch-Captain Marrus to delay the extermination order)
Combat (Swarm-Mind Nexus defense — coordinated copper-tail rat swarms, Medium encounter)

permanent_effects.effect: settlement_morale +2; settlement_stability +1; wild rat population survives the extermination order
settlement_morale -1; wild rat population takes significant casualties; Rat Council trust reduced by 1 tier

turns.narrative: Dawn completely breaks. The city wakes to an incredibly terrifying silence in the normally bustling streets and incredibly dense, violent motion within the stone walls. Market Ward stallholders emerging early find the massive central square completely reconfigured: absolutely every rat in a three-block radius has perfectly assembled in a massive, dense ring around the central market fountain, sitting perfectly still, staring blankly inward. They are not frantically eating, not violently fighting, not aggressively fleeing. They are perfectly assembled in terrifying military precision. This horrific anomalous behavior violently spreads by panicked report across the entire city inside twenty minutes. In the Lower Ward alleys, rats are aggressively forming massive, perfectly straight directional corridors. In the High Ward, heavy copper-tail units are entirely abandoning their usual erratic patrol routes to furiously converge directly on the primary mana-grid service tunnels. Something is brilliantly, flawlessly coordinating all of them simultaneously. Inventor Voss frantically sends a desperate note to you via an incredibly urgent, terrified courier: 'This is the catastrophic neural-lattice prototype violently firing. I have been deeply waiting for this. Please find me at my workshop immediately before the Ward Guard decides to violently solve this entirely with intense fire.'
turns.choice_a: Go immediately to Inventor Voss's workshop
turns.consequence_a: You violently shove your way through the terrified, frantically screaming civilian crowds, brutally forcing a clean path entirely through the absolute chaos. You flawlessly reach Voss's heavily fortified workshop incredibly quickly, saving absolutely invaluable minutes before the heavily armed Guard arrives.
turns.choice_b: Begin investigating the swarm pattern directly without Voss
turns.consequence_b: You elegantly scale the damp masonry, violently leaping aggressively across the narrow, rain-slicked rooftops. You brilliantly avoid entirely disturbing the terrifying, perfectly still vermin formations completely, arriving exactly at Voss's heavily barricaded skylight precisely undetected and unhindered.
turns.convergence: You violently crash into Voss's Workshop just as a massive, loudly humming, completely overloaded crystalline control-pillar violently begins heavily sparking, radiating a deeply sickening, intensely powerful subsonic frequency that violently hurts your teeth.

turns.narrative: Voss's working theory, presented in organized priority: the neural-lattice coordination matrix (from EH_SQ_076 if the party has the Blueprint, or reconstructed from behavioral observation otherwise) is not a remote control system. It is a distributed processing network. Today's event is a test run of the network at full scale — it is doing something computationally with the combined sensory data from every augmented rat in the city. The patterns in rat movement, when mapped, are not random crowd behavior. They trace EmberHeart's mana-grid infrastructure. The rats are conducting a diagnostic. On the city's infrastructure. Simultaneously. This is what the copper-tail relay network was always supposed to do: assess the city's structural health. The person who initiated this test run — V.A./Vane — is somewhere with a transmitter.
turns.choice_a: Focus on identifying the Nexus — destroy the central coordination node to stop the event
turns.consequence_a: The fastest path to resolution. The Nexus location is determined by triangulating where all swarm patterns converge. Mid-way through the quest.
turns.choice_b: Investigate what the network is actually diagnosing before stopping it
turns.consequence_b: The diagnostic takes the full six-hour window to complete. If you can prevent the extermination order and let it run, the network produces a complete infrastructure assessment of EmberHeart's mana-grid — an extraordinarily valuable document. Risk: the extermination order is very hard to prevent for the full duration.
turns.convergence: Either path requires dealing with Watch-Captain Marrus in the next hour.

turns.narrative: Watch-Captain Marrus is on his third cup of something that isn't helping and growing faster at each report. His training covers riots, fires, organized crime, and mana-accidents. It does not cover 'coordinated rat civic behavior.' His current working theory is Void-contamination or hostile magical attack, which his protocols suggest he should eliminate. His extermination order requires approval from three Watch seniors and one city administrator. The approval would take 2 hours to process. He has already sent two of the three requests. He is an intelligent man in a situation his intelligence cannot parse.
turns.choice_a: Present Marrus with the full technical explanation — the neural-lattice network, Concordat origin, the diagnostic purpose
turns.consequence_a: Persuasion DC 16. He is skeptical. If the party has the Bio-Augmentation Blueprint or Voss's documentation, DC reduces to 12. On success: Marrus delays the extermination order by 3 hours, giving significantly more time. On failure: he proceeds on the original timeline.
turns.choice_b: Give Marrus a partial explanation — focus on 'Concordat artifact behavior' and ask for time to resolve it professionally
turns.consequence_b: Persuasion DC 13. Easier sell. He delays by 90 minutes — enough to find the Nexus if investigation is efficient. He doesn't fully understand but trusts 'Concordat artifact' as a categorizable problem.
turns.convergence: Marrus grants a delay — duration depending on the persuasion approach. The extermination clock is pushed back.

turns.narrative: Mapping the swarm. The rats are not random — they're organized along the city's mana-grid conduit routes, each cluster positioned at a specific infrastructure node. Investigation (or Voss's triangulation work) reveals the pattern: all movement converges toward a single point in the Market Ward sub-basement, the original Concordat infrastructure junction that the modern mana-grid was built above. The Nexus is in the junction. Reaching it requires descending through the Market Ward's commercial sub-level, which is currently threaded with rat-swarm corridors. The rats are not aggressive — they have no aggression directive in the current coordination mode — but they are physically obstructive and dense.
turns.choice_a: Move through the rat corridors using Animal Handling to navigate without disturbing the pattern
turns.consequence_a: Animal Handling DC 13 (DC 10 with Rat-Tongue Amulet). Success: you reach the junction quickly, and the swarm diagnostic is undisturbed. You can observe it in progress. On failure: you disrupt a section of the pattern; the coordination compensates but the Nexus goes briefly into alert mode.
turns.choice_b: Force through quickly regardless of disruption — speed over subtlety
turns.consequence_b: You reach the junction in half the time. The swarm's alert mode activates in a two-block radius. Copper-tail units converge toward the disruption point — not aggressive, but physically obstructive. The Nexus has 10 minutes to prepare its defensive posture.
turns.convergence: The Concordat infrastructure junction beneath the Market Ward. The Swarm-Mind Nexus is visible: a Concordat-era signal processor the size of a large cabinet, active for the first time in 200 years, surrounded by a ring of copper-tail sentinel rats arranged like a chorus.

turns.narrative: The Swarm-Mind Nexus is not a creature. It is a piece of infrastructure: a Concordat signal processor, 200 years old, recently reactivated. Its processing cycle is visible in real time: thousands of data points from the copper-tail relay network flowing in, being organized, generating an output report. The output report is in Concordat data notation — inscribed onto a compressed clay disk by an automated press mechanism. The disk is halfway formed. If the Nexus is allowed to complete the cycle, the disk is a complete mana-grid infrastructure assessment of EmberHeart. If it is destroyed now, the disk is partial. The defensive posture is maintained by the surrounding copper-tail units in a coordination mode the party has not encountered before: individually weak, but responsive collectively.
turns.choice_a: Allow the Nexus to complete its full cycle before destroying it — a few more minutes
turns.consequence_a: The complete infrastructure assessment disk is produced. Extraordinarily valuable civic and intelligence data. The additional time puts pressure on the Marrus extermination timeline. Requires ensuring Marrus has been given sufficient extension.
turns.choice_b: Destroy the Nexus immediately — the extermination order is more urgent than the data
turns.consequence_b: Partial disk recovered. Some infrastructure data salvageable. The coordination event ends. Marrus's extermination order can be canceled cleanly.
turns.convergence: Combat begins with the Nexus's defensive swarm posture — whether you chose to wait or act immediately determines how much of the data disk was completed before the fight.

turns.narrative: The Swarm-Mind Nexus fight: the Nexus itself has no direct attack capability (AC 8, HP 40 as a Large Object), but it coordinates the surrounding copper-tail sentinel swarm as a collective defense. The swarm behaves as a single entity: CR 4, AC 13, HP 60, resistant to individual-target effects, capable of a coordinated charge (3d6 piercing to all targets in a 15-foot cone) and a signal-pulse (Arcana DC 14 or disadvantage on checks relying on precision for 2 rounds). The swarm takes full damage from area effects. The Rat Council's recognition token, if present, causes the swarm to briefly hesitate at the start of each of its turns (reduces its action to one per round instead of two).
turns.choice_a: Focus attacks on the Nexus object directly, accepting swarm damage while doing so
turns.consequence_a: The Nexus is destroyed in 2-3 rounds if focused. Swarm continues for 1 round after Nexus destruction before dispersing. High damage taken by the party.
turns.choice_b: Eliminate the swarm first, then destroy the undefended Nexus
turns.consequence_b: Takes longer (4-5 rounds total) but party takes less overall damage. The Nexus continues processing during the delay.
turns.convergence: The Nexus is destroyed. Signal ceases. Throughout the city, rats break from coordinated behavior simultaneously — each individual animal snapping back to self-directed action, like a choir stopping on the same beat.

turns.narrative: The city's reaction is immediate and layered. Watch-Captain Marrus receives confirmation that the coordinated behavior has ceased. Citizens throughout EmberHeart report normal rat behavior resuming. The extermination teams, already deployed to staging positions, stand down on Marrus's order — sent with visible relief. In the Market Ward sub-basement, surrounded by dispersing copper-tail units returning to their patrol grids, the party holds what they made: a destroyed signal processor, a clay disk of city infrastructure data (partial or complete), and the knowledge that someone activated this deliberately as a prototype test. V.A./Vane is somewhere in the city with a transmitter powerful enough to fire the full neural-lattice network simultaneously.
turns.choice_a: Report the full incident to the City Watch with all technical details
turns.consequence_a: The Watch officially documents the event as a 'Concordat infrastructure anomaly.' Marrus files a full report. City administration requests a meeting about mana-grid assessment protocols — the partial or complete infrastructure disk is of significant interest.
turns.choice_b: Give Marrus a simplified version — the threat is stopped, the technical details are ongoing investigation
turns.consequence_b: Marrus accepts. The party retains intelligence control over the full scope of what the network was doing and why.
turns.convergence: Voss is examining the destroyed Nexus components with intense interest. She identifies the reactivation signal source: transmitted through the city's mana-grid conductor channels, originating from beneath the North Ward. The same direction the Chronos thread investigations have been pointing.

turns.narrative: Voss's analysis of the clay disk — partial or complete — reveals the infrastructure assessment data. If complete: the city's mana-grid has seventeen significant structural vulnerabilities, four of which are actively deteriorating, two of which are in the Chronos thread's investigation area (the North Ward mana-junction beneath the Chronal Pint tavern). The copper-tail network was performing civic infrastructure maintenance that no human institution has been doing. The city has been less safe than anyone knew, and the Concordat built these rats specifically to tell it so. If partial: nine vulnerabilities identified, one confirmed critical (the North Ward mana-junction).
turns.choice_a: File the infrastructure assessment with the City Planning Authority immediately
turns.consequence_a: The Authority responds with alarmed gratitude. Emergency inspections are authorized for the flagged sites. Settlement stability +3 over the following month. The source of the data is awkward to explain.
turns.choice_b: Hold the assessment data; determine who needs to know it and in what form
turns.consequence_b: Intelligence controlled. The party can selectively share findings — for example, flagging the North Ward mana-junction without explaining the copper-tail network in full.
turns.convergence: Voss says: 'The network was doing its job. Badly, because it's been running alone for two centuries without calibration. But it was doing its job.' She pauses. 'Whoever reactivated it knew that. They wanted the assessment run. The question is whether they wanted you to see the results.'

turns.narrative: The North Ward mana-junction flagged in the infrastructure assessment is beneath the Chronal Pint tavern — a location that will shortly become relevant in EH_SQ_065 (The Frozen Moment). The junction, if the party investigates now, shows evidence of recent Concordat-era equipment installation: a signal relay booster that should not be in a 20-year-old mana-junction, running a transmission protocol the party recognizes from the Squeaker-Box. The booster has been routing V.A./Vane's transmissions through the mana-grid to reach the Forgeline and the Swarm-Mind Nexus. It is the link between Vane's location and every Concordat system he has been maintaining. It is also the reason the North Ward mana-grid has been experiencing the temporal disruptions logged in the Chronos thread.
turns.choice_a: Disable the relay booster — cut Vane's remote access to the Concordat systems
turns.consequence_a: Vane loses remote access. He will need to visit facilities in person for any further changes. His operational capacity is significantly degraded. The North Ward temporal disruptions stop. He will know someone found the relay.
turns.choice_b: Leave the relay booster intact and monitored — it is a line to Vane
turns.consequence_b: The relay remains active. The party can attempt to trace transmissions back to Vane's physical location (Arcana DC 18, multiple sessions of monitoring). If successful: Vane's location is identified. Risk: Vane may detect the monitoring.
turns.convergence: The mana-junction and its relay booster become a significant strategic decision point in the Vermin-Chronos convergence storyline.

turns.narrative: Voss requests a formal meeting at her workshop the following evening to present her compiled analysis. Her documentation of copper-tail behavioral anomalies, combined with the Swarm-Intelligence event data, produces a working model: the Reactivation Protocol is not a single event. It is a sequence. Event 1 was the contact infection (spreading the base augmentation). Event 2 was today's Swarm-Intelligence test (validating that the neural-lattice network fires correctly at scale). Event 3, according to her projection, is a full-scale infrastructure remediation attempt — the network, if allowed to operate with a complete active roster and functioning Nexus, would begin physically guiding copper-tail units to reinforce, seal, and repair the city's mana-grid vulnerabilities. Someone has been trying to fix EmberHeart using rats. Badly. For a very long time.
turns.choice_a: Ask Voss to formalize her analysis into documentation that can be shared with the City Administration
turns.consequence_a: Voss produces a formal technical report over the next 3 days. The City Administration initiates a Concordat Infrastructure Working Committee. Slow institutional response but legitimate.
turns.choice_b: Keep Voss as a private consultant; the party manages what information leaves this room
turns.consequence_b: Voss agrees to confidentiality with conditions: she wants credit when this eventually becomes public, and she wants first access to any further Concordat bio-system discoveries.
turns.convergence: Voss and her analysis become a recurring resource for the Vermin thread's resolution arc.

turns.narrative: The broader city reaction to the Swarm-Intelligence event plays out over the following 48 hours. Three distinct narratives emerge. The Watch files it as 'resolved Concordat anomaly, ongoing investigation.' Citizens who observed the coordinated rat behavior are divided: half are frightened and want immediate extermination of all augmented vermin; half are, unexpectedly, fascinated and want to know more. A pamphlet appears in the Market Ward two days after the event, author unknown, titled 'The City Has a Pulse': it describes the copper-tail relay network, the Swarm-Intelligence test, and the infrastructure assessment in language a non-technical reader can understand. Someone knows what happened and is telling people about it. The pamphlet is accurate. It is not the party's work. Someone else was watching today's events.
turns.choice_a: Investigate who published the pamphlet
turns.consequence_a: Investigation DC 14. The printing marks trace to a small press in the Academic Quarter. The operator received the text anonymously, delivered already written on clean paper with no identifying marks. The writing style, with Arcana or Investigation, shows the same syntactic pattern as the Squeaker-Box transmissions. Vane wrote the pamphlet.
turns.choice_b: Ignore the pamphlet — its accuracy suggests a second observer but chasing speculation is inefficient
turns.consequence_b: The pamphlet circulates widely over the following week. Public awareness of the copper-tail network grows — both its protective intent and its current dangerous state. This creates political pressure on the City administration.
turns.convergence: Whether or not the pamphlet's authorship is traced back to Vane, its existence tells the party something important: whatever Vane wants, it includes the citizens of EmberHeart understanding what he has been trying to do.

turns.narrative: One week after the Swarm-Intelligence event, the city has somewhat normalized. The Watch has deployed additional patrols in copper-tail-heavy areas. Voss has begun publishing preliminary findings through academic channels. The infrastructure assessment data (if filed) has triggered three emergency engineering inspections, two of which have confirmed critical vulnerabilities. The mana-junction beneath the Chronal Pint has been flagged for priority review — a review that will, within a week, discover the temporal disturbances that begin EH_SQ_065. The Vermin thread has converged with the Chronos thread. Two ancient systems — the copper-tail relay network and the North Ward temporal infrastructure — are connected through the same underground mana-junction that Vane has been using as a transmission relay. Someone built EmberHeart as a single interconnected system. That someone has been trying to maintain it alone for 200 years.
turns.choice_a: Follow the Chronos thread connection immediately — investigate the North Ward temporal events
turns.consequence_a: Directly transitions into EH_SQ_065 investigation. The Vermin and Chronos threads merge into a unified investigation arc.
turns.choice_b: Consolidate the Vermin thread findings before moving to Chronos
turns.consequence_b: A final debrief session solidifies everything learned in the Vermin thread. The party enters the Chronos investigation with complete Vermin context, giving advantage on checks that involve the connection between the two threads.
turns.convergence: Quest complete. The Swarm-Intelligence event has been resolved, but it has also confirmed that EmberHeart's infrastructure is far more interconnected — and far more intentional — than any living citizen knew. Vane has been trying to run the whole city. He is running out of time to do it alone.

conclusion: The neural-lattice prototype is decisively violently deactivated, instantly breaking the unnatural, city-wide trance and dispersing the massive vermin rings. Voss's deeply dangerous experiment proves definitively that the local vermin population can be completely neurologically hijacked and perfectly controlled as a massive, unified network.
loot_table: Mana-Grid Infrastructure Assessment — Partial/Complete (Concordat clay disk; EmberHeart's seventeen mana-grid structural vulnerabilities mapped; immediate value to City Planning Authority; strategic value to understanding Vane's Reactivation Protocol; partial if Nexus destroyed quickly, complete if cycle allowed to finish)

Mind-Shield Circlet (Concordat-era cognitive defense item, recovered from Nexus processing unit; grants advantage on saves against mental coordination effects such as charm, domination, or collective consciousness abilities)
Voss's Behavioral Analysis Report (months of copper-tail documentation; advantage on Vermin-thread Animal Handling and Investigation checks where copper-tail behavioral patterns are relevant)

Swarm-Mind Nexus Fragment (salvageable from destroyed Nexus; Arcana research material; uniquely useful for understanding the neural-lattice signal protocol; Voss will offer significant favors for access to this)
1000 gold (Watch Captain Marrus's emergency civic resolution payment — standard procedure for contracted resolution of public safety incidents)

nexus_destroyed_before_cycle_completes.description: Nexus destroyed mid-cycle; partial infrastructure assessment recovered

consequences.permanent_effect: Nine mana-grid vulnerabilities identified; two confirmed critical; extermination order canceled; wild rat population intact

cycle_allowed_to_complete.description: Full cycle completed before Nexus destroyed; complete infrastructure assessment produced

consequences.permanent_effect: All seventeen mana-grid vulnerabilities identified; complete civic resource; extermination order required careful political management throughout; settlement stability +3 from engineering responses to findings

risk_matrix.penalty: Watch-Captain Marrus's extermination order fires before the Nexus is destroyed. 60% of the wild rat population in the Market Ward is killed. The Rat Council's trust with the party drops by one tier. The coordination event still ends when the Nexus is eventually destroyed, but the damage to the city's non-augmented rat population is permanent and the Rat Council does not forgive it quickly.
risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed with minor consequences.

title: The Copper-Virus Outbreak
location: Market Ward commercial district and the mana-grid tunnels beneath it

npcs.name: Dr. Mira Solt
npcs.description: District physician for the Market Ward who identified the illness cluster and summoned the party. Calm, overworked, unwilling to panic in front of patients. Privately terrified. Has the medical expertise to synthesize the antidote if the party provides the biological source material.

npcs.name: The Virus-Carrier Alpha
npcs.description: A large male copper-tail rat whose augmentation has been corrupted by the mana-virus it carries. Hyper-aggressive, with copper wiring visible at the skin surface and erratic movement. The virus has overloaded its neural-lattice components. The Alpha is not malicious — it is in pain — but it is extremely dangerous.

npcs.name: Grid-Technician Fen Moss
npcs.description: One of the Market Ward's mana-grid maintenance team. Knows the tunnel system and can guide the party to the viral contamination source. Does not know why any of this is happening and is deeply unhappy about being involved.

description: Dr. Solt reports a deeply disturbing localized medical anomaly: 23 patients suffering from a copper-tinged visual field, mild mana-sensitivity, and terrifyingly involuntary behavioral mirroring of nearby vermin. Tracing the infection back to the deeply buried mana-grid junction B-7, she fears stage three neural disruption within 36 hours. The party must descend into the highly toxic, deeply infected grid tunnels, isolate the heavily augmented vermin acting as the transmission vector, and secure completely untainted biological samples for Dr. Solt.
mechanics: Investigation (trace illness clusters to grid-tunnel sections)
Medicine (understand the virus mechanism and support Dr. Solt's synthesis work)
Engineering (navigate and operate the mana-grid tunnel system safely)
Combat (Virus-Carrier Alpha — Medium encounter, aberrant copper-tail)
Arcana (identify the mana-contamination signature and locate the primary source)

permanent_effects.effect: settlement_morale +2; 23 affected citizens recover; Dr. Solt becomes a recurring medical resource
settlement_morale +1; settlement_stability -1 (48-hour Market Ward power outage); affected citizens recover but antidote is lost

turns.narrative: Dr. Solt's incredibly urgent, highly classified message is chillingly clinician-precise: exactly 23 patients actively presenting with an incredibly identical, terrifying symptom cluster over precisely 4 days—a sickly copper-tinged visual field, an intensely strange mild mana-sensitivity in their hands and feet, and highly involuntary, deeply terrifying behavioral mirroring of the movements of entirely nearby rats. Three critically advanced patients aggressively progressed to stage two overnight: violent, incredibly dangerous electrical arcing violently erupting directly from their fingertips, aggressively triggered by close physical proximity to heavily powered equipment. Solt desperately does not want to alarm the Ward Council, has explicitly not reported this to the primary administration yet, and has approximately 36 desperate hours before the first three patients either miraculously stabilize or fatally decline to stage three, which her terrifying working diagnostic model suggests aggressively involves complete, permanent neural pathway disruption. She has brilliantly traced the infection's absolute origin to four adjacent, highly populated city blocks. All four perfectly intersect directly over the deeply buried, heavily restricted mana-grid junction B-7. She absolutely needs someone highly capable to go violently into the deeply infected grid tunnels and find exactly what horrifying thing is down there.
turns.choice_a: Go immediately with Grid-Technician Fen Moss as guide
turns.consequence_a: You brilliantly wrap a heavily insulated, chemically treated cloth securely over your face to completely avoid localized spore inhalation. You flawlessly extract a violently pulsing, completely infected copper-tail corpse cleanly from the primary junction box completely intact for critical medical study.
turns.choice_b: Gather information about the specific illness mechanism from Solt before going in
turns.consequence_b: You violently channel extremely focused, incredibly intense magical fire perfectly into the deeply corrupted, slime-coated primary air vents. The horrific, intensely glowing biological corruption is violently incinerated into harmless gray ash, absolutely perfectly sterilizing the entire heavily compromised area completely.
turns.convergence: With the deeply infected source beautifully isolated or violently purged, the highly erratic, violently unstable mana-flow immediately abruptly stabilizes perfectly, abruptly plunging the heavily scorched junction completely into pitch-black, deeply silent darkness.

turns.narrative: The B-7 mana-grid tunnels run at a depth of three meters below the Market Ward surface. The infrastructure here is a patchwork: modern conduit housing wrapped around Concordat-era ceramic channels that were too integral to remove during the last grid upgrade. The Concordat ceramic is warm in a way modern conduit isn't — not dangerously, but perceptibly. Fen identifies the feeling as 'normal for old grid sections.' Three minutes into the tunnel, normal stops: the ceramic channels in this section have a visible discoloration, a faintly blue-green tinge that Arcana identifies as biological material in the conductivity medium. The mana-grid is not just carrying power — it is carrying something biological. And in this section, that biological material is dense.
turns.choice_a: Sample the discoloration from the conduit wall for Dr. Solt to analyze
turns.consequence_a: Medicine DC 12 to collect a viable sample without contaminating yourself. Success: Dr. Solt has source material for antidote synthesis. Failure: sample is contaminated; another will be needed from nearer the Alpha's location.
turns.choice_b: Trace the contamination gradient towards its highest density — find the source directly
turns.consequence_b: Arcana DC 13 to track the gradient. Success: you navigate to the Alpha's location without needing to backtrack. Failure: you take a wrong branch and waste 20 minutes.
turns.convergence: The contamination grows denser as you move northeast along the B-7 corridor. Something is sitting at the center of the gradient.

turns.narrative: The B-7 junction chamber: a round room at the intersection of four conduit corridors, with a central mana-transfer housing that looks designed to route power in four directions simultaneously. The transfer housing is currently offline — the circuit breaker has tripped, probably from the biological contamination interfering with conductivity. Against the northwest wall, partially wedged between the housing base and the stone: the Virus-Carrier Alpha. It is the largest copper-tail rat the party has encountered. Its augmentation is visibly wrong: copper wiring emerges from sub-skin tissue at too many points, the neural-lattice components visible through worn sections giving off erratic pulses of light. It is not asleep — it is in acute distress. Its breathing is labored. It is shed-contaminating the entire section with every exhale.
turns.choice_a: Attempt to approach carefully — the Alpha may not be immediately aggressive if it is in distress
turns.consequence_a: Animal Handling DC 15 (DC 11 with Rat-Tongue Amulet). Success: the Alpha registers you as non-threat and allows approach. You can examine its augmentation failure up close — and potentially extract biological source material for the antidote without combat. On failure: the Alpha's pain response triggers aggression.
turns.choice_b: Clear the room of contamination first by tripping the emergency mana-flush valve on the transfer housing, then deal with the Alpha
turns.consequence_b: The mana-flush clears the immediate contamination in this section but drives the Alpha into the secondary corridors, and you must pursue it. The flush also cuts power to the junction chamber.
turns.convergence: The Virus-Carrier Alpha is the primary source. The decision about how to handle it shapes the rest of the quest.

turns.narrative: If combat: the Virus-Carrier Alpha is a Medium encounter with unusual properties. It takes its action each round but also performs a contamination shed (15-foot radius, DC 13 Constitution save or mana-sensitivity begins triggering; advantage on this save with mana-insulated equipment). Its attacks deal standard piercing damage plus 1d4 lightning. It is fast and erratic but not tactical — its pain is driving its behavior, not intelligence. At 20 HP or below, it stops attacking and retreats to the wall. It does not flee. It is too exhausted to flee. Medical observation of the Alpha at 20 HP or below grants advantage on the Medicine check to synthesize the antidote.
turns.choice_a: Subdue the Alpha without killing it — restrain and extract the source material
turns.consequence_a: Athletics or Medicine check (DC 14 combined) to restrain a debilitated but panicking large rat. On success: the Alpha is restrained, source material extracted, Alpha can be treated (not cured, but its immediate distress reduced). Dr. Solt may be able to help it further.
turns.choice_b: Kill the Alpha — fastest resolution and safest for the party
turns.consequence_b: Alpha is killed. Source material is easier to extract from a non-moving subject. Rat Council informed later registering as 'necessary but noted.' The Alpha was a known member of a copper-tail colony the Duchess tracked.
turns.convergence: Biological source material for the antidote is secured. The contamination in B-7 section will clear naturally over 48 hours without the Alpha shedding.

turns.narrative: With source material secured, the choice: synthesize antidote or purge the grid. Antidote synthesis requires Dr. Solt's lab, the source material, and approximately 8 hours of work. Mana-grid purge requires accessing the ward's primary mana-junction (B-1, three sections away) and activating the emergency flush protocol — kills the biological contamination in the entire grid but powers down the Market Ward for 48 hours. Fen Moss's reaction to the purge option: 'The Market Ward runs on that grid. Open-air refrigeration units, medical equipment at the ward clinic, the water pumps for the north quarter. Forty-eight hours of outage in winter.' He is not exaggerating. The antidote path costs 8 hours. The purge path costs 48 hours of civic disruption.
turns.choice_a: Take the source material to Dr. Solt; synthesize the antidote
turns.consequence_a: 8 hours of clinic work. The antidote can be produced in sufficient quantity for all 23 current patients in one synthesis run. If the viral contamination is spreading, new cases may develop during those 8 hours.
turns.choice_b: Activate the mana-grid purge
turns.consequence_b: Immediate contamination clearance. All 23 patients stop worsening immediately (their bodies will clear the existing mana-compound naturally over 48 hours). But 48 hours of Market Ward power outage causes secondary harm to the population dependent on grid-powered infrastructure.
turns.convergence: The chosen resolution path begins. Fen Moss handles whatever grid work is needed — he knows the tunnels.

turns.narrative: Dr. Solt's synthesis workroom is a converted closet in the back of her clinic, equipped with precision instruments that look like they belong somewhere with a larger budget. She works quickly once she has the source material, narrating as she goes with the efficiency of someone who talks to keep her hands steady. The mana-virus is not a natural pathogen. It is an engineered biological interface compound — designed, she determines, to create a temporary sensory bridge between human nervous systems and the copper-tail neural-lattice network at low concentration. At the concentration the Beta-7 section was producing due to the Alpha's augmentation failure, it is causing harm. But at the designed concentration, this compound is what would allow a human to interface with the relay network. Someone built a protocol for humans to tap into the copper-tail sensor grid. Using a biological vector.
turns.choice_a: Ask Solt if a controlled dose of the compound would produce the intended effect without harm
turns.consequence_a: Solt: 'In theory? At 5% of the concentration in the tunnel section, maybe thirty minutes of low-fidelity sensory access to whatever the relay network is currently processing. I could titrate it. I am very much not recommending this, but I could titrate it.' The option exists.
turns.choice_b: Focus on the antidote synthesis; the compound's interface properties are a secondary concern
turns.consequence_b: Solt completes the antidote efficiently. Full cure for all 23 patients. The interface compound's intended purpose is documented in her notes but not pursued.
turns.convergence: The antidote is synthesized. Distribution to the 23 patients begins.

turns.narrative: Antidote distribution: a house-call circuit through Market Ward's affected households, conducted with Solt and two clinic assistants. The treatments work: within three hours, copper-tinged vision clears, sensitivity normalizes, the behavioral mirroring stops. Fourteen patients are ambulatory and bewildered. Six are bedbound but recovering. Three had reached stage two — the electrical arcing — and their recovery is slower but stable. Solt is meticulously recording every detail. The 23 patients share one distinct characteristic she notes with growing interest: every one of them has spent significant time in the Market Ward's sub-basement sections directly above the B-7 corridor in the past 30 days. She thinks this is exposure correlation. It is also, with Arcana or History, recognizable as a pattern: the people most exposed to the relay network signal are the ones who crossed the contamination threshold. Someone who spends time near mana-grid section B-7 regularly could interface with the copper-tail network by design.
turns.choice_a: Tell Solt what you know about the intended purpose of the interface compound
turns.consequence_a: Solt processes this with visible effort. 'Someone designed a city infrastructure sensor grid and then built a way for people to tap into it. Two hundred years ago. And then left.'She pauses. 'What a lonely system to leave behind.'
turns.choice_b: Keep the Concordat background from Solt; her role is medical, not intelligence
turns.consequence_b: Solt's notes document the compound's effects and the exposure pattern without context. She will eventually figure out the connection independently if she continues this work.
turns.convergence: All 23 patients are treated. The outbreak is resolved. The compound source is neutralized. The interface capability — if anyone wants to use it — has been documented.

turns.narrative: The Alpha's fate: if subdued alive, it is currently restrained in B-7. The Rat Council, through Skitter-Jack, sends a message when they learn: the Alpha is a member of a High Ward copper-tail colony, designation 'Hammer-Nail' in chitter. He was augmented involuntarily approximately five months ago. His augmentation failure began three months ago. He has been in increasing pain throughout. The Council's formal request: if the party is able to do anything for him, they would view it as a significant reciprocal action. If the party cannot, they ask that it be clean.
turns.choice_a: Bring the Alpha to Dr. Solt and request she attempt to stabilize or remove the failing augmentation
turns.consequence_a: Medicine DC 16 and Engineering DC 14 (surgery to remove neural-lattice components without killing the animal). On success: the Alpha survives with non-functional augmentation; restored to wild-rat status. The Rat Council's gratitude is substantial. On failure: the Alpha does not survive the procedure. The Council's recognition deepens for the attempt.
turns.choice_b: Honor the Council's request for a clean end
turns.consequence_b: The Alpha is humanely euthanized. The Rat Council's grief is noted. Their trust in the party's word deepens because you fulfilled a request they did not want to make.
turns.convergence: The Alpha's fate is resolved. The Rat Council's relationship with the party shifts depending on the outcome — either deepened gratitude or deepened respect.

turns.narrative: Fen Moss, in the days after the resolution, submits a quiet report to the Ward Grid Authority about section B-7's biological contamination event. His report is accurate but strips all Concordat context: contaminated grid section, source identified and removed, section cleared. He does not mention copper-tail rats specifically. When asked why not, he tells the party privately: 'I've been maintaining these tunnels for twelve years. I know there are things down there the city would rather not have official reports about. I'm not covering anything up. I'm just not making it harder than it needs to be.' His report is filed. No institutional follow-up is generated.
turns.choice_a: Thank Fen and ask if he's seen other anomalies in the grid tunnels over twelve years
turns.consequence_a: He has a list. Not written down, in his memory. Sections that run warmer than they should. Sections where his instruments read interference patterns that don't match any known mana-source. Two sections where the Concordat ceramic is significantly more active than adjacent sections. He'll share coordinates if the party wants them.
turns.choice_b: Let Fen's report stand as filed; his discretion is valuable
turns.consequence_b: Fen nods. 'Same thing.' Future Vermin or Concordat-infrastructure investigation checks in the Market Ward grid tunnels have advantage due to the working relationship established.
turns.convergence: Fen Moss becomes a secondary recurring resource — not as prominent as Ossa Veld but useful for grid-tunnel knowledge.

turns.narrative: The Mana-Filter Implant, recovered from the Alpha's augmentation components, is examined by both Voss (if the party has the relationship) and Solt. Their combined assessment: it is a filtration device designed to be surgically implanted at the primary mana-intake point of a copper-tail augmented rat, preventing the neural-lattice from overloading when exposed to high-density mana-flux. The Alpha didn't have one. That's why his augmentation failed. Every other copper-tail unit in the city's relay network either has a functional filtration device or is in the early stages of the same failure the Alpha experienced. Voss's calculations: without the Forgeline producing replacement units, the existing copper-tail relay network will begin experiencing mass augmentation failure within four to six months. The rats' upgrades will burn out. The sensor grid will collapse. The Reactivation Protocol, whatever stage it is at, will have a hard deadline.
turns.choice_a: Share this timeline with the City Watch and administration
turns.consequence_a: The 4-6 month deadline creates institutional urgency. The Concordat Infrastructure Working Committee, if it exists, accelerates. If it doesn't exist, Solt's report creates one.
turns.choice_b: Keep the timeline as intelligence controlled within the party
turns.consequence_b: The party knows Vane has 4-6 months before his relay network collapses. His urgency and theirs are now synchronized.
turns.convergence: A 4-6 month internal deadline established. The Vermin thread has a ticking clock.

turns.narrative: Solt files a full medical report on the outbreak, citing 'novel mana-biological vector, source neutralized, antidote developed, all patients recovered.' She attributes the compound's development ambiguously as 'pre-modern engineering, origin under investigation.' Her report is read by the City Physician-General, who contacts her immediately. There are two prior incidents in clinic records — one eleven years ago (3 cases, dismissed as mana-sensitivity disorder), one four years ago (7 cases, attributed to grid contamination incident). The same symptom cluster. Both times spontaneously resolved without treatment. Both times the resolution correlated with a copper-tail rat death in section B-7 vicinity. The compound has been released before. This is not the first Virus-Carrier Alpha. Vane has been attempting the human-copper-tail interface before.
turns.choice_a: Request the full records from both prior incidents
turns.consequence_a: The records contain names. Five of the eleven-year-ago patients and two of the four-year-ago patients are still living in the Market Ward. Some of them might remember the experience — what it felt like to briefly interface with the relay network.
turns.choice_b: Note the prior incidents but don't pursue patient interviews
turns.consequence_b: The pattern is documented. Prior attempts are noted. The historical record of Vane's work extends further back than the party realized.
turns.convergence: The Copper-Virus outbreak is fully resolved. Its implications extend the Vermin thread's timeline and confirm Vane has been actively working on the interface protocol repeatedly over at least eleven years.

turns.narrative: Two weeks after the outbreak's resolution, the Market Ward has returned to normal by visible metrics. The grid is running. The clinic's special ward has been discharged. Solt sends a final case note with a personal addition: 'One patient — the stage-two case who had the most severe arcing — reported that during the worst of the mana-sensitivity episodes, she could distinctly feel where every rat in the Market Ward was. Not see. Feel. She said it was like being very briefly part of something that extended in all directions and processed everything at once. She said it was the most alone she had ever felt while feeling the most connected.' A pause in the handwriting. Solt has added: 'I don't know what to do with that, professionally. But I thought you should know.'
turns.choice_a: Interview the patient directly
turns.consequence_a: She remembers the experience in detail. Her description of the relay network in operation is consistent with Voss's technical model — but described from the inside. She wants to know if it can happen again without the harm.
turns.choice_b: File the anecdote in the research notes and move forward
turns.consequence_b: The anecdotal evidence is documented. Future understanding of the interface compound's intended experience is informed by this.
turns.convergence: Quest complete. The outbreak is resolved, the Alpha's fate determined, and a 4-6 month internal deadline for the copper-tail relay network's collapse established. Vane's interface protocol has been tried before and will be tried again. The city's rats are running out of time.

conclusion: The heavily augmented transmission vectors are aggressively isolated and violently eliminated within junction B-7, securing the crucial, uncorrupted biological samples for Dr. Solt. The terrifying discovery of a virus entirely capable of aggressively bridging the neurological gap between augmented vermin and humans narrowly averts a massive, completely devastating city-wide pandemic.
loot_table: Mana-Filter Implant (Concordat-era surgical component; protects against mana-overload when interfacing with high-density mana-flux; prevents augmentation-failure in copper-tail units if installed correctly; research value with Voss and Solt for understanding the relay network's failure cascade)
Antiviral Serum (Dr. Solt's synthesis; 4 doses; cures mana-biological contamination illness; neutralizes copper-tail interface compound exposure; medical value beyond this quest)
Virus-Carrier Alpha's Augmentation Core (partially intact; research component; Concordat neural-lattice design with failure-mode documentation; technical insight into augmentation degradation)
Fen Moss's Grid Coordinates (informal list of twelve anomalous tunnel sections from 12 years of observation; future Vermin or Concordat-infrastructure investigation advantage)
Dr. Solt's Outbreak Documentation (complete medical case notes; prior incident records from 11 and 4 years ago; patient anecdotal descriptions of relay-network experience)
950 gold (City Physician-General's emergency resolution payment for the outbreak response)

antidote_synthesized.description: Source material extracted, antidote produced and distributed, 23 patients cured

consequences.permanent_effect: Dr. Solt becomes an active medical resource; interface compound documented; 48-hour outage avoided

grid_purged.description: Mana-grid emergency purge activated, contamination cleared, 48-hour power outage

consequences.permanent_effect: Immediate halt to contamination spread; secondary harm from 48-hour Market Ward power outage; no antidote produced for future exposures

risk_matrix.penalty: Three stage-two patients advance to stage three (neural pathway disruption). Their symptoms become permanent unless a different antidote can be found later. The contamination continues spreading through the grid for additional 48 hours, producing 7-12 new cases.
risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed with minor consequences.

title: The Rat-Mask Cult
unlock_conditions: Complete SQ-04 (The Rat King's Crown) — quest works regardless of how the Rat King encounter resolved
location: Lower Ward — Catacomb access points, the Underpipe Cathedrals, the Gnaw-Market perimeter

npcs.name: High Priest Dorren Vex
npcs.description: Former Lower Ward city administrator who became obsessed with the Rat King assassination/mercy event and organized the cult from its aftermath. Augmented with copper-tail wiring that he installed himself, imperfectly. He is intelligent, charismatic, and completely convinced that the Rat King was a god whose death or departure was a divine punishment for humanity's failures. He genuinely believes.

npcs.name: Sister Nara (Nara Fent)
npcs.description: A cult member who reached out to Skitter-Jack privately. She joined the cult six months ago when her family lost their Lower Ward tenement. She wants out but is afraid of Vex. She will cooperate with the party if they guarantee her safety.

npcs.name: The Rat Council / The Duchess
npcs.description: The Rat Council is watching the cult with wariness. The worship of the Rat King as a deity is not something they endorse — they knew the Rat King personally, and he was not a god. But the cult has been valuable to copper-tail units in the Lower Ward, providing shelter and protection. The Duchess's position: the cult is complicated.

description: Sister Nara brings deeply disturbing intelligence regarding the 'Rat-Mask Cult', a desperate religious movement formed in the Lower Ward by displaced citizens following the Rat King events. The cult's leader, Vex, is actively planning a horrific 'Communion' ceremony to surgically install scavenged copper-tail neural-lattice components directly into the skulls of willing congregation members. The party must infiltrate the catacomb antechambers, aggressively interrupt Vex's lethal surgical ritual, and prevent the horrific mass-conversion of desperate citizens.
mechanics: Persuasion (convert leadership or key members; negotiate with Vex directly)
Deception (infiltrate the cult with false devotion)
Investigation (map cult size, leadership structure, and Communion plan timeline)
Combat (High Priest Vex if confronted directly — Medium encounter, imperfect copper-tail augmentation giving him enhanced physicality at the cost of pain and instability)
Medicine (assess the Communion procedure's lethality; potentially propose a safe alternative)

permanent_effects.effect: settlement_morale +3; new Lower Ward community mutual-aid network established; copper-tail units in Lower Ward become less aggressive toward cult territory
settlement_stability +2; settlement_morale -1 (community services lost); Vex imprisoned or fled

turns.narrative: Skitter-Jack brings terrifying word from Sister Nara: the fanatic 'Rat-Mask Cult' has been violently organizing in the shadows since the Rat King was deposed. Under the charismatic leadership of an unhinged man named Vex, the cult has established genuine community services in the ancient catacomb antechambers, filling a desperate gap the Ward Council ignores. Nara's terror, however, is specific: Vex has announced a 'Communion' ceremony in twelve days. He plans to surgically install crude, corroded copper-tail neural-lattice components—salvaged from dead augmented rats—directly into the skulls of willing cult members. She fears they don't understand what 'willing' truly means, and she is positive they won't survive the procedure.
turns.choice_a: Meet with Sister Nara immediately and gather full intelligence on the cult's structure
turns.consequence_a: You powerfully step directly before the utterly desperate, deeply misguided congregation and beautifully aggressively expose Vex's horrifying, violently lethal technological delusion. Your deeply genuine, powerfully impassioned plea utterly breaks his incredibly fragile charismatic hold, causing the absolutely terrified cult members to completely violently abandon him immediately.
turns.choice_b: Observe the cult's public activities first before making contact with Nara
turns.consequence_b: You slip completely unnoticed into his highly guarded back room. You deploy a small, concentrated acidic charge that silently melts the salvaged copper-tail components into utterly useless, harmless slag.
turns.convergence: Vex realizes his Communion is violently ruined. He draws a jagged, heavily rusted blade, his eyes flashing with absolute, terrifying madness as he screams for his congregation to kill the intruders.

turns.narrative: The Rat Council's position, communicated through Skitter-Jack: the Duchess knew the Rat King. He was large, clever, and in significant pain from the copper-tail augmentation that had been done to him. He was not a god. He was a rat who had been modified beyond his biology's tolerance and was managing it with exceptional will. The cult's worship implies a divinity that the Duchess finds factually incorrect, not theologically offensive. She is more concerned about the copper-tail units the cult has been sheltering and feeding. In exchange for this hospitality, the copper-tail units have been providing the cult with 'security patrols' — early warning of Watch incursions. The cult and the copper-tail network have a symbiotic relationship the Duchess did not arrange and does not entirely approve of. She asks the party: 'If you dismantle the cult, what happens to the sixty humans who currently have food?'
turns.choice_a: Tell the Duchess you intend to convert the cult, not destroy it — the community services will survive
turns.consequence_a: The Duchess's position shifts slightly: if the cult's community function is preserved under different leadership or mandate, she will instruct copper-tail units in the territory to maintain their current non-aggressive stance during the party's intervention.
turns.choice_b: Tell the Duchess you'll assess and decide — no prior commitment
turns.consequence_b: The Duchess accepts. The copper-tail units remain neuter — not hostile but not helpful. The party's options are fully open.
turns.convergence: The party's approach to Vex and the cult begins taking shape.

turns.narrative: The Communion plan, assessed medically with Dr. Solt's consultation (if she is a contact) or Medicine DC 15 from party knowledge: salvaged copper-tail neural-lattice components installed surgically by a non-surgeon into human skull tissue. The neural-lattice is designed for rat neurology — the synaptic bridging compounds are calibrated for mammals but not human-scale neural density. At rat scale: manageable with the Mana-Filter Implant. At human scale: catastrophic inflammatory response. Vex's Communion ceremony will kill between 70% and 90% of participants within 48 hours of implantation. The survivors, if any, will not be enhanced — they will be in permanent neural distress, like the Alpha rat in EH_SQ_078. He genuinely does not know this. He believes the Rat King's augmentation gave him strength; he is designing a ceremony to share that strength with his congregation.
turns.choice_a: Tell Vex the procedure will kill his congregation
turns.consequence_a: Meeting with Vex required. This is the conversion path's hinge point. Persuasion DC 17 (he deeply believes the procedure will work; his faith is sincere; he will not accept criticism easily). With medical documentation (Solt's notes, the Alpha's case) DC reduces to 13. Success opens negotiation about what the cult becomes instead.
turns.choice_b: Prevent the Communion without telling Vex — remove the materials, destroy the procedure space
turns.consequence_b: Covert sabotage. Deception or Stealth DCs required to enter the catacomb Communion chamber and remove or destroy the salvaged neural-lattice components. This delays the ceremony but does not resolve the cult's leadership problem.
turns.convergence: The party must ultimately decide whether to engage Vex or work around him.

turns.narrative: Vex in person: he meets in the catacomb antechamber wearing his High Priest regalia — a full rat-skull mask, copper wire wrapped around his forearms and calves in patterns that mirror (imperfectly) the copper-tail augmentation routing. The wiring is installed under his skin in sections. It is clearly painful; he holds himself carefully to avoid flexing his wrists. He is in his 50s, previously well-dressed, still articulate. He believes completely that the Rat King was a manifestation of something greater than an ordinary creature — something the city threw away, something that suffered for what EmberHeart failed to protect in its underclass. His sermon, delivered without prompting, is not delusional. It is a very coherent theology of urban neglect. The Communion, he says, is not surgery. It is sacrament.
turns.choice_a: Engage with his theology before presenting the medical reality — meet him where he is
turns.consequence_a: Insight check DC 12: Vex wants to be heard more than he wants to be right. He has had this faith for eight months and has not had a single conversation with someone who took it seriously enough to argue with. Spending twenty minutes on his theological framework before introducing the medical problem reduces Persuasion DC to 11.
turns.choice_b: Present the medical evidence directly and clearly — he is a former administrator, he respects documentation
turns.consequence_b: His administrative instincts engage alongside his faith. He asks technical questions about the neural-lattice scale-calibration issue. He is harder to persuade emotionally but easier to persuade logically. Persuasion DC 15, but with advantage if the Mana-Filter Implant case is presented.
turns.convergence: Vex is either opened to conversation or beginning to entrench. The next several turns determine whether the conversion path succeeds.

turns.narrative: The conversion path, if succeeding: Vex's breaking point is not the mortality statistics. It is the Alpha's case — the photograph of an animal in pain from the same augmentation he is proposing to give his congregation. He looks at this (if presented) for a very long time. Then: 'He was suffering.' A statement, not a question. 'For months.' He sits down. The theology does not break — he finds the Alpha's suffering consistent with his belief that the Rat King's augmentation was a form of sacrifice. But the Communion procedure, he concedes, would not give his congregation the Rat King's strength. It would give them the Alpha's pain. Those are not the same thing. He does not disband the cult. He asks: can there be a Communion without this procedure. The party has twelve days to answer.
turns.choice_a: Propose the interface compound from EH_SQ_078 as a controlled, temporary Communion alternative
turns.consequence_a: With Dr. Solt's involvement: a Communion ritual using a controlled safe dose of the mana-interface compound could give participants a brief genuine connection to the copper-tail relay network. This is closer to theological authenticity than Vex's procedure. He is stunned. He agrees to delay the Communion to consider this.
turns.choice_b: Propose converting the cult to a secular community organization — drop the theological frame entirely
turns.consequence_b: Persuasion DC 17 — this requires Vex to abandon his faith, which is also his identity since SQ-04. On success: a very painful concession that he makes because the community services matter more to him than the sacrament. On failure he agrees to delay but not abandon the theology.
turns.convergence: The Communion ceremony is either replaced with a safer alternative, postponed indefinitely, or dismantled. The cult's community services continue in some form.

turns.narrative: Sister Nara's exit: regardless of how the Vex negotiation goes, Nara and the three members she identified want to leave. They have families outside the cult, lives they returned to only partially. None of them were coerced in the classic sense — they joined willingly, desperately, and now want out with equal desperation. The exit requires navigating out of the catacomb district without the more zealous cult members noticing. Vex, depending on his current disposition (converted or still resistant), either facilitates this quietly or does not oppose it. He has never prevented anyone from leaving. That is, unexpectedly, true.
turns.choice_a: Escort Nara and the three others out personally
turns.consequence_a: The extraction goes cleanly. No confrontation. Nara provides one final piece of intelligence: the copper wire in the catacomb walls — decorative, she thought — is actually connected to the copper-tail units outside. Vex has been using them as an alarm system for months. He knew the party was coming before they arrived.
turns.choice_b: Arrange the extraction through a third party — Skitter-Jack or Fen Moss
turns.consequence_b: Extraction completed safely through intermediaries. The party is not seen leaving with the defectors. Vex cannot formally acknowledge knowing.
turns.convergence: Nara and the three members are safely extracted. Vex knew they were leaving. He did not stop them. Whatever his theology, this is not a coercive organization.

turns.narrative: The combat path, if the Vex negotiation has failed or the party chose disruption over diplomacy: Vex in combat is a Medium encounter defined by his imperfect augmentation. His copper-wire installation is causing him constant base-level pain; in combat it becomes an active liability. He has enhanced strength (the copper-wire provides genuine if crude augmentation) and surprising speed, but every high-exertion movement causes him visible agony. He fights with a long copper-bound staff and will attempt to use the catacomb's geography — tight, low corridors — to limit area-effect attacks. At half HP, the copper-wire installation begins arcing across his forearms, dealing 1d4 lightning damage to anyone adjacent. He does not flee. He believes in this cause enough to die for it. A successful Persuasion DC 14 mid-combat can stop the fight.
turns.choice_a: Subdue Vex without killing him — he should face justice, not martyrdom
