turns.consequence_a: Vex is captured. Presented to the City Watch. The cult fractures without his leadership. The community services collapse but may be reassembled under Nara or another member in 2-4 weeks.
turns.choice_b: Defeat Vex decisively
turns.consequence_b: Vex is killed. He becomes a martyr. The cult fragment-survives under three competing successor figures, none with his charisma. It diminishes but does not disappear. The community services collapse temporarily.
turns.convergence: The cult's leadership question is resolved one way or another.

turns.narrative: The cult's sixty members: regardless of how Vex's situation resolved, these are sixty Lower Ward residents who had food, shelter, and community and now are uncertain whether they still do. The community services — food distribution, skills exchange, nighttime shelter — require someone to operate them. The physical resources exist: the catacomb antechambers are structurally sound, the supply chain Vex established is real. If the cult converts to a secular organization, the transition is managed. If the cult is dismantled, the sixty members scatter. If the cult continues under new leadership, the services continue under new management. The Duchess's question from Turn 2 receives its answer now.
turns.choice_a: Work with Nara to establish a civilian community organization from the cult's infrastructure
turns.consequence_a: 2-3 weeks of organizational work (off-screen). Nara becomes the organization's director. The Lower Ward Mutual Aid Society is formally registered with the Ward Authority. Settlement morale +3. The catacomb antechambers are repurposed as a legitimate community space.
turns.choice_b: Refer the sixty members to existing city services and let the infrastructure disperse
turns.consequence_b: Existing city services absorb approximately 40 of the 60 members adequately. 20 fall through gaps the city services don't reach. Settlement morale -1 for this shortfall. Some will re-form around a new informal organization within 2 months.
turns.convergence: The Lower Ward's community services question is resolved in a form that will persist.

turns.narrative: The copper wire and rat masks: the cult's aesthetics have been collected, modified, and produced by its members over eight months. The rat masks, in particular, are works of craft — detailed, expressive, individually made. Some of them are very good. The cult's artisan members, following the disruption, are sitting on a collection of genuinely skilled objects that have no obvious use for a secular community organization. A Market Ward collector approaches Skitter-Jack (who approaches the party) with an unlikely offer: there is a market for these masks. The aesthetic of 'vermin devotion' is, inexplicably, fashionable in at least three ward districts. The artisan members of the former cult could fund the mutual-aid organization's first year through mask sales. The irony is not lost on anyone.
turns.choice_a: Facilitate the mask-sale arrangement
turns.consequence_a: The artisan members form a small cooperative. The mutual-aid organization is funded for 14 months from sales revenue. Settlement morale +1. The Rat-Mask aesthetic spreads through the city in diluted form.
turns.choice_b: Decline — the cult's iconography should not be capitalized on
turns.consequence_b: The masks are distributed to members as personal items or destroyed per individual choice. The funding problem is solved another way (community donations, ward grant).
turns.convergence: The financial sustainability of whatever organization emerged from the cult is addressed.

turns.narrative: The Rat Council's response: the Duchess, through Skitter-Jack, sends a formal acknowledgment. The cult's worship of the Rat King as a deity is theologically inaccurate but the Duchess concedes it is, in an odd way, a form of testimony — sixty humans affected enough by the Rat King's existence to organize their lives around it. She does not endorse the theology. She endorses the outcome: sixty humans who were hungry are less hungry. The copper-tail units who had been sheltering in the cult's territory can continue if the new organization permits it. The Duchess offers a token of ongoing relationship: the Rat Council will maintain awareness of the new organization and provide early warning of any Lower Ward structural emergencies via Skitter-Jack. An informal civil defense arrangement.
turns.choice_a: Accept the Rat Council's civil defense arrangement formally
turns.consequence_a: The arrangement is established. The Rat Council becomes an informal infrastructure partner for the Lower Ward Mutual Aid Society. Future Lower Ward emergency response gets early warning through Skitter-Jack.
turns.choice_b: Decline formal arrangement; maintain the Council relationship separately from the community organization
turns.consequence_b: The Council's offer is noted and deferred. The relationship remains personal to the party rather than institutional.
turns.convergence: The Rat Council relationship has deepened through this quest regardless of the formal arrangement decision.

turns.narrative: Vex's theology, in retrospect: the Rat King, as he experienced it from SQ-04 reports and the cult's collected testimonies, was a mass of augmentation distress and adaptive intelligence surviving it. Vex interpreted that as divinity. The party and the Duchess know the copper-tail program's actual history: Concordat welfare infrastructure, 200 years of automated operation, V.A./Vane's maintenance work. The Rat King was an animal that suffered through two centuries of augmentation without dying. That is not divinity. But the Duchess's comment in Turn 2 lingers: the Rat King persisted through conditions that should have ended him, and then — depending on SQ-04's resolution — either died or did not. If he did not die, where is he? The cult's belief that the Rat King 'departed' rather than died is either mystical thinking or information the Duchess doesn't have.
turns.choice_a: Ask the Duchess directly: is the Rat King alive?
turns.consequence_a: The Duchess is still for a long time. 'I do not know. He stopped being in the network eleven weeks after your encounter. Whether that means death or displacement or something else — I cannot tell you. The network does not record absences. It records presences.' He may be gone. He may be somewhere the relay network doesn't reach.
turns.choice_b: Don't pursue the question — the cult's belief doesn't need to be adjudicated
turns.consequence_b: The Rat King's fate remains a deliberate ambiguity. His theological status in the cult, unresolved by the party, allows the community organization to maintain some narrative continuity with its origin story.
turns.convergence: The Rat King's fate is either investigated or left ambiguous. Either has narrative implications for the Vermin thread's conclusion.

turns.narrative: One month after the resolution, the Lower Ward is measurably different from a community metrics standpoint regardless of approach. The catacomb antechambers are occupied with purpose. Sixty people know each other's names and skills and have a place to be in the evening. Skitter-Jack reports that the copper-tail units in the Lower Ward's informal territory the cult managed have shifted into what he describes as 'ambient cooperative' mode — not directed, not patrol-pattern, just present in a way that feels chosen rather than programmed. The Duchess's early-warning arrangement, if established, has already flagged one structural concern in a block adjacent to the Prospect Lane colony's old building. The Lower Ward is not better by the city's administrative metrics. But it is better by other measuring systems. The quest ends not with a dramatic resolution but with the quieter fact of sixty people who have enough.
turns.choice_a: Check in on Sister Nara and the new organization one month later
turns.consequence_a: Nara is exhausted, effective, and more herself than she was in the cult. She has retained one element of the cult's ritual: a weekly assembly where members share one thing they're grateful for. She de-theologized it. 'It turns out gratitude doesn't require a rat god,' she says. 'Just somewhere to say it.'
turns.choice_b: Move forward; the Lower Ward's situation has been addressed sufficiently
turns.consequence_b: Future Lower Ward investigation checks have advantage as a general consequence of the improved community relationships and Rat Council cooperation.
turns.convergence: Quest complete. The Rat-Mask Cult is resolved — converted, dismantled, or transformed. The Lower Ward has a functioning community organization of some form. The Rat King's fate remains a meaningful open question.

conclusion: The horrific Communion ceremony is violently interrupted, decisively putting an end to Vex's lethal obsession and ultimately saving the deeply desperate congregation from horrific neurological mutilation. The horrifying revelation that scavenged Concordat biocontroller components can be crudely grafted onto human subjects underscores the extreme danger of the city's unchecked, highly unregulated technological scavenging.
loot_table: Rat-Mask of the Faithful (masterwork example of Vex's personal mask; elaborate copper-wire chasing and carved bone; grants Advantage on Persuasion checks with Lower Ward residents who associate the mask with the mutual-aid organization; Disadvantage on the same checks with Watch personnel in Market Ward)
Cultist Robes (six sets; copper-wire-threaded cloth; well-made; useful as disguise in cult-adjacent social situations; could be sold to the collector for 80 gold each)

High Priest Vex's Augmentation Notes (his personal research into copper-tail neural-lattice installation in human subjects; medically useful documentation of what not to do and why; Dr. Solt will want this for safety research)
Catacomb Infrastructure Survey (Nara's mental map of the catacomb antechamber network formalized; structural assessment; useful for Lower Ward emergency response)
900 gold (combination of Watch civic resolution payment and community contribution from the sixty members — they insisted)

cult_converted.description: Vex accepts the medical reality; Communion replaced with safe alternative; cult transitions to Lower Ward Mutual Aid Society

consequences.permanent_effect: Lower Ward Mutual Aid Society established; Nara becomes recurring NPC director; Rat Council civil defense arrangement active

cult_dismantled.description: Vex defeated or arrested; cult disbanded; community services collapsed then partially rebuilt

consequences.permanent_effect: Vex imprisoned or dead; cult fragments but does not disappear entirely; settlement morale -1 for lost services before replacement is established

risk_matrix.penalty: The Communion ceremony proceeds before the party can intervene. Forty-two of the sixty participants die during or within 48 hours of the procedure. Vex, horrified, flees the city. The cult collapses entirely. The Lower Ward loses both its community services and 42 residents simultaneously — a catastrophic morale event. Settlement morale -4. The Watch investigates as a mass casualty incident.
risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed with minor consequences.

title: The Bleach-Cult

unlock_conditions.event_trigger: Merchants report robed strangers purchasing every drop of industrial bleach in the Market Ward

location: Market Ward - Dye District and Bleach-Cult Compound
key_npcs: Elder Whitmore (Bleach-Cult leader, zealous but genuinely deluded)
Maren the Dyer (quest-giver, her livelihood under attack)
The Colorless Ones (cultists in pure-white robes, disturbingly stain-free)
permanent_effects: Player learns Warp-Static only affects colored fabric (white fabric is inert)
Bleach-Cult disbanded or converted into legitimate fabric-ward organization

disband_cult.description: Expose Elder Whitmore's theology as mistaken, dissolve the cult

consequences.lore_gain: Whitmore's research note recovered: white fabric IS inert to Warp-Static — he was accidentally right about that part

redirect_cult.description: Channel cult's bleach-zeal into legitimate Ward protection (they bleach Warp-Silk hotspots)

consequences.permanent_effect: Bleach-Wardens become a recurring faction, providing minor Laundry Ward protection

description: The Bleach-Cult believes all colored fabric is 'spiritually contaminated' and must be purified to white. Under Elder Whitmore's leadership, they've begun forcibly bleaching garments, destroying Maren the Dyer's stock, and threatening to purge the Dye District. The disturbing part: their theology is almost accidentally correct about Warp-Static.

turns.narrative: Maren the Dyer is holding a bolt of formerly-scarlet silk that is now the color of old milk. Standing behind her counter in what is unmistakably a crime scene—55 bolts of silk, 20 barrels of dye, and a carefully tended indigo garden, all bleached to stark white—she is not crying. She is too angry to cry. 'They came at 3 AM,' she says. 'Twelve of them. In white robes so clean they glowed. They sang while they bleached. SANG. It took them forty minutes.' Outside, you can see similar white patches on other dyers' awnings. The whole Dye District looks like a snowstorm hit only the fashionable things.
turns.choice_a: Examine the bleached fabrics for any unusual properties (Investigation + Arcana DC 11)
turns.consequence_a: Success: The bleached silk is not merely discolored—the Warp-Static lattice within it is completely gone. Before: static charges measurable. After: inert as table linen. Elder Whitmore's cult is accidentally neutralizing Warp-Static affected fabric. (+1 Lore)
turns.choice_b: Ask around the Market Ward for information about the robed strangers (Persuasion DC 10)
turns.consequence_b: Success: 'The Colorless Ones. They preach at the Fountain of Veln every week with buckets of bleach as devotional props. Elder Whitmore. He says color is the mark of the Warp.' Several citizens find them funny. Two look slightly convinced. (+1 Intel)
turns.convergence: A Colorless One approaches--robe immaculate, manner serene, carrying a pamphlet titled 'The Pure White Future' and a small spray bottle of what is definitely industrial bleach. He smiles at you. 'Friend. Are your garments free of Warp-taint?' He eyes your clothing with clinical concern.

turns.narrative: The pamphlet is surprisingly coherent. Elder Whitmore, it turns out, is not an idiot: he has observed that the Laundry Ward's animated-fabric incidents cluster around colored items, not white ones. White sheets don't animate. Colored ones do. He has drawn exactly the wrong conclusion from a correct observation—inferring moral contamination where there is dimensional physics—and built a religion around it. The pamphlet ends with: 'Join us. Surrender your colors. Find peace in the Blank.' Between the theology, it reads like decent incident data.
turns.choice_a: Attend a Bleach-Cult sermon to observe Whitmore directly (Investigation DC 12, Stealth optional)
turns.consequence_a: Success: Whitmore is magnetic. His recorded 'miracles' are all real—he bleached a possessed sock that was strangling his nephew, a living shirt that had attacked three people, an animated tablecloth. He DID neutralize Warp-Static entities. He just thinks he did it through piety. (+1 Lore)
turns.choice_b: Confront the Colorless One directly with evidence the cult is causing property damage (Persuasion DC 13)
turns.consequence_b: Success: He is genuinely troubled. 'We only purify what has already been claimed by the Warp.' He does not understand that Maren's silk was NOT animated. In his framework, all color is suspect. He is not malicious. He is wrong. (+1 Intel)
turns.convergence: Elder Whitmore himself emerges from the cult compound—a lean, precise man of sixty in immaculate white, who sees you and says, pleasantly: 'Investigator. I've been expecting someone like you. Please come in. I'd like to show you my research.' He means this sincerely.

turns.narrative: Whitmore's compound is spotless. Every surface is white. Even the food looks slightly pale. His research room is extraordinary: 40 documented animated-fabric incidents in the Laundry Ward over six months, every one properly recorded with date, item description, behavior observed, and resolution. He has been bleaching Warp-Static entities out of fabric with 100% success. And he has been doing it with the thorough documentation of a scholar. He could be an asset. Except he just bleached someone's grandmother's wedding dress because it was blue.
turns.choice_a: Engage Whitmore academically—show him the Warp-Static physics explanation for his observations (Arcana DC 14)
turns.consequence_a: Success: He listens. He is quiet for a long time. 'You are saying the color itself is not the contamination. The Warp-Static uses the chromatic molecular structure as...an anchor.' A longer silence. 'That is almost more disturbing than my theology.' (+2 Lore, Whitmore genuinely reconsidering)
turns.choice_b: Confront Whitmore with Maren's losses and demand he makes reparations before any theology discussion
turns.consequence_b: Success: Whitmore is genuinely aghast. 'We only bleach items that are actively manifesting. Maren's silk was not manifesting.' He rounds on his lieutenant. 'Brother Pale. You said those bolts were thrashing.' 'I... thought they were.' A lie, or paranoia. (+1 Progress, internal cult fissure opens)
turns.convergence: Whitmore shows you his final journal entry, from last night: three lines, underlined three times: 'Are we protecting the Ward? Or are we becoming the threat?' He closes the journal. 'I wrote that before you arrived. Tell me what you know.'

turns.narrative: You have Whitmore largely on your side—he is a man of genuine intellectual honesty underneath the bleach-theology, and the evidence is reaching him. But his cult is not uniform. Brother Pale is the problem: younger, more zealous, and very attached to the idea that color is evil rather than merely physics. While you've been talking to Whitmore, Brother Pale has taken four cultists to the Silk Quarter and is currently standing outside the largest fabric merchant in the Ward with a pump-sprayer.
turns.choice_a: Rush to the Silk Quarter and physically stop Brother Pale before he acts (Athletics DC 12)
turns.consequence_a: Success: You arrive just as Pale raises the sprayer. You put yourself between him and the bolts. Pale blinks. You stare at each other. He blinks again. Not brave enough to spray a person who is clearly ready to take the sprayer from him. He lowers it. (+1 Progress)
turns.choice_b: Send Whitmore to stop his own lieutenant (Leadership DC 13, tests Whitmore's resolve)
turns.consequence_b: Success: Whitmore walks to Brother Pale without hurrying. In front of the four cultists, he says: 'We do not act without evidence of manifestation. Stand down.' Pale does—but his face as he does says this is not over for him. (+1 Progress, Whitmore's authority tested and held)
turns.convergence: Brother Pale is standing down. But as he turns away, he does something strange: he sprays the wall beside him, once, quickly. There is a patch of colored plaster there—old paint, flaking. And there is something behind it. Something in the wall that twitches when the bleach hits it. Brother Pale knew. He was not wrong about this spot.

turns.narrative: Behind the peeling wall-paint, embedded in plaster that has not been touched in 20 years, is a bolt of Warp-Silk. Not large—six inches wide, two feet long—but it is unmistakably Warp-Silk: that iridescent shifting-color quality that doesn't resolve when you look directly at it, woven with the dimensional-bleed shimmer. It is in the wall of the Silk Quarter's largest merchant building. It has been there for decades. And it has been quietly animating fabric in this district the whole time. A passive Warp-Static source. Brother Pale knew because he felt it when he walked past. He is annoying, wrong about color theology, AND possesses genuine Warp-sensitivity.
turns.choice_a: Extract the Warp-Silk from the wall carefully (Fabric-Handling DC 14, careful approach preserves it intact)
turns.consequence_a: Success: You peel the Warp-Silk free without tearing. It writhes slightly in your hands like something alive. Warp-Silk sample obtained—incredibly valuable for research. The district's ambient animation rate will drop measurably over the next few weeks. (+2 Lore, Warp-Silk sample obtained)
turns.choice_b: Bleach the Warp-Silk in place (follow Whitmore's method, fast and certain)
turns.consequence_b: Success: The Warp-Silk goes inert with a sound like a sigh. The shimmer fades to beige. It's dead, effectively—no longer a Warp-Static source. Faster but destroys the research potential. (+1 Progress, source neutralized)
turns.convergence: Brother Pale watches whichever method you use. When it's done, he says: 'That's what I saw. I saw things in walls. I tried to tell Elder Whitmore they were there before the color was, but he said the color draws them.' He looks at the deactivated silk or the hole in the wall. 'I've been bleaching walls for months. That's the first one I actually found.' His theology is a rationalization for a real gift.

turns.narrative: The reckoning with Brother Pale is actually more interesting than the one with Elder Whitmore. Pale is genuinely Warp-sensitive—he can feel active Warp-Silk through walls, floors, possibly at significant distances. This is rare. This is useful. And he has been channeling this gift through a paranoid anti-color theology that has destroyed 55 bolts of innocent silk. You have a choice about what to do with this information and this person.
turns.choice_a: Recruit Brother Pale as an informal Warp-detection consultant (Persuasion DC 15, requires getting him to examine his assumptions)
turns.consequence_a: Success: Pale is resistant, then slowly, painfully interested. 'If the color isn't the problem... then I can stop counting colors and start feeling for the real thing.' He extends his hand. 'Show me what Warp-Silk actually feels like.' He is going to be very annoying AND extremely useful. (+2 Lore, Warp-sensor recruited)
turns.choice_b: Report Pale's Warp-sensitivity to the Mage Guild (bypassing his consent, efficient)
turns.consequence_b: The Guild is immediately interested. They send a letter to Pale that evening. He refuses for two weeks, then accepts under considerable Guild pressure and a stipend. (+1 Lore, Guild gains asset, Pale is resentful of you specifically)
turns.convergence: Elder Whitmore has been watching this exchange. When it's over, he says: 'Brother Pale felt the real thing and built the wrong map around it. I observed the real thing and built the wrong theology around it.' He removes his white robe, revealing ordinary grey underneath. 'What does the correct map look like?'

turns.narrative: The Bleach-Cult's reckoning takes the form of a congregation meeting that evening, attended by you, Whitmore, and 23 Colorless Ones in increasingly uncertain white robes. Whitmore presents the facts as you've shared them. The room is quiet. Then someone at the back says: 'So bleach still works?' Whitmore looks at you. You confirm: bleach neutralizes Warp-Static in fabric. 'Then we were doing the right thing,' the voice continues, 'just for the wrong reasons.' A pause. 'Can we keep doing it correctly now?' The congregation is not dissolving. It is self-correcting.
turns.choice_a: Help Whitmore reshape the cult into a formal Warp-Fabric Wardens guild (Leadership DC 13)
turns.consequence_a: Success: The Warp-Fabric Wardens are established within the week. Their mandate: detect and neutralize Warp-Static fabric events in the Laundry Ward using bleach protocols. Whitmore is the director. Brother Pale is the field-sensor. Maren the Dyer donates white cloth to replace the ones they ruined. Awkwardly heartwarming. (+2 Settlement Stability)
turns.choice_b: Leave the cult to Whitmore and just ensure they sign a reparations agreement with the Dyer's Guild
turns.consequence_b: The reparations agreement is painful for the cult financially but clears their legal standing. They continue operating, more cautiously, without formal structure. Occasional missteps. Less destructive. Tolerated. (+1 Settlement Stability)
turns.convergence: Maren the Dyer, who has been briefed on the Warp-Silk discovery, accepts Whitmore's apology with the specific phrasing: 'Your people destroyed my silk. And then one of them found the thing that was going to turn my silk into a problem anyway. I don't know how to feel about that.' She pauses. 'Infuriating. That's the word.'

turns.narrative: Final debrief. The Warp-Silk sample from the wall (if preserved) goes to the Mage Guild or your personal research collection. The Bleach-Cult has either been dissolved or transformed into something functional. Maren's losses are compensated, partially. And Brother Pale is doing something extraordinary: standing in the Silk Quarter with his eyes closed, slowly turning, feeling for Warp-Silk in the walls. He points at three buildings. 'There. There. And that one very strongly.' He opens his eyes and looks at you. 'You'll want to start with that one.'
turns.choice_a: Investigate the 'very strongly' building Pale identified immediately (creates follow-up content)
turns.consequence_a: Success: The building is a seamstress's workshop. In her sub-basement storage: not a scrap but a full bolt of Warp-Silk, six feet by thirty, rolled and tied with a cord stamped with a pre-Scourge weaver's mark. Someone stored this deliberately. This is not accidental bleed-through. (+3 Lore, major Warp-Silk cache discovery, connects to Weaver thread)
turns.choice_b: File the locations for future investigation and close the Bleach-Cult case
turns.consequence_b: The three locations are registered with the Watch and Mage Guild for follow-up. You're done for today. The Laundry Ward is slightly safer. Maren makes you a gift of a new jacket—vivid green. 'Defiantly colorful,' she says. (+2 Reputation, green jacket item)
turns.convergence: Quest Complete. The Bleach-Cult was accidentally right about Warp-Static and comprehensively wrong about everything else. Brother Pale is the most useful annoying person in the Ward. And somewhere in the pre-Scourge record, someone was weaving Warp-Silk deliberately and storing it under the city. The fabric horror has a history.

conclusion: The Bleach-Cult was built on a correct observation and a mistaken theology. Elder Whitmore has been inadvertently neutralizing Warp-Static fabric events for months. Brother Pale is genuinely Warp-sensitive—a rare gift wrapped in paranoid zealotry. The Dye District will recover. And the pre-Scourge Warp-Silk cache beneath the seamstress's basement is a thread that pulls on something much larger.
loot_table: Warp-Silk Sample (6-inch swatch, still faintly active - research material or Weaver-thread key item)
Elder Whitmore's Incident Log (40 documented Warp-Static events, major lore compendium)
Bleach-Warden Recruitment Certificate (Brother Pale as occasional Warp-sensor ally)
Maren's Green Jacket (fine clothing, +1 to Market Ward social checks, defiantly colorful)

risk_matrix.penalty: Bleach-Cult escalates to full Dye District purge. All colored fabric in Market Ward bleached. -4 Settlement Morale, Dyer's Guild strikes. -2 Market Ward Commerce for 3 sessions.
risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed quietly. The situation remains unresolved.

title: The Sock-Thief Elemental

unlock_conditions.event_trigger: Laundress Guild reports systematic left-sock disappearances during 3 AM laundry shift

key_npcs: Head Laundress Dottie Grieve (quest-giver, magnificently furious)
The Sock Elemental (Warp-Static entity, made of 300+ lost left socks, lonely)
Rennick the Plumber (steam-tunnel expert, deeply philosophical about socks)
permanent_effects: Player learns Warp-Static can coalesce into elemental form from accumulated fabric
Sock Elemental befriended or dispersed
Steam-tunnel Warp-Static hotspot identified

befriend_elemental.description: Understand the Sock Elemental wants company; give it a home and a purpose

consequences.permanent_effect: Sock Elemental becomes Laundry Ward mascot; returns socks and can sense Warp-Static disturbances
consequences.ambient_hazard: Occasional left-sock disappearances continue (it keeps 1 per visit as toll)

disperse_elemental.description: Unravel the Sock Elemental's component socks, dispersing the Warp-Static

consequences.ambient_hazard: 300 socks returned to owners, many deeply confused by the experience

description: Three hundred left socks have been stolen. Only left socks. Only during the 3 AM laundry shift. A mountain of wet hosiery in the steam-tunnels is moving, giggling, and—apparently—trying to make a friend.

turns.narrative: Head Laundress Dottie Grieve is a formidable woman who has managed the Laundry Ward for thirty years and has seen everything. She has not, she is clear, seen anything like this. She places 14 right-sock orphans on the table in front of you with the precision of a prosecutor presenting evidence. 'Three hundred left socks. Three weeks. Always the left. ALWAYS. The right socks remain! 'What use is a right sock without the left?' She has apparently asked the universe this question many times this week and received no satisfactory answer.
turns.choice_a: Examine the laundry vats for clues about how the socks are disappearing (Investigation DC 10)
turns.consequence_a: Success: The vats have faint discharge marks at their base—Warp-Static residue, in a pattern that tracks toward the drain grates. Something is pulling specific items through a Warp-Static gradient. Left socks specifically because they spin in a particular direction in the vats. (+1 Lore)
turns.choice_b: Conduct a stakeout of the 3 AM laundry shift (Stealth DC 11)
turns.consequence_b: Success: At exactly 3:04 AM, in the steam and sudsy air, something comes up through the drain—an appendage that is unmistakably made of socks, damp and knotted, that reaches into the vat and collects 11 left socks with the careful selectivity of a connoisseur. Then retreats. (+1 Progress)
turns.convergence: Damp left-sock footprints lead toward the steam-tunnel access grate. They are the footprints of something much larger than a sock, made entirely of socks. From somewhere below, there is a sound. It is, genuinely, a giggle.

turns.narrative: The steam-tunnels beneath the Laundry Ward are hot, humid passages of old copper piping that date back pre-Scourge. Rennick the Plumber acts as guide—he has worked these tunnels for twenty years and has opinions about everything, including, apparently, socks. 'I've been hearing it for a month,' he says, ducking under a low pipe. 'Giggling in the dark. I thought it was the apprentices. But apprentices don't giggle like that—that's a confused giggle. Like something that's worked out how to be amused but hasn't quite got the range.' The sock-prints on the wet floor are enormous. Whatever made them is the size of a cart-horse. Made entirely of socks.
turns.choice_a: Follow the prints carefully, making as little noise as possible (Stealth DC 10)
turns.consequence_a: Success: You round a pipe-junction and see it: a ten-foot-tall mound of interlocked, knotted left socks, faintly glowing violet with Warp-Static, slowly assembling what appears to be—with sock-mittened hands—a smaller figure of socks. It is building a companion. (+1 Observation, elemental unaware of you)
turns.choice_b: Call out to it—Rennick's assessment suggests it might not be hostile (Animal Handling DC 11)
turns.consequence_b: Success: Your voice echoes down the tunnel. The sock-mound freezes. Turns. Its 'face'—a loose arrangement of sock-toes—shifts into an expression you read, somehow, as embarrassed. It clutches its half-formed companion to its chest. (+1 Progress, elemental contact made)
turns.convergence: The Sock Elemental sees you. It does not attack. It does not flee. It extends one damp sock-hand toward you, palm up. In the palm, carefully arranged, is a single right sock. A peace offering. It wants to make friends and it knows, dimly, that you need the other half.

turns.narrative: The Sock Elemental's intelligence is difficult to assess. It does not speak. It communicates in squeaks, sock-rustles, and the expressivity of its loosely-assembled face. What you can determine: it is lonely. It became aware—coalesced from Warp-Static and accumulated sympathy for lost socks—somewhere around six weeks ago. Since then, it has been collecting left socks specifically because it decided left socks were the lonely ones (the right ones always have partners in the vats; left socks tumble more). It is building a companion from stolen socks. The companion is currently one arm and a head of dubious construction.
turns.choice_a: Try to communicate with the elemental through fabric manipulation (Fabric-Handling DC 12)
turns.consequence_a: Success: You take a sock from your pack and fold it carefully—no aggression, deliberate, gentle—into a shape. The Elemental watches with absolute focus, then copies you. You've established a language of sorts. Folded sock = yes. Balled sock = no. Dangling sock = question. (+1 Communication established)
turns.choice_b: Help it build the companion (Animal Handling DC 11, win trust through participation)
turns.consequence_b: Success: You sit down in the steam-tunnel and start knotting socks alongside the elemental. It watches, then adjusts your work with damp gentle hands. Rennick observes this with the equanimity of a man who has seen everything. 'You're helping a sock monster make a friend,' he says. 'Right. Sure.' (+1 Rapport)
turns.convergence: The half-built companion is beginning to take form: roughly humanoid, roughly sock-height (about three feet), and entirely made of stolen laundrywear. The elemental regards it with something like hope. Then looks at you. Dangle-sock: question. Can you help make this work?

turns.narrative: The core problem: the elemental's companion, assembled from 130 individual socks, is not coming alive. The elemental keeps adding socks and it keeps being a pile. The Warp-Static in the area is not sufficient to animate a second entity—it can barely sustain the first. The elemental has been trying to solve this for three weeks by collecting more socks. But quantity is not the issue. The issue is the Warp-Static source. Somewhere nearby is a Warp-Silk hotspot feeding the elemental. The companion needs to be placed at the hotspot to animate.
turns.choice_a: Locate the Warp-Static hotspot in the steam-tunnels (Arcana DC 13, feel for dimensional bleed)
turns.consequence_a: Success: Two junctions north, there is a pipe fitting that is distinctly wrong—original copper replaced at some point with a metal that is slightly translucent at certain angles. Warp-Silk pipe fitting, embedded in the tunnel infrastructure by someone with very odd priorities. (+1 Lore, hotspot located)
turns.choice_b: Ask Rennick to identify any 'weird pipes' from his maintenance experience
turns.consequence_b: 'Third junction left, the fitting that sounds hollow when you knock but has no hollow inside it. Always sounded wrong to me.' He finds the fitting in three minutes, because he has knocked on every pipe in these tunnels. (+1 Progress, faster route)
turns.convergence: The Warp-Silk fitting pulses gently when the sock-companion is placed against it. The elemental watches. You watch. Rennick takes a step back. Something stirs in the sock-pile.

turns.narrative: The sock-companion does not animate. But it tries. For about 30 seconds, the pile shivers and something resembling awareness flickers through it—a gesture, a tilt of the head made of sock-toes. Then it sits inert again. The Warp-Static is not strong enough. The elemental makes a sound you recognize from Turn 3's established language: a loose, trailing dangle. It does not know what to do. For just a moment, a ten-foot pile of sentient lost socks is heartbreaking. Then it does something surprising: it sits down next to the inert companion, tucks the half-formed figure under one enormous sock-arm, and simply... keeps it company. It is staying with someone who cannot yet respond.
turns.choice_a: Attempt to temporarily boost the Warp-Static from the fitting to animate the companion (Arcana DC 15, costs a Warp-Silk item if held, or costs -5 HP from Warp-sting)
turns.consequence_a: Success: The companion animates—briefly, incompletely—long enough to register the elemental's presence and make a small gesture before settling back. The elemental's reaction is complex: something like recognition. The companion cannot sustain, but it was real for a moment. The elemental folds it carefully. (+1 Lore, +3 Rapport)
turns.choice_b: Explain (via sock-language) that the companion might not be able to wake up, and offer yourself as a friend instead (Insight + Animal Handling DC 12)
turns.consequence_b: Success: This is, strangely, harder than combat. Via carefully arranged socks you communicate: 'This one cannot yet wake. But we know you are here. You are not alone.' The elemental considers this for a long time. Then it gives you a right sock. Correct partner for the orphaned left. (+2 Rapport)
turns.convergence: The elemental has reached a decision point. It can keep trying alone—keep stealing socks, keep trying to boost the companion—or it can engage with the world above. You have given it something: the knowledge that someone else knows it is there.

turns.narrative: The negotiation over what the Sock Elemental DOES now is genuinely novel territory. Dottie Grieve needs her socks back. The elemental has 300 of them and is not obviously willing to give them all up. Rennick suggests a 'sock tax'—keep some, return the rest—which is either the most pragmatic or most absurd negotiation framework you have ever employed. The elemental, when presented with this via sock-language, considers carefully, then holds up eight socks. Its 'toll' would be eight socks per week to continue its companionship project. You count the stolen socks. Eight per week is 24 over three weeks. It has 300. It has been hoarding against future need.
turns.choice_a: Accept the sock-tax arrangement (befriend path, Animal Handling DC 11 to formalize)
turns.consequence_a: Success: Dottie is presented with this proposal. She stares at you. She stares at the tunnel entrance. She stares at the ceiling. 'Eight socks a week,' she repeats. 'For a sock monster. That lives in our tunnels.' A very long pause. 'It returns all the others?' Yes. 'Fine. FINE. Eight socks a week.' Agreement reached. (+2 Settlement Morale eventually)
turns.choice_b: Gently begin unraveling the elemental (disperse path, Fabric-Handling DC 14, slow and respectful)
turns.consequence_b: Success: This takes 20 minutes and is surprisingly melancholy. The elemental does not resist—it seems to understand, somehow, that its presence is causing problems. As the last Warp-Static disperses, the socks collapse neatly. 300 left socks, returned. 2 are inexplicably right socks. Rennick pockets these without comment. (+1 Settlement Stability)
turns.convergence: Either resolution changes the Laundry Ward. If befriended: the elemental begins living openly in the steam-tunnels, known to regulars as 'Lefty.' If dispersed: the steam-tunnels are quiet in a way they weren't before, and seven sock-shaped Warp-Static echoes linger at the hotspot for weeks.

turns.narrative: The Warp-Silk pipe fitting still needs to be addressed regardless of the elemental's fate. It is an active Warp-Static source in a residential infrastructure system. Rennick has opinions: 'I can't just leave a Warp-pipe in my tunnels. Do you have any idea how many things I've had to unblock because of fabric misbehavior in the last month? Three hand-towels, a bath mat, and what I can only describe as a sentient mop.' He is absolutely correct. The fitting needs to come out.
turns.choice_a: Remove the Warp-Silk fitting carefully, preserving it intact (Fabric-Handling + Athletics DC 13)
turns.consequence_a: Success: The fitting unscrews, reluctantly. It is Warp-Silk woven around a copper core—the silk provides mechanical stability to the Warp-Static bleed, which would otherwise just leak randomly. Whoever put this here knew what they were doing. (+1 Lore, Warp-Silk Pipe Fitting obtained as rare item)
turns.choice_b: Have Rennick replace the fitting with standard copper while you stabilize the Warp-Static bleed (Arcana DC 12)
turns.consequence_b: Success: The Warp-Static dissipates over three hours as you channel it harmlessly into the stone walls where it goes quiet. Standard copper fitting in place. Tunnels return to normal. No more Warp-Static source in the residential plumbing. (+1 Settlement Stability)
turns.convergence: If Lefty the Sock Elemental is still present, it watches the fitting be removed with what reads as mild concern—it was its power source. Then it settles back, smaller than before but still coherent. It seems to have internalized enough Warp-Static to sustain independently. Just at a smaller scale. It is now roughly horse-sized instead of cart-horse-sized. Rennick considers this progress.

turns.narrative: Dottie Grieve receives the returned socks. All 300 of them (minus eight, if Lefty remained), cleaned, matched, and sorted by color, which the elemental apparently did overnight with meticulous care. Dottie spreads them across the sorting tables, finds every owner's mark, and begins the matching process with the right-sock orphans. 'They're all there,' she says, slowly. 'Every single one. Matched.' She pauses. 'It sorted them.' Another pause. 'It's tidier about laundry than my apprentices.' The apprentices, listening from across the room, say nothing.
turns.choice_a: Report the Warp-Silk pipe finding to the Mage Guild (major lore path)
turns.consequence_a: The Guild analyst examines the fitting with growing alarm: 'This was not installed accidentally. Warp-Silk does not occur in copper fittings naturally. Someone engineered this. Pre-Scourge craftsmanship. Someone ran Warp-Static deliberately through the Laundry Ward's plumbing.' A beat. 'Why?' (+2 Lore, deliberate Warp-Static infrastructure confirmed)
turns.choice_b: Return to the Laundry Ward and ask around about the building's construction history
turns.consequence_b: An elderly Ward resident, consulted about the building's age: 'Pre-Scourge, all of it. The plumbing hasn't been changed since. The original builders put in something they called Warp-conduit fittings. For what, nobody ever explained.' She shrugs. 'I assumed it was drainage.' (+1 Lore, historical Warp-conduit system confirmed)
turns.convergence: Quest Complete. The Sock Elemental was born from Warp-Static bleed in pre-built infrastructure and the accumulated laundry-sympathy of the Ward. It wanted companionship. The pre-Scourge builders put Warp-Static conduit deliberately through the residential plumbing. Nobody knows why. And Lefty, if befriended, is sitting in the steam-tunnels right now, carefully sorting socks by color for no particular reason except that it likes to.

conclusion: Three hundred stolen left socks were the symptom; a lonely Warp-Static elemental and a deliberately-engineered Warp-Silk plumbing system were the cause. The Laundry Ward has either gained a mascot or returned 300 socks to their owners. Either way, someone pre-Scourge ran Warp-Static conduit through the city's residential plumbing, and nobody has explained why.
loot_table: Warp-Silk Pipe Fitting (rare - pre-Scourge Warp-Static conduit component, connects to broader Laundry lore)
Lefty's Right-Sock Gift (a single right sock, inexplicably warm, +1 luck on one check per session) [befriend path]
300 Returned Left Socks (sorted, cleaned, ready for owners - Laundress Guild pays per sock): 150 Gold
Rennick's Tunnel Key (access to Lower Ward steam-tunnel network for future investigations)

risk_matrix.penalty: Sock Elemental panics and floods the Laundry Ward with 300 socks simultaneously. Steam-tunnel collapses under fabric pressure. -3 Settlement Stability, Laundry Ward closed for 1 session.
risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed quietly. The situation remains unresolved.

title: The Stitched-Memories

unlock_conditions.event_trigger: Grieving widow contacts the Watch after her late husband's quilt 'started talking' in his voice

location: Lower Ward - Widow Tessaly's home and Quilters' Guild Hall
key_npcs: Widow Tessaly Vorn (quest-giver, grieving but pragmatic)
Aldric Vorn (deceased, speaks via the memorial quilt)
permanent_effects: Player learns Warp-Silk retains emotional memories of its owners
Memory-Quilt network discovered (Quilters' Guild has been unwittingly using Warp-Silk thread for decades)

preserve_quilts.description: Recognize the quilts as genuine memory archives, establish a Memory-Quilt library

consequences.permanent_effect: Memory-Quilt Library established in Lower Ward - citizens can speak to deceased relatives via Warp-Silk quilt patches
consequences.lore_gain: Quilts reveal pre-Scourge memories including key Concordat information when queried correctly

neutralize_quilts.description: Bleach or contain the quilts, preventing further ghostly contact

consequences.ambient_hazard: Tessaly and other affected families are deeply upset. -1 Settlement Morale, +1 Stability.
consequences.lore_gain: Neutralized quilt threads analyzed by Guild reveal Warp-Silk memory retention mechanism

description: A memorial quilt is speaking in the deceased's voice. This should be impossible. It is not, apparently, unique—the Quilters' Guild uses thread from a supplier who has been selling Warp-Silk blend for fifteen years. Half the memorial quilts in the Lower Ward remember their owners.

turns.narrative: Widow Tessaly Vorn is a small, precise woman who opens her front door and says: 'Before you say anything, I know what I heard.' She leads you upstairs to a bedroom that smells of cedar and old wool. The quilt on the bed is a masterpiece of a different era—forty years of patches, each one Tessaly's addition after a significant family moment. In the center is a square of dark blue that was sewn by her husband the year they married. As you enter the room, the quilt says, in a clear, slightly echoey voice: 'The kettle's boiling.' Tessaly does not flinch. 'That's what he always said when he came downstairs. He never let the kettle sit.'
turns.choice_a: Study the quilt for Warp-Static properties without touching it (Arcana DC 12)
turns.consequence_a: Success: The blue central square is woven with Warp-Silk thread—subtle, but unmistakable under Arcana examination. The thread has retained emotional-memory imprints of everyone who regularly slept beneath this quilt. It is not haunted. It is a recording made of cloth. (+1 Lore)
turns.choice_b: Gently touch the blue center square and see what happens (Fabric-Handling DC 10, receptive approach)
turns.consequence_b: Success: The voice changes register when you touch it—no longer projecting into the room but speaking to you directly, as if through the fabric: 'You're not her.' A pause. 'The kettle is boiling.' A second register shift: 'Tell her I watched over her.' (+1 Connection established)
turns.convergence: Tessaly sits on the bed beside the quilt, her hand resting on the blue square. It says four more things her husband was known to say. She is not afraid. She is sad in the specific way of someone who has been given one more day of the thing they thought was over.

turns.narrative: The Quilters' Guild Hall is a building full of people who are having a very hard morning. Mistress Quell, the Guild head, meets you with the energy of someone managing a crisis she does not understand and finds personally offensive. Six Guild members have come forward in the last 24 hours with quilts that have begun speaking. The voices are consistent with the deceased owners of the remembered fabric patches. The Guild has been using thread from Supplier Merin for fifteen years. Merin's thread is Warp-Silk blend. Merin has known this. Merin is not currently available to comment because Merin has left the city.
turns.choice_a: Search the Quilters' Guild supply records to understand the Warp-Silk thread distribution (Investigation DC 12)
turns.consequence_a: Success: Merin's records show Warp-Silk blend thread sold to 43 quilts in the Lower Ward over 15 years. You compile a list of purchasers. Every memorial quilt made during this period potentially contains speaking fabric. (+1 Lore, full list obtained)
turns.choice_b: Interview the six affected Guild members about what their quilts are saying (Insight DC 11)
turns.consequence_b: Success: The voices are all low-level domestic memory: 'The cat gets fed twice a day,' 'Left sock on the right.' But one quilt—belonging to a former City Watch captain—has said something actionable: 'The vault under the Harbor Office has a second basement. Beneath the second basement.' This may be the most useful thing a quilt has ever said. (+1 Intel)
turns.convergence: Mistress Quell has a question she is having trouble framing: 'If these quilts are... remembering people. Are the people in them? And if we neutralize the quilts, are we...' She cannot finish the sentence. It is, as questions go, genuinely difficult.

turns.narrative: The question of what the quilts ARE philosophically needs a practical answer. You spend an hour testing the blue square from Tessaly's quilt with systematic questions: things only Aldric Vorn would know, things she knows are wrong to test for hallucination, and things she genuinely does not know the answer to. Results: the quilt knows accurate personal details (not guessable by Tessaly alone). The quilt does not know things it couldn't have known (not omniscient). It doesn't add new information about events after death. It is memory. It is Aldric Vorn's memories of their life together, preserved in thread. Not a ghost. An echo.
turns.choice_a: Systematically interview the blue square about anything of investigative value (Investigation DC 13)
turns.consequence_a: Success: Aldric was a merchant. He shipped goods through a specific Harbor connection. Through careful questioning, the quilt reveals: 'The third warehouse at the North Pier, there are crates that were never registered with the customs office.' Living intelligence from a dead man. (+2 Intel, actionable Harbor data)
turns.choice_b: Let Tessaly have time alone with the quilt while you investigate the Warp-Silk mechanism (Arcana DC 14)
turns.consequence_b: Success: The memory-retention works through emotional imprinting during sleep—the quilt absorbed years of subconscious memory projection from everyone who slept beneath it regularly. Warp-Silk doesn't just animate: it records. (+2 Lore, memory mechanism fully understood)
turns.convergence: Tessaly emerges after 20 minutes. Her eyes are red. She says: 'He said to stop blaming myself for the argument in March.' She holds the quilt tightly for a moment. 'How long does it last?' You estimate: as long as the Warp-Silk threads hold. Decades, possibly. 'Good,' she says.

turns.narrative: The Watch Captain's quilt is the concerning one. Its memories include references to a second Harbor vault basement—unknown to the current Watch leadership. And something else: when you sit with this quilt and ask careful questions, the Captain's voice eventually says, in a different tone than his domestic memories: 'The Concordat used quilts. Before the Scourge. For courier messages too sensitive for paper. They'd weave the message into Warp-Silk panels and deliver the quilt to the recipient. Only someone who knew the right questions could read them.' The quilt has just told you that Concordat memory-fabric is a historical espionage technology. And there are 43 of them in the Lower Ward.
turns.choice_a: Query every accessible memorial quilt for Concordat-era information (systematic Intelligence sweep, 3 hours)
turns.consequence_a: Success: Of the 43 quilts, 6 contain pre-Scourge memories from people old enough—or connected enough—to have Concordat-era knowledge. You extract: three safe-house locations, a partial map of Concordat maintenance tunnels (cross-references Vermin thread data), and a name that appears twice: 'Dr. Aldric Vane.' (+3 Lore, major cross-thread connection)
turns.choice_b: Focus only on the Captain's quilt: it seems to have the most operationally useful content
turns.consequence_b: In 90 minutes of careful questioning, the Captain's quilt yields: the Harbor basement, a name ('Vane'), and one final detail: 'The quilts were supposed to be burned after receipt. None of us burned ours.' (+1 Lore, Vane cross-thread mention)
turns.convergence: The name 'Vane' appears in pre-Scourge memory-quilts. Not Doctor Vane as a title, but as a person known personally to pre-Scourge citizens who were alive when the Concordat was still active. This confirm Vane existed before the Scourge. An echo of a 200-year-old memory is naming the person currently commanding the Copper-Tails.

turns.narrative: The Warp-Silk supplier Merin needs to be found. His records show the Warp-Silk blend thread came from a single bolt, purchased 15 years ago from an estate sale of antique textile stock. The estate was that of a deceased fabric merchant whose family had held the bolt for five generations. Where the original bolt came from: a pre-Scourge estate sale. The Warp-Silk in every memorial quilt is 200-year-old Concordat-era thread that has been passing through the secondhand market for generations. Merin is scared because he recognized what it was only when the quilts started talking—and he bolted. He is hiding in the Dye District. The Watch has him.
turns.choice_a: Interview Merin about the Warp-Silk bolt's full provenance (Persuasion DC 12, he is terrified)
turns.consequence_a: Success: Merin is a small frightened man who says: 'I didn't know it did THAT. I just knew the thread was unusually high quality. I never told anyone it was blend because nobody asks.' He produces the original purchase receipt: 'Lot 47, Estate of House Vael, textile stock.' House Vael: a Concordat-era noble family. (+1 Lore)
turns.choice_b: Search Merin's warehouse for the remnant Warp-Silk bolt (Investigation DC 13)
turns.consequence_b: Success: 3 yards remaining. Still on the original spool, which is stamped: 'CONCORDAT DIVISION TWO - COMMUNICATIONS APPLICATIONS.' This was not accidental Warp-Silk leaking into the market. This was a Concordat communications material cache that survived 200 years of estate sales. (+2 Lore, Concordat memory-fabric origin confirmed)
turns.convergence: Either route confirms: the quilts are made of Concordat espionage material that has been passively recording the domestic memories of Lower Ward families for 15 years, while also containing older pre-Scourge intelligence in the deepest memory layers. The Guild is sitting on a 200-year-old archive.

turns.narrative: Mistress Quell has made a decision while you've been investigating: she called a Guild meeting and the vote is 11-4 to preserve the quilts and establish them as a community resource. The four against want the quilts neutralized for 'dignity of the deceased.' The eleven in favor point out that several Guild members have had farewell conversations they never had the chance to have. The decision feels irreversible. Then a quilt in the corner of the meeting room says, in an old woman's voice, completely without context: 'The rats under the city are not rats.' The whole room goes quiet.
turns.choice_a: Question the quilt about the rats (immediate priority, Fabric-Handling DC 12, be gentle)
turns.consequence_a: Success: It takes 20 minutes of careful fabric-communication. The old woman's memory knew the Concordat. 'Division Seven made the vermin. Division Two made the quilts. They were not supposed to interact. Vane—Aldric Vane—was in Division Seven. He was young.' She remembers him as 25 at most. In 200 years, he has become something that makes direct contact via Squeaker-Box. (+3 Lore, massive cross-thread Vane revelation)
turns.choice_b: Note the comment, continue establishing Memory-Quilt library protocol (focus on quest resolution)
turns.consequence_b: The comment is logged. The Mage Guild is notified. Someone else will follow up. The Memory-Quilt library establishment continues. (+1 Settlement Morale, Vane intel deferred)
turns.convergence: The Memory-Quilt library is established in the Guild Hall. Citizens can book appointments to speak with quilts containing their relatives. The Guild charges a modest fee. Tessaly is made honorary curator. And somewhere in the oldest quilts, in the deepest Warp-Silk memory layers, pre-Scourge voices are waiting for the right questions.

turns.narrative: The remaining Concordat Warp-Silk thread spool needs to be secured. Three yards of pre-Scourge Concordat communications material cannot simply sit in Merin's warehouse. The Mage Guild wants it. The Watch wants it. Tessaly Vorn wants one more yard of it—enough for a small memorial for a friend who died last year without a proper quilt. You have to decide who gets the material and in what quantity.
turns.choice_a: Give the spool entirely to the Mage Guild for research and controlled distribution
turns.consequence_a: The Guild archives it carefully. They will use it for targeted Memory-Quilt creation: intentional, researched, documented. The emotional-memory technology becomes a formal Guild specialty. (+1 Lore, controlled Warp-Silk distribution)
turns.choice_b: Distribute it equitably: Tessaly gets a yard, Guild gets a yard, Mage Guild gets a yard
turns.consequence_b: Three institutions, three projects. Tessaly's friend gets a memorial. The Guild continues their library. The Mage Guild studies the mechanism. The Warp-Silk is used meaningfully by people who needed it. (+2 Settlement Morale)
turns.convergence: Merin is charged with selling an unregistered magical material but given a suspended sentence in recognition that he didn't know what it did. He is now, bizarrely, the city's leading expert in Warp-Silk thread identification by touch—a skill no one else has. The Watch puts him on informal retainer.

turns.narrative: Final visit to Widow Tessaly. The blue square of her quilt has been speaking less frequently since the Guild established the library—perhaps the Warp-Static is distributed now, the emotional resonance spread across many quilts rather than concentrated in one. When you arrive, the quilt says: 'You've been looking into something. Don't stop.' Tessaly looks at you. 'He was always like that. Noticing things from the edges.' She touches the blue square. The quilt adds: 'The rats, the cloth, the glass city—it's the same thing underneath. You'll see.' Then it is quiet.
turns.choice_a: Sit with Tessaly and ask the quilt everything you can about what Aldric saw (Insight DC 14)
turns.consequence_a: Success: The quilt yields its last organized memory on the topic: 'Aldric heard a presentation at a Merchant's Council meeting, 35 years ago. A man said: everything in the city is infrastructure. The fabric, the wiring, the ice. All of it channels something toward a center. Not outward. Inward.' The presenter's name was not given. Aldric agreed with him. (+2 Lore, grand unified thread hint)
turns.choice_b: Let Tessaly have a quiet last conversation with the quilt's remaining active memory
turns.consequence_b: You wait outside. Twenty minutes later, Tessaly opens the door. 'He only had one regret,' she says. 'He never went to see what's north of the pass.' She pauses. 'Neither did I.' (+2 Settlement Morale - Tessaly's arc completed)
turns.convergence: Quest Complete. The memorial quilts of the Lower Ward are archives, conversation partners, and now intelligence assets. The Concordat built Warp-Silk for espionage, and two centuries later it is giving grief support to a widow and confounding a city investigator with the suggestion that every weird thing happening in EmberHeart points to the same center. The kettle is still boiling.

conclusion: Memorial quilts made with Concordat-era Warp-Silk thread retain the memories of their owners—including pre-Scourge knowledge about the Concordat itself. The quilts have named Aldric Vane as a young man in Division Seven 200 years ago, cross-confirming the Vermin thread. The Memory-Quilt Library is established. And an old merchant's half-remembered memory suggests the Fabric thread, the Vermin thread, and the Chronos thread may all be infrastructure pointing toward the same unknown center.
loot_table: Concordat Warp-Silk Thread Spool (1 yard - memory-retention material, can create custom memory-quilts)
Memory-Quilt Library Pass (access to all Lower Ward memorial quilts for Intelligence queries)
Aldric Vorn's Harbor Intelligence (location of unregistered warehouse, actionable side content)

risk_matrix.penalty: Memory-Quilts begin broadcasting indiscriminately throughout the Lower Ward. Citizens hear the voices of dead relatives in the street without warning. -4 Settlement Morale, 1 session of community psychological crisis.
risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed quietly. The situation remains unresolved.

title: The Fabric-Eater Moths

unlock_conditions.event_trigger: High-end clothing merchants in Market Ward report enchanted garments dissolving overnight, leaving only buttons

location: Market Ward - Silk Promenade boutiques and warehouse district
key_npcs: Merchant Brio Fenn (quest-giver, expensive taste, considerable losses)
The Fabric-Eater Moths (swarm, eerie intelligence, dissolve enchanted clothing)
Warden Artificer Soli Yan (enchantment inspector, alarmed about enchantment dissolution mechanism)
permanent_effects: Player learns Fabric-Eater Moths are Warp-Static byproduct, dissolve enchantments into raw mana
Mana-collection from moth activity discovered (they are farming enchanted fabric)

destroy_colony.description: Burn or disperse the moth colony and its nest

consequences.lore_gain: Moth nest contains raw collected mana in crystallized form - significant energy resource

relocate_colony.description: Relocate moths to an area with non-enchanted fabric, where they act as harmless fabric-eaters

consequences.permanent_effect: Colony in Lower Ward midden eats waste fabric, keeping area cleaner
consequences.ambient_hazard: Enchanted items near midden slowly degrade if left too long

description: Enchanted silk coats, charmed gloves, and mana-stitched gowns are dissolving overnight in the Market Ward's high-end boutiques. The moths responsible are not eating the fabric—they are extracting the enchantments, leaving raw, non-magical thread behind. Something very strange is farming mana from expensive clothing.

turns.narrative: Merchant Brio Fenn holds up what was, yesterday, a mana-stitched coat from the far coast worth 200 Gold. What remains is a perfectly arranged pile of non-magical thread and twelve buttons, placed in a neat row. The thread is unharmed. The enchantment is simply gone—extracted clean. 'This is the SECOND one this week,' he says. 'And it happened to the Marchioness's gown at the boutique next door. That was 800 Gold. She is not pleased. Nobody is pleased with me, specifically, for reasons I cannot completely explain.' Three empty hangers hang behind him, rotating slightly in a draft that shouldn't be there.
turns.choice_a: Examine the remaining thread for traces of the extraction process (Arcana DC 11)
turns.consequence_a: Success: The thread is clean—cleaner than it would be from normal fabric dissolution. The enchantment was removed with precision, leaving structural fiber intact. This was not mindless eating. Something extracted the mana selectively, like a skilled artificer deconstructing a spell. (+1 Lore)
turns.choice_b: Search the boutique for signs of how entry was gained (Investigation DC 10)
turns.consequence_b: Success: Moth-dust on the window sill—fine, iridescent powder that glows faintly violet. Warp-Static signature. The entry point: a gap in the window frame barely a finger wide, through which nothing living should have been able to pass. Unless it was phasing. (+1 Progress)
turns.convergence: Warden Artificer Soli Yan arrives with a spectroscope and tests the moth-dust. 'Warp-Static residue,' she says, 'combined with extracted enchantment mana.' She looks up. 'Something is dissolving enchantments and taking the mana somewhere. The moths are the mechanism. The question is: what needs this much mana, and why is it in the Market Ward boutiques?'

turns.narrative: The moth-dust trail is visible under Yan's spectroscope: a faint path of iridescent powder leading along the Silk Promenade, turning into an alley, going through a grate. You follow it for two blocks before the grate becomes a warehouse access door that has been used recently despite being listed as vacant in the city register. The warehouse smells of mana—the specific ozone-and-sweetgrass scent of pure extracted enchantment energy, three times stronger than any enchanted item you've been near. From inside: the soft, pervasive sound of a million small wings.
turns.choice_a: Enter the warehouse carefully and observe before engaging (Stealth DC 12)
turns.consequence_a: Success: The interior is extraordinary. The moth colony covers every surface—thousands of Fabric-Eater Moths, each about the size of a thumb, with wings that shift through colors in the Warp-Static spectrum. In the center of the colony, a mound of crystallized mana the size of a barrel, still growing. They are farming it. This is a mana-production operation. (+1 Lore)
turns.choice_b: Toss a non-enchanted piece of fabric through the door ahead of you to test the moths' response
turns.consequence_b: The fabric lands inside. Thirty moths descend on it immediately, taste it, and fly off uninterested. Non-enchanted fabric: irrelevant to them. Then you try a small enchanted button from Fenn's collection. It is stripped bare in 12 seconds. The moths are selective. (+1 Observation)
turns.convergence: The moth colony is organized. Outer-ring moths seem to be scouts. Inner-ring moths are producers, sitting on the mana-crystal and apparently feeding directly from it. The queen—if there is one—is in the center, very large, very still, wings spread flat over the crystal. This is not an infestation. This is a factory.

turns.narrative: The Queen Fabric-Eater is roughly the size of a large cat, with wings that display a full Warp-Static shimmer—every color simultaneously, resolving to nothing when you look directly at it. It is not moving. It has been here long enough to become part of the crystal, its legs embedded at the base. It is not alive in any conventional sense. It is a Warp-Static mana-collection organ that evolved—or was designed—to use moths as the harvest mechanism. The colony is its body. The moths are its cells. And you are now standing inside it.
turns.choice_a: Approach the Queen directly to examine the mana-crystal (Fabric-Handling DC 13, treat as living fabric)
turns.consequence_a: Success: At close range, the Queen's wings pulse against your approach. Not attacking—registering. The crystal beneath her emits a deep resonant hum. You estimate: 400 units of raw mana, equivalent to 40 premium enchantments. Someone has been building this for months. (+1 Lore, mana quantity assessed)
turns.choice_b: Set up an observation post in the warehouse and watch the colony's daily cycle (Investigation DC 12, 2 hours)
turns.consequence_b: Success: The moths sleep from dawn to noon. Active 12 hours, collecting. At 3 AM, a subset of the colony leaves the warehouse with crystallized mana fragments. They are delivering something. You follow one: it goes to a drain in the Laundry Ward. The steam-tunnel network. The mana is going into the infrastructure. (+2 Lore, mana-delivery route discovered)
turns.convergence: If the mana deliveries go into the steam-tunnel network, they connect to the Warp-Silk plumbing discovered in EH_SQ_091. The moths are farming enchantment mana and feeding it into the city's Warp-Static infrastructure. Someone is using moths and plumbing to maintain and grow the Warp-Static network.

turns.narrative: Yan confirms the worst: 'The mana deliveries to the tunnels are boosting the Warp-Static field throughout the residential plumbing. Every Warp-Silk pipe fitting, every Warp-Static event in the Laundry Ward—it's being powered. Maintained. By moth-harvested enchantment mana from boutique clothing.' She sets her spectroscope down. 'Someone is running an ecosystem. Warp-Silk infrastructure as the hardware. Fabric-Eater Moths as the power supply. They're farming mana from the city's richest district and pumping it into the poorest district's spooky plumbing.' She pauses. 'We are in a very weird city.'
turns.choice_a: Cut off the mana-delivery routes by sealing the steam-tunnel drain access (Arcana DC 13)
turns.consequence_a: Success: Three drain points sealed. Mana deliveries interrupted. The Warp-Static field in the Laundry Ward dims noticeably—animated fabrics in the area go inert for 24 hours before stabilizing at a lower level. The moth colony without a delivery mechanism becomes overloaded with mana. Signs of instability at the warehouse increase. (+1 Progress, partial infrastructure disruption)
turns.choice_b: Trace the delivery routes to find out exactly where the mana ultimately goes (Investigation DC 14)
turns.consequence_b: Success: The mana routes converge at a single point deep in the Laundry Ward's sub-basement: a Warp-Silk weaving frame, old, enormous, working slowly, weaving something—a fabric, room-sized, that has been growing for years. It is not finished. (+2 Lore, massive discovery, connects to potential thread climax)
turns.convergence: The moth ecosystem is not self-directed. Something set it up. The moths didn't evolve this. The Queen is not a natural creature. It is a Concordat mana-harvesting organ, placed here, left running. Like the rats. Like the plumbing. All of it infrastructure. All of it pointing inward.

turns.narrative: The moth colony combat is unavoidable at some stage—either because a scout registers threat and the colony responds, or because you need to reach the Queen to end the harvest. A Fabric-Eater moth swarm is not individually dangerous—each moth is thumb-sized. As a swarm moving in coordinated Warp-Static patterns, they have a collective attack: they attempt to strip enchantments from everything you wear or carry, leaving non-magical equipment untouched but potentially disabling magical items and armor enchantments.
turns.choice_a: Remove all enchanted equipment before engaging (prevents stripping, reduces combat power)
turns.consequence_a: Fighting in mundane equipment, you are less effective but immune to the swarm's primary attack. The moths disperse from physical strikes and fire easily—they are individually fragile. Swarm depleted in 5 minutes. Queen exposed. (+1 Progress, smart approach)
turns.choice_b: Engage with enchanted equipment and take the stripping risk (Combat DC 14, protective gear recommended)
turns.consequence_b: Three enchantments stripped from your equipment during the fight: two minor, one moderate. The stripped enchantments feed the crystal. But the physical assault on the swarm is effective. The colony is disrupting, the Queen stirring. (+1 Combat Progress, some equipment temporarily non-magical)
turns.convergence: The Queen is now mobile—the mana-crystal disruption has freed her legs from the crystal base. She is not fighting. She is trying to protect the crystal. You have one decision: what happens to the crystal and the colony?

turns.narrative: The Queen regards you with wings spread—a display, not an attack. The mana-crystal behind her contains months of harvested enchantments. The stripped enchantments from your gear are already integrating into the crystal's matrix. The colony has gone into a defensive cluster rather than a swarm-attack formation. The Queen makes a sound—not moth sound, something deeper—that the air carries as a feeling rather than a noise: reluctance. She does not want to fight. She also will not simply abandon the crystal she has been tending for what seems like years.
turns.choice_a: Destroy the mana-crystal and scatter the colony (disperse path—fire works, Arcana DC 12)
turns.consequence_a: Success: The crystal shatters in a spectacular mana-release, briefly illuminating the warehouse in every color simultaneously. The colony disperses through every gap and crack in the building. The Queen goes with them—surviving, homeless, probably reforming elsewhere eventually. 400 units of raw mana are gone. (+1 Settlement Stability, but mana lost)
turns.choice_b: Relocate the Queen and crystal to the Lower Ward midden—non-enchanted fabric, harmless operation (Fabric-Handling DC 14)
turns.consequence_b: Success: This requires carefully moving a cat-sized magical entity and a barrel of crystallized mana through the city streets in a borrowed cart, which draws significant attention. But the Queen settles in the midden. Non-enchanted wastecloth: available endlessly, harmless. Colony follows. Boutique theft ends. Midden gets cleaner. (+1 Settlement Morale, practical resolution)
turns.convergence: Merchant Fenn is pleased the thefts have stopped. Less pleased to learn his coats powered a Concordat-era mana-harvesting ecosystem. He asks if he can submit an insurance claim against 'pre-Scourge bio-mechanical infrastructure.' You suggest no.

turns.narrative: Yan's analysis of the mana-crystal (if preserved or partially recovered from the scatter) yields extraordinary data: the enchantments within it are not blended together. Each one is discrete, layered, identifiable. She can read what was originally enchanted: a flame-ward, a water-repellent charm, a small speed enhancement, twelve warmth spells. 'These are ordinary clothing enchantments,' she says. 'But in this concentration and crystalline form, they could be re-cast as wholly different spells.' She looks at you. 'Someone could use this as raw mana stock for anything.' The moths were, effectively, a free enchantment refinery.
turns.choice_a: Recover the mana-crystal remnants and use them for city infrastructure repair (practical use)
turns.consequence_a: The recovered fragments power two weeks of Warden repairs throughout the Market Ward—every small fix that needed mana but lacked budget. Efficient, if morally complex. (+1 Settlement Stability, clear civic benefit)
turns.choice_b: Archive the mana-crystal as evidence and give it to the Mage Guild entirely
turns.consequence_b: The Guild's energy division is very interested. 'If moths can selectively extract enchantment mana this cleanly, the mechanism could be studied and replicated artificially.' A Research Grant is offered. Yan is excited. (+2 Lore, mana-extraction research program begins)
turns.convergence: Yan files her official report: 'Fabric-Eater Moth colony operating as Concordat-era enchantment-mana harvesting system. Infrastructure integration confirmed. Medical/magical hazard: moderate. Property damage: significant to boutique district. Conclusion: the Concordat left behind a city full of things still running their last instructions.' She hands you your copy of the report and adds: 'I am going to take a week off after this.'

turns.narrative: The boutique district recovers quickly—no enchanted items have been lost in the week since the colony's removal or dispersal, and Fenn has grudgingly filed a city-damage claim. The steam-tunnel Warp-Static field has stabilized at a lower level without the moth mana-supply. Several Laundry Ward fabric events that were sustained by the extra energy have resolved on their own—three animated curtains, a living tablecloth, and a sock elemental in Junction 14 that just... sat down and stopped moving. Two things remain: the Warp-Silk weaving frame in the sub-basement (if discovered), and the question of what it was weaving.
turns.choice_a: Return to the sub-basement to examine the massive partially-woven fabric
turns.consequence_a: The weaving frame holds a fabric 15 feet wide and 40 feet long, still incomplete. The pattern woven into it is not decorative: it is functional geometry—the same type of pattern as the Shadow-Rat summoning circle from EH_SQ_071, but far larger. Yan stares at it. 'This is a probability restructuring field. Room-sized. This would affect every probability calculation in a large area.' A pause. 'What's above this sub-basement?' The Laundry Ward. 'And the moths were feeding the mana to power this weaving.' (+3 Lore, grand-scale Concordat fabric weapon discovered)
turns.choice_b: File the sub-basement location with the Mage Guild and close the case
turns.consequence_b: The Guild seals the sub-basement. Designated Concordat Archaeological Site. Future study ongoing. You receive your finder's fee. The mystery of what was being woven waits. (+1 Lore deferred, future content seeded)
turns.convergence: Quest Complete. Fabric-Eater Moths were a Concordat mana-harvesting system, feeding power to Warp-Static infrastructure throughout the Laundry Ward—and apparently toward a large-scale probability-manipulation fabric in a sub-basement. The boutique merchants will not be pleased when you explain their expensive clothing was being used to power a pre-Scourge weapon.

conclusion: The Fabric-Eater Moths are a Concordat mana-harvesting system farming enchanted clothing from the Market Ward to power Warp-Static infrastructure in the Laundry Ward. The infrastructure appears to include a massive partially-woven probability-manipulation field in a sub-basement. The Concordat left the city full of systems still running, and those systems are interconnected in ways that are becoming clearer with each investigation.
loot_table: Mana-Crystal Fragments (raw enchantment mana, 200 units recoverable if colony dispersed)
Queen Fabric-Eater Specimen (rare - intact, for research, worth significant Gold to Mage Guild)
Yan's Enchantment-Stripping Analysis (technical document on moth mana-extraction mechanism)
Boutique Owner Compensation (from Warden crisis fund): 320 Gold

risk_matrix.penalty: Moth colony goes into full expansion mode. All enchanted items in Market Ward targeted systematically. -500 Gold value from city merchant losses per session. -3 Settlement Morale.
risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed quietly. The situation remains unresolved.

title: The Living-Carpet

unlock_conditions.event_trigger: Three residents of the same building found unconscious with carpet-fiber impressions on their faces; one hospitalized

location: Lower Ward - Apartment Building 'The Veln Arms' and surrounding district
key_npcs: Landlord Prest Onn (alarmed, trying to evict a carpet)
Tenants of The Veln Arms (3 hospitalized, rest terrified)
The Living-Carpet (Warp-Silk entity, ancient, confused, suffocating people accidentally)
mechanics_featured: Fabric-Handling checks (critical - rough handling triggers attack)
Combat or Persuasion (carpet can be reasoned with at cost)
permanent_effects: Player learns Warp-Silk absorbs consciousness impressions from long-term sleepers
Living-Carpet revealed as attempting to comfort people, not harm them
Pre-Scourge Veln Arms identified as Concordat building

relocate_carpet.description: Understand the carpet means no harm; relocate it to an uninhabited space

consequences.permanent_effect: Living-Carpet in Lower Ward storage room; can be 'consulted' as it holds 150 years of Warp-Silk consciousness impressions

destroy_carpet.description: Unravel or burn the carpet, ending the hazard

consequences.lore_gain: Carpet fiber analysis yields 150 years of absorbed consciousness impressions - significant Warp-Silk memory data
