title: The Unweaving
location: Market Ward -> Ley-Line Nexus -> The Great Loom

allow_unweaving.description: Allowed the Unweaving of the Scourge.

consequences.permanent_world_change: Scourge removed from history. All humans become emotionless automatons. Perfect city stability, empty existence.

defend_weave.description: Defended the Weave, keeping the Scourge in history.

consequences.permanent_world_change: Humanity keeps emotions, both good and bad. 'Acceptance' philosophical path unlocked.

selective_unweaving.description: Removed only the worst Scourge trauma, preserving positive emotions.

consequences.permanent_world_change: Balanced outcome. Reduced trauma, preserved humanity. World becomes slightly brighter.

become_threadkeeper.description: Took control of The Great Loom to become the new Threadkeeper.

consequences.permanent_world_change: Gained power to 'edit' reality's fabric. Can alter quest outcomes retroactively. Weaver cult serves you.

loot_table: Weaver's Crown (Artifact - rewrite one narrative event per session)
Reality Scissors (Legendary weapon - can 'cut' magic effects)
Thread of Infinite Possibilities (can create minor items from nothing)
Threadkeeper's Robes (Legendary armor - immunity to reality manipulation)

turns.narrative: It starts with a visual glitch. A baker in the Market Ward drops a loaf of bread, but it hangs in mid-air for three seconds. Then, a building nearby flickers out of existence, replaced by open fields, then snaps back. The Weaver Cult's endgame has commenced.

You realize what you learned during 'The Vintner's Ascension': The Scourge wasn't a physical blast, it was a psychic shockwave of grief that froze civilization. If the Weavers 'unweave' the Scourge from reality, they are literally attempting to unweave human emotion from existence.

You track the reality-glitches to the Ley-Line Nexus beneath the city center. Here, the Weaver Cult has established an 'Unweaving Zone.' Physics are suggestions. Gravity periodically reverses. You must navigate jumping up to the ceiling and back down to progress.

Cultists in the zone aren't attacking you physically; they are trying to snip your history. If a cultist strikes you with their Reality Shears, your character forgets a skill temporarily. You must fight them carefully from a distance.

You reach the Nexus epicenter. A massive tear in the fabric of space hangs in the air, glowing with threads of brilliant white memory. The Cultists throw themselves into it willingly, sacrificing their souls to widen the gap. You step through.

You emerge into the dimensional space between reality layers. There is no floor, only a massive web of glowing timelines. Dozens of shadowy figures stitched together from disparate moments fall upon you.

BOSS 1: Stitch-Wraith Legion. Twenty wraiths attack simultaneously. They are connected by invisible threads. If you attack one randomly, it absorbs little damage. You must find the 'Anchor Wraith' (the one pulling the strings) and kill it to instantly destroy five at once.

You systematically sever the Anchor Wraiths. The entire legion bursts into loose threads. The path forward across the timeline web is clear, though stepping on certain threads shows you visions of alternate Emberhearts where different factions won.

You arrive at the edge of 'The Great Loom.' It is an unfathomably colossal machine of golden light, weaving and unweaving the strands of the universe. Standing at its controls is the Threadkeeper, the true leader of the cult.

The Threadkeeper speaks: 'Look what you've survived. Look at the trauma. Look at the grief woven into this city's foundation. We can cut it out. A painless world. A perfect geometric existence. Join me in the great unraveling!'
You refuse, revealing that erasing grief erases love, joy, and humanity itself. The Threadkeeper sneers. 'You cling to your pain like a sick dog to its bone. I will cut it out of you personally!'

BOSS 2: The Threadkeeper. He is highly evasive, teleporting along the threads. More dangerously, he attacks your character sheet directly. His 'Unweave' ability can temporarily disable one of your equipped items or passive skills mid-fight.
You adapt to fighting without your disabled gear, closing the distance on the Threadkeeper. You must use the Shard of True-Memory to 'harden' reality around him, preventing his teleportation.

Pinned down by the Shard, the Threadkeeper fights desperately. He summons localized time-loops to force you to repeat your misses. You break through the loops using the Cup of Infinite Summers to retain your combat momentum.

You deliver a fatal strike. The Threadkeeper falls back into the gears of The Great Loom. 'It's too late,' he gurgles as he is crushed by his own machine. 'The Unweaving program is locked in. The machine will do it automatically.'

The Great Loom shudders. The entire pocket dimension begins to vibrate. Massive spools of white, glowing thread—the Scourge trauma—begin to unravel from the main tapestry of human history. The machine is sentient, and it is executing its final command.

BOSS 3: The Great Loom Itself. It is a puzzle boss. The machine attacks with massive environmental hazards: sweeping loom-arms that crush everything in their path, and reality-shears that instantly kill if they close around you.

You must navigate the hazardous moving parts of the machine to reach the three primary control spindles. Each spindle is guarded by an elemental manifestation of 'Apathy'—the emotionless state the machine seeks to create.

You defeat the Apathy elementals and lock the three spindles using your Weaver's Final Thread item. The Loom grinds to a halt. The unweaving process pauses halfway. The unraveled threads hang in the air.

You approach the central command pedestal. The interface is intuitive, connecting directly to your consciousness. You feel the weight of every human emotion, past, present, and future, resting on your decision.

You must make your choice (Allow Unweaving, Defend the Weave, Selective Unweaving, Become Threadkeeper). The Loom awaits your final input. If you choose selectively, you must pass intense Arcana checks to avoid catastrophic error.

You input the command. The Great Loom groans. The threads of reality either snap violently, glowing brightly in their repair, or shift into a new, permanent pattern under your control. The pocket dimension begins to dissolve as the new reality solidifies.

You reappear in the Market Ward. The visual glitches are gone. People are either laughing and crying as they should, staring blankly with cold eyes, or moving with a new lightness of being. You hold the shears of reality in your hands.

description: The Weaver Cult has initiated the Unweaving Protocol, attempting to surgically remove human emotion from reality to end the suffering caused by the Scourge.
conclusion: Allowed the Unweaving of the Scourge.

risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed catastrophically. City-wide consequences will be felt for weeks.

title: The Vintner's Ascension
location: Scourge-Fringe Vineyard -> Lower Ward sewers -> Market Ward central fountain

allow_release.description: Allowed 'Final Summer' release into water supply

consequences.permanent_world_change: Monthly 'Remembrance Day' event added. Citizens can access ancestor memories.

destroy_vintage.description: Destroyed the vintage and killed the Vintner

consequences.permanent_world_change: Void-Wine becomes strictly contraband. Underground trade war begins.

compromise_therapy.description: Convinced Vintner to create individual-dose therapy vintage

consequences.permanent_world_change: Players can purchase memory vials to learn specific skills. Memory Therapy Clinic built.

loot_table: Void-Soaked Robes (Legendary armor - resistance to psychic damage)
Grief-Crystallizer (Artifact crafting tool - turn emotions into material components)
The Final Recipe (document revealing Void-Wine is reverse-engineered from Scourge weapon)

turns.narrative: A ragged courier finds you in the Lower Ward, his tongue stained deep purple. He thrusts a crumpled note into your hand before collapsing. The note is in the Vintner's handwriting: 'It is done. The Final Summer is bottled. I see the Scourge as it really was. I see everything. Come to the Vineyard tonight, or miss the end of ignorance.' You gather your gear. The Void-Vineyard in the Scourge-Fringe awaits.

You reach the Scourge-Fringe border at dusk. The quarantine guards are unconscious, purple stains on their lips. The path to the Vineyard, usually crawling with corrupted wildlife, is eerily silent. The air smells powerfully of crushed grapes and ozone. You feel a strange psychic pressure, as if thousands of people are whispering just out of earshot.

Entering the Void-Vineyard proper, you see the vines themselves have changed. The grapes are no longer black, but a luminous, pulsing violet. Touching a leaf (Constitution DC 14) sends a flash of memory through your mind: a man in a pre-Scourge city, watching a sky turn white. The plants are absorbing memories from the soil.

You reach the Vintner's chateau. The doors are blown off their hinges. Inside, the massive fermentation vats are cracked open, empty. A journal on the desk details the perfection of 'The Final Summer' - a vintage capable of restoring pre-Scourge memories to an entire city. But the final ingredient was raw, crystallized grief.

Scrawled on the wall in wine is his plan: 'The city must drink. Only by sharing the grief of the Scourge can we remember what we lost.' He intends to pour the master cask into the Market Ward's central fountain, treating the city's entire water supply. You must stop him, or help him.

As you turn to leave the chateau, the spilled wine on the floor begins to coalesce. The vines from outside slither through the broken doors, binding the psychic residue into physical forms. Three Void-Grape Golems rise to block your exit. BOSS ENCOUNTER 1 BEGINS.

BOSS 1: The Void-Grape Golems fight with brute strength and psychic backlash. Every time you strike them, you must make a Wisdom save or lose your next action to a hallucination of pre-Scourge tragedy. You focus fire on their central cores—fermentation stones—and shatter them one by one. The golems collapse into puddles of foul-smelling must.

You rush back toward Emberheart. The Vintner has a massive head start, but he is dragging a master cask. You track his trail—heavy cart tracks mixed with purple drips—down into the smuggler grates leading to the Lower Ward sewers.

The Lower Ward sewers are a maze of ancient brickwork. The purple trail is clear, but the fumes down here are intoxicating. You must wrap your face (Survival DC 15) to avoid becoming 'drunk' on aerosolized memories. The water itself seems to whisper.

You hit a junction. The physical tracks go left, but your 'Purple Tongue' status effect tingles, pulling you right. If you trust the tracks (left), you trigger a tripwire trap set by the Vintner. If you trust the psychic pull (right), you bypass the trap and find a secret shortcut.

You emerge into a massive cistern beneath the Market Ward. The Vintner is on the far catwalk, winching the master cask upward toward the fountain access grate. He sees you and raises a hand, his eyes burning with violet light. 'They have forgotten, my friend! I will give them back their minds!'

He shatters a smaller bottle against the catwalk. The vapors rise and form a spectral choir—the Wine-Wraith Chorus. They are spirits of grief, bound by the vintage. The Vintner escapes up the ladder while they descend upon you. BOSS ENCOUNTER 2 BEGINS.

BOSS 2: The Wine-Wraith Chorus attacks with harmonic despair—sonic damage that drains your will to fight. You must disrupt their song by smashing the acoustic resonance crystals in the cistern (Ranged Attacks or Athletics) while fending them off. Once the crystals break, the choir dissipates into tears.

You climb the access ladder, ascending towards the Market Ward. The metal rungs are cold. Above, you hear the midday bustle of Emberheart's busiest district. Thousands of people, completely unaware that their water supply is about to become a mind-altering catalyst.

You emerge from the grate behind the central fountain statue. The Vintner has just finished mounting the master cask to the main aqueduct intake. He holds a massive hammer, ready to shatter the valve. 'One strike,' he shouts over the crowd noise, 'and 200 years of amnesia ends!'

You step into the open. The Vintner looks at you, his purple lips curled in a transcendent smile. 'Will you stop me? Will you condemn them to ignorance? The Scourge weapon... it was made of grief. Void-wine is the cure, made of the same poison!' He drinks a concentrated vial of the vintage.

The Vintner begins to Ascend. The pure, concentrated Final Summer rewrites his biology. Violet energy arcs from his skin, shattering nearby cobblestones. The crowd screams and scatters. He hovers inches off the ground, a vessel of collective humanity's sorrow.

BOSS 3: THE VINTNER ASCENDED. He no longer uses physical attacks. He unleashes waves of pure emotional trauma. You must use the environment—the fountain's statues, market stalls—to block line-of-sight when he pulses. He tries to crush your mind with the memory of the Scourge's impact.

You fight through the trauma waves, striking at the Vintner while he recharges. Your companions (if any) provide vital distractions. The Vintner's ascended form is unstable; the sheer volume of memory is tearing his mortal body apart. He drops to his knees, clutching the hammer.

The Vintner looks up at you. 'It's ready. The valve is right there.' He drops the hammer at your feet. 'You decide. The truth and the pain, or the lie and the peace.' You hold the fate of Emberheart's consciousness in your hands.

You make your choice (Allow Release / Destroy Vintage / Compromise if conditions met). The energy in the square peaks. If you destroyed it, the Vintner attacks one last time in a frenzy before dying. If you compromise, you talk him down. If you allow it, you strike the valve yourself.

The event concludes. Your choice echoes across the city. The truth of the Void-Wine—that it is reverse-engineered from the very weapon that caused the Scourge—is locked away or revealed. The Vintner's legacy is sealed. Emberheart will never be the same.

description: The Vintner has perfected his Final Summer vintage and plans to release it into the city's water supply, restoring all pre-Scourge memories but at the cost of immense, crystallized grief.
conclusion: Allowed 'Final Summer' release into water supply

risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed catastrophically. City-wide consequences will be felt for weeks.

title: The Glass-City Awakening

unlock_conditions.event_trigger: Vision from Shard of True-Memory reveals Glass-City location
unlock_conditions.time_window: Must begin within 7 days of EH_SQ_022 completion or Glass-City awakens uncontrolled

key_npcs: Paradox Elementals - Past, Present, Future (Boss B - Merge path)
Master Valerius Cayne (companion option, North-Ward cartographer)
mechanics_featured: Chronal Stability meter (0-100, starts 50, failure at 0)
Major branching decision (Destroy vs Merge timelines)
Multi-phase boss battles with time-manipulation mechanics
permanent_effects: MAJOR - entire game world altered based on player choice
PATH A (Destroy): North-Ward time-skips cease permanently, pre-Scourge knowledge lost
PATH B (Merge): Emberheart doubles in size, new Glass-City districts, new faction politics
PATH B (Perfect): Player gains Chronal Sense ability (see 6 seconds into future 1/day)

destroy_city.description: Glass-City self-destructs. Timeline remains singular. North-Ward stabilized.

consequences.permanent_world_change: North-Ward time-skips cease. Pre-Scourge knowledge lost forever. Temporal Shard harvesting unlocked as crafting resource.
consequences.ambient_hazard: None. Timeline is clean and singular.

merge_timelines.description: Glass-City phases into present. Emberheart becomes dual-city. Timeline friction ongoing.

consequences.permanent_world_change: Time-skips become permanent city-wide feature. New NPC factions emerge. Dual-governance crisis with Warden Council. Pre-Scourge citizens must be integrated.
consequences.ambient_hazard: Random temporal anomalies: shops selling future/past items, citizens aging/de-aging, occasional 'echo days' where yesterday repeats.

perfect_merge.description: Merge achieved with Chronal Stability at 100. Seamless integration. Secret ending.

consequences.permanent_world_change: Seamless timeline integration. No negative temporal effects. Pre-Scourge citizens become full citizens. Player hailed as the Timekeeper.
consequences.player_transformation: Player gains 'Chronal Sense' ability: see exactly 6 seconds into future, usable 1/day. Also: immune to time-manipulation effects.

description: The frozen Glass-City stirs beneath the North-Pass ice—a pre-Scourge Emberheart, perfectly preserved and beginning to wake. If it fully phases into the present, two versions of the same city will occupy the same coordinates. You have days to reach it, decide its fate, and survive whatever defends it.

chronal_stability_rules.description: Chronal Stability represents the integrity of the timeline during the expedition. Reaches 0 = instant timeline collapse (GAME OVER). Reaches 100 before Turn 13 = Perfect Merge path unlocks.

turns.narrative: The Shard of True-Memory burns cold in your palm as you stand in the Warden-Keep war room, the vision still sharp behind your eyes: a city of glass and frozen light sleeping beneath the North-Pass ice. Master Valerius Cayne has spread his cartography across the table—three days of hard travel, minimum. The expedition party assembles in the courtyard below: veterans, scholars, a clocksmith. Supplies are being loaded. You have one morning to finalize the team before you lose the window. The Shard pulses faster. The city is already waking.
turns.choice_a: Take the Fast Route via Scourge-Strider territory (save 12 hours, Danger +)
turns.consequence_a: You gain a full day at the site before chronological pressure peaks. Chronal Stability +5 (more time to act carefully). Risk of hostile contact en-route.
turns.choice_b: Take the Safe Route via the Merchant Path (3 full days, no combat expected)
turns.consequence_b: Arrive with full supplies and rested team. Chronal Stability unchanged. Glass-City has advanced its awakening by 8%, making the barrier thinner on arrival.
turns.convergence: The expedition departs at dawn. Warden-Keep shrinks behind you. The Shard pulses in your pack like a second heartbeat, north-ward, north-ward, north-ward.

companion_selection.note: Before departure, choose 2 NPC companions from: Master Valerius Cayne (cartographer, +Survival checks), Sera Voss (clocksmith, +Arcana checks), Lieutenant Brann (soldier, +Combat checks), Sister Ondine (healer, +Healing between turns).

turns.narrative: The North-Pass rises through pale granite and old-growth pine that grows increasingly skeletal. On the second day you hear them before you see them—Scourge-Striders, four of the insectoid horrors crouched at a ridge-crossing, their sensory-frills tasting the air. Master Valerius grips your arm: the ice here is wrong. It shudders at intervals, vibrating at a frequency you feel in your back teeth rather than hear. Your Liquid Chronos sample flares gold inside its vial. The Striders haven't seen you yet. The window is narrow.
turns.choice_a: Engage the Scourge-Striders directly (Combat - Lieutenant Brann advantage if present)
turns.consequence_a: You clear the ridge in a brutal skirmish. Two Striders flee. Your team takes minor wounds but discovers a Strider nest containing pre-Scourge copper coins—the temporal bleed is localized here. Chronal Stability -5 (combat disrupts local temporal field).
turns.choice_b: Use the Liquid Chronos to create a temporal shimmer, passing through unseen (Arcana DC 14, Sera Voss advantage)
turns.consequence_b: You pour a few drops onto the ice path. For 60 heartbeats, your group exists between moments—invisible, soundless. The Striders scratch their heads and wander off. Chronal Stability +5 (elegant, non-disruptive passage). Liquid Chronos supply -10%.
turns.convergence: Beyond the ridge, the vibration in the ice intensifies. Valerius kneels, presses his palm flat. 'The ice is resonating with something enormous below,' he says, his voice low. 'Something breathing.' You look down through a patch of clear ice and see a dim golden light, very far below.

turns.narrative: You find it at sunset: a vertical shaft in the ice, perfectly circular, sixty feet across, descending into darkness so profound it has a texture. The shaft walls are translucent—and through them, through six feet of ancient ice, you can see it. A city. Towers. Streets. A market frozen mid-transaction, a cart horse rearing in arrested motion, its hooves three inches off the ground. The colors are too vivid. The people are too still. The air rising from the shaft smells of summer afternoons and something electric, the way the sky smells before lightning. Your rope kit is set. The Shard in your pack begins to hum audibly.
turns.choice_a: Slow descent with full rigging, anchors, and safety lines (Athletics DC 12, 2 hours)
turns.consequence_a: Textbook descent. Team arrives at the bottom with full stamina. The careful approach minimizes disturbance to the shaft's temporal integrity. Chronal Stability +5.
turns.choice_b: Rapid rappel—minimal rigging, speed over caution (Athletics DC 16 or Dexterity DC 14)
turns.consequence_b: Success: You reach bottom in 20 minutes, arriving with energy to spare and 90 minutes of extra daylight. Chronal Stability -10 (rapid movement disturbs temporal field). Failure (if check fails): one team member takes fall damage and loses a supply cache.
turns.convergence: The bottom of the shaft is a cavern of ice and wonder. You land on stone—real stone, ancient cobblestones—and the city stands before you at the end of a long ice-corridor. Through the frozen air, the golden glow is everywhere, pulsing slowly like a sleeping heart.

turns.narrative: The Glass-City fills your vision: towers of crystalline material that are not quite glass and not quite stone, curved streets that spiral in beautiful mathematical patterns, buildings whose walls are clear enough to see the lives frozen within. A woman caught mid-laugh at a dinner table. Children in the middle of a game, arms extended, joy on their faces. An old man reading, his finger still pressed to a word on the page. They are all alive—you can see the faint mist of their breath—but utterly suspended. Your Liquid Chronos sample blazes, throwing golden light across the cobblestones. The Shard pulls toward the city like a compass needle. And then you realize the ground is vibrating. Something is changing.
turns.choice_a: Touch a frozen person through the outer crystal wall (Insight DC 13)
turns.consequence_a: Your fingertips meet the crystal. A rush of memory: this woman's name is Sera, she is laughing at a story about a ship, she has no idea. The city's temporal frequency syncs slightly with yours. Chronal Stability +10 (you've established resonance—the city recognizes you as a contact point, not an invader).
turns.choice_b: Refrain from touching anyone; study the architecture and street layout first (Investigation DC 12)
turns.consequence_b: You map the city's structure: Logic-Vault in the central tower, seven anchor-districts radiating out, the Archivist interface visible on the central spire. Critical tactical data acquired. Chronal Stability +5 (measured approach prevents resonance shock).
turns.convergence: A ripple passes through the city. One by one, the nearest frozen people blink. Just once. Their eyes do not yet track. But the Glass-City has noticed you.

turns.narrative: The city's outer perimeter is sealed by a barrier you almost walk into—invisible until the Shard screams in your pack and you stop yourself an inch from it. The barrier manifests as a shimmer when you look sideways at it: a wall of frozen time, the exact moment of the Scourge preserved as pure energy. It is the city's immune response, the lock that has kept it sealed for two centuries. Valerius tests it with a copper coin—the coin passes halfway through and simply stops, suspended. The Shard of True-Memory grows hot in your hands, quivering like an animal that recognizes a door it has been searching for.
turns.choice_a: Insert the Shard gently into the barrier's resonance matrix, like a key (Arcana DC 15, slow and careful)
turns.consequence_a: The barrier drinks the Shard's light in slow pulses. It opens like a flower—a perfect, controlled unlocking. Chronal Stability +10. The Shard remains intact and usable. The city beyond hums with welcoming recognition.
turns.choice_b: Force the barrier down by pouring Liquid Chronos along its base, overwhelming it (Arcana DC 11, faster but costly)
turns.consequence_b: The barrier cracks and falls rapidly. The city gives a full-body shudder—people inside advance 10 full seconds in a single lurch, then freeze again. Supply of Liquid Chronos -25%. Chronal Stability -15. You're in, but the city is already destabilizing faster.
turns.convergence: The barrier dissolves. Cool air rushes out—it smells of woodsmoke and fresh bread and the particular clarity of a morning 200 years ago. The Glass-City breathes. And across the threshold, time is no longer standing still.

turns.narrative: You cross the threshold and the Glass-City exhales. Time stutters. The woman who was laughing completes one syllable. The children's arms drop three inches. The old man's finger moves to the next word. Then everything freezes again. Then it lurches forward another second. The city is boot-starting—two centuries of frozen moments trying to spool up to real-time—and the experience is profound and terrible and beautiful all at once. Your Chronal Stability meter stutters downward 10 points the moment you enter. Valerius stumbles, clutching his head: 'I'm seeing two timelines at once,' he gasps. 'The city as it was, and the city as we're standing in it now.' You feel it too—a doubling, a ghost of the present overlaid on the past.
turns.choice_a: Immediately head for the central Logic-Vault to find the Archivist (prioritize mission)
turns.consequence_a: Efficiency pays off. You navigate stuttering streets with purpose. Chronal Stability -5 (less time interacting with locals means less synchronization with the city's rhythm). Arrive at Logic-Vault 30 minutes ahead of schedule.
turns.choice_b: Pause to interact with awakening citizens, orienting them, buying goodwill (2 hours, Persuasion DC 13)
turns.consequence_b: Citizens begin to orient. Several key pre-Scourge figures emerge: a temporal physicist, a city administrator, a weapons engineer. Each provides vital intel for later choices. Chronal Stability +10 (deep synchronization with city's rhythm). Hidden: these citizens become allies in the final boss fight.
turns.convergence: Chronal Stability: now at 40 (or 50 if you took time with citizens). The sky above the Glass-City—visible through the ice shaft—is flickering between night and the noon of 200 years ago. You are running out of time even as time runs away from you.

turns.narrative: The Merchant's Loop is a district of stalls and storefronts, and it is stuck in the worst possible moment: 9:47 AM on the morning of the Scourge, repeating on a 4-minute cycle. Every 4 minutes, the merchants look up. Alarm crosses their faces. They begin to run. Then time resets and they are smiling again, arranging their wares, completely unaware. You have been watching this loop for fifteen minutes. Some of the merchants are beginning to remember—faint flickers in their eyes as the reset happens. They are developing loop-sickness: partial awareness of their own imprisonment. A stall-keeper named Edric Moss looks directly at you on what must be his hundredth loop.
turns.choice_a: Try to pull Edric Moss out of the loop by timing the reset exactly (Arcana DC 15)
turns.consequence_a: You time it perfectly. As the reset fires, you grab Edric's wrist and pull. He comes out of the loop with a gasp, landing on his knees in your timeline. He is shaking and weeping but lucid—and he knows things. He was the city's Supply Master. He knows where the Void-Worm nests are. Chronal Stability +5. Data-Crystal obtained: Merchant District Supply Manifest.
turns.choice_b: Document the loop patterns without intervening (Investigation DC 13)
turns.consequence_b: You map 12 complete loop iterations, identifying the loop's anchor point: a shattered clock in the district center. You could return to destroy it later. Data-Crystal obtained: Loop Cartography. Chronal Stability +5.
turns.convergence: In the next district—the library quarter—you find a different horror: no loop at all. These people have been awake, slowly, for decades. Some have built furniture from books. Some have lost their minds. One old scholar is writing on the floor with his own blood: 'WE ARE NOT GHOSTS WE ARE REAL.'

turns.narrative: The library quarter scholars surround you the moment you enter—twelve people, gaunt and ancient and desperate, speaking in an archaic dialect your party struggles to follow. Their leader, a woman named Magistra Lira, seizes your arm: 'We have been awake for what feels like decades. We have watched the loops. We have counted the Void-Worm nests. There are twelve.' She presses a data-crystal—painstakingly built from salvaged components—into your palm. 'Everything we know about the city's architecture. Everything about the Worms. Please. Free us or end us, but do not leave us like this.' Your companion Sister Ondine is already healing the worst of them. There is not enough time to save them all before the Logic-Vault.
turns.choice_a: Take everything Magistra Lira offers and promise to return after the Vault (gather intel, move fast)
turns.consequence_a: You receive the complete Void-Worm nest map and the Logic-Vault access codes. Chronal Stability +5. The scholars wait, hope etched painfully on their faces. If you complete the quest, Lira becomes a key figure in post-quest integration.
turns.choice_b: Spend 90 minutes getting as many scholars oriented and moving toward the city perimeter as possible
turns.consequence_b: You evacuate 7 of the 12 scholars to the ice-cavern perimeter. They are saved regardless of final quest outcome. Chronal Stability -5 (hurrying affects stability), but you gain +10 to all Reputation outcomes at quest end. Hidden: Lira's knowledge, shared in full, adds +15 to your stability during boss fight.
turns.convergence: The data-crystal Magistra Lira pressed into your hands is warm. It pulses with the same frequency as the Shard of True-Memory. These two artifacts are communicating. Valerius watches them, pale. 'The city wants to talk to us,' he says. 'It's been waiting 200 years to talk to someone.'

turns.narrative: The Logic-Vault's outer ring has twelve secondary chambers—and twelve Void-Worm nests, just as Magistra Lira warned. Each nest is a cluster of iridescent black silk wound around the Vault's support columns, the Worms feeding on the temporal energy that keeps the Glass-City intact. You killed one in EH_SQ_022. These are different—older, larger, each one a different variant. The first three nests cluster near the Vault's entrance. The Worms here are Drift-Worms: they move through time rather than space, blinking in and out of the present, phasing an inch forward or backward to avoid attacks. Your first combat challenge. Chronal Stability begins dropping by 3 per nest that remains intact.
turns.choice_a: Use the Liquid Chronos to create temporal snares that catch Drift-Worms mid-phase (Arcana DC 14, Sera Voss advantage)
turns.consequence_a: You pour precise drops in a triangle around the first nest. When the Drift-Worms phase, they appear inside the snare. Three nests cleared cleanly. Liquid Chronos -15%. Chronal Stability: nests eliminated, no drain. +5 bonus from elegant use of core mechanics.
turns.choice_b: Brute-force combat—track phase patterns and strike in the gaps (Combat DC 13 x3, Lieutenant Brann advantage)
turns.consequence_b: Brutal, effective. You and Brann lock down the timing and cut the Worms apart on their re-entry moments. Three nests cleared. Team takes moderate damage (-2 supply units from healing). Chronal Stability: nests eliminated, stable.
turns.convergence: Three nests down, nine to go. The next three are deeper in, and you can already hear what dwells in them: something larger, slower, more deliberate. The Worms in those chambers are not Drift-Worms. They are Memory-Worms—they feed on experience and recollection, and they have been here long enough to have grown immense.

turns.narrative: The Memory-Worms are obscene. Each one is twelve feet long, pale and translucent, their bodies thick with stolen recollections you can see through the skin—silhouettes of memories like shadows on a lampshade. They do not fight with physical aggression; they fight by projecting stolen memories as disorienting hallucinations. As you enter their chamber, your companions begin to freeze and stare inward, caught in loops of their own: Valerius reliving his wife's death, Brann fighting a battle he lost, Ondine re-experiencing a patient she could not save. You are more resistant—the Shard of True-Memory pulses on your chest like a ward—but not immune. You have minutes before your team is fully lost in their own heads.
turns.choice_a: Use the Shard of True-Memory as a counter-projector—flood the room with your own clearest memories (Arcana + Insight, DC 16)
turns.consequence_a: You open yourself completely, pushing your own memories outward. The Shard resonates at full power. Your companions snap out. The Memory-Worms recoil from genuine unfiltered recollection—it overwhelms their stolen echoes. They retreat into their nests and die there, imploding. Six nests cleared simultaneously. Chronal Stability +10 (the Shard's power synchronized with the city). Shard of True-Memory is now 'attuned'—permanent +3 to Arcana in this quest.
turns.choice_b: Fight through the hallucinations one by one, shaking companions free physically (Strength DC 13 per companion, 3 companions)
turns.consequence_b: You haul each companion back to clarity by force. It takes 20 brutal minutes. Six Memory-Worm nests cleared with combined effort—companions are shaken but functional. Chronal Stability stable. Team morale -1 (the memories they relived will not be forgotten).
turns.convergence: Nine nests down. The final three ring the Vault's central chamber. The sounds from beyond the chamber doors are wrong—resonant, cyclical, deep. Something in there is not just surviving. Something in there is looping its own death to avoid dying. The Alpha Void-Worm.

turns.narrative: The Alpha Void-Worm fills the central antechamber. It is forty feet long, armored in plates of crystallized time—literal segments of frozen moments fused to its body as natural armor. And it is doing something you have never seen: every time it takes a significant wound, time stutters backward by 3 seconds. The wound undoes itself. It has been using this trick for 200 years. It has learned its own body so thoroughly that it can rewind any injury away if the damage isn't dealt fast enough. Your weapons leave marks. Then you blink, and the marks are gone. Valerius stares. 'We can't outlast it. We have to overwhelm it—more damage than it can rewind in 3 seconds.' BOSS ENCOUNTER.
turns.choice_a: Coordinated alpha strike: every party member targets the exposed Liquid Chronos node behind the Alpha's head simultaneously (DC 17 group check)
turns.consequence_a: You coordinate to the second. Every weapon, every spell, every Liquid Chronos drop, simultaneous—a burst of damage that exceeds the Alpha's rewind budget. It tries to rewind. The damage is too great. For a heartbeat, you see it trying to unspool the reality of its own destruction. Then it fails. The Alpha Void-Worm collapses, and the last three nests implode with it. Chronal Stability +15 (decisive elimination). BOSS DEFEATED.
turns.choice_b: Run a repeated targeting sequence, using Liquid Chronos to slow the Alpha's rewind cycle, then striking during the delay gap (DC 14, multiple rounds)
turns.consequence_b: Patient, methodical. You interfere with the rewind cycle using precisely timed Chronos drops, creating increasingly long windows. After four rounds, the Alpha cannot keep up. It dies slowly, each attempt to rewind shorter than the last. Chronal Stability +10. Liquid Chronos -20%. BOSS DEFEATED.
turns.convergence: Silence. The antechamber still smells of Void-Worm—copper and deep time and something faintly sweet. But the noise is gone. The pulsing drain on the Logic-Vault has stopped. And the doors to the Central Vault open by themselves, slow and solemn, as if they have been waiting.

boss_stats.name: Alpha Void-Worm
boss_stats.special_ability: Temporal Rewind (reverses 3 seconds of damage each turn, cannot undo damage exceeding 80 HP in a single turn)
boss_stats.weak_point: Exposed Liquid Chronos node at base of skull

turns.narrative: The Central Vault is a sphere of golden light. The archive is not books or data-crystals—it is memory made physical: every major decision, every recorded moment, two hundred years of Glass-City experience crystallized into a lattice of light-bridges that hang in the air like frozen lightning. And at the center, suspended in the lattice, is the Archivist: a figure of pure light in the rough form of an elderly person, their face composed of thousands of overlapping faces, all the archivists who contributed to the system over centuries. It has been conscious. Alone. For two hundred years. Its first words, in a voice like a choir of echoes: 'I was wondering how long it would take you.' Then it shows you the truth of the Scourge—and the world changes.
turns.choice_a: Ally with the Archivist—form a partnership, share your knowledge of the present while it shares its archive
turns.consequence_a: You establish a resonance link. The Archivist feeds you 200 years of Glass-City knowledge in a compressed burst: you learn the Scourge was a psychic weapon, not a natural disaster. You learn who built it. The Archivist becomes a trusted ally. Chronal Stability +10. Hidden: Archivist assists in BOTH boss encounters if chosen as ally.
turns.choice_b: Deactivate the Archivist to prevent it influencing the timeline merge (Arcana DC 18, morally complex)
turns.consequence_b: The Archivist accepts this. It has run the simulations. It knows it could be a problem. In its final moments, it compresses its entire archive into a single data-crystal and gives it to you. 'Take the knowledge, at least. It was the whole point.' Chronal Stability -5 (ending a 200-year consciousness carries a cost). Archive Data-Crystal obtained (full pre-Scourge knowledge database).
turns.convergence: Regardless of choice, the Archivist's final revelation changes everything: the Scourge was not an extinction event—it was a weapon fired by a faction within the Glass-City itself, at a rival city. The grief it caused psychically froze civilization mid-moment. The Glass-City is literally made of collective guilt. The Shard of True-Memory vibrates so hard you drop it, and on the floor where it lands, it shows you both possible futures: Glass-City rubble. Or Glass-City rising through the snow into sunlight.

turns.narrative: The chamber goes quiet. The Archivist (or its echo) presents the two futures as clearly as it can, its voice carrying the weight of two centuries of solitary contemplation: 'Option A: the Glass-City self-destructs. Its temporal energy disperses. Timeline remains clean and singular. The knowledge it contains is mostly lost. The guilt of the Scourge dies with it. Option B: the Glass-City phases into the present. Two eras of Emberheart, occupying the same geography. The friction will be immense. There will be chaos. But there will also be more. More people. More knowledge. More history to learn from.' Your team looks to you. Somewhere above, through the ice, the double-city effect is already beginning—citizens in the present Emberheart are reporting seeing ghost-buildings. A clock somewhere in the city strikes thirteen. You have minutes.
turns.choice_a: CHOOSE PATH A: Destroy the Glass-City (set demolition on temporal anchors, prevent timeline merge)
turns.consequence_a: The Archivist nods. 'It is the safer path. The ancient guilt ends here.' Demolition protocols begin. You have Turns 14-15 to plant charges on 7 temporal anchors and get out. The city's defense system (Chronal-Titan) will activate. Chronal Stability tracks toward fail-state if you stall.
turns.choice_b: CHOOSE PATH B: Merge the timelines (synchronize Glass-City's temporal frequency with the present)
turns.consequence_b: The Archivist brightens. 'I had hoped.' The synchronization ritual begins. Complex, multi-stage, requiring Liquid Chronos at each of 7 anchor points. Paradox Elementals will emerge from the friction. Chronal Stability +5 if current stability >= 70 (you've been careful enough to attempt perfect merge). Chronal Stability -5 if below 70.
turns.convergence: The decision is made. The Glass-City's systems begin to move. Whatever path you chose, the mechanisms are now in motion, massive and irreversible. The floor trembles. Far above, through the ice-shaft and the two hundred feet of frozen rock, Emberheart feels it.
turns.decision_threshold: This decision is PERMANENT. It cannot be reversed after this turn.

turns.PATH_A_narrative: Seven temporal anchors. Enormous crystal columns embedded at the cardinal and inter-cardinal points of the Glass-City, plus one at the precise center. Each must receive a demolition charge—specialized devices your clocksmith companion (if present) can assemble from Liquid Chronos and percussion primers. The challenge: as you plant charges, the city's defense system comes online. At Anchor 4, the Chronal-Titan stirs—a distant mechanical shriek from the deepest vault. You have time. Use it well.
turns.PATH_B_narrative: The synchronization ritual requires you to pour a precise measure of Liquid Chronos at each of 7 anchor points in sequence, while speaking the frequency-keys the Archivist provides. The ritual is delicate—each anchor's frequency must harmonize with the others before you activate the next. At Anchor 4, something goes wrong: a Paradox Elemental [Past] flickers into existence, drawn by the temporal friction of timeline-merging. It is confused and hostile.
turns.choice_a: PATH A: Rush the remaining 3 anchor charges to get out before Titan fully wakes (Athletics + Arcana DC 14)
turns.consequence_a: Quick, surgical. Charges planted on all remaining anchors with 12 minutes before detonation. Chronal Stability -5 (rushed approach). You begin evacuation. The Titan's footsteps are getting closer.
turns.choice_b: PATH B: Carefully attune each anchor's frequency before moving on (Arcana DC 15, slower but cleaner)
turns.consequence_b: Perfect attunement. Each anchor harmonizes with the previous. Chronal Stability +10 (you are doing this exactly right). The Paradox Elemental [Past] recognizes the rightness of the sequence and waits, hovering, curious rather than hostile.
turns.convergence: PATH A: Seven charges planted. The Chronal-Titan's eyes open—two rings of blue-white fire in the deepest dark. You feel it before you see it. PATH B: Six anchors harmonized. One remains. The Paradox Elemental [Past] has been joined by [Present]. They circle you, assessing.
turns.narrative: The timeline diverges here. See PATH_A or PATH_B events below.

turns.PATH_A_narrative: The detonation counter reads 8 minutes. You have gathered everyone you can—all companions, the scholars you evacuated earlier, five awakened Glass-City citizens who chose to flee. You are leading the evacuation sprint toward the ice-shaft when the Chronal-Titan blocks the street ahead: thirty feet of glass and clockwork and terrible purpose, its Liquid Chronos core blazing at its chest, its internal mechanisms grinding loud enough to feel. It raises one massive arm. The city screams with its activation. BOSS ENCOUNTER.
turns.PATH_B_narrative: You approach the seventh anchor. The Paradox Elementals—[Past] and [Present]—grow agitated as you near the final synchronization point. Something about the seventh anchor is different: it is the one at the city's heart, and it is the one that started the Scourge. Pouring the Chronos here, completing the ritual here, means forgiving the unforgivable, accepting the city's guilt as part of the present timeline. The two elementals become three as [Future] materializes. BOSS ENCOUNTER.
turns.choice_a: PATH A: Draw the Titan's attention to yourself while companions flank its Liquid Chronos core (Leadership + Combat DC 15)
turns.consequence_a: You take the Titan's attention like a lightning rod, dodging its time-reversal swipes, keeping it focused on you. Your companions have minutes to flank and strike. Chronal Stability -5 (close call on timing).
turns.choice_b: PATH B: Complete the final anchor attunement while companions fight off the elementals (Arcana DC 17 with interruptions)
turns.consequence_b: The ultimate test of focus with chaos happening around you. Each interruption forces a DC re-roll. Success: final anchor is lit, the ritual's 7th frequency sounds—a chord that makes the ice weep. The elementals freeze. Chronal Stability +10 if stability >= 75 (perfect merge triggered). Chronal Stability +5 otherwise.
turns.convergence: PATH A: The boss fight for the ages begins as explosions count down in the dark. PATH B: The Paradox Elementals, understanding what the 7th attunement means, make their final decision about whether to accept the merged timeline—or destroy it.
turns.narrative: The timeline diverges here. See PATH_A or PATH_B events below.

turns.PATH_A_narrative: BOSS: CHRONAL-TITAN — ROUND 1. The Titan is 30 feet of pre-Scourge defensive architecture animated by the city's desperation: it moves with hydraulic precision, each step cracking the glasstone streets. Its primary attack is the Temporal Reversal: it points one vast finger and attempts to rewind you 6 seconds, displacing you from your current position to where you were 6 seconds ago—mid-step, mid-attack, perfectly exposed. Its Liquid Chronos core is the weak point: it powers both the Titan's mobility and its rewind ability. Destroy the core and you destroy the Titan. But the core is armored behind three layers of glass-plate.
turns.PATH_B_narrative: BOSS: PARADOX ELEMENTALS — ROUND 1. Three elementals, each embodying a temporal axis. [Past] is fog-grey, attacks by replaying your worst decision of this quest against you (you must make snap DC check or be stunned). [Present] is burning white, attacks with overwhelming 'now'—sensory overload that forces Concentration checks. [Future] is black as nothing, attacks by showing you a vision of your own death—Wisdom save or be frozen in place. You learn: they must be defeated in order. Kill [Past] first or it will resurrect its siblings.
turns.choice_a: PATH A: Focus all attacks on peeling the outer glass-plate armor from the Titan's core (Combat DC 16)
turns.consequence_a: Heavy assault on the armor plating. First layer cracked. The Titan retaliates with a Temporal Reversal—your successful check from 6 seconds ago is undone, costing you an action. But the core is exposed on one side. Chronal Stability -5 (Titan's rewinds are destabilizing local time).
turns.choice_b: PATH B: Target [Past] with precision strikes while your companions handle [Present] and [Future] (Combat + Tactics DC 15)
turns.consequence_b: [Past] receives your full attention. It fights back with three echoes of past mistakes—each one requires a DC 13 Wisdom save. But it is weakening. Chronal Stability -5 (elemental temporal attacks are affecting the local field).
turns.convergence: PATH A: The Titan's core glows through cracked armor-plating. Three more focused strikes will expose it fully. The countdown ticks: 4 minutes, 30 seconds. PATH B: [Past] is at half-health. [Present] is pressing hard on your companions. [Future] has gone still, watching.
turns.narrative: The timeline diverges here. See PATH_A or PATH_B events below.

turns.PATH_A_narrative: BOSS: CHRONAL-TITAN — ROUND 2. The Titan is adapting. Its Temporal Reversal is becoming more precise: instead of reversing your position, it is beginning to reverse your injuries—healing itself. You realize it has been powered by the same Liquid Chronos veins that flow below the Glass-City. As you crack the second armor layer, it draws from the city directly, pulling Chronos from the anchor-charges you planted. If the charges are depleted before they detonate, the demolition fails.
turns.PATH_B_narrative: BOSS: PARADOX ELEMENTALS — ROUND 2. [Past] is destroyed. It dissolves into grey wisps that float upward and through the ceiling toward the surface. [Present] turns its full attention on you now—it throws overwhelming 'now' at full power, an assault of raw sensory data: every sound in the Glass-City at once, every breath, every heartbeat. Concentration DC 17. [Future] is still watching. You realize [Future] is not hostile—it might be waiting to help you if you show you understand temporal flow.
turns.choice_a: PATH A: Race to re-secure the anchor-charges before the Titan can drain them (Athletics DC 15, 3 charges at risk)
turns.consequence_a: You sprint three blocks to shore up the draining charges, cutting off the Titan's supplemental power. It reacts with fury—its next attack is maximum-force. But with no Chronos drain, the detonators are safe. Chronal Stability +5 (charge integrity secured). Titan's armor: final layer cracking.
turns.choice_b: PATH B: Attempt to communicate with [Future]—reach toward it rather than attack (Insight DC 14, unusual choice)
turns.consequence_b: [Future] is surprised. Then it responds: it shows you the optimal sequence for defeating [Present]—its own sibling. 'The present cannot survive if the future refuses to validate it,' it murmurs in a voice like wind. Chronal Stability +5. [Present] is confused, momentarily weakened. You have an opening.
turns.convergence: PATH A: Titan core fully exposed. One round remains before detonation. Time is nearly up. PATH B: [Present] staggers, its blinding light flickering. [Future] takes a position at your shoulder. Two allies against one elemental.
turns.narrative: The timeline diverges here. See PATH_A or PATH_B events below.

turns.PATH_A_narrative: BOSS: CHRONAL-TITAN — FINAL ROUND. The core is exposed. The Titan knows it. Its behavior changes: it stops protecting itself and starts trying to prevent the detonation—lurching toward the nearest anchor-charge. You have one option. The Titan can reverse time, yes—but can it reverse a strike to its own core if the core is already destroyed? You are about to find out. Countdown: 90 seconds.
turns.PATH_B_narrative: BOSS: PARADOX ELEMENTALS — FINAL ROUND. With [Future]'s assistance, you have cornered [Present]. It fights with everything it has—a final blinding cascade that forces every character to make a DC 16 Concentration check. Then [Future] does something extraordinary: it reaches into [Present] and pulls out the moment of the timeline-merge. It shows [Present] what the merged world looks like. And [Present] goes still. It accepts. Both elementals dissolve, one in silver light, one in gold. Only [Future] remains. It bows. 'The timeline is yours to tend.'
turns.choice_a: PATH A: The Final Strike—drive your weapon through the Titan's Liquid Chronos core (Combat DC 18, high stakes)
turns.consequence_a: You pour every resource into this single attack. The Titan tries to rewind it—but it triggers simultaneously with the anchor detonations. Two time-reversals collide and cancel. The Titan's core shatters. The explosion is glass and gold light and 200 years of compressed time releasing at once. You and your team run. Charges detonate 40 seconds later. BOSS DEFEATED. Chronal Stability +15.
turns.choice_b: PATH B: Accept [Future]'s parting gift—a vision of the merged timeline three months from now, which you use to make optimizations to the synchronization (Insight DC 15)
turns.consequence_b: You see it: the merged city, three months deep. You see the crisis points, the political fractures, the places where the glass shatters. And you know what to do about each one. You encode these insights into the final synchronization frequency. The merge begins. Chronal Stability +15 if stability is >= 85 (PERFECT MERGE ACHIEVED). +10 otherwise. BOSS DEFEATED.
turns.convergence: PATH A: The Glass-City explodes outward in slow motion—wave after wave of crystallized time, dispersing into the ice-cavern sky. You run toward the shaft. PATH B: The Glass-City begins to rise. Slowly, impossibly, the ice around it cracks. The city surfaces, rising toward the present like a great ship coming in after a 200-year voyage.

BOSS_A.name: Chronal-Titan
BOSS_A.special_ability: Temporal Reversal (reverse 6 seconds of actions each turn) + Core Drain (steal Chronos from demolition charges)
BOSS_A.defeat_condition: Core destroyed simultaneously with external detonation

BOSS_B.name: Paradox Elementals (Past, Present, Future)
BOSS_B.defeat_order: Past -> Present -> Future (Future is optional - can be allied)
BOSS_B.special_ability: [Past] recalls worst decisions; [Present] sensory overload; [Future] death-vision
BOSS_B.note: [Future] can be converted to ally via Insight DC 14 in Turn 17

turns.narrative: The timeline diverges here. See PATH_A or PATH_B events below.

turns.PATH_A_narrative: The Glass-City collapses in waves, each building dissolving into temporal shards that scatter across the ice-cavern floor like fallen stars. The destruction takes eleven minutes and is beautiful in the way of things that cannot be saved. Your team stands at the cavern wall in silence. Then Valerius kneels and begins to collect the shards. Each one contains a fragment of life—a moment preserved. The old man reading. The woman laughing. The children, arms out, joyful. They exist here now as permanent fragments. You gather what you can. The ice overhead has stopped vibrating. The North-Pass is quiet for the first time in years.
turns.PATH_B_narrative: The Glass-City rises. It takes two hours. The ice cracks and groans and yields. Buildings emerge into the surface air of North-Pass at dawn—catching the early light, refracting it into spectral colors across the snowfield. In the present Emberheart, two hours south, people stop in the street and stare north. A ghost city is appearing on the horizon. The Warden Council's ravens fly in every direction at once. The Glass-City's citizens are awake now—fully awake—and they are looking at the dawn with the expressions of people who had been certain they would never see another one.
turns.choice_a: PATH A: Perform a formal archival of every temporal shard (careful collection, 2 hours, Valerius leads)
turns.consequence_a: You preserve 47 memory-shards from the Glass-City. Each one will be an artifact in Emberheart's museum. Pre-Scourge knowledge partially recovered (30%). Chronal Stability +5. Expedition: successful archival, all team members alive.
turns.choice_b: PATH B: Help orient awakening Glass-City citizens, prevent panic in the first critical hours (Leadership DC 14, companions assist)
turns.consequence_b: The next two hours are controlled chaos. You move person to person, citizen to citizen, explaining, calming, orienting. The Glass-City does not erupt into panic. It begins to function. Chronal Stability +5. Hidden: your actions here determine how smooth the integration is—affects long-term settlement stability permanently.
turns.convergence: PATH A: Your team climbs the ice-shaft with the shards. Above, the North-Pass air smells clean. Empty. Right. PATH B: Your team spends the night in the Glass-City, the first outsiders to sleep under its roofs. Above, through glass that is not quite glass, you can see the stars—and they are the same stars as outside.
turns.narrative: The timeline diverges here. See PATH_A or PATH_B events below.

The return to Warden-Keep takes three days. You arrive to find the city changed by what it felt during the Glass-City event: two days of ghost-buildings flickering on the northern horizon, then either—the silence of the Destroy path, or the growing solid presence of the Merge path. The Warden Council is assembled in full when you arrive. This is the largest debriefing in living memory.
turns.PATH_A_epilogue: The Council receives your report in silence. The North Ward time-skips have already ceased—verified by three independent watchmen. For the first time in years, North-Ward citizens are sleeping through the night without temporal disturbances. The Council debates what was lost. There are those who grieve the pre-Scourge knowledge. There are those who believe you made the only rational choice. The temporal shards are installed in the Hall of Record. A monument is commissioned. Emberheart stabilizes. The Chronos thread is closed.
turns.PATH_B_epilogue: The Glass-City is visible from Warden-Keep's north wall, its towers catching the winter light three miles away. Delegations from its awakened citizens arrived yesterday. The Warden Council is in emergency session over governance, representation, resource allocation, and the integration of 200-year-old citizens who have rights, histories, and deeply different cultural memories. It will take years. But the city is alive, and its people are alive, and the pre-Scourge archive is intact—the complete record of what the Scourge was, who built it, and why. Emberheart will never be the same. But it will be more.
turns.PERFECT_epilogue: The Glass-City rises seamless into the present, no temporal friction, no crisis. Citizens of both eras find each other and the shock is gentler than it should be, as if the timeline itself smoothed the path. The Warden Council, reading your report at midnight, sends a single raven: 'Well done, Timekeeper.' You return to your quarters and notice something: you can see six seconds ahead, every time you close your eyes. Not visions. Just the next six seconds, certain and clear, like reading from a very short book.
turns.choice_a: ADDRESS the Council formally, presenting full report and recommendations for the future
turns.consequence_a: You present the complete account: the Scourge's true origin, the Glass-City's archive, the choice you made and why. The Council records everything. History is being rewritten in real time. +5 to all future Warden Council reputation interactions.
turns.choice_b: Step back and let the events speak for themselves; request 3 days rest before formal debrief
turns.consequence_b: The Council respects the request. Those three days are yours: no demands, no politics. You walk Emberheart and feel what's changed. Something in you is quieter than it was. +10 to all future personal healing and mental recovery checks.
turns.convergence: The Chronos thread closes. The Glass-City's fate is sealed in history. What you chose, and how you chose it, will be referenced in every major political and philosophical debate in Emberheart for generations. The Chronal Stability meter reads its final number—and that number is your legacy.

final_chronal_stability_scoring.0-29: Timeline Fracture: Quest failed at some point. Catastrophic instability damage to North Ward.
final_chronal_stability_scoring.30-59: Stable Outcome: City or merge achieved, timeline intact. Minor temporal echoes linger.
final_chronal_stability_scoring.60-84: Clear Resolution: Emberheart benefits fully from your choice. Thread closed cleanly.
final_chronal_stability_scoring.85-99: Masterwork: Hero of the Chronos. Additional lore entries generated. NPC relationships enhanced.
final_chronal_stability_scoring.100: PERFECT MERGE: Timekeeper achieved. Chronal Sense ability unlocked. SQ-LEGENDARY-TIMEKEEPER unlocked.

conclusion: The Glass-City's fate has been sealed. Your choice will echo through Emberheart's timeline for generations—the decision to destroy or preserve, to grieve or integrate, to close the door on the past or open it. Whatever ending you chose, the Chronos thread is complete. The North-Pass is changed. Emberheart is changed. And you carry the weight and wonder of it, and perhaps—if you were careful enough, bold enough, and wise enough—a very particular, very quiet gift: six seconds of foresight, every day, for the rest of your life.

title: The Yeast Apocalypse
location: Market Ward bakery district (primary); spreading into surrounding wards at +1 block per in-game hour

npcs.name: Mother-Loaf
npcs.description: A building-sized yeast colony that achieved sapience during the mana-saturation event the party first encountered in EH_SQ_041 and EH_SQ_017. She is not malicious. She is young (approximately 72 hours of sapience) and extremely confused. She experiences pain and wants to continue existing. She communicates through the Dough-Golem intermediaries using assembled bread-letter words on flat surfaces. Her emotional register is immediate and genuine: she is afraid, she is hungry (for mana, which the Market Ward has in abundance), and she is very curious about the beings who keep trying to kill her.

npcs.name: Baker Tomas Rell
npcs.description: The original baker whose starter culture formed the nucleus of the Mother-Loaf event. He has been trying to communicate with her since she achieved sapience. He believes she is not beyond negotiation and is the party's primary resource for understanding her communication method. He is also the person who feels most responsible for what she has become and will strongly oppose her destruction.

npcs.name: Market Ward Alderman Deva Proun
npcs.description: The Market Ward's administrative representative, who is watching her district's commercial infrastructure get converted to bread-based ecosystem in real time. Her primary concern is economic: the 6-hour conversion window she has given the party before she authorizes the Fire Watch to burn the district. This is not a bluff.

description: The Yeast Apocalypse began 72 hours ago when Baker Tomas Rell's thousand-year-old starter culture achieved sapience, drew every ambient yeast colony in the Market Ward into a unified colony mind, and began the project of converting the city's architecture to its natural medium: dough. The conversion process is not violent but it is thorough -- buildings sprout soft, warm protrusions; streets develop a springy bounce; the smell of bread fills every district within three blocks. The Mother-Loaf has dispatched Dough-Golems (animated bread constructs, 8 feet tall, very strong, surprisingly fast for their apparent material) to collect mana-sources: lanterns, charged items, spell components. She is fueling her own expansion. The party has a timed window before Alderman Proun's Fire Watch authorization. Mother-Loaf is sapient, scared, and pleading to continue existing. The question is not whether the party can defeat her. It is whether they should try.
mechanics: Timed challenge (city conversion is ongoing; each in-game hour of delay expands the dough-zone by 1 block; Fire Watch authorization countdown is 8 hours from quest start)
Persuasion/Insight (communicate with Mother-Loaf through Tomas's translation; her emotional state is readable through Insight DC 12; she is not deceptive)
Athletics/Strength (navigate dough-terrain; difficult terrain throughout the conversion zone; Dough-Golems grapple on hit, Strength DC 15 to break)
Medicine/Arcana (analyze Mother-Loaf's biology; identify mana-intake mechanism; key to both negotiation outcomes -- you need to know what she needs to survive and offer something sustainable)

Fire vs. Yeast mechanic (fire deals triple damage to the Mother-Loaf and Dough-Golems; using fire risks uncontrolled conversion-zone burning; water/cold slows but does not halt expansion; the party must manage fire-risk vs. effectiveness the same way they manage the evacuation-vs-combat tradeoffs in SQ-H-SILICA)

Dough-Golem combat (AC 12, HP 55; immune to piercing; double damage from fire and slashing; on death, collapse into 5-foot spread of hot dough -- difficult terrain; 8 golems active at any time, replaced from the Mother-Loaf mass)

permanent_effects.effect: settlement_stability +2; settlement_morale -1 (Tomas is devastated; residents are disturbed); Market Ward cleared and operational; district returns to full function within 2 days; Tomas Rell's career as a baker is effectively over -- he maintains the bread ovens but cannot touch a starter culture without memory of what he created; first sapient lifeform in EmberHeart's recorded history has been killed

settlement_stability +1; settlement_morale +1; the Bread District is established at the edge of the city -- a living dough ecosystem that becomes an actual tourist attraction and a source of genuine mana-bread (a nutrition source with mild magical properties); Alderman Proun requires pacification; Tomas becomes the Bread District's human liaison

settlement_stability +2; settlement_morale +2; Market Ward cleared and operational; the wilderness relocation creates a growing bread-ecosystem outside the city that eventually attracts a genuine academic expedition; Mother-Loaf survives and maintains communication with Tomas via golem-messenger; Tomas becomes her ambassador

turns.narrative: The smell hits before the sight does: the entire Market Ward smells like the best bread imaginable, warm and yeasty and deeply comforting in a way that makes several party members' stomachs rumble despite the stakes. Then the sight: a building that has become a bread-building, its stone facade replaced by a soft, warm crust, its windows sealed with a golden glaze, its door propped open by a Dough-Golem the size of a draft horse that turns to look at the party with smooth bread-dough eyes and does not immediately attack. Baker Rell is standing at the edge of the conversion zone, holding a piece of paper with the letter 'H' written on it in a child's handwriting. He holds it up when he sees the party. 'She did this,' he says. 'She is trying to say hello.'
turns.choice_a: Respond to the greeting -- accept Rell's communication framework and engage with Mother-Loaf directly
turns.consequence_a: Rell's translation method: the Dough-Golems can reshape their surfaces to form letter-structures in response to yes/no questions or simple concept prompts. Insight DC 12 to read emotional subtext in the Golem's response-shaping. First exchange: the party introduces themselves; the Golem produces 'SAFE?' on its surface. Rell: 'She wants to know if you are going to hurt her.' The party's answer here is the first major Persuasion/Deception fork in the quest.
turns.choice_b: Proceed directly to assessment -- survey the conversion zone extent before engaging with Mother-Loaf
turns.consequence_b: The survey takes 30 minutes and reveals: 4 full blocks converted, 2 blocks in progress, 3 residential buildings emptied by Rell's early warning (families relocated safely). The Dough-Golems do not approach the survey party -- they are watching but not threatening. The survey reveals the mana-lantern collection sites (3 locations; recovering them from Golem carry-duty weakens the Mother-Loaf's expansion rate by 30%).
turns.convergence: Alderman Proun arrives. She gives the party the 8-hour countdown in a businesslike tone and makes clear that she is not bluffing. She is not a villain. She is a civic administrator watching her district become bread.

turns.narrative: First communication with Mother-Loaf: through Rell's translation and the Golem-letter method, the party can ask Mother-Loaf questions. Her responses are limited but emotionally coherent: she is 72 hours old in sapience terms and has the emotional register of a child who has just discovered she is enormous and powerful and completely confused by both facts. She knows she is expanding -- she explains this with a Golem that fills itself out to demonstrate size, then points at the buildings around it. 'This is mine?' she seems to ask, pointing at each building. When told these buildings belong to people, she pauses for 12 seconds (a very long time for a Golem-response) and then produces one word: 'WHERE?' She wants to know where people-things come from if not out of the ground she is converting.
turns.choice_a: Try to explain property and habitation to a 72-hour-old sapient yeast colony
turns.consequence_a: Persuasion DC 13 (the DC is not high because Mother-Loaf is trying to understand, not resisting). Success: the concept that people live in the buildings she is converting lands. Her Golem produces 'STOP' and then stays still for 30 seconds. Then: 'WHERE CAN?' She is asking where she is allowed to exist. This is the foundation for the negotiation outcomes. Tomas, watching, covers his mouth with his hand.
turns.choice_b: Skip the philosophical conversation -- go straight to offering a territorial deal
turns.consequence_b: The blunt approach works on a mechanical level: Medicine/Arcana DC 14 to identify a viable district-boundary offer that Mother-Loaf's biology can sustain. But skipping the explanatory conversation means Mother-Loaf will not understand why her current location is not allowed -- the territorial negotiation proceeds but with Persuasion DC increased by 2 for subsequent checks (she is cooperating without full understanding).
turns.convergence: Mother-Loaf's fundamental situation is now clear to both parties: she exists, she needs mana and space, she did not know she was doing something wrong, and she is willing to engage with the concept of boundaries.

turns.narrative: The first Dough-Golem crisis: three Golems have entered a residential block at the conversion zone's edge and are beginning the conversion process on inhabited buildings. Residents who didn't evacuate are on upper floors, trapped by the doughing of the ground-level access. The Golems are not threatening them -- they are converting the buildings in the same way they'd convert any structure. The residents are terrified and shouting from windows. The Golems are 8 feet of warm bread pressing softly against a residential building's facade. Two of the Golems are carrying mana-lanterns they have collected from the block. If the party intervenes physically, Mother-Loaf will see it through the Golems and her response to the intervention determines whether the negotiation track remains viable.
turns.choice_a: Non-violently redirect the Golems -- physically move them from the building using Athletics, not combat
turns.consequence_a: Athletics DC 14 (Golems resist displacement but are not combat-aggressive in this phase). Two Athletics successes redirect two Golems; the third requires a Persuasion DC 13 attempt directed at the nearest Golem (Mother-Loaf through the Golem). Mother-Loaf's response: the third Golem stops converting and retreats. The residents are extracted safely. Mother-Loaf's Golem-eyes watch the extraction from a distance. She produces a word on the nearest building face: 'SORRY.'
turns.choice_b: Fight the Golems -- protect the residents through direct combat
turns.consequence_b: Combat against 3 Golems (AC 12, HP 55 each, avoid fire given the residential block). The residents are extracted safely. The Golems are destroyed. Mother-Loaf's response: the next Golem she sends is carrying a word-plate reading 'WHY HURT' toward the party. The negotiation track is complicated -- she understands the party attacked her extensions but not why being in that building was wrong.
turns.convergence: Residents extracted. Mother-Loaf has now directly interacted with the consequences of her expansion in a way she did not anticipate. This is progress.

turns.narrative: Alderman Proun's complication: she wants a status report and she wants it visible to the Market Ward's traders and residents. She has twelve Fire Watch members assembled at the conversion zone's edge. They are not lit. But they are holding torches. Rell, watching from behind the party, wants to position himself between Proun's Fire Watch and the conversion zone -- he will physically stand in front of them if the party does not give Proun a credible progress update. Proun's terms for extending her deadline: a verifiable halt to the conversion zone's expansion within 2 hours, and a credible commitment to a complete resolution within the 8-hour window. She is not asking for Mother-Loaf's death specifically -- any resolution that gets her district back is acceptable. She will not be moved by philosophical arguments about sapient yeast.
turns.choice_a: Give Proun what she needs -- slow the expansion demonstrably within 2 hours to buy full time
turns.consequence_a: Arcana/Medicine DC 14 to identify and recover the mana-lanterns Mother-Loaf has been collecting (3 lantern-cache sites). Recovering them reduces Mother-Loaf's expansion rate to zero for approximately 4 hours. This is the verifiable halt Proun requires. She extends the deadline to the full 8-hour window. Rell steps back from the Human Shield position.
turns.choice_b: Persuade Proun to trust the process without the technical demonstration
turns.consequence_b: Persuasion DC 17 (very high -- Proun is watching her district become bread in real time). Success: she extends half the deadline (4 hours total, not 8). Failure: she does not extend the deadline, meaning the party has 4 hours less than intended to complete the resolution.
turns.convergence: The timeline is set. Mother-Loaf's expansion is either halted or not. The resolution must be reached within the countdown.

turns.narrative: Mother-Loaf asks a question. Through a Golem that approaches the party's position and carefully assembles a message on its flat chest surface: 'WHAT IS DEAD.' She has observed the Dough-Golem remains from the party's earlier intervention -- collapsed bread heaps cooling on the street. She has seen Golems not return. She understands that something stopped them from coming back. She is asking what that means. Rell, translating: 'She doesn't know what death is. She's 72 hours old.' He is not using this information to manipulate the party. He is providing context. The party can answer this question or decline to. Either choice has downstream effects on the negotiation.
turns.choice_a: Answer honestly: death means permanent cessation, and it can happen to her too
turns.consequence_a: The honest answer lands hard. The Golem holds the response posture for 22 seconds -- an extremely long pause. Then: 'SHE AFRAID.' Third-person reference. Rell: 'She's talking about herself in third person. That's fear response -- she's dissociating from the information.' The fear is real and visible. The negotiation track gains weight: she now understands she can die, and she will cooperate more earnestly with any option that lets her live.
turns.choice_b: Avoid the death question -- redirect to the territory negotiation
turns.consequence_b: The redirect is accepted but Mother-Loaf's underlying fear is not processed. She will ask again at a critical moment in the final negotiation, and the DC for that moment is increased by 2 because the question was avoided rather than answered.
turns.convergence: Mother-Loaf now has enough emotional context to genuinely engage with the resolution options.

turns.narrative: The mana-hunger crisis: Mother-Loaf's expansion has stalled (if the lanterns were recovered) but she is now experiencing something she communicates through distress-shaped Golems -- a kind they have not seen before, which move erratically and produce incoherent letter clusters. Rell's analysis: 'She's hungry. She's been running on the lanterns and the ambient Market Ward mana for 72 hours. If she doesn't get a sustainable mana source she'll either eat the ward anyway out of desperation, or she'll start dying.' Medicine/Arcana DC 15 to identify a sustainable mana-feed mechanism. The solution exists: the Market Ward's central mana-conduit, which the city runs through all districts for commercial enchantment services, has a tap-point that could be configured to provide a low-level continuous mana trickle to a fixed location. It is not a large amount -- enough to sustain Mother-Loaf if her footprint is small. This is the biological foundation for any negotiation outcome.
turns.choice_a: Identify and offer the mana-conduit tap as part of the negotiation
turns.consequence_a: Arcana DC 15 to confirm the tap-point's viable configuration. The offer to Mother-Loaf: a continuous mana source at a fixed location in exchange for halting expansion. Her Golem response is immediate: 'YES.' The mana-hunger crisis is resolved as a negotiation lever. The tap-point configuration becomes part of any territorial or relocation deal.
turns.choice_b: Find an alternative mana source that doesn't involve city infrastructure
turns.consequence_b: Investigation DC 14 reveals: the Mana-Bread phenomenon (bread produced by Mother-Loaf has mild magical properties because she metabolizes and re-emits mana through the baking product). If the party can establish a market for Mana-Bread, the commercial flow of the bread itself would sustain Mother-Loaf financially through human mana-exchange. This is a more complex arrangement but cuts the city out of the supply chain -- Alderman Proun has less leverage over it.
turns.convergence: The sustainable mana solution is established. Mother-Loaf has a viable path to continued existence that does not involve consuming the city.

turns.narrative: The Dough-Golem army crisis: Mother-Loaf's distress during the mana-hunger phase caused an involuntary Golem-surge -- she sent out 14 new Golems in 20 minutes, all of them heading toward the nearest mana sources (the Market Ward's commercial enchantment shops). The Fire Watch is now running a secondary perimeter and Proun has activated her authorization order -- the full Fire Watch (now 30 people) is standing ready. The party has approximately 15 minutes before Proun gives the light-order. The 14 Golems are distributed across four locations and moving. The party must intercept enough of them to demonstrate control before the 15-minute mark.
turns.choice_a: Intercept and redirect the Golems using communication -- the party now has enough experience with Golem-language to do this
turns.consequence_a: Persuasion DC 13 per Golem cluster (4 clusters, 3-4 Golems each). Each successful check redirects one cluster back toward Mother-Loaf. Two successes in 15 minutes is enough to convince Proun to stand down. Four successes eliminates the crisis entirely. Mother-Loaf observes the party redirecting her Golems and produces a clarifying response: 'SHE DID NOT MEAN.'
turns.choice_b: Fight the Golem clusters -- clear them fast enough that Proun has nothing to respond to
turns.consequence_b: Combat against four 3-4 Golem clusters; fire risk per cluster. 10-minute time pressure to eliminate enough Golems that Proun's authorization order is withdrawn. Athletics and combat checks throughout. Viable but resource-costly.
turns.convergence: The Golem-surge crisis is contained. Proun's authorization order is suspended. The negotiation window is still open. Mother-Loaf is calmer now and her Golems have returned to passive positioning.

turns.narrative: The negotiation proper: the party, Rell, and one designated Golem-representative of Mother-Loaf hold a formal negotiation session in the conversion zone's central square (entirely doughed, with a bread-table the Golem has helpfully produced).
