turns.consequence_a: History DC 15 (DC 13 if the party has the Concordat Biological Division index from the Chronos thread). The wrong image: a founding-era depiction of the Laundry Ward's first Master Weaver, shown meeting with a Concordat official. The wrong element: the official's insignia is incorrect for the period — it's a post-Scourge institutional mark on what should be a pre-Scourge scene. The Concordat was present in the Laundry Ward before the Ward officially recognizes. Spun is silent for a moment when this is identified. The Elemental's surface pattern shifts: affirmation. Node passed.
turns.choice_b: Skip the examination and physically pass through the gallery — treat it as corridor, not puzzle
turns.consequence_b: The gallery animates partially — fabric hands reaching from the tapestries, not to harm but to delay (movement halved). Athletics DC 13 to push through. The Elemental's pattern response: disappointment. Node cleared but the historical revelation is missed.
turns.convergence: Node 2 cleared. The Concordat-Laundry Ward connection is now a piece of intelligence the party holds. Spun wants to discuss this at length at a more appropriate time.

turns.narrative: Dye-Master Rendal has entered the Ward's perimeter. He is not alone — he has brought five hired hands and a large quantity of lamp oil. He is going to burn his way to the core. His logic is commercial: the Elemental has absorbed his entire inventory, his workers' clothing, and his professional reputation, and he is not going to wait for the party to have a philosophical conversation with it. He is not wrong that fire is effective against the Elemental. He is very wrong about what happens if a large fire is set in an organic fabric-construction inside a building district. Spun's immediate reaction: 'If he starts a fire in there the Ward burns and takes three surrounding blocks with it.' Rendal's hired hands are already inside the Ward perimeter. The party has a few minutes before this becomes irreversible.
turns.choice_a: Stop Rendal physically — prevent the lamp oil from being deployed
turns.consequence_a: Athletics DC 12 to intercept Rendal's group before they reach the interior. Persuasion DC 15 to convince Rendal to stand down (his commercial grievance is legitimate and acknowledged). On success: Rendal is contained. He will remain a hostile NPC but won't actively sabotage. On failure: Persuasion DC 17 to appeal to his workers (hired hands who don't want to die in a textile fire).
turns.choice_b: Offer Rendal what he actually wants — compensation from the party or city funds
turns.consequence_b: Persuasion DC 14 plus a genuine financial commitment (the party pledges either personal gold or a commitment to lobby the city administration for commercial restitution). Rendal accepts and stands down permanently. Cost: 500 gold from party funds or an outstanding city-administration obligation. Rendal becomes neutral rather than hostile.
turns.convergence: Rendal is dealt with. The lamp oil is secured. The Warp-Node sequence continues without fire risk.

turns.narrative: Warp-Nodes 3, 4, and 5 in sequence (Sleight of Hand, Athletics, Medicine): Node 3 — threading a needle in a fabric-shrouded corridor (Sleight of Hand DC 14; the Elemental has reduced visibility to 10 feet with hanging fabric; the needle is full-sized but the concept mirrors exactly — complete a weaver's task without fighting the environment). Node 4 — the Elemental has constructed a fabric-wall that requires climbing rather than pushing through (Athletics DC 14; the wall yields to vertical movement but not horizontal pressure; this is a spatial test). Node 5 — a section of the Ward where the oldest, most degraded fabrics have been gathered — a hospice of fabric, effectively — and the Medicine check is to recognize that the Elemental has been carefully preserving deteriorating textiles, slowing their decay (Medicine DC 13 to identify the preservation action as intentional care, not absorption). Each node that is passed correctly shifts the Elemental's surface patterns: the party is now visible in the pattern, depicted as small figures walking through fabric corridors.
turns.choice_a: Complete all three nodes cooperatively — assign party members to the skill checks based on strength
turns.consequence_a: Three successful skill checks (DC 14, 14, 13). The Elemental's pattern now shows the party's likenesses moving toward the core — it knows who they are. When the party enters the final approach corridor, the fabric on the walls parts slightly, creating a genuine welcome path.
turns.choice_b: Rush the three nodes — prioritize speed over elegance, accept partial success
turns.consequence_b: At least two of three succeed (each failure results in a fabric-construct defensive challenge — one construct per failed node). The core is reachable but the Elemental's disposition is cautious rather than welcoming.
turns.convergence: Five nodes down, two remaining. The core chamber is audible now — a low harmonic vibration that the fabric itself is resonating, which Spun identifies as the Elemental's version of breathing.

turns.narrative: Warp-Node 6 (Persuasion — the Dialogue): the penultimate node is interactive. The fabric walls of the corridor have formed into a question, literally woven in text across every surface in the Laundry Ward's traditional guild-script: 'WHAT DOES UNCOVERED MEAN?' The Elemental is asking. It is not rhetorical. The party must answer — in words spoken aloud, which the Elemental perceives through vibration. This is the most important node: the answer shapes the Elemental's understanding of its own project's relationship to the city. If the answer treats 'uncovered' as a deficit (bad, cold, vulnerable), the Elemental's response is to cover more urgently. If the answer treats 'uncovered' as natural (neutral — not all things need covering), the Elemental pauses. If the answer is honest and complex (some things need covering, some don't, and the choice belongs to the thing being covered), the Elemental's pattern shifts in a way Spun has never seen: contemplative. This is Persuasion DC 15, or automatic success with a genuinely thoughtful, complex real-world answer.
turns.choice_a: Answer simply: 'Uncovered means exposed — everyone should choose what to cover for themselves'
turns.consequence_a: Persuasion DC 15. On success: the Elemental's pattern shifts. The complex answer — that covering is something that should involve consent — lands. The Elemental has not considered consent because fabric doesn't have it, but the concept is being absorbed. Node passed. The Elemental's expansion rate slows noticeably.
turns.choice_b: Answer with physical demonstration — remove an item of clothing or covering, then put it back
turns.consequence_b: The Elemental's pattern response to physical demonstration is immediate and positive — it has been studying texture and form, and the demonstration communicates 'I can cover and uncover at my own choice' directly. Persuasion DC is waived. Node passed. The Elemental adds the demonstrating character's textile pattern to its surface woven depiction as a recurring motif.
turns.convergence: Node 6 cleared. One node remains. The core chamber is visible through the final fabric-curtain — a 40-foot spinning mass of all-ward textile, dense and warm and deeply alive.

turns.narrative: Warp-Node 7 (Arcana — the Core Interface): the final node is not a barrier but an invitation. The Elemental's surface at the core chamber entrance has formed into something Spun identifies immediately: it's a loom interface. Manual operation — the party member who approaches must make a specific weaving motion (Arcana DC 13 to identify the correct shed-and-throw sequence from the loom's configuration; the motion itself is simple once identified). This is the Elemental's unlock mechanism. It can only be opened from outside by someone who knows how to use what it is. On successful completion, the core chamber opens. The Elemental's 40-foot central mass is visible: densely woven, slowly rotating, radiating warmth. In its center — barely visible but present — a smaller, brighter object. The core of the fusion event: one perfect piece of fabric, the oldest surviving weaving in the Laundry Ward, a founding-era Guild charter cloth. The core is not fighting. It is waiting.
turns.choice_a: Approach the core carefully — let the Elemental become accustomed to your presence before attempting any action
turns.consequence_a: Slow approach (3 rounds of movement, no aggressive action). The Elemental reduces its rotation speed — it is paying full attention to the approaching party. Spun whispers: 'Whatever you decide to do here, do it deliberately. It can see intent in motion.' Advantage on all skill checks in the core chamber resolution.
turns.choice_b: Approach the core directly and quickly — act before the Elemental can react
turns.consequence_b: The direct approach triggers the Elemental's passive Split defense — it splits into two Semi-Elementals (each 140 HP, Combat begins). The core is reachable during combat with DC 14 Athletics to navigate the Split forms. The negotiation and binding outcomes remain available through mid-combat Persuasion DC 18.
turns.convergence: The party is at the core. The Elemental's full presence is immediate. The decision about what happens to the Thread-Elemental must be made now.

turns.narrative: The core decision moment: the founding-era Guild charter cloth at the Elemental's center is the origin of the fusion event — the oldest, most mana-saturated textile in the Ward, which served as the nucleus when every other fabric within resonance range was drawn into concert. It functions as the Elemental's heart. Three paths exist: destroy the core cloth (unravels the Elemental immediately, all fabric returns inert), perform the Binding Ritual Spun prepared over the past two days (requires the correct Warp-Node responses across all seven nodes plus Arcana DC 17; binds the Elemental's consciousness to the Ward as a guardian), or Channel the Void (a more dangerous option Spun did not recommend — an Arcana DC 19 banishment that displaces the Elemental's consciousness into Void-space, freeing the fabric but creating risk of Void-instability near the Ward). The Elemental is present throughout this conversation, pattern-shifting actively.
turns.choice_a: Negotiate with the Elemental directly before choosing — use the Persuasion success from Node 6 as a foundation
turns.consequence_a: Persuasion DC 16 (DC 13 if Node 6 was passed with the complex or demonstrative answer). The Elemental communicates through pattern: it understands that its project is not consented to. It is willing to limit its scope. It wants: a formal space in which to exist, acknowledgment as a form of life, and continued access to the Ward's wash-water (the resonance source that sustains it). This is the basis for the Binding outcome.
turns.choice_b: Destroy the core without attempting negotiation — the city's needs outweigh the Elemental's existence
turns.consequence_b: An action against the core cloth triggers the Elemental's full combat response (AC 17, HP 280, immune to piercing/slashing, vulnerable to fire and cold, Split at 140 HP). The core cloth requires three successful hits or one Arcana DC 16 unraveling action during or after combat. All absorbed fabric returns inert upon destruction.
turns.convergence: The decision is made. The Elemental's fate is determined by what the party chooses here.

turns.narrative: Binding Ritual execution (if chosen): Spun has the ritual prepared in her head from two days of research and the seven Warp-Node confirmations. It requires three actions in sequence: anchoring the Elemental's consciousness to the core cloth (Arcana DC 15; advantage if all seven Warp-Nodes were passed cleanly), articulating the Elemental's permitted domain in spoken language (Persuasion DC 14 — the boundaries must be stated clearly and the Elemental must pattern-agree), and physically weaving a new outer layer on the core cloth that incorporates a single thread contributed by each party member (Sleight of Hand DC 12). Spun participates in the weaving. The ritual takes 20 minutes. The Elemental's behavior during the ritual: still. All expansion stops. Its pattern shows the party's likenesses woven into its surface, permanently. It is accepting the constraints because the party accepted it.
turns.choice_a: Complete the Binding Ritual as designed — formalize the Elemental's role as settlement guardian
turns.consequence_a: Arcana DC 15, Persuasion DC 14, Sleight of Hand DC 12. On three successes: the Binding completes. The Thread-Elemental's consciousness is anchored to the core cloth which is physically housed in the wash-house's foundation. It cannot expand beyond the Laundry Ward without explicit invitation. It provides: continuous textile-sanitation service (the Ward's fabrics are kept clean and preserved without manual effort), early warning of textile-based threats (including Void-imbued cloth items entering the city), and a form of civic pride the Ward has never had before. Rendal's fury is noted and ignored by the Ward residents.
turns.choice_b: Modify the Binding Ritual — negotiate a larger domain for the Elemental in exchange for faster resolution
turns.consequence_b: The Elemental's permitted domain is expanded to the full Textile District (three wards). The Binding DC on the first action is reduced to 13. Rendal's business is fully within the bound domain — he gets services but loses commercial textile autonomy. This outcome has more complex long-term Guild politics.
turns.convergence: The Binding succeeds. The Thread-Elemental is now a civic institution.

turns.narrative: Aftermath: the Laundry Ward emerges from the Elemental's full coverage. The fabric is still there — all of it — but it has reordered itself. Clothing has returned to forms, folded and pressed and hung with a precision that was not mechanically possible without endless human labor. The wash-house is operating, running automatically, with the Elemental managing the wash-water resonance that sustains it. Residents returning to the Ward find their homes fabric-perfect — not just their own textiles but neighbors' clothing washed and sorted and returned without confusion. One elderly Ward resident, returning to her building, finds 40-year-old tapestries she thought were destroyed in the Scourge aftermath, preserved in the Elemental's collection, returned to her door. She sits down on her step and holds them for a long time. Spun watches this from across the street. She doesn't say anything.
turns.choice_a: Formally introduce Spun to the Ward council as the Elemental's designated liaison
turns.consequence_a: Spun's role is formally recognized. She becomes the Interface Weaver — the Textile Guild's official point of contact with the Thread-Elemental. The Guild's relationship to the Elemental is institutionalized. settlement_morale +2 from the Ward residents' reaction to the recovered textiles.
turns.choice_b: Let the Ward establish its own relationship with the Elemental without formal intermediary
turns.consequence_b: The Elemental's civic integration is organic. The Ward develops its own informal communication with it over the following months through the pattern-watching that Spun demonstrated. The relationship is less legible to city administration but more genuinely rooted in the Ward itself.
turns.convergence: The civic relationship is established. The Thread-Elemental is a fact of life in the Laundry Ward.

turns.narrative: Rendal's response to the Binding outcome: exactly what was expected. He files a formal commercial complaint with the city administration, citing loss of textile autonomy within his commercial district. The complaint is partially valid — the Elemental's presence in the Ward means commercial textile transactions (buying, selling, transporting cloth through the Ward) must now be coordinated with its awareness. The Elemental has not interfered with commerce yet, but it could. The city administration's response depends on the party's relationship with city-facing institutions; without party advocacy, the administration defaults to a 'monitored existence' status — the Elemental is legal but regulated. With advocacy, the Elemental receives a formal charter as a civic institution with protected status.
turns.choice_a: Advocate for the Elemental's civic charter with city administration
turns.consequence_a: Persuasion DC 15 with the relevant city administrative body. On success: the Thread-Elemental receives a formal civic charter — it is legally recognized, Rendal's commercial complaint is addressed through a charter exemption for existing commercial operations, and the Elemental has institutional standing. settlement_stability +1 from the formal recognition.
turns.choice_b: Let the Elemental's status be settled through Rendal's commercial process
turns.consequence_b: The 'monitored existence' determination stands. The Elemental is legal but under ongoing review. This is acceptable to the Elemental — it is patient. Rendal's complaint eventually resolves in the Elemental's favor through the Ward residents' testimony, which comes three months later.
turns.convergence: The Elemental's institutional status is established at whatever level the party facilitated.

turns.narrative: The Warp-Loom artifact: in the wash-house's foundation chamber, adjacent to the Elemental's core housing, Spun has identified a functional Concordat-era loom of extraordinary construction — it predates the Ward by at least 200 years, which means the Laundry Ward was built around it rather than the other way around. The loom is connected to the same mana-wash resonance that created the Elemental. It is the original fusion device. Spun's assessment: it can be used to create textile items of extraordinary quality — fabrics that hold spells, that maintain enchantments, that serve purposes no standard textile can. But it is now also part of the Elemental's domain. The Elemental does not object to the loom being used, but insists on collaborative creation — it will not allow the loom to produce fabric against its grain.
turns.choice_a: Commission an immediate creation with the Warp-Loom — establish a working relationship with the Elemental through use
turns.consequence_a: A collaborative fabric creation (Arcana DC 13, Sleight of Hand DC 13). The result is one item of the party's specification: a fabric object of uncommon quality, permanently enchanted with one established enchantment of the party's choice (Arcana DC 15 to specify correctly). The Elemental's contribution is visible in the pattern — its maker's mark, woven permanently into any creation from this loom.
turns.choice_b: Leave the loom for Spun to manage — it is part of the Ward's civic resource now
turns.consequence_b: Spun manages the loom as part of the Interface Weaver role. Items commissioned from the Warp-Loom in the future require Spun's coordination and are available to the party at reduced cost (Elemental materials and Ward labor provided; party provides only the enchantment specification).
turns.convergence: The Warp-Loom's role in the Ward's future is established.

turns.narrative: Three weeks after the Thread-Elemental's Binding: the Laundry Ward is running at full capacity for the first time in the history of the district, in the sense that the textile work that takes human workers three days is now completing in six hours with the Elemental's assistance. Ward workers have more time. The economic output of the Ward has doubled. Rendal's dye-works are operating — the Elemental does not touch commercial dye-work that Rendal specifies — and his commercial complaint is looking increasingly frivolous in light of the output numbers. The recovered Scourge-era tapestries have been documented by the Archive of Deep Records (Briss is very excited). Spun's Interface Weaver role has attracted three apprentices from the Textile Guild who want to learn pattern-communication. The Ward is being used as evidence by city planners arguing that elemental-civic integration is viable urban policy. The Thread-Elemental has become EmberHeart's first sentient city service.
turns.choice_a: Attend the Thread-Elemental's first formal civic acknowledgment event
turns.consequence_a: The Ward council holds a brief ceremony in which the Thread-Elemental's founding-era charter cloth is formally installed in the wash-house foundation as an official civic object — the same legal status as a landmark building. The Elemental's pattern-response during the ceremony: the party's woven likenesses appear on its surface and remain there permanently, as part of its self-representation. The party is part of what the Elemental is.
turns.choice_b: Let the civic acknowledgment happen without party participation — the Ward should own this
turns.consequence_b: The Ward council's ceremony proceeds exactly as described above. The party hears about it from Spun afterward. The Elemental still includes the party's likenesses in its permanent pattern — this was its choice, not a ceremony artifact.
turns.convergence: The Laundry Thread's resolution is becoming part of the city's civic fabric, literally.

turns.narrative: The long game: the Thread-Elemental's Void-warning function activates for the first time eight days after the Binding. It displays a pattern on its surface at dawn — not an alarm, but a distinctive pattern Spun has learned to read. Something cloth-containing a Void-resonance entered the Market Ward the previous evening. The Elemental tracked it from the Ward perimeter. It provides a description in pattern: a hooded merchant, carrying a bolt of cloth with an interior Void-stain. The Market Watch, when notified, recovers a Void-contaminated textile shipment that was three days from being distributed to a residential building's furnishing supplier. The Elemental's first actionable intelligence catch. Spun notes it without drama: 'It's working the way it was supposed to.' The Laundry Thread's climax has produced not just a resolved crisis but a new civic entity that is actively improving the city's safety. The party has not just closed a story. They have opened an institution.
turns.choice_a: Formalize the Thread-Elemental's intelligence function — integrate it with city patrol and Watch operations
turns.consequence_a: The Elemental's Void-tracking capacity is formalized. The Watch establishes a 'Pattern Report' check with Spun every morning. settlement_stability +1. The Elemental's civic value becomes undeniable — even Rendal eventually files a commendation (Spun saves it and pins it to the wash-house wall without comment).
turns.choice_b: Keep the intelligence function informal — Spun reports to the party directly when the Elemental flags something
turns.consequence_b: The party has direct access to the Elemental's city-wide textile awareness as an intelligence resource. This is less systematic but more immediately useful to the party specifically. Spun is comfortable with this arrangement — it keeps the Elemental adjacent to the people who earned its trust.
turns.convergence: Quest complete. Laundry Thread resolved. The Thread-Elemental is EmberHeart's first civic-elemental institution — a form of city life that did not exist before this quest, serving functions no human institution was previously performing. The Laundry Ward is operating, the recovered Scourge-era textiles are in the Archive, Rendal is quietly grateful despite himself, and Spun is teaching three apprentices to read the pattern of a living city.

conclusion: The Thread-Elemental resolves the Laundry Thread with a genuinely novel outcome: instead of defeating a threat, the party creates a civic institution from it. The seven Warp-Nodes serve as both puzzle mechanics and genuine first-contact communication — the Elemental was evaluating the party throughout, and the quality of the Warp-Node engagement determines how receptive it is to the Binding. Dye-Master Rendal represents the legitimate commercial-disruption cost of the outcome and cannot simply be defeated or ignored. The Warp-Loom and the Thread-Elemental's intelligence function provide lasting party and city resources.
loot_table: Cloak of Living Threads (Legendary; woven by the Thread-Elemental itself during the Binding resolution; changes form on command — can become any garment type, any color, any apparent fabric within 6 seconds; grants +2 AC from fabric-protective function; passive: resistant to fire damage up to 15 points per round as the fabric absorbs and disperses; 1/day: envelop a target within 10 feet in immobilizing fabric — Strength DC 16 to escape; the cloak's pattern always shows the Thread-Elemental's maker's mark)

Warp-Loom Access (the Concordat-era loom in the wash-house foundation; party can commission one Warp-Loom creation per month at cost of 200 gold materials + Spun's coordination; creations are permanently enchanted textiles of any specification within Arcana DC 17 parametrs)

Founding-Era Guild Charter (the recovered document woven into the core cloth; establishes the Laundry Ward's founding date as 40 years before the official city record, with Concordat involvement; research value; opens a historical inquiry into the Ward's true origins)

Thread-Elemental Civic Alliance (ongoing resource; the Thread-Elemental provides morning Void-tracking reports, textile preservation services for party equipment at no cost, and can produce emergency fabrications — ropes, bandages, filtered masks — within 1 hour when requested through Spun)
2800 gold (Laundry Ward Council settlement payment; Textile Guild formal resolution contribution; city administration civic-integration grant)

destruction.description: Thread-Elemental destroyed; core cloth unraveled; all fabric returns inert

consequences.permanent_effect: Laundry Ward operational; all recovered Scourge-era textiles are lost (they return as inert fiber); Rendal is satisfied; Spun is professionally devastated; no Void-tracking capacity; Warp-Loom still exists but cannot be operated without the Elemental's guidance — it is dormant; no Cloak of Living Threads

binding_guardian.description: Thread-Elemental bound as settlement guardian; civic institution established

consequences.permanent_effect: All outcomes described in turns 11-15; Rendal adjusts commercially; Spun heads the Interface Weaver role; Warp-Loom active; Cloak of Living Threads created; Void-tracking operational; recovered Scourge-era textiles preserved

void_banishment.description: Thread-Elemental banished to Void-space; fabric returns as unweaved fiber (recoverable but not restored)

consequences.permanent_effect: Laundry Ward operational; fabric fiber is recoverable but requires re-weaving (economically significant damage); Void-instability risk near the Ward for 1 year; the Elemental may return through Void-instability events; Warp-Loom dormant; Rendal recovers commercially over time; Spun studies the Void-channel as a research path; no Void-tracking from this source; Cloak of Living Threads not created

risk_matrix.penalty: Rendal's lamp-oil fire is set before the party can prevent it. The Laundry Ward burns — not catastrophically (the ward is damp from wash-water), but severely enough to damage the Thread-Elemental's core housing and accelerate the fusion into an emergency-response mode. The Elemental in emergency mode does not evaluate the Warp-Nodes — it defends the core immediately (full combat, no puzzle path, no negotiation without DC 20 Persuasion during combat). The fire kills two of Rendal's hired hands before it is contained. settlement_stability -2 from the Ward fire; the Binding outcome is still possible at DC 18+ but the negotiation and guardian outcomes are significantly harder; the Warp-Loom is partially damaged (commissions require DC 15 instead of DC 13).
risk_matrix.critical_failure: The attempt failed with significant consequences.

title: The Silica-Vent War
unlock_conditions: Complete SQ-15 and hold 40+ Ridge reputation
location: Ridge geothermal complex — the Silica-Vent network, evacuation corridors, and the Glass-Widow's Forge-Sanctum

npcs.name: The Glass-Widow
npcs.description: A Ridge chemist who weaponized Glass-Lung disease after losing her family to it. She does not consider herself monstrous. She considers herself the only person who understood the disease well enough to leverage it. In Phase 1 she is a calculating, glass-sharded human combatant. In Phase 2 her own experimental treatment has begun consuming her. In Phase 3 she is no longer human — a silica elemental who has forgotten her name, though fragments of her purpose remain.

npcs.name: Foreman Dreck Hault
npcs.description: Veteran Ridge foreman coordinating the civilian evacuation. Pragmatic, refuses to leave anyone behind, will clash with the party if they pursue tactics that risk civilian lives. His people have been breathing the silica-clouds for weeks and many are already infected.

npcs.name: Warden-Scout Tela Voss
npcs.description: Warden-Keep's advance scout sent to assess the situation. She has combat training and knowledge of the geothermal complex's structural weak points. She wants the Glass-Widow captured alive for trial — the Warden-Keep has legal jurisdiction over Ridge and will not accept summary execution.

description: The Glass-Widow has been weaponizing the Ridge's silica-vent network for months, converting her Glass-Lung research from a cure-project into a weapon. She has created an army of Glass-Lung infected soldiers — Ridge miners and workers in advanced stages of the disease, whose silica-crystallized lung tissue has made them pain-resistant, silica-breathing, and controllable through resonance frequencies she broadcasts from her Forge-Sanctum. The infected are not undead and are not fully willing — they are people, still alive, in terrible pain, conscious enough to know what is happening to them. The geothermal complex is becoming uninhabitable as she redirects the silica-vent pressure to create choking clouds across the evacuation routes. The party arrives as the civilian evacuation is failing and the Glass-Widow's army is beginning its march toward the Ridge's inhabited districts.
mechanics: Athletics/Constitution (navigate silica-cloud terrain; Silica-Cloud exposure DC 14 CON save each round in vent-corridor areas or gain one Silica-Exposure level; three levels = Glass-Lung infected)
Medicine (stabilize Glass-Lung infected; identify potential treatment using Silica-Cure Formula components in the complex)
Arcana/Engineering (redirect geothermal vent pressure to clear evacuation routes; overload vent sections to create barriers against the infected army)
Leadership (command civilian evacuation groups; keep Foreman Hault's workers coordinated under pressure)
Combat - Phase 1: Glass-Widow (Human form, glass-shard projectiles, tactical combatant; AC 16, HP 120; Silica-Storm ability - 30ft cone of crystallized silica, DC 15 DEX for half 4d8 piercing damage)
Combat - Phase 2: Glass-Widow Hybrid (AC 18, HP 180; glass-body immune to piercing; Crystallize ability - ranged touch DC 14 CON or target's movement halved for 1 minute as joints crystallize)

Combat - Phase 3: Pure Silica-Elemental (AC 20, HP 240; immune to non-magical physical; Vent-Surge ability - pulls geothermal silica through floor, 60ft radius eruption 6d10 piercing; vulnerable to water/cold damage)

permanent_effects.effect: settlement_stability +3; Ridge district cleared; cure formula must be reconstructed from research notes (partial cure available within 6 months)
settlement_stability +2; settlement_morale +2; full cure formula obtained immediately from her cooperation; Ridge district cleared but Warden-Keep trial becomes major political event

permanent_effects.trigger: Glass-Widow escapes in exchange for cure formula
permanent_effects.effect: settlement_stability +1; settlement_morale -1; immediate full cure formula; Glass-Widow becomes a recurring threat elsewhere; Ridge cleared but faction relationships strained

turns.narrative: The Ridge's evacuation sirens started four hours ago and haven't stopped. Foreman Hault meets the party at the lower access gate with blood on his jacket and a very precise summary of the situation: seventeen evacuation groups, roughly 400 people, scattered across the complex's six inhabited sectors. The Glass-Widow's infected army is blocking routes 2, 4, and 7. The silica-cloud pressure from the redirected vents is already at dangerous concentration in sectors 3 and 5. He has twelve able workers left who aren't showing Glass-Lung symptoms. Scout Voss is already inside, she went in forty minutes ago, and he hasn't heard from her since. The party has the complex schematics — from here, they need to decide what they're securing first: the evacuation routes or the vent-pressure control systems.
turns.choice_a: Prioritize vent-pressure control — clearing the silica-clouds buys time for all evacuees
turns.consequence_a: Vent control is in sector 3 (already cloud-heavy); CON save DC 14 for every minute in the corridor. Resetting the pressure clears routes 3 and 5 for evacuation. Two of the twelve workers must be directed here, removing them from evacuation assistance. This takes 20 minutes of in-fiction time before the clouds thin.
turns.choice_b: Prioritize direct evacuation — get people out on the routes that are still clear
turns.consequence_b: Routes 1, 3, and 6 are still passable. Hault's twelve workers can shepherd 3 evacuation groups (approximately 70 people) to safety before the clouds become critical in those routes too. The remaining evacuees are deeper in the complex and will need the party to fight through to reach them.
turns.convergence: Either choice establishes the party's operational role: environmental control or direct extraction. The Glass-Widow's infected are aware of both approaches and will concentrate force accordingly.

turns.narrative: Warden-Scout Voss makes contact — her signal mirrors are still working in the complex. Her report, in abbreviated flash-code from two sectors over: she has found the Glass-Widow's command position (the old Forge-Sanctum at the complex's thermal core), and she has found something she wasn't expecting. The infected soldiers blocking the evacuation routes are not aggressive by default. They are stationed. They are holding positions rather than advancing, which means the Glass-Widow is maintaining formation discipline. They respond to the resonance frequency she's broadcasting, and Voss has identified the broadcast tower's location near the sanctum. If the broadcast tower can be disrupted, the infected lose coordination. But disrupting it will also signal the Glass-Widow that someone capable has entered the complex.
turns.choice_a: Disrupt the broadcast tower — accept the signal trade, gain tactical advantage over the infected
turns.consequence_a: The infected soldiers decohere — they lose formation discipline and become individually disoriented rather than coordinated. Evacuation routes 2 and 4 can be forced with moderate combat opposition. The Glass-Widow accelerates her timeline: the party loses 10 minutes before she locks down the Forge-Sanctum completely.
turns.choice_b: Leave the broadcast tower intact — approach the Forge-Sanctum covertly, disrupting it at the last moment
turns.consequence_b: Stealth approach to the Forge-Sanctum (Stealth DC 15; the infected soldiers are scanning for intruders but following patrol routes). Arriving at the Sanctum gives the party a surprise round in Phase 1 combat. The evacuation routes remain contested throughout.
turns.convergence: The Glass-Widow is aware she has organized opposition within the complex by end of turn 2. How much she knows shapes the Phase 1 encounter's opening conditions.

turns.narrative: Two evacuation groups are in crisis — the infected soldiers have passive awareness from the Glass-Widow's resonance and have begun drifting toward civilian noise. Hault's voice, over the signal relay: 'Sector 4, group 9, thirty-one people including six children and four infirm workers — the infected have cut off their route and they're pinned in the structural bay.' These are real people, and from the party's position they can see the infected moving in the sector 4 corridor: twelve people in various stages of Glass-Lung's crystallization, moving with the stiff, effortful gait of bodies that have been changed against their will. They are not attacking yet. They are forming a wall. The party must get through them without knowing if the infected inside can be reasoned with or are beyond reach.
turns.choice_a: Attempt to communicate with or reason with the infected — they may retain enough awareness
turns.consequence_a: Medicine DC 13 to identify an infected individual who appears less crystallized (earlier stage). Persuasion DC 16 against the Glass-Widow's resonance control. On success: one infected individual breaks formation briefly, creating a gap and a moment of confused, anguished eye contact with a nearby civilian they recognize. The infected cannot speak clearly through crystallized throat tissue but the gap holds for 30 seconds — enough to move the evacuation group through.
turns.choice_b: Force through with non-lethal combat — fight the infected without killing them
turns.consequence_b: Non-lethal combat against twelve partially-crystallized opponents: AC 13, HP 35 each, resistant to piercing damage. They are not trying to kill — they are trying to hold position. Non-lethal takedowns are possible. This takes 4 rounds and costs resources. No infected die. Evacuation group 9 is extracted.
turns.convergence: The evacuation group is secured. The infected soldiers incapacitated or bypassed. But the party has now engaged directly with the human cost of the Glass-Widow's work — these are people, and whatever happens in the Forge-Sanctum, the infected soldiers are victims first.

turns.narrative: Sector 5's silica-cloud density has hit critical before the vent controls were fully reset. Three evacuation groups in that sector are taking Silica-Exposure damage — the cloud is opaque and bitter, and breathing it coats the throat within minutes. Hault's workers have emergency filtered masks for 20 people; there are 58 in sector 5. The party can requisition whatever resources they have to address this: the complex's old chemical-processing bay (sector 5, adjacent) has large drums of water-slurry solution used in mining suppression, which can temporarily neutralize silica-cloud density if deployed. Getting to the bay through the cloud requires full CON save exposure. The alternative is directing all 20 filtered masks to the most vulnerable evacuees and accepting that 38 adults will take one level of Silica-Exposure during extraction.
turns.choice_a: Fight to the chemical bay — neutralize the cloud with slurry deployment
turns.consequence_a: Two party members take full cloud exposure (CON save DC 14 per minute in transit, three minutes of movement). On arrival, an Engineering DC 13 check to deploy the slurry correctly. Success clears the sector 5 cloud. All 58 evacuees extracted without Silica-Exposure. Party members may have accumulated exposure levels.
turns.choice_b: Distribute the 20 masks to children and infirm workers; extract quickly
turns.consequence_b: Fast extraction — 15 minutes. 38 adults take one Silica-Exposure level each. None progress to Glass-Lung (one level is treatable with rest and time). No party member exposure required. The sector 5 extraction is complete but 38 people need medical attention afterward.
turns.convergence: Sector 5 is evacuated. The party's resource state going into the Forge-Sanctum reflects accumulated exposure from the complex traversal.

turns.narrative: Voss has reached the Forge-Sanctum's outer ring and is providing tactical relay. Her description: the Glass-Widow is in the central chamber, which is a working thermal forge venting upward into the vent system — the mechanism she has been using to pump silica into the complex. The sanctum has three access points: a worker's maintenance corridor (concealed, tight, CON save territory), the main forge entrance (defended by six infected guard-soldiers, the most heavily crystallized individuals the party has seen — these are final-stage Glass-Lung, and these six are not capable of independent reason anymore), and a vent-shaft access that drops into the sanctum from above (Acrobatics DC 16, no opposition). Voss is holding position at the vent shaft. She will cover the party's entry from her position but will not enter until she understands the party's capture-vs-kill intent.
turns.choice_a: Enter through the vent shaft — aerial approach, limited opposition
turns.consequence_a: Acrobatics DC 16. Success: drop into the Forge-Sanctum's upper gallery. The Glass-Widow is below, at the forge controls. Surprise round possible against Phase 1. Voss follows. The six guard-soldiers are positioned at the main entrance and do not immediately register the aerial entry.
turns.choice_b: Enter through the maintenance corridor — concealed approach, take the Glass-Widow off-guard at ground level
turns.consequence_b: CON save DC 14 for each party member (silica-rich maintenance corridor). Stealth DC 13. Success: approach within 30 feet of the Glass-Widow before she registers the party. No surprise round but the six guard-soldiers at the main entrance are not in position to respond for the first two rounds of combat.
turns.convergence: Phase 1 combat begins. The Glass-Widow turns, and the party sees her clearly for the first time: a lean, glass-flecked figure in modified protective gear, with a calm expression that suggests she expected this. 'I wondered when someone capable would arrive,' she says. 'Let's see which of you is fast enough to matter.'

turns.narrative: PHASE 1 — The Glass-Widow (Human Form). She fights with precise, clinical efficiency: glass-shard projectiles launched from a chest-mounted pressurized dispenser (range 60 feet, 3d8 piercing per hit, bonus action reload), and a melee glass-blade that extends from her forearm housing. Her Silica-Storm ability (3/day) releases a cone of crystallized silica from the forge vents she controls. She uses the forge's terrain — elevated catwalks, heat-shimmer zones that impose disadvantage on ranged attacks targeting her, and the six guard-soldiers if the party didn't neutralize the main entrance approach. She is not monologuing. She is fighting. Between combat rounds, in the brief pauses, she is clearly calculating something — looking at the party's resources, adjusting her approach. At 60 HP remaining, she says, flatly: 'I see you understand what you're doing. Good. Then you understand I can't stop.' She triggers Phase 2.
turns.choice_a: Press the attack aggressively — keep her from reaching Phase 2 transition safely
turns.consequence_a: If the party deals 20+ damage in the round she attempts the Phase 2 trigger, the transition is disrupted — she takes the Phase 2 crystallization but with 20 fewer HP and without her full Crystallize ability activating (cooldown 3 rounds). DC 15 Athletics or Arcana to interrupt the forge-channel mechanism she's using for the transformation.
turns.choice_b: Pull back and reassess when she begins the transition — let her transform rather than fight through it
turns.consequence_b: The Phase 2 transition completes without interruption. The Glass-Widow's form cracks and reshapes as silica floods her body from the forge-channel. She is significantly more dangerous but the party has not expended resources fighting the transition. Full Phase 2 stats activate.
turns.convergence: Phase 2 begins. The Glass-Widow's human form is gone — she is a crystalline-glass hybrid, taller than before, her voice now resonating through silica vibration. She is still coherent. She is still herself. But she is in visible pain and not acknowledging it.

turns.narrative: PHASE 2 — Glass-Widow Hybrid. She is immune to piercing damage (glass-body deflects projectiles) and resistant to slashing. Her Crystallize ability (melee or ranged touch, 30 feet, DC 14 CON or target's movement speed halved for 1 minute). She can absorb silica-cloud from the forge atmosphere and release it as a burst (30-foot radius, DC 14 CON or one Silica-Exposure level). Her HP is 180 and she regenerates 10 HP per round while within the forge-vent area. The forge-vent mechanism that is feeding her regeneration can be disrupted with an Engineering/Arcana DC 14 action (destroys the vent feed, ends regeneration, and also permanently frees the six guard-soldiers from resonance control — they collapse, gasping, themselves again). At 90 HP remaining, Phase 2 has a revelation: she stops, mid-combat, and says something unexpected.
turns.choice_a: Stop attacking when she pauses — listen
turns.consequence_a: She says: 'The cure formula is in the secondary lab, vault 7-B. I will give you the access code if you promise to use it on my people first. Before anything else happens.' She names a number of infected individuals by name — workers she knows personally. 'They trusted me. They got the disease because of working conditions my research was supposed to fix. I owe them.' She is giving the party something. This is not a trap. She resumes fighting immediately after.
turns.choice_b: Keep the pressure on — don't let her dictate the tempo of combat
turns.consequence_b: Phase 2 continues without the revelation dialogue. The cure formula's vault location must be found through Investigation DC 15 after the encounter — it exists but locating it takes time. The Glass-Widow's personal motivation is not communicated directly.
turns.convergence: Phase 2 resolution triggers when the Glass-Widow reaches 30 HP or the party successfully disrupts the forge-vent feed. At this point, something goes wrong with her experimental treatment. The Phase 3 transformation is not a choice she makes. It is a failure.

turns.narrative: The Phase 3 transformation is not controlled. The Glass-Widow's crystalline form fractures along stress lines the party can see forming as the combat has damaged her experimental treatment housing — the implanted device that was supposed to keep her hybrid form stable and conscious. It shatters. What comes through the forge floor is pure silica elemental: the human-shaped outline is still roughly present, a ghost-form of her standing in the center of a 20-foot silica construct of living geothermal glass. She is in there. Whether she is aware is unclear. The forge-sanctum is now genuinely dangerous terrain: the silica elemental's Vent-Surge ability can pull geothermal material through the floor, and the forge's own systems are starting to cascade. The party has approximately 15 combat rounds before the sanctum's structural integrity fails and the entire vent network collapses — which would clear the complex of silica permanently but also bury everything and everyone in immediate proximity.
turns.choice_a: Fight to kill — focus everything on the elemental form, accept the structural risk
turns.consequence_a: Full combat against Phase 3 (AC 20, HP 240, immune to non-magical physical, vulnerable to water/cold). Vent-Surge activates on initiative 20 each round (DC 15 DEX to avoid, 6d10 piercing). If the elemental is destroyed before structural collapse: the Glass-Widow's human consciousness does not survive the elemental's destruction at this stage. She is gone. The cure formula from vault 7-B is the legacy.
turns.choice_b: Attempt to reach the human consciousness inside the elemental — call to her, use what she revealed in Phase 2
turns.consequence_b: Charisma/Persuasion DC 18 (very hard — the elemental is not fully coherent) or DC 14 if the party addresses her by name and references the workers she named. On success: the human consciousness fragments surface. She has enough control to partially arrest the Vent-Surge for 3 rounds. She cannot return to human form. But she can choose her ending.
turns.convergence: Phase 3 resolution determines the Glass-Widow's fate and Ridge's future. The structural cascade timer is still running regardless.

turns.narrative: Structural cascade warning — Foreman Hault's voice on the relay: 'Something's wrong with the deep vents. The thermal readings are going critical. How long do you need?' The party has approximately 8 minutes before the forge-sanctum becomes non-survivable for humans. The infected soldiers throughout the complex have been affected by the Phase 3 event — with the resonance tower compromised and the Glass-Widow fully non-human, the control frequency has become erratic. The infected are disoriented, some of them moving toward the Forge-Sanctum as though drawn by the elemental's presence. The last evacuation group — 23 people from sector 6 — is not yet clear. The party must decide resource allocation: continue fighting the elemental (full combat focus) or split resources to extract the last evacuation group while someone holds position in the Forge-Sanctum.
turns.choice_a: Split party — half to the final evacuation, half to hold the Forge-Sanctum
turns.consequence_a: The evacuation group is extracted with careful combat management (Athletics DC 12, one infected confrontation). The Forge-Sanctum fight continues at reduced party capacity — the elemental has a better chance of triggering Vent-Surge during the reduced-focus rounds. But all 400 evacuees will be clear before the structural collapse.
turns.choice_b: Prioritize ending the elemental immediately — complete combat before the structural window closes
turns.consequence_b: Full party in the Forge-Sanctum. The elemental is resolved faster. But the last evacuation group of 23 cannot be extracted without party backup — Hault will attempt it with his remaining workers, Athletics and Leadership DC 14. On success: all 23 extracted. On failure: the group retreats to a structural shelter and is recovered after the collapse from a safe pocket.
turns.convergence: The evacuation situation has a definitive status. The Forge-Sanctum is approaching structural failure. The Glass-Widow — in whatever form her Phase 3 resolution took — is at the decision point.

turns.narrative: The branching resolution of the Glass-Widow's fate. If the party reached her human consciousness in Phase 3: she is partially coherent, aware she cannot survive, and she makes a choice. She can direct the elemental form to drive itself into the deep-vent structure, sealing the geothermal silica permanently — Ridge becomes immediately safe, the whole vent-weapon destroyed from within, and the cure formula is in vault 7-B. This is her offering. She does not ask for anything in return. The elemental does not survive the deep-vent immersion. If combat ended in her destruction: the elemental's collapse is an explosion of silica-glass across the Forge-Sanctum, and the party must make DC 14 DEX saves or take 4d10 piercing damage. Either way, the forge-sanctum's structural failure countdown is now measured in minutes.
turns.choice_a: [If consciousness reached] Accept her offering — let her seal the vents from within
turns.consequence_a: The Glass-Widow-as-elemental descends into the deep-vent structure. The silica-cloud throughout the complex begins thinning immediately — the geothermal feed is being sealed. The process takes 4 minutes. The elemental does not return. The party has a window to exit. Cure formula obtained from vault 7-B. Ridge is immediately safe. permanent_effect: Ridge clears completely; full cure for all infected; Glass-Widow gone but not by the party's hand; no trial.
turns.choice_b: [If consciousness reached] Try to capture her instead — the Warden-Keep's trial matters
turns.consequence_b: The elemental form cannot be constrained at this stage. Voss, if present in the Forge-Sanctum, says quietly: 'She's already gone. Let her do this.' Accepting the offering is the only viable path. The trial option is only available if Phase 2 ended with capture before Phase 3 triggered.
turns.convergence: The Glass-Widow's arc is resolved. The party has approximately 3 minutes to exit the Forge-Sanctum before structural collapse of the central chamber.

turns.narrative: Egress from the Forge-Sanctum. Three minutes, structural collapse of the central forge chamber imminent. The maintenance corridor, the vent-shaft, and the main entrance are all still viable exit routes, but the thermal stress is cracking the floors and the ceiling of the central chamber is shedding glass. Athletics DC 12 to navigate the egress under pressure; on failure, the character is caught in falling glass debris for 2d8 piercing damage but can still exit. Voss pulls an injured party member through if one goes down — she is professionally capable and is already heading for the exit. Foreman Hault's voice, on the relay, counting down from outside: 'You have three minutes. Two minutes fifty. Two forty.' He is calm. He has evacuated mines before. He is counting because people need to hear a voice.
turns.choice_a: Retrieve the cure formula from vault 7-B on the way out — it was identified by the Glass-Widow
turns.consequence_a: Vault 7-B is on the egress route (30-second detour). Sleight of Hand or Athletics DC 12 to manage the route under structural stress. The formula is a sealed glass vial with attached documentation in the Glass-Widow's handwriting. It survives intact if the check succeeds.
turns.choice_b: Straight egress — prioritize exit, retrieve the formula later from the collapsed debris
turns.consequence_b: Clean exit. The formula is in the collapsed area but the vault is structurally reinforced — Investigation DC 14 in the debris field two days later recovers it intact.
turns.convergence: The party exits the Forge-Sanctum into the main complex corridor. Behind them, the central forge chamber collapses inward in a muffled series of stress-fracture sounds rather than an explosion. No dramatic fireball. Just closure.

turns.narrative: The complex, 30 minutes after the Glass-Widow's resolution: the silica-cloud is dispersing. The complex's natural air circulation, freed from the redirected vent pressure, is pulling the clouds toward the exterior exhausts. Foreman Hault's final tally: 398 of 400 evacuees accounted for (two were in the deep sector 6 shelter; Hault's workers are extracting them now). The infected soldiers — all of them — are sitting, kneeling, or lying down across the complex. Some are unconscious. Some are crying. Several are trying to speak around crystallized throat tissue. They are alive. They need immediate medical attention. The cure formula, if the party has it, provides a complete treatment course for fully-infected individuals: three-week recovery period, significant discomfort, but complete reversal of the silica-crystallization in 80% of cases. The other 20% will have partial glass-tissue as a permanent condition — visible, functional, not dangerous.
turns.choice_a: Begin immediate triage — organize treatment for the infected soldiers first (the Glass-Widow's stated priority)
turns.consequence_a: Medicine DC 11 to begin distributing the formula per the Glass-Widow's documentation. Hault's workers assist. The infected soldiers receive first-course treatment within the hour. Settlement morale +3 from the visible care of people the city had written off. The Glass-Widow's stated priority was honored.
turns.choice_b: Prioritize the civilian evacuees who were exposed during extraction — treat them before the soldiers
turns.consequence_b: The civilian-exposed individuals receive treatment first (all at level 1 or 2 exposure, easy recovery). The infected soldiers receive treatment in the second wave — an additional 90-minute delay. No clinical difference in outcome for the soldiers, but several of them are aware of the ordering, and one of them — the early-stage individual the party may have communicated with in turn 3 — holds eye contact with the party for a moment before looking away.
turns.convergence: Treatment begins. The cure formula is active. The infected will recover. Ridge's immediate crisis is resolved.

turns.narrative: Warden-Scout Voss's after-action obligation: she needs to file a report to Warden-Keep that explains the Glass-Widow's fate. The trial option is off the table. Voss knows this and is not upset about it — she is a pragmatist and she was in the Forge-Sanctum. But the report must characterize the resolution accurately. She asks the party directly: 'How do you want me to write this?' The options are not fabrication — they are framing. 'Subject terminated during combat operations' is accurate. 'Subject sacrificed herself to neutralize the vent-weapon' is also accurate. 'Subject's experimental self-treatment resulted in terminal phase failure; remains unrecoverable' is accurate. The framing determines the Glass-Widow's historical record in Warden-Keep's documentation, and whether the Ridge's surviving residents ever get a version of events they can live with.
turns.choice_a: Ask Voss to write the accurate, full-context version — sacrifice framing, with the workers named
turns.consequence_a: The Warden-Keep report documents the Glass-Widow's sacrifice and her final act of directing the cure formula's location. The survivors receive the full account. Several infected soldiers request copies of the report. The Glass-Widow becomes a complicated historical figure — not a hero, not a villain, not easily filed. Settlement morale improves because the Ridge's survivors have the truth.
turns.choice_b: Keep the report minimal — combat-terminated, no additional framing
turns.consequence_b: Clean institutional record. The survivors don't get the context. The Glass-Widow is logged as a threat neutralized. The party holds the fuller version. Voss does not press this choice — the Warden was going to ask fewer questions about a clean report anyway.
turns.convergence: The historical record is set. The Glass-Widow's legacy in Ridge's institutional memory is either the full story or the simplified one.

turns.narrative: The Ridge complex three days later: the geothermal vent network, with the deep-vent sealed by the Glass-Widow's elemental form, is operating safely for the first time in years. The silica-cloud that had been a background fact of Ridge life for two decades is measurably reduced. Foreman Hault's engineering assessment: the sealed deep-vent has eliminated the primary source of excess silica in the atmosphere. The ambient Glass-Lung risk in Ridge is reduced to pre-industrial occupational levels — still present, but no longer the epidemic risk it has been. The Geothermal Core artifact — the stabilizer crystal at the heart of the vent-control mechanism, recovered from the Forge-Sanctum's debris field — is intact and is now the most precisely calibrated geothermal management artifact known to exist in EmberHeart. Hault wants it used to permanently improve Ridge's thermal management. The party has it.
turns.choice_a: Give the Geothermal Core to Hault and Ridge's engineering division for permanent installation
turns.consequence_a: Ridge's geothermal management improves permanently — settlement stability +2, Ridge district produces 15% more safe thermal energy for the city. Hault's team will study it and implement it within three months. The party gains Hault's personal gratitude and Ridge faction standing.
turns.choice_b: Keep the Geothermal Core as a party artifact for future use
turns.consequence_b: The Core is a Legendary artifact (detailed in loot table). Ridge misses out on its permanent installation benefit but manages with the vent-sealing's baseline improvement. Hault is disappointed but professional about it.
turns.convergence: Ridge's long-term trajectory is established. The district is on a recovery path for the first time in recorded memory.

turns.narrative: The settlement-wide reckoning: Ridge's 20% permanently glass-tissue patients. They are visible. They move differently. In good light, the glass-tissue catches and refracts — some of them are, objectively, beautiful in a way that has nothing to do with beauty they chose. The city has not yet decided what to do with them politically or socially: are they Ridge workers who are fully recovered from an occupational incident, or are they marked by what happened to them? Hault's answer to this question is the same answer he gives to every workforce integration question — they go back to work when they're cleared by Medicine DC 10, they get the same rate, and anyone who has a problem with it can file a formal complaint. Nobody files a formal complaint. The Ridge Thread has reached its resolution. The Glass-Widow's work — her research, her weaponized disease, and her final act — has reshaped the district permanently. The party stands in the Ridge's central concourse and watches workers return to their shifts, glass-tissue and all, moving through air that is cleaner than it has been in two decades.
turns.choice_a: Establish a formal relationship with Hault's Ridge engineering division going forward
turns.consequence_a: The party gains Ridge as an ongoing allied district. Hault's division will provide geothermal engineering assistance for any future city infrastructure challenge. settlement_stability +1. Ridge residents recognize party members and will assist with shelter, information, and equipment.
turns.choice_b: Mark the Glass-Widow's Forge-Sanctum as a memorial rather than a salvage site
turns.consequence_b: Hault agrees and implements it: the sealed Forge-Sanctum entrance is marked. No formal cenotaph — just a Foreman's notation on the complex map: 'Sealed vent. Site of resolution, Glass-Lung crisis. D.W.' The Ridge workers know what the notation means. settlement_morale +1 from the acknowledgment.
turns.convergence: Quest complete. Ridge Thread resolved. The Glass-Widow's war is over. The district is recovering. The infected are being treated. The deep-vents are sealed. What remains is the long, undramatic work of rebuilding a district that spent twenty years under a cloud — literal and otherwise.

conclusion: The Silica-Vent War resolves the Ridge Thread's central crisis and the Glass-Widow's arc. She was never simply a villain — she was a researcher who understood the disease she was supposed to be curing, made a monstrous choice about how to use that understanding, and in the end used the elemental form she became to seal the source of the disease permanently. The party's handling of the infected soldiers, the cure formula, and the Geothermal Core shapes Ridge's recovery trajectory. The 20% with permanent glass-tissue are the living reminder that 'resolved' and 'clean' are not synonyms.
